SECTION: Section A; Page 12; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 530 words

HEADLINE: Poland Outcapitalisms America

 BODY:
In a stroke, Poland is about to create capitalism out of the rubble of socialism -- and to an extent unmatched in the West. In a breathtaking announcement, the Polish Government has proposed making every Pole a capitalist -- by handing over to 27 million adults majority ownership of 400 state-owned factories, representing 25 percent of the country's industrial sales.
In the U.S., few own much capital: the poorest half of all families owns a mere 3 percent of the nation's assets. Under the Government plan, Poland would create more capitalists, relatively, in six months than the U.S. has created in 200 years. 
 Turning over state-owned factories is a tricky task. The Polish Government can't easily sell them because there are no markets to establish fair values. Besides, the process would take decades and virtually no Pole has enough wealth to make a bid.
Nor would widespread giveaways work. If every Pole owned a fraction of each firm, none would own enough to exercise control. Diffuse ownership means, effectively, no ownership: the managers would be free to enrich themselves.
The Government's solution is to hand over 60 percent of the equity in each of 400 companies to about 20 investment funds. Ownership of the funds, in turn, would be handed over to every Pole over 18. Initially each adult would receive vouchers worth one share of each fund. The investment funds would be run by financial experts from the West and work much like Western-style mutual funds.
One more wrinkle: 33 percent of each company, out of the 60 percent, would be concentrated in just one investment fund. That would give this lead fund a stake in the financial health of the company, compelling it to tightly supervise management.
The upshot: Ownership is diffuse, but control is concentrated. That's astonishingly clever.
The balance of the firm would be owned by the state, with 30 percent, and workers, with 10 percent. Over time, investment funds would trade shares in companies, leading to a stock market where individuals could buy and sell shares on their own.
The plan works spectacularly -- on paper. But whether it will work in practice is impossible to say; nothing close has ever been tried. And there are obvious dangers. By concentrating control in a handful of investment funds, the Poles may be inviting them to act like cartels.
Indeed, Czechoslovakia is so afraid of cartels that it has drawn up a privatization plan that would use vouchers to sell firms directly to citizens. And Hungary, which has experimented with decentralized control for decades, will avoid vouchers altogether by selling off firms to the highest bidder, foreign or domestic.
The beauty of the Polish plan is that it would make every Pole a capitalist -- an ambition unmatched in the West. And to make sure the lofty achievement survives, the plan turns over control to financial experts until ordinary Poles learn to manage finances for themselves. That way naive investors won't be prey to knaves operating in competitive markets. Karl Marx promised workers of the world their rightful share. A capitalist overthrow is on the verge of delivering that promise.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: More Than a Parade

 BODY:
To the Editor:
With all the hoopla about Operation Desert Storm, it is an outrage that former service members may receive a maximum of only 13 weeks of unemployment insurance, while many other unemployed people are eligible for up to 26 weeks of benefits. 
 In 1981, Congress, at President Reagan's request, eliminated unemployment compensation for former service members, then restored the program to half what it was before. Further, these recipients must wait five weeks to receive a check, while everyone else waits a week at most.
In 1990, there were 132,860 initial claims of this kind. The number is likely to increase with the downsizing of the military. Congress is considering legislation to restore compensation for former service members to a 26-week maximum. This legislation should be enacted quickly, to give returning soldiers more than just a parade.
 
RAYMOND AVRUTIS
Washington, June 20, 1991

HEADLINE: 'India Is Now in a New Ball Game'

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, July 7

 BODY:
The Finance Minister of India says his impoverished nation has begun a fundamental shift in priorities that looks, for the first time, to South Korea and prosperous Southeast Asian nations as guiding economic symbols. For more than four decades, India's policies have been marked by suspicion of capitalism, the United States, foreign investment and trade.
"India is now in a new ball game," said Manmohan Singh, the newly appointed Minister of Finance, a self-effacing international economist who virtually acknowledges that he is seeking to lead a revolution. "Our country is now prepared for big changes and I think we can launch a process of changing the mind-sets of our people." 
 In an interview in his office last week, Mr. Singh said India hoped to attract "multinationals to look upon India as an opportunity for investment and an opportunity for profitable business."
 
Unthinkable in the Past
 Such comments by a senior Government official, no less the Finance Minister, would probably have been unthinkable in the 1970's and 1980's, when India viewed the West, and multinational corporations, as rapacious.
Mr. Singh said, essentially, that the nation's elite must forget their "ideological hangovers," because India has no viable option except to open its doors to the West as well as Asia to deal with the worst balance-of-payments crisis in the nation's history, a huge international debt, a plunging credit rating, 14 percent inflation and dwindling foreign exchange reserves.
At the edge of an economic crisis, India has urgently requested a multibillion-dollar loan from the International Monetary Fund.
In a series of sweeping moves in recent days, Mr. Singh has pledged to open India's doors to multinational companies, overhaul the crippling bureaucracy, scale down subsidies, accelerate trade and, perhaps most fundamental, turn India away from the socialist model that has traditionally guided its economic path.
 
A Second Devaluation
 On Wednesday, India devalued the rupee for the second time in three days, with Mr. Singh saying the Indian currency was finally at the appropriate level to maintain the competitiveness of the country's exports.
At this point, Mr. Singh exerts considerable muscle in the Government, partly because he has become the point man on economic policy, partly because of his candor and partly because of his reputation as a man without political or ideological baggage. But his critics say Mr. Singh's talk may not ultimately match his accomplishments, suggesting that he is politically naive and has failed to come to grips with the powerful realities of India's bureaucracy and business class, which have a vested interest in maintaining the status quo.
Mr. Singh, a thickly bespectacled 59-year-old former Governor of the Reserve Bank of India, has held senior economic jobs with the Indian Government as well as the United Nations. He was an adviser to former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, who viewed American economic involvement with hostility.
 
Influence of the Soviets
 "The overall thinking of the economic profession of this country was greatly influenced by the Soviet model," Mr. Singh said. "With the collapse of the command economy of the Eastern European type, everybody is convinced that it is time for fresh thinking."
Mr. Singh said his travels, especially to Asia, left him "with a deep feeling of dissatisfaction about India's economic progress."
He said: "We have tremendous potential, a country of 850 million people, a vast domestic internal market; we have a tremendous reservoir of managerial, entrepreneurial and technological skills and our people, when they compete abroad, are second to none whether it's in terms of academic institutions or in terms of making money in the U.S. or U.K. Yet I found India has become increasingly marginalized.
 
'India Has to Wake Up'
 "There must be a deep examination of what has gone wrong. Why is it that South Korea is talked about? In 1960, South Korea had the same per-capita income as India. Today, South Korea's income is 10 times India's."
Other economies of Asia, including Indonesia, impressed Mr. Singh. "I got the message that India has to wake up," he said.
Foreign investment in India totals $100 million a year, of which $20 million comes from the United States.
"I would hope that this small trickle will turn into a flood," he said. "Japanese officials have already told Mr. Singh that Japan could invest $2 billion annually if India had the right policies."
But fundamental changes in the way India operates are a Herculean task, Mr. Singh acknowledged. Certainly the nation's crumbling public services, enormous poverty and illiteracy, mammoth bureaucracy, backwardness, social and caste systems and blurred ideology leave India almost locked in a cycle of economic despair. Politicians, within the Congress Party as well as the opposition, have voiced uneasiness, if not resentment, at the new Government's efforts.
And the labyrinthine bureaucracy has a vested interest in maintaining the blizzard of licensing that stirs considerable corruption. As Tavleen Singh, a colmunist in The Economic Times, wrote last week: "The trouble with our earlier finance ministers has been that they have made policies, even some very good ones, in the ivory towers without ever going into why the policies never seem to work on the ground. Has any finance minister gone into why an exporter still needs 200 signatures before he can export his first shipment?"
The Finance Minister said resistance on the part of the bureaucracy was possible. "I do not minimize the difficulties of the task," he said. "But I get the feeling that now is the time to do big things because most people now, in their heart of hearts, feel that the old habits of thinking have not yielded results."

CORRECTION-DATE: July 10, 1991, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
A chart in Business Day Monday titled "Growing Trade in the Developing World" misstated export statistics in some copies. From 1980 to 1989, the average annual growth in exports was as follows: 4.9 percent for Chile, 5.6 percent for Ghana, 11.4 percent for Turkey, 12.8 percent for Thailand and 13.8 percent for Korea.

HEADLINE: Court Choice Puts Nation's Racial Legacy on Table

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 7

 BODY:
It is 13 years since the Supreme Court ruled in the case of Allan Bakke that while public universities could not set strict racial quotas in admissions they could achieve diversity by considering the race of their applicants.
 "In order to get beyond racism, we must first take account of race," Justice Harry A. Blackmun wrote in a separate opinion. It was a succinct and powerful statement of the rationale for affirmative action, the code words for policies intended to compensate blacks for their historical exclusion from the full range of economic and educational opportunities. That rationale still underlies as much of the Court's legacy in this area as has survived the erosion of the intervening years. 
But to Clarence Thomas, President Bush's Supreme Court nominee, taking account of race in government policy is itself the essence of racism, a harmful and constitutionally impermissible approach that demeans and discourages black achievement.
 
Thomas's View of Racism
 In his view, as expressed in speeches, articles and interviews over the last several years, racism is an enduring reality that American society is unlikely ever to "get beyond" in any event, and the Government can best serve racial minorities by treating all people equally.
 Judge Thomas has been forceful and articulate in this view. It brought the young black lawyer to the attention of the Reagan Administration, propelling him to the chairmanship of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, to a Federal judgeship and to the threshold of the Supreme Court.
 His nomination brings the polarities in the country's view of affirmative action to the fore as the long-running debate over civil rights legislation has not really managed to do.
 While the legislative debate has often appeared to be mired in legal technicalities, this one promises to get back to principles, much as the battle over Robert H. Bork's nomination to the Supreme Court four years ago engaged the public in a debate over the constitutional dimensions of privacy. The question this time is the relationship between the country's racial past and its present, and the degree to which modern legal and constitutional understanding should reflect what has gone before.
 
Potential Court Role
 If Judge Thomas joins the Court, this abstract inquiry will very quickly take concrete form. The Court has agreed that in its next term it will decide two important cases involving the legacy of official segregation.
 His confirmation would put him in a position to influence a Court that is very much in flux on the full range of questions about public policy and race.
 One case to be argued in the fall, Freeman v. Pitts, involves a suburban Atlanta school district that was formerly segregated by law and has been under Federal court supervision since the 1960's.
 The other case, United States v. Mabus, concerns Mississippi's public university system, once segregated by law and and still essentially a dual system that is almost completely separated by race.
 In both cases, the issue is whether the government agencies in question have met their constitutional obligation to dismantle the legacy of segregation.
 The future of hundreds of public school systems in the South as well as the outlook for many historically black colleges will be shaped by what the Court decides.
 While the Court's current majority clearly wants to be able to return school systems to local control and to get Federal judges out of the business of administering local government institutions, Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist has lacked the votes to do so. Even after Justice William J. Brennan Jr. retired last year, there was a kind of deadlock as long as Justice Thurgood Marshall remained on the Court.
 
Affirmative Action Issues
 Several times in the last term, the Court denied review in cases presenting affirmative action questions that might have been vehicles for the Court to expand on its recent rulings in that area. The Court does not explain its refusal to hear a case, but a likely explanation is that Chief Justice Rehnquist could not be sure he would have the votes to accomplish the results he wanted.
 In short, there could not have been a more consequential moment for Justice Marshall to retire and for Judge Thomas to be in a position to succeed him. "The modern story of the Supreme Court has centrally been about race," Paul Gewirtz, a professor at Yale Law School, said in an interview.
 He added: "Race has also been the centerpiece of Thomas's public career. We know he is not simply another judge who is likely to move the Court in a conservative direction. His public career has stood for a set of ideas about race that have been at odds with the central story on the Court. He is engaged with this largest issue of American history in an utterly authentic and personal way."
 With the stakes so clear, the confirmation process is likely to be polarizing and divisive. But the intriguing question remains whether, assuming Judge Thomas is confirmed, his contribution to this debate as a Supreme Court Justice might not eventually help bring an end to the polarization over how to deal with the country's racial legacy.
 Equally intriguing is how Judge Thomas will come to terms, publicly and privately, with the richly ironic combination of politics and historical imperative that has brought him to this moment. His entire career has been spent arguing that race must be treated as irrelevant in government policy, yet its relevance to his selection Monday is beyond question.
 President Bush chose not to acknowledge the paradox, simply proclaiming his nominee the best possible choice, Judge Thomas himself will no doubt be pressed harder during his confirmation hearing, and he will no doubt have an eloquent response at the ready to explain the apparent contradiction between his life story and his life's work.
 The challenge, assuming he is confirmed, is whether he can reconcile the two in an approach to the law that contains both the intellectual rigor he prizes and the humanity that the Court and the country may need.

HEADLINE: Careers;
Innovations For M.B.A. Candidates

BYLINE: By Elizabeth M. Fowler

 BODY:
ABOUT a year ago, Scott S. Cowen, dean of the Weatherhead School of Management at Case Western Reserve University, spoke about an innovative, even radical, new program at the school to be introduced that fall.
Under the program, as soon as they arrive, M.B.A. candidates take assessment tests to determine their writing and speaking ability and other skills. 
 The new program, five years in the making, came at a time when many business schools were revamping programs to meet the new influences on business -- the environment, ethics, internationalism, growing resentment of high executive compensation, to name a few.
At Case, in Cleveland, "we are moving from a teaching process to a learning process, a different emphasis," Dr. Cowen said in a telephone interview yesterday.
A year ago he spoke glowingly of the new assessment program to meet the needs of an ever more diversified group of students -- diversified because of different cultural and educational backgrounds and diversified in personalities and interests.
"Now we want to develop more skill modules for the course, one on computers, one on negotiating skills and one on interviewing, including even how to dress and act." Dr. Cowen said.
Dr. Cowen found new ideas such as the assessment program in unusual places. "We were inspired by Alverno College's innovative use of assessment in its liberal arts curriculum," he said.
Alverno, he explained, moved from the "brink of extinction" to being one of the five United States institutions most frequently cited by academic deans as having a successful general education program.
He described Alverno as a small women's liberal arts college, in Milwaukee, which assesses students so that they take courses that fill their educational needs -- an approach to handling diversity.
Another major change at Case, in addition to assessment, involves a reduction in the number of core, or required, courses, to 11 from 16, to make room for some additions.
Core courses have to be kept for an important reason, Dr. Cowen explained. "We have dual roles to fill," he said. "Students need the knowledge, skills and perspective of a general manager, but we must give them the flexibility to take a concentration in a particular area so they can get an entry-level job."
The 11 core courses provide students with a basic, homogeneous background on which to build more specific skills -- accounting, labor and human resources, management information, economics, finance, marketing, statistics, operations management, organizational behavior, policy and quantitative methods.
As for the new importance assigned by most schools to international aspects, he said: "We do it four ways. Almost every course has an international component. We offer international finance and other specialties as electives. We are developing semester exchange programs with Erasmus University, in the Netherlands, for example."
The fourth approach is through a new "perspective course" in global management, with faculty from the fields of religion, political science, history and economics. Dr. Cowen said most of the 300 M.B.A. students would take the course because they are required to take two out of three of the new perspective courses.
This fall the two remaining perspective courses will be introduced, technology management and industrial history. For the technology course the faculty will come from science departments, the engineering school, the medical school and the history department.
Students taking the industrial history course, Dr. Cowen said, will be formed into teams, each of which will focus on a specific industry, such as the auto, steel, or tire and rubber industries, along with newer areas like computers and the biomedical field.
Despite the popularity abroad of shorter M.B.A. programs such as the year program at Insead, in France, Dean Cowen said the Weatherhead school would keep the two-year format. "There is so much ground to cover, and we can't do it in a period as short as a year," he said.
At Case, the students see their dean in action almost as soon as they arrive on campus. He gives a half-day workshop on what he calls "value creation," using three short case studies that explore the role of individuals and companies in society.
The current agenda includes a case study on Donald J. Trump to discuss whether he is an American hero or nightmare. A second focuses on the Walt Disney Company and pay for performance, with discussion of high executive compensation, as well as the example of high management reward at Time Warner Inc., and the third case study considers the responsiblity, or lack of it, evinced by oil companies about price increases at the time Iraq invaded Kuwait.

HEADLINE: Business and Health;
On Approving Generic Drugs

BYLINE: By Milt Freudenheim

 BODY:
IN a little-noticed move with broad implications for the $40 billion prescription drug industry, the Food and Drug Administration has started a debate on changing the way it approves generic versions of brand-name drugs.
Under one proposal, the maker of a brand-name drug would have to tell the agency more than it now does about what goes into its product. The F.D.A. would publish standards for the ingredients and for testing them. Years later, when a drug loses patent protection, other drug makers could refer to the publication, called a monograph, to speed F.D.A. approval of a low-priced generic version. 
 Generic-drug makers say they often face years of bureaucratic wrangling over the safety and effectiveness of their products, which mimic long-established drugs. "Now 10 different F.D.A. chemists review the same thing and come up with 10 different questions," said Harold Snyder, chairman of Biocraft Laboratories, a generic-drug maker based in Fair Lawn, N.J.
The leading drug companies have interests on both sides of the issue. At least two-thirds of generic sales dollars are generated by divisions of brand-name drug makers. But the biggest profits by far are in the brands, which sometimes retain as much as 40 percent of the market even after patents expire.
With much at stake for the companies, the monographs are certain to be debated on legal, economic and public policy grounds. But spokesmen for industry trade groups -- the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association, representing brand-name drug makers, and the Generic Pharmaceutical Industry Association -- said the groups had not yet made up their minds about the issue. The F.D.A. Commissioner, Dr. David A. Kessler, is also proceeding with caution, buying time by naming a committee to study the pros and cons. For one thing, F.D.A. officials are said to disagree over whether the agency is empowered to require monographs without new legislation, which could open a Pandora's box of industry lobbying.
The proposals, which the F.D.A. published in the Federal Register on May 28, include suggestions by Representative John D. Dingell, chairman of the oversight subcommittee of the House Energy and Commerce Committee. Subcommittee investigators found instances of generic-drug company employees bribing F.D.A. officials and submitting fraudulent test samples.
The agency said in the Register, "The lack of available information has created problems" for generic drug makers. It said a public monograph system might "streamline" the approval process, "help insure generic drug safety and effectiveness, and increase public confidence in generic drug products."
Even so, Hemant K. Shah, an independent securities analyst in Warren, N.J., said that "monographs would be a disaster for both the brandname and generic companies." He added, "If the F.D.A. told the generic companies how to make the drugs, the companies could not say 'my drug is better than the other drug.' "
Monographs with some information are already published by the United States Pharmacopeia, a private organization based in Rockville, Md. The Pharmacopeia leaves it up to the drug makers to designate and exclude "trade secrets," said Jerome A. Halperin, executive director of the Pharmacopeia, a drug reference publisher since 1820. He said the F.D.A. could require expanded versions of the Pharmacopeia's descriptions of ingredients and tests, which cover 90 percent of all drugs.
The Federal agency already uses monographs to approve antibiotics. The monographs describe the ingredients but do not provide a recipe for putting them together. Mr. Snyder at Biocraft said the F.D.A. formerly had a special unit that approved generic antibiotics speedily, but the unit was abolished and the process "slowed down."
After the fraud scandals, the Generic Pharmaceutical Industry Association last year created a committee that they said was intended to restore public confidence. The committee rejected the idea of F.D.A. monographs, saying it doubted that the agency's chemists would be competent to produce them. It suggested an alternative, which the F.D.A. says it is also considering: Several years before the expiration of patents on the largest-selling prescriptions, the F.D.A. would discuss generic versions with interested drug makers. Later, several generic versions would be approved on the same day, removing an incentive to cut corners to get lucrative rewards for being first to market.
Arguing against monographs, the generic industry committee said that brand-name drug makers might boobytrap the papers by inserting "unnecessarily narrow or restrictive criteria to discourage generic competition." But Mr. Snyder at Biocraft said: "There really aren't many secrets in the drug business. As far as manufacturing goes, if there is a secret, somebody will steal it."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Drops Amid Worries Over German Interest Rates

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar declined against most major currencies yesterday amid worries over German interest rates and a reduction of tensions in Yugoslavia.
Gold was slightly higher. 
 Dealers said traders were uncertain over whether the Bundesbank's policy-making council would move Thursday to raise German rates. The mark, like all currencies, would be supported by higher interest rates.
The German currency was also supported by apparent moves yesterday toward peace in Yugoslavia. In recent weeks the mark has been hurt by fears that the crisis could hurt Germany's economy.
The dollar fell to 1.8110 German marks in European dealings, down from 1.8336 late Friday. In New York, the dollar fell to 1.8058 marks, down from late Friday's 1.8265.
 
Yen Battered
 The yen, meanwhile, continued to be battered by news of Japan's securities scandal. The Finance Ministry suspended four brokerage houses from soliciting business from corporate clients for four days starting tomorrow. The Government also ordered them to stop compensating favored clients for stock market losses.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.48 yen, to a closing 138.75 yen, and it slid to 138.65 yen in European dealings. But in New York, the dollar edged up to 138.55 yen, from late Friday's 138.30.
Belal Khan, a corporate dealer for Fuji Bank Ltd. in New York, said the dollar was also undermined by a growing feeling that the economic recovery in the United States might be slower than expected. The sentiment came on the heels of Friday's Government report that the nation's unemployment rate rose to 7 percent in June.
In London, the British pound was higher, at $1.6275, compared with $1.6165 late Friday. The pound also gained in New York, where sterling fetched $1.6345, more expensive than late Friday's $1.6173.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with rates late Friday, included: 1.5584 Swiss francs, down from 1.5745; 6.1325 French francs, down from 6.1840; 1,345.75 Italian lire, down from 1,358.00, and 1.14565 Canadian dollars, up from 1.14385.
On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold prices rose to $370.90 an ounce, up 70 cents from late Friday. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $370.20 an ounce, up 65 cents from late Friday.
In London, gold traded at $370.40 an ounce, up from late Friday's $370.00. In Zurich, the bid price was $370.15, up from $370.00 late Friday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose 45 cents to close at $371.15.

HEADLINE: Consumer Borrowing Fell in May

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 8

 BODY:
Americans reined in their borrowing at a 1 percent annual rate in May -- the fifth pullback in six months -- because of a 14.1 percent plunge in automobile loans, the Government said today.
The Federal Reserve said consumer credit fell by a seasonally adjusted $626 million after increasing at a 1.9 percent rate in April. The April gain, originally estimated at a 2.8 percent rate, was the first since installment credit advanced last November at a 4.5 percent rate. 
 Analysts attributed the decline to both consumer and lender caution, which they said could stall the economy's recovery.
Sandra Shaber, an economist at the Futures Group, a Washington management consultant firm, said the consumer credit report suggested two things: that "consumers are still cautious, taking a wait-and-see attitude as to whether the economy really is recovering, and that lending institutions are not too willing to extend credit."
 
Consumer and Lender Caution
 "Putting both together -- consumer caution and lender caution -- suggests a real constraint on this turnaround," she said, adding that a sustained recovery would require both spending by consumers and lending by financial institutions.
Consumer credit includes all consumer loans except mortgages and home-equity debt. It helps finance much of overall consumer spending, which represents two-thirds of the nation's economic activity.
Analysts look to the consumer sector to lead the economy out of the recession.
Installment debt shrank at a six-tenths of 1 percent rate in December, the first dip since it inched down two-tenths of 1 percent in February 1989. And as the recession wore on, consumers continued to rein in their debt as their jobs and incomes became threatened.
Consumer credit fell at a rate of 3.7 percent in January, three-tenths of 1 percent in February and five-tenths of 1 percent in March. It was the first four-month stretch of declines since 1980, when credit controls were in place.
The automobile industry has been among the worst affected by the recession, and borrowing for new vehicles has not shown an increase since it posted a 3.6 percent gain in December.
In May, it was down a seasonally adjusted $3.3 billion despite industry reports that sales ticked up slightly that month. Auto loans had declined at a 4 percent annual rate in April.
"It says more people liquidated their old car loans than took out new ones," Ms. Shaber said. She said sales continued to improve in June, and the next consumer credit report should reflect new loans.
Despite their caution, consumers continued to use their credit cards in May. Revolving credit rose at a 7.7 percent rate, or a seasonally adjusted $1.5 billion, following a 6.3 percent advance a month earlier.

HEADLINE: 9 Republics Back Gorbachev in Summit Stance

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, July 8

 BODY:
President Mikhail S. Gorbachev won the backing of Boris N. Yeltsin and the leaders of eight other republics today for the case he will make to leaders of major industrial nations at their meeting in London next week.
Details of Mr. Gorbachev's presentation have not been made public. But the show of support from republics' leaders, with whom the President is negotiating a new union treaty -- and especially from Mr. Yeltsin, the politically powerful President of the Russian federated republic -- was intended to convince the Western leaders that Mr. Gorbachev will be speaking for at least a sizable portion of his country. 
 The common front was reached at a meeting at the village of Novo-Ogarevo outside Moscow, where the same leaders negotiated a truce in April, called the "nine-plus-one" agreement, that halted the struggle between the Kremlin and the republics and opened negotiations toward a new union treaty.
The main evening television news program, Vremya, showed a smiling Mr. Gorbachev bantering with Mr. Yeltsin and the other leaders in a spirit of camaraderie.
The six republics that have declared their independence of the Kremlin -- Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Georgia, Armenia and Moldavia -- are not involved in the negotiations.
The leaders gathered in Novo-Ogarevo were those of Russia, the Ukraine, Byelorussia, Azerbaijan and the five Central Asian republics. Since the "nine-plus-one" agreement was reached, they have been negotiating a new federation in which republics would play a determining role.
"We are united by the common responsibility that is at the basis of 'nine-plus-one,' a responsibility for the fate of the country, a responsibility to stabilize political life and emerge as quickly as possible from this profound and serious crisis," Mr. Gorbachev said.
Mr. Yeltsin declared that Mr. Gorbachev was heading for London "not only as a representative of the center, but as the representative of all nine republics, with their agreement."
"Here we demonstrated a common understanding that we can resolve all our problems, that we are one mighty economic market with a certain division of labor, that we are all interdependent," Mr. Gorbachev said. "All this was broadly discussed, and we understood that we must retain this market, that we must give it new breath, use the initiative of the people. These are weighty concerns, the decisions are grave, it cannot be minimized."
The negotiations over the new federation have run up against sharp disagreement between the republics and the Soviet Government on taxation. The republics demand a monopoly on taxation, which would guarantee them control over the purse strings. The Kremlin is seeking a dual system, in which it would have independent revenues.
The state of Soviet internal politics is one of the main criteria by which the heads of the seven industrial powers -- the United States, Japan, Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada -- are expected to assess Moscow's appeal for aid.
The broad strategy that has evolved among the seven is evidently to grant Moscow some immediate assistance, such as associate membership in the International Monetary Fund, but to link major aid to specific economic and political reforms. Mr. Gorbachev, for his part, may seek guarantees that reforms will generate specified amounts of aid.
The Soviet leader's presentation to the summit participants is expected to be based in part on a plan linking Soviet reforms with Western assistance that was worked out by Grigory A. Yavlinsky, a liberal economist, and a group of Harvard political scientists. He is also expected to draw on a less ambition program designed by his Prime Minister, Valentin S. Pavlov, who was with him today at Novo-Ogarevo. No details of Mr. Gorbachev's approach have been made public.

HEADLINE: NCNB Grows (but Profits Don't)

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, July 8

 BODY:
The NCNB Corporation's Hugh L. McColl Jr., hailed as a savvy regional banker who is reshaping the industry, has an impressive track record at invading and succeeding in new markets, but his record at generating profits in some of these conquests has been unimpressive lately.
The McColl formula is to buy banks, convert them to NCNB's aggressive sell-sell-sell sales culture and get the troops out there scrambling for market share. Along the way, profits can take a back seat for a while. 
 "Hugh McColl has proven that he's willing to sacrifice profitability for market share," said Alen R. Smith, president of Allen C. Ewing & Company, a brokerage in Tampa, Fla., that specializes in Southeastern banks. "But he wouldn't tolerate nonprofitability for a long time."
Aggressive selling and price cutting sometimes lead to bad loans. And bad loans eat into profits quickly. Last year, after two years of record profits, NCNB's earnings slipped for the first time since 1987, falling 18.2 percent, to $365.7 million. This year profits are still lagging, having fallen by 8.3 percent in the first quarter, to $128.4 million.
The problem is rising loan troubles in the two states where NCNB has operated for several years: Florida, where it was the first out-of-state bank to invade, in 1982, and in NCNB's home state of North Carolina.
By being an aggressive real estate lender in Florida, where it is now the third-largest bank, NCNB tried to gain ground on bigger rivals by offering easier credit terms. But recession and a real estate glut last year exposed the risks of such liberal lending policies.
Bad loans in Florida rose to a profit-draining 5.4 percent of NCNB's loans in the state at the end of March and caused a loss of $8.1 million in the unit last year. This year, the Florida division bounced back with a profit of $19 million in the first quarter, according to reports filed by Federal regulators. NCNB does not publicly report results of its banking operations by individual states.
In North Carolina, the loan portfolio has also taken its lumps. While Charlotte-based NCNB holds a bigger share of total deposits than its rivals, the Wachovia Corporation and the First Union Corporation, Mr. McColl, NCNB's chairman and chief executive, nearly doubled the loan-loss reserve for NCNB in the 12 months ended in March, to $309 million, because of growing problem loans. As a result, profits slumped at the North Carolina bank to $25.9 million in the first quarter, from $32 million a year ago.
Lately, according to Salomon Brothers, NCNB's profitability as measured by bankers and analysts slipped below the average for major regional banks last year, after NCNB had outpaced the group through the late 1980's.
 
Brighter Future Seen
 Kenneth D. Lewis, president of all non-corporate banking activities at NCNB, acknowledged in an interview today that NCNB's aggressive steps had pared its profitability compared with that of some rivals, but added that the benefits of the strategy would soon be apparent.
"When things settle down sometime during this decade, we're going to show that we can grind it out with the best of them," he said. "This is not a sprint, it's a marathon. Given all the things we've done, the record is rather remarkable."
Robert B. Albertson, senior banking analyst at Goldman, Sachs & Company, thinks NCNB has made the right moves. He said that while Mr. McColl is best known for leading NCNB's expansion beyond the Carolina borders, the 56-year-old former marine has assembled an organization that has proved masterful in wringing costs from merged banks. "That to me is the new wave of banking, not new products," Mr. Albertson said.
The company's bright spot has been its celebrated entrance in Texas in 1988, where it took over 40 failed banks of the First Republicbank Corporation with billions of dollars in Federal assistance. The prospering Texas unit, with half of NCNB's total assets of $66 billion, has been shielded from major losses so far by Mr. McColl's 1988 deal with Federal regulators.
NCNB requested and received a key ruling from the Internal Revenue Service that would allow losses piled up at the failed First Republicbank to provide a huge tax shelter for NCNB. The practical effect has been to reduce NCNB's taxes and increase profitability, giving it an invaluable edge over rivals that often find it difficult to match NCNB's terms for pricing new loans and other business. Last year, NCNB paid an unusually low tax rate of 16 percent on its income compared with an average of 34 percent for most banks.
Thomas H. Hanley, banking analyst at Salomon Brothers, estimated that NCNB would pay little tax on its Texas profits through 1994 because of the more than $500 million it retains in unused tax benefits obtained from First Republicbank.
NCNB also has an unusually small portfolio of bad loans in Texas, thanks to an arrangement with Federal bank regulators that allowed NCNB to dump $8 billion in bad loans inherited from the First Republicbank into a separate "bad assets" unit that it manages at a profit for the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.
 
Merger Under Study
 Platoons of loan examiners from the C&S/Sovran Corporation will have to weigh all this as they examine NCNB's books to determine whether a combination of the two Southeastern banking companies will be profitable for them. One question is whether banking troubles in Florida and North Carolina will worsen this year or are about to abate, as NCNB executives maintain and many Wall Street analysts believe.
A gloomy report would give directors of C&S/Sovran one of the few practical reasons for rejecting NCNB's merger bid. C&S/Sovran, weakened by real estate loan troubles in the Washington area, would become part of a super-regional powerhouse in the Southeast and Texas by casting its lot with NCNB. Together, the bank, which Mr. McColl wants to rename Nationsbank, would be the second largest in the United States, with $116 billion in assets, behind Citicorp, which has $216 billion in assets.
Nationsbank would also be the dominant lender in North Carolina, Georgia, Virginia and Texas, and a major force in Florida.
But C&S/Sovran stockholders have been down the aisle before with not too pleasant memories. They saw the value of their shares plunge this spring after the merger of the Citizens & Southern Corporation, Georgia's biggest bank, and the Sovran Financial Corporation of Norfolk, Va. Executives at C&S/Sovran have cautioned that bad loans will continue to mount, and that a dividend cut is possible when C&S/Sovran's board meets on July 16.
Thus C&S/Sovran shareholders, including company directors, risk a falling market value again if NCNB's earnings tumble following a marriage of the two banking companies. Mr. McColl's initial terms apparently call for C&S/Sovran stockholders collectively to own 47 percent of NCNB following an exchange of three-fourths of a share in NCNB for each share of C&S/Sovran. Analysts say Mr. McColl might sweeten the deal to just under 50 percent of NCNB total shares.
 
Rise in Earnings Expected
 Most analysts doubt that NCNB will stumble in its effort to contain the loan troubles in Florida and North Carolina. "We believe the asset-quality deterioration will slow considerably in 1991," said Mr. Albertson of Goldman, Sachs. He added that a slowdown in problem loans should result in smaller increases in loss reserves and higher profits. Mr. Hanley of Salomon Brothers estimated that NCNB's earnings would rise by more than 13 percent next year.
NCNB established a troubled-asset division in the Southeast modeled after its Texas "bad assets" unit and stepped up its classifications of bad loans in the third quarter last year. Non-performing loans over all rose by 3 percent in the first quarter, to $759 million, the lowest percentage increase in five quarters.
But Charles W. Peabody, a bank analyst at Kidder, Peabody & Company in New York, is one critic of NCNB who believes that problem loans will rise in the second half of the year, and fester longer than the troubles at C&S/Sovran.
"Right now, C&S/Sovran is viewed as being more risky than NCNB" by investors, he said. "But that's the fickleness of the market. In the second half of this year, people will change their view of NCNB. There are still fundamental problems in their loan portfolio."
He said banks that compete with NCNB in the Southeast, like Suntrust, C&S/Sovran and First Union, have reported bigger increases than NCNB in bad construction loans this year, which Mr. Peabody said raised the question in his mind of whether NCNB had been slow in recognizing similar problems.
Mr. Lewis of NCNB would not rule out any increase in nonperforming loans later this year. But for now, he said, "the rate of increase in nonperformers has dramatically declined."

HEADLINE: Critics Fear Time Bombs In Dinkins Budget Tactics

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
In the scramble to limit the deep service cuts in New York City's $29 billion budget, the Dinkins administration found hundreds of millions in savings that will reduce costs now but increase the burden on future taxpayers.
Tucked away in the budget are plans to sell an $87 million city-owned mortgage on a middle-income apartment complex, even though city taxpayers will continue to pay off the bonds sold to build the project for years to come. And there are other plans: to refinance bonds to save $100 million in debt-service payments, to give bonuses to teachers who retire early, to sell assets including 1,000 city-owned apartments and to spend surplus cash in city-owned corporations.
 
Shifting Cost of Upkeep
 For example, when a painting crew descends on the Williamsburg Bridge in September for its first maintenance painting in years, it will mark the start of an ambitious new maintenance plan for the city's rusted and decayed bridges. But it will also mark the inauguration of a less-heralded city fiscal maneuver: the sale of bonds to pay for routine bridge work. 
 The $20 million bond sale will shift the cost of routine upkeep and building supplies from current taxpayers to future ones for the first time since the 1970's, when the city sold bonds to pay for textbooks.
"These kinds of practices -- bonding for bridge painting and the like -- are just what got New York City into trouble in the 1970's," said the State Comptroller, Edward V. Regan. "The bucket of paint for the bridge used today will be paid for by taxpayers five years from now."
City budget officials say some of these maneuvers make economic sense when all the costs and savings are totaled, while others simply generate cash and avert the need for much deeper cuts amid a recession.
 
Fewer Budget Gimmicks
 And they say that with the city under intense scrutiny from bond-rating agencies this year, there are far fewer fiscal gimmicks than the $1 billion Mr. Regan counted in the last two years. They add that there are far fewer than found in the budgets of other state and local governments.
Why look at the city, asked Philip R. Michael, the budget director, when New York State used a panoply of gimmicks -- according to Mr. Regan, more than $2.7 billion in one-time revenues last year -- before it found itself in the midst of its own fiscal crisis?
"They sell highways and prisons in other places and throw them into the budget," Mr. Michael said. "We throw in these little crumbs and everybody comes down on us. We still budget better than anyplace else."
 
Disguising a Money Drain
 But many fiscal analysts say that the city's budgetary maneuvers can mean trouble in future years. Mr. Michael said he could not project the actual overall savings or costs of the maneuvers, but one thing is certain: When the city uses one-time revenues to balance the budget -- much like a homeowner who sells his car and furniture to pay his mortgage -- it temporarily disguises an imbalance between revenues and spending that will surface sooner or later.
That is precisely what happened to the city this year. A series of bond refinancings by the city in the late 1980's artificially reduced the city's debt-payment costs by hundreds of millions of dollars a year. But the savings ended this year, forcing the city to cut spending or raise taxes by a like amount, just to pay the extra interest costs.
And in March, the staff of the state's Financial Control Board warned that the city faced a "structural imbalance" of more than $2 billion a year, in part because of such maneuvers, and said that the imbalance must be addressed before the city's fiscal troubles are over.
 
Early Retirees, Late Costs
 To avoid layoffs, the city developed an early-retirement program in which teachers who retired this year would receive higher pension payments. Because teachers hired to replace them would initially earn less than the retirees, the city would save $44.8 million this year if 2,800 teachers and administrators retired.
The program was carefully structured, officials said, to produce a theoretical savings over the life of the project, if the costs and savings all occurred this year, rather than over many years during which pensions are paid.
But in practice, all the savings will occur in the next three years, while costs of more than $2 million a year are projected to continue at least through the year 2012. Now city officials are saying that 3,486 teachers are requesting early retirement, while the teachers union puts the figure at 4,200, raising the costs and savings accordingly.
And city officials say that the program could be expanded to more than 150,000 other workers, in which case the costs could be far higher and theoretical savings nonexistent.
 
Cashing In a Mortgage
 Manhattan Plaza, the Federally subsidized development on 42d Street for artists and theater people, was born during the fiscal crisis of the 1970's. Now the city is seeking to sell its mortgage on the property to come up with cash in the middle of another crisis.
In 1975, after the city's fiscal problems forced it to default on its mortgage commitment to the developer, it came up with a plan to use Federal Section 8 housing money to pay for the project.
Now the $87 million, 8 percent city mortgage that was eventually issued is for sale for between $50 million and $70 million, officials said -- even though taxpayers will continue to pay principal and interest on the bonds sold to build the project for years to come.
Under state law, the city would have had to put at least $30 million of the sale price into an escrow fund, city officials said, to cover the cost of principal and interest due on the bonds.
But city officials, working quietly in the closing days of legislative session, won legislative approval for a two-year suspension of the law so that the $30 million could be used to pay part of the city's debt service this year on other projects, freeing up money for other spending.
The City Comptroller, Elizabeth Holtzman, raised questions about the measure, but in the end joined Mayor David N. Dinkins in supporting it to "assist the city with its short-term fiscal obligations," according to a memo she submitted to the Legislature.
 
Bonded Bridge Painting
 In 1971, as part of the scramble for cash that led to the fiscal crisis of 1975, the city convinced the Legislature to pass a measure permitting it to sell bonds of up to five years to pay for bridge painting. In a sign of the fiscal pressures of the times, the law was made retroactive to the previous year.
The practice was stopped in 1975, when the city's bonding practices came under attack. But while the laws authorizing bonding authority for school textbooks and vocational training were repealed, the bridge painting authorization remained on the books.
After issuing bonds for $4 million worth of painting last year under special circumstances -- only when it was part of major rehabilitation projects -- the city now plans to sell bonds to pay for $80 million in routine bridge painting over the next four years.
The city argues that the costs to it are less than they would be if the bridges eventually had to be rebuilt because of a lack of routine maintenance. "We will be painting 400 bridges over the next four years," said Joseph DePlasco. "The painting prolongs the life of the bridge."
 
Housing Money to Pay Bills
 The rehabilitation of scores of city-owned building shells for poor and homeless families was one of the city's success stories of the 1980's. Now budget officials have found away to cash in on it.
A thousand apartments, from Southern Boulevard in the Bronx to Madison Avenue in Manhattan, are to be sold for $66 million in Federal money to the New York City Housing Authority this year.
The housing authority, an independent agency, had been promised the Federal aid to build or renovate low-income housing. But it was stymied, officials said, by Federal rules that required it to build in mixed-income neighborhoods, where land was prohibitively expensive.
So far the city has sold $30 million in bonds to pay for the project, and under the amendment to the state finance law just passed by the Legislature, it plans to use this to meet current expenses, not pay off the bonds.
Since the city has not had time to sell bonds to cover the rest of the cost, the $36 million remaining would be used to reimburse the city for the cost of completing the renovation. One city official said if there had been time to sell the bonds, this too, would have been used for budget balancing.
Approval of the sale by the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development is pending.
 
Bonds to Pay for Interest
 When private developers put up an office tower, they include the cost of interest during construction when they figure the cost of the project. Why shouldn't New York City, budget officials ask?
City budgeters have included $50 million in budget savings this year and in the next few years from what they call capitalizing interest costs during construction of schools and other buildings: selling bonds to pay the interest incurred by the city during construction.
For example, if it took the city two years to build a $10 million school, the city would sell $11 million in bonds, including an extra $1 million to cover the cost of interest.
Since the city advances cash for its construction projects out of its regular tax collections, it would in effect, be paying interest to itself. The extra bond proceeds would go toward balancing the budget this year, but be paid off over the next decades.
In selling the bonds, New York will break ranks with most cities. Only Washington and one local government in Florida are known to have used it when selling general obligation bonds, city officials say.
Opponents of the measure -- City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman has so far blocked it -- say that a school is not an business, and that the city is not a businessman, making a precise calculaton of profit and loss. It is more like a homeowner, she says, who builds a house for his own purposes.
 
Bonds to Pay Off Bonds
 In the closing moments of the budget negotiations between the Mayor and the City Council, budget officials came up with a complicated bond-refinancing plan that they said could save the city $100 million this year.
The plan is intended to allow the city, which has little or no access to bond insurance, to sell $1 billion in insured bonds at rates far lower than the city now pays for its regular bonds. To do this, the city would sell other bonds to pay off insured bonds issued several years ago.
If the city's calculations are correct, this would save $100 million over the life of the bonds. And the refinancings would be structured so that the entire savings could be taken this year, officials said.
 
Lurking in the Shadows
 There are other one-time revenue measures and refinancings lurking in the shadows of the current budget.
Mayor Dinkins said he had hoped to get $350 million this year from a bond refinancing from the Municipal Assistance Corporation, a state agency set up during the fiscal crisis of the 1970's to sell bonds for the city.
But when Standard & Poor's suggested that the borrowing was a form of deficit financing and threatened to reduce the city's credit rating, the corporation backed off.
Under the plan, the corporation was to refinance $1 billion in bonds due over the next four years, so that they would be paid off between 1996 and 2008. This would save the city $1 billion over four years, but sharply increase the costs to city taxpayers after 1996.
And at the request of union leaders, the city is studying a plan to restructure the way it reimburses pension systems for unfunded liabilities, money the city owes the system from prior years.
Union leaders said the changes could save the city several hundred million dollars this year, but the city's chief actuary, Robert C. North, said it would increase the costs born by taxpayers in the next century.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Infiniti, Lexus Lead Consumer Survey

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: DETROIT, July 8

 BODY:
The two newest Japanese luxury car divisions, the Nissan Motor Company's Infiniti and the Toyota Motor Corporation's Lexus, tied for the highest ranking in a consumer satisfaction survey for 1990 by J. D. Power & Associates, a leading automotive market research company.
The ranking is widely regarded as an unbiased assessment of how cars and trucks perform. Manufacturers with high quality ratings aggressively use the survey in advertising and marketing in the United States. The highest-rated American car line was the Cadillac, in eighth place in this year's listing. Mercedes-Benz was third, Acura and Honda tied for fourth, Toyota sixth and Audi seventh. The survey showed the Lexus and Infiniti divisions tied at the highest level of dealer and product satisfaction since the survey was created by J. D. Power in 1986.

HEADLINE: U.S. ARMS REQUEST BACKED BY MOSCOW

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 8

 BODY:
The White House said today that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev had swiftly agreed to President Bush's request that he send his Foreign Minister to Washington this week in an effort to conclude a new nuclear arms treaty in time for signing at a summit meeting in Moscow in late July.
Arms analysts said that since Mr. Bush told Mr. Gorbachev in a cable that he should not send Foreign Minister Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh unless he was empowered to make the final deals needed to complete the treaty on long-range arms, the decision to send the Soviet team was probably the most positive signal yet that both leaders were finally serious about finishing the negotiations, which began in 1982.
 
'Plenty of Time'
 For the first time, Administration officials are also saying they really do believe that the talks should be able to conclude the treaty. 
"A lot depends on this meeting," Mr. Bush told reporters today, adding that there was "plenty of time" to complete the negotiations and still hold a summit meeting in Moscow by the end of July.
The Bush Administration, by holding up a full-scale summit meeting until the nuclear accord is completed, has been effectively saying to the Soviet leader that there will be no major breakthrough in other areas of United States-Soviet relations -- like economic aid -- until the treaty on long-range arms is completed.
While American officials insist that they have not promised the Soviets any more economic aid if the long-range arms treaty is finished next week, the mere fact of its completion would make it politically that much easier for the Bush Administration to justify whatever support it gives to the Soviet economy.
Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev will meet for two hours in London on July 17, after the meeting of the leaders of the major industrial democracies.
A full-scale, two- or three-day summit meeting in Moscow had long been planned for the end of June, but it was repeatedly postponed because both sides insisted that it could take place only if they could sign the long-negotiated Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty, which would cut long-range nuclear arsenals by roughly 30 percent.
To speed the arms talks, the two leaders said they would hold a summit meeting in Moscow only after the treaty was done. But instead the treaty negotiations lagged and ended up putting all the other aspects of the relationship, including American economic help for Mr. Gorbachev's reforms, largely on hold.
 
'Starting to Become a Joke'
 "We made the Moscow summit contingent on finishing the treaty and we have postponed it now for so long it is starting to become a joke," said one Administration official. "We really can't get on with the rest of the relationship until this is done."
For the last two months the two sides have been trying to resolve the last three major issues holding up the treaty: how much missile test data to exchange, how to determine what constitutes new missiles that won't be covered by treaty limits, and how many warheads must be removed from each existing missile. Some progress has been made.
Ten days ago, a high-level American team of experts, carrying compromise proposals to overcome these differences, met with a team of Soviet experts in Geneva. The Soviet team, though, said it did not have the authority to accept any of the American proposals, and this is what prompted Mr. Bush's appeal to Mr. Gorbachev to send Mr. Bessmertnykh to Washington with the authority to make decisions on the spot, American officials said.
But there are other reasons for wanting to finish the treaty now. Mr. Bush and other American officials increasingly recognize that given Soviet economic and political turmoil, the potential for major disruptions in the United States-Soviet relationship is very high, officials said. They also said the instability in Yugoslavia is another source of uncertainty.
 
U.S. Officials See an Advantage
 American officials insist that the treaty is weighted to United States advantage because it requires the Soviet side to make big cuts in those areas, such as large land-based missiles, where they have numerical superiority, and requires the American side to make lighter cuts in their areas of superiority, such as air-launched and submarine-launched missiles.
These lopsided concessions were first made by Mr. Gorbachev four years ago when he was trying to persuade the West that the Soviets were no longer a threat, and he has been dragging his own military along ever since -- which is why so many American officials want to lock in the treaty before he loses his room for maneuver.
The Soviet leader, and to a lesser extent Mr. Bush, also want to be rid of the arms treaty because it is symbolic of the old Soviet-American agenda, which revolved mainly around arms control, and to get on with what officials call the new agenda, which revolves around broadening relations, economic ties and providing American assistance for a Soviet transition to political pluralism and market economics.
American experts say arms control is a useful vehicle for Mr. Gorbachev to achieve greater control over his military budget and military industrial complex.
Mr. Gorbachev informed the White House on Sunday through the Soviet Embassy in Washington that the delegation headed by Mr. Bessmertnykh will arrive on Wednesday evening.
The "good news" from today's announcement, said Richard R. Burt, who recently retired as the senior American arms negotiator, is that both President Bush and President Gorbachev have clearly made a political decision to finish the treaty. The bad news, he added, is that the endgame in such a negotiation is always a highly political phase, which makes agreement that much more difficult.

HEADLINE: Shock Lingers as Happy Land Trial Starts

BYLINE: By ROBERT E. TOMASSON

 BODY:
An unemployed Cuban refugee went on trial in a Bronx courtroom yesterday, charged with committing the largest mass murder in American history: the arson fire that killed 87 people at the illegal Happy Land social club in the Bronx nearly 16 months ago.
Even before jury selection began yesterday, the judge agreed to admit into evidence three admissions made to the police by the defendant, 37-year-old Julio Gonzalez. 
 Mr. Gonzalez, who has pleaded not guilty by reason of insanity, is accused of starting the fire in a rage after he argued with a former girlfriend, who worked at the club, and was ejected by a bouncer.
The fire, set with a dollar's worth of gasoline, quickly engulfed the club and trapped its victims, who had gathered for an evening of drinking and dancing on the night of March 25, 1990. They could not escape from the crowded second floor, which had been been added on illegally and had no emergency exit. Only five people survived.
The owners of the Happy Land, at 1959 Southern Boulevard in the East Tremont section, had repeatedly ignored officials who cited the club for fire violations and ordered it closed. In the aftermath, officials closed scores of other illegal clubs around the city, many of them, like the Happy Land, sanctuaries for the city's growing Hispanic population.
 
Honduran Victims
 Fifty-nine of those who died at the Happy Land were from Honduras. And while the fire stunned the city and the nation for its circumstances and the sheer number of the victims, it cut its deepest swath through the heart of New York's Honduran community. Everyone, it seemed, knew or was related to someone who had died. In the months after the disaster -- as the case moved tortuously through pretrial proceedings -- the survivors and the friends and families of the victims waited with loneliness and frustration for the trial to begin.
At 12:45 P.M. yesterday, Mr. Gonzalez stood up from his seat in front of a large oak table in the fourth-floor courtroom in the Bronx County Courthouse, turned, and with a brief nod, faced 70 prospective jurors seated in the spectators' section. Mr. Gonzalez, who is being held without bail, has not denied that he started the fire, but has pleaded not guilty on the basis of a "lack of criminal responsibility because of mental disorder or defect."
In one statement to the police that was videotaped, Mr. Gonzalez said that after he was barred from the club, "I lost my mind," then bought gasoline, poured it over an entranceway and ignited it.
For relatives of the victims who came to the opening of the trial, the horror has remained vivid even as they became conditioned by time to their losses.
"I think about my father, how he was," said Maria Colon, the 14-year-old daughter of Ramon Colon, 40, who died in the fire. Surrounded by glaring television lights in the corridor outside the courtroom, the girl nervously answered reporters' questions, and her eyes filled with tears as she tried to talk about life without her father.
Jennie Dantzler, whose 31-year-old daughter, Natalie, died, said the sound of fire trucks still triggers painful memories, "and when I look at Natalie's daughter, I see my own daughter, so beautiful."
Justice Burton B. Roberts of the State Supreme Court denied a motion by the defense to suppress the three admissions made by Mr. Gonzalez, as well as physical evidence including sneakers with gasoline residue owned by the defendant.
In denying the motion, Justice Roberts ruled that the admissions had been made voluntarily and that the physical evidence had been seized properly. He said he would outline the legal reasoning for his decision in an opinion later in the trial.
 
Judge's Anger
 The first day of the trial was marked by repeated delays in bringing prospective jurors to the courtroom, logistical problems, and a blast of anger directed at the defense lawyer, Richard W. Berne, by Justice Roberts. He is the administrative judge of the Bronx, and has long been known for his florid style on the bench and before that as the Bronx District Attorney.
"I am not a martinet," Justice Roberts said after admonishing the lawyer, who had stepped out into the corridor during a wait for jurors. "You are not to try the case in the corridor," the judge said.
No jurors were seated yesterday, and jury selection is expected to take a week or more.
The case is likely to involve conflicting testimony by numerous expert witnesses about the state of mind of Mr. Gonzalez on the night of the fire.
 
Ex-Girlfriend Survived
 Mr. Berne and Eric Warner, the senior executive assistant district attorney who is in charge of the prosecution, did not elaborate on what witnesses they expected to call. However, the court-appointed defense lawyer said he had been to Cuba, apparently to investigate Mr. Gonzalez's background.
One probable witness is Lydia Feliciano, Mr. Gonzalez's former girlfriend, who escaped the fire. The prosecution contends that Mr. Gonzalez set fire to the club in an attempt to kill Ms. Feliciano, who was working as a coat-check attendant there.
Mr. Gonzalez, who has a full beard and was dressed yesterday in dungarees, a light blue shirt and a zippered navy blue and gray jacket, sat between his lawyer and a translator who rendered the court proceedings in Spanish.
Mr. Gonzalez faces a total of 178 counts, including two murder counts for each victim: one for acting with a depraved disregard for human life, and the other for felony murder -- death resulting during the commission of a felony, in this case arson. The other counts are arson and assault charges.
Mr. Gonzalez had been examined repeatedly by psychiatrists for both the defense and the prosecution.
Under an agreement worked out by the lawyers and Justice Roberts, if Mr. Berne abandons a psychiatric defense, the prosecutor will not be allowed to use information from its interviews as evidence.

Judge: Burton B. Roberts
Administrative judge for the criminal and civil branches of State Supreme Court in the Bronx . . . tough-talking and theatrical in court, but considered progressive in sentencing . . . a Bronx Democratic Party insider . . . viewed as the model for Judge Myron Kovitsky in Tom Wolfe's novel "The Bonfire of the Vanities" . . . now 69, he graduated from New York University in 1943 . . . law degrees from Cornell University and New York University School of Law . . . was an assistant district attorney in Manhattan from 1949 to 1966 . . . became chief assistant district attorney in the Bronx in 1966 . . . was the Bronx District Attorney from 1968 through 1972 . . . was elected justice of the Supreme Court in November 1972 . . . named administrative judge of the criminal branch of State Supreme Court in the Bronx in December 1983 . . . named to present post in August 1988.

Defense Lawyer: Richard Berne
Partner in the Bronx law firm of Brown, Berne & Serra . . . now 39, he is a former lawyer for the Legal Aid Society, which provides legal services to poor people . . . representing Moses Riegler, charged last December in a child-abuse case in which Mr. Riegler's wife was accused of fatally beating their 8-year-old mentally retarded son. HEADLINE: Bank Rules Gain Urgency After Collapse

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The collapse of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International may give added impetus to changes in bank supervision that regulators worldwide have talked about for years but have not yet put in place.
As more of B.C.C.I.'s operations were closed yesterday around the world, regulators from the central banks of the 10 leading industrial nations met in Basel, Switzerland, and began to assess what changes could be made in the wake of allegations of widespread fraud at the bank. 
 In London, a Treasury official said the Bank of England received an important tip about the problems in the bank from a new employee who came forward early in the year. [Page D6.]
B.C.C.I.'s speculation in the Treasury bond market -- on such a scale that it reportedly lost $500 million -- is a reminder that regulators in the United States and other countries do not have uniform standards for measuring or limiting the amount of risk a bank might assume in trading securities or foreign currencies. The authorities have said that part of B.C.C.I.'s fraud was an effort to cover up speculative losses.
"We have asked ourselves what lesson we can draw," said Jacques de Larosiere, head of the Bank of France and chairman of the Group of 10 regulators.
The official takeover of B.C.C.I. began on Friday in London and Luxembourg when banking authorities in each location said they had discovered a pattern of widespread fraud within the bank, which has operations in 69 countries.
E. Gerald Corrigan, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said after the meeting in Basel that the existing system for measuring a bank's capital relative to its risk of loss from bad loans needed to be refined to include the risk of loss from trading activities.
Mr. Corrigan was named head of the Group of 10's bank regulatory committee yesterday. In the late 1980's, the committee developed a system requiring banks to hold capital equal to 8 percent of their assets, adjusted for risk, by 1992.
Mr. Corrigan said that system needed to be changed "to build in explicit allowances for market risks as it pertains to foreign exchange trading, debt securities and equities."
 
Regulators Act in Hong Kong
 In Hong Kong, the authorities closed B.C.C.I.'s local operation yesterday, after indicating on Friday that it would be allowed to remain open. The crown colony's banking commissioner, David Carse, explained that he was worried that there might be a run on the bank, although no such problem occurred on Saturday.
On Friday, Bank of England officials had indicated that they thought the operation in Hong Kong was well enough protected to remain open.
Operations were also closed or suspended in Tokyo, South Korea, Sri Lanka, Cyprus and in the special Shenzhen economic zone of China. For a third day, there was a run on the B.C.C.I. operation in Pakistan, but the bank was not closed. An operation also remained open in Thailand.
In addition, Swiss authorities did not close the Swiss operation of B.C.C.I., but the Swiss bank is under close supervision and cannot make payments to its parent company.
In Tokyo, the B.C.C.I. operation suspended its own operations on an order from Luxembourg, where one of the company's two main operations was established. (The other, in the Cayman Islands, was also closed.) Japan's Ministry of Finance said there was now no reason to freeze the assets and deposits of the bank.
The problems of supervising B.C.C.I., a privately owned bank, were far greater than a lack of knowledge about its trading. Until Bank of England officials obtained a report by B.C.C.I.'s auditor, the absence of a strong bank regulator in Luxembourg left regulators in other countries with little knowledge about the scope of the activities of the bank, its financial condition and its management policies.
 
Lack of Consolidated Review
 "The B.C.C.I. case provides an example of an institution not subject to consolidated review by any one regulator, which enhanced B.C.C.I.'s ability to carry out its operations without normal regulatory scrutiny," J. Virgil Mattingly Jr., general counsel of the Federal Reserve, said at a Senate Banking Committee hearing in May.
Mr. Mattingly was testifying about B.C.C.I.'s role, which was concealed from the Fed, in financing the purchase in the early 1980's of the Washington banking company now called First American Bankshares, as well as its purchase of smaller banks in California and Georgia.
The Fed is now convinced, Mr. Mattingly said, that legislation is needed to require that foreign banks obtain Fed approval for any new branch or office in the United States. The Fed should also have full authority to arrange for examinations of foreign banks and to obtain information to determine if American operations are complying with American laws.
Mr. Mattingly said stronger enforcement was needed because American regulators had been stymied by some banks' efforts to hide information by keeping it offshore.
