HEADLINE: Kohl, in Shift, Is Reported to Favor Indirect Economic Aid to Moscow

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, July 8

 BODY:
As a result of his talks with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Chancellor Helmut Kohl has decided against urging Western leaders to provide direct financial aid to the Soviet Union when they meet next week in London and instead will seek a consensus on granting Moscow some kind of "special status" that could lead to eventual assistance from the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, German officials say.
Faced with opposition from several Western governments to large-scale money grants to the Soviet Union, the Chancellor is instead hoping to win approval for the idea of indirect aid channelled through the World Bank and International Monetary Fund. Such aid is likely to be given only if the Soviets adopt sweeping economic reforms. 
 At the summit meeting of seven industrial democracies in London next week, Mr. Kohl is expected to urge that the Soviet Union be given "special status" membership in both financial institutions, and full membership as soon as possible. Mr. Gorbachev is flying to London to talk to the seven leaders at the close of their meeting.
In advance of this, Mr. Kohl, who has been the strongest advocate among Western leaders for aid to Moscow, flew to Kiev on Friday to confer with Mr. Gorbachev. With a week to go before the London meeting, diplomacy has intensified, with Mr. Kohl saying he planned to contact the other leaders -- from Britain, France, Italy, Canada, the United States and Japan -- to discuss the results of his talks.
Speaking to reporters aboard his return flight from Kiev, where he met with Mr. Gorbachev for nearly five hours, Mr. Kohl said he was optimistic that Western powers would support aid channeled through international agencies. He said he expected Mr. Gorbachev to present a reform program that would impress Western leaders.
"It would be foolish for the Western countries to sit back and calmly watch what happens in the Soviet Union," Mr. Kohl said in an interview with the newspaper Welt am Sonntag.
 
Political and Economic Issues
 In Kiev, the two discussed political as well as economic issues, people close to Mr. Kohl said. Both agreed that it was important for the Soviet Union to show that it was making progress on the "union treaty" that will redefine relationships between the central Government and the Soviet republics. In the absence of such a treaty, many foreign investors have been unwilling to launch projects in the Soviet Union because they do not know whether they should be negotiating with local authorities or federal agencies in Moscow.
Mr. Kohl told Mr. Gorbachev that if a union treaty could be concluded, and if the Soviet Union took other steps to attract investors, Moscow would not need long-term aid from abroad.
Another political problem that might have been an irritant between Germany and the Soviet Union was apparently resolved in Kiev. Mr. Gorbachev promised that Soviet troops would be withdrawn from eastern Germany on schedule, by 1994. He attributed reports that the withdrawal would be delayed to "outsiders," apparently referring to Soviet military officers.
The two leaders also drew up a list of projects in the Soviet Union where foreign aid could be well used. They included renovation of power plants, reconstruction of the Soviet rail network and construction of new oil and gas pipelines, which could help expand Soviet oil and gas exports, from which the country could earn large amounts of hard currency.
Because investor confidence in the Soviet Union is so low, these projects can only be financed with foreign aid or credits. German banks, for example, were last year willing to give loans to the Soviet Union if the Bonn Government guaranteed 80 percent of them, but they are now insisting on 100 percent guarantees.
"Everywhere there are growing doubts about the political and economic development of the Soviet Union," said Horst Kohler, a Finance Ministry official who is in charge of summit preparations for Mr. Kohl.

HEADLINE: Bush Sets Up Foundation to Start Model Schools

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 8

 BODY:
In a move he described as a milestone in the "educational revolution" he outlined in April, President Bush today announced the establishment of a foundation to foster the creation of model schools.
In a Rose Garden ceremony, Mr. Bush, who was accompanied by Education Secretary Lamar Alexander, introduced 18 business, education and political leaders as members of the board of the New American Schools Development Corporation, saying they would help "set aside stale preconceptions" about how schools should work and "seek nothing less than a new generation of schools." 
 Mr. Bush has said he hopes the private, nonprofit corporation will persuade businesses to donate as much as $200 million for the creation of 535 experimental schools intended to be models of reform for the nation. The schools, one in each Congressional district and two more for each state, are part of Mr. Bush's education legislation now being considered by Congress.
"We want to encourage and experiment," Mr. Bush said. "No one will conduct our educational revolution for us. We've got to do it ourselves. We've done enough hand-wringing about the state of our schools and now let's act."
The Rand Corporation's Institute on Education and Training will serve as the research arm for the new corporation. An advisory panel of educators is to assist the corporation.
Thomas H. Kean, the former New Jersey Governor and chairman of the corporation, said the group had already received $30 million in donations. Walter H. Annenberg, the publisher and former diplomat, is a member of the board and donated a $10 million "challenge" grant to encourage other corporations to help.
But with a recession, some companies that plan to contribute to the new program are cutting back on financial commitments to existing education projects.
The Exxon Corporation, for example, told Theodore R. Sizer, a professor of education at Brown University, that it would give him one year's worth of financial aid instead of the five years he had requested for his Coalition of Essential Schools, a nationwide group of schools that have been promoting innovative teaching and learning techniques.
Edward F. Ahnert, executive director of the Exxon Education Foundation, said, "We have not made a decision to cut back our longer-term funding but rather to review our long-term commitments to his program in the light of the New American School Program."
 Here is complete list of members of the board of the New American Schools Development Corporation.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

International
President Bush is likely to order the lifting or suspension of sanctions against South Africa as soon as the middle of this week, a senior Administration official said. The State Department has concluded that South Africa has met, or is meeting, all five conditions specified in 1986 legislation for lifting the sanctions. [Page A1.] 
 The Japanese Government, trying to put a quick end to a stock market scandal before the economic summit next week, announced penalties against the country's four biggest securities houses and apologized to the international financial community. [D1.]
The Commerce Department proposed stiff duties on certain computer screens from Japan. The duties are on active matrix liquid crystal displays, expected to be the most common type of screen in the laptop and notebook computers of the future. [D1.]

HEADLINE: Oregon Peyote Law Leaves 1983 Defendant Unvindicated

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEATTLE, July 8

 BODY:
As a drug and alcohol abuse counselor for American Indians in Oregon, Galen Black said he thought it was important to learn the ancient Indian art of spiritual healing. He took in sweat-lodge ceremonies and sun dances, and he even smoked the occasional pipe filled with sacred herbs.
Then one day in 1983, Mr. Black attended one of the most sacred healing rituals of all: As a guest, he and others ingested a small amount of peyote, a cactus containing the hallucinogen mescaline, in a ceremony of the Native American Church. 
 "My job required me to learn cultural-specific treatments," Mr. Black said. But his bosses at the Douglas County Drug and Alcohol Treatment Center disagreed and dismissed him, and Mr. Black's quest for vindication was ultimately denied by the United States Supreme Court.
Nevertheless, Mr. Black's legal battle has resulted in expanded religious rights for American Indians in the state. A new Oregon law, signed June 24 by Gov. Barbara Roberts, permits the sacramental use of peyote.
 
No Unemployment Benefits
 After telling of his experience, Mr. Black was dismissed by the center on charges of misconduct. Alfred Smith, an American Indian and a counselor who worked with Mr. Black, was also dismissed after admitting he had taken peyote.
The state did not seek criminal prosecution of the two men. But it said the men would be ineligible for unemployment compensation because under Oregon law, work-related misconduct can be the basis for denying such compensation. By 1990, the case went to the United States Supreme Court, which upheld the state's position.
Under the new law, Mr. Black and Mr. Smith, as guests, would still be subject to prosecution, while people practicing the religion would not.
Federal law and the laws of 23 states, including many with large Indian populations, exempt the sacramental use of peyote from criminal penalties. Idaho has a law permitting the use of peyote in "bona fide religious rites" of native American religious ceremonies.
While peyote is still illegal, the Oregon law provides a defense for people who use the hallucinogen in connection with "good faith practice of a religious belief."
The bill's chief sponsor, State Representative Jim Edmunson, a Eugene Democrat, said the new law was meant to counteract the Supreme Court's decision in April 1990. The Justices, voting 6 to 3, said state governments may prosecute those who use illegal drugs in religious ceremonies.
Opponents of the new law argue that peyote is a dangerous hallucinogen. State Representative Ron Sunseri, a Republican of Gresham, said he voted against the bill because it continued to allow the drug to be given to children and pregnant women in the sacred ceremony.
Though a lawyer for Mr. Black and Mr. Smith says there was no vindication of the actions of his clients, the men are relieved that the years of public scrutiny and court battles are finally over.
"It's all been traumatic for me," said Mr. Black, 43 years old, who lives in Cottage Grove, Ore., and who has spent about $10,000 on legal fees. "No one will hire me as a counselor, and I've had to take second-rate jobs. Several times after my job applications were declined, I knew they did so because of the scrutiny."
Mr. Smith, 71, now a freelance counselor in the Eugene area, specializing in Indian cultural affairs, said he was glad he endured the long fight.
"Over the years, I questioned whether the ceremony was worth losing my job over and being scrutinized by the nation," Mr. Smith said, referring to the religious ritual. "But I did nothing wrong. How could they tell me I was attending a drug party when the ceremony was one of the most sacred Native American ceremonies that has survived for thousands of years?"

HEADLINE: White House Called Ready to Lift Trade Sanctions on South Africa

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 8

 BODY:
President Bush is likely to order the lifting or suspension of trade and financial sanctions against South Africa as soon as the middle of this week, a senior Administration official said today.
The State Department has concluded that South Africa has met or is in the process of meeting all five conditions specified in 1986 legislation for lifting the sanctions, the official said. And the State Department has recommended the sanctions be lifted, he added.
 
Early Action Seen
 "The President is reviewing it and will make an announcement about lifting the sanctions as early as midweek," said the official, who insisted on anonymity. 
 The United States Embassy in South Africa has concluded that the Government there has released enough political prisoners to satisfy the only condition that, according to the administration, had not already been met, the official said.
The President could still impose a temporary condition on the action, or may temporarily suspend the sanctions pending the actual release of all remaining political prisoners. But Administration officials felt that Mr. Bush was more likely to drop the sanctions.
The Administration's move, first reproted in The Washington Post's Tuesday issue, seems likely to meet surprisingly little opposition in Congress.
The shift in United States policy comes at a time when there is no more agreement on the effectiveness of the sanctions than when they were imposed in 1986.
Senator Richard Lugar, Indiana Republican and one of the architects of the sanctions, favors their removal. And a prominent Congressional opponent of any immediate removal conceded in an interview before word of Mr. Bush's intent to lift the sanctions that he did not have the support to block such a move.
"If the President does lift sanctions, I don't think we have the votes to override on either side, in the House or in the Senate," said Representative Edolphus Towns, the Brooklyn Democrat who is the chairman of the Congressional Black Caucus. The 26-member group has led an effort to introduce a more stringent basis for the sanctions.
 
Delaying End of Sanctions
 Mr. Towns said that while his group could not win on a vote to override, it would try to rally support in Congress to dissuade the President from taking action until recent political changes in South Africa have clearly become irrevocable.
If President Bush does act to lift the five-year-old sanctions, a reversal of the decision would require a majority vote in both houses within 30 days that not all the conditions had been met and that the sanctions should not be removed.
Administration officials have now concluded that South Africa has met the five conditions specified in the original legislation that authorized the sanctions. South Africa has lifted state of emergency regulations, ended bans on some political groups, given assurances that it will enter negotiations for a new system of government and abolished the legal foundations of the system of racial separation known as apartheid.
The last condition called for South Africa to release all political prisoners, but did not define closely just who qualified as such a prisoner. The United States Ambassador to South Africa, William Swing, reviewed South African compliance with this condition and determined that it had been met, said a State Department official who insisted on anonymity.
Mr. Lugar said that efforts to expand on the original conditions now were comparable to, "moving the goalposts."
But Mr. Towns said that his call for ensuring that change is irreversible in South Africa, "is not moving the goal posts, it's making sure the goalpost is up straight."
Much of the disagreement in Congress now on the sanctions reflects differences that have persisted for years over their effectiveness and purpose.
 
Prospects for Change
 Some experts on South Africa contend that freedom of political organization is limited while some opposition leaders remain in exile. They also note that discriminatory legislation remains on the books in South Africa, and say that even the recent repeal of major apartheid legislation may not bring immediate social change.
For example, the repeal of a law barring blacks from buying land in areas designated for whites will not result in an immediate change in the pattern of land ownership in South Africa because blacks there have limited financial resources and the process of land purchase takes time, said Phillip G. LeBel, the chairman of the economics faculty at Montclair State College in New Jersey and the director of the Center for Economic Research on Africa.
Nelson Mandela, who was elected president of the African National Congress last Friday, called for the sanctions to be maintained.
The sanctions barred most trade with South Africa, except for strategic minerals, and banned new investment there. The economic effect on both the United States and South Africa has been unclear, particularly because the sanctions coincided with strong public pressure and local laws in the United States aimed at forcing companies to shut down operations in South Africa.
According to a report last month by the Investor Responsibility Research Center, a non-profit group in Washington, the number of American companies doing business in South Africa has plummeted since the beginning of 1984, from 323 to 114. Mr. Lugar estimated that the trade and investment restrictions had depressed South Africa's entire economic output by 1 to 3 percent annually since the sanctions were put in place.
 
More Trade With Neighbors
 But the trade restrictions did not severely reduce South Africa's overseas commerce because other countries stepped in to take the place of the United States, said Michael D. Johns, a foreign policy analyst specializing in African issues at the conservative Heritage Foundation in Washington. South African exports to its neighbors and the Soviet Union increased when the American market was closed to them, he said.
"They did adjust, to the extent they could, to develop markets elsewhere," Mr. Johns added.
At the same time, however, the sanctions have not been as painful for the United States economy as many people feared, Mr. LeBel said. Gold has lost much of its former role in international trade and finance, and this has made South Africa's production less important, he said.
Even more debated than the economic effectiveness of the sanctions has been their political role. Mr. Towns said that the sanctions had forced the various factions in South African politics to begin negotiating seriously with each other, and that these negotiations were less likely to continue if the sanctions were dropped.
President F. W. de Klerk of South Africa, "needs sanctions to keep people talking," Mr. Towns said. "The moment sanctions are lifted, I'm not sure he can keep people at the table."
Mr. Lugar said that Congress's action in 1986 had contributed to the release of Mr. Mandela from prison and other changes in South Africa, and may even have helped avert a civil war there. But he also contended that the spirit as well as the letter of the law imposing sanctions had been satisfied, and that Congress would support any move by President Bush to lift the sanctions.
Mr. Johns said that the effect of sanctions had been modest, and that their apparent success mostly reflected the fact that they were imposed at the same time that the Cold War was waning and Communism was in collapse. The severing of economic ties has eroded American influence in South Africa and made it difficult for United States policymakers to affect the rapid changes now taking place, he said.

HEADLINE: Russian Seeks U.S. Buyer For World's Biggest Rocket

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

 BODY:
DR. BORIS IVANOVICH GUBANOV is the designer of the world's most powerful rocket, a 20-story giant with eight engines that can hurl more into orbit in one stroke than 100 small launchings did at the start of the space age.
He is also a salesman, forced by circumstance to wander the globe with a battered suitcase, trying to drum up business. 
 His timing could be auspicious. As the Western powers prepare for an economic summit later this month, and debate how to help the Soviet Union, they may conclude that the best way to help is to buy its products. And services like those of Dr. Gubanov are among that country's few competitive goods.
At 61, the gray-haired Soviet scientist shows little unease over his predicament. He smiles effortlessly, sipping coffee and speaking with pride of his rocket and with reluctance of the Soviet Union's economic ills that are gnawing at his program.
Planned firings of his rocket, known as Energia, have repeatedly been delayed "because of difficulties in my country," he said last week during a New York visit.
His rocket had its debut in 1987, thundering from central Asia into the night sky atop a huge column of red flame, its engines strong enough to lift 100 tons of payload. But Energia has flown only once since then, in 1988, when it launched the Soviet space shuttle on its maiden voyage. The rocket's next flight is set for 1992. But Western experts say economic crisis in the Soviet Union could cause the program to be canceled.
"We have spent a lot of money," Dr. Gubanov said with a sigh. "We have very powerful rockets. The tragedy is that we go very slow."
His goal in the West is to sell launching services or rocket engines or nearly anything else related to space in order to generate revenue for his beleaguered country and keep production lines open for his rocket. Dr. Gubanov recently spent two weeks in the United States to address a rocketry conference and talk with Western companies and space experts about the possibility of joint programs and business deals.
 To some analysts, the solicitations of such a high official indicate a new level of desperation in the Soviet space program -- and perhaps a new opportunity for the West.
With the end of the cold war, Western experts have increasingly called for cooperative space ventures. Last month a Stanford University study suggested that an Energia-based effort between East and West could put people on Mars for $60 billion rather than the $400 billion to $500 billion estimated by the space agency.
"The Energia is the only way to go to Mars soon and at a reasonable cost," said Dr. Bruce Lusignan, a Stanford engineer who directed the study. "There's nothing that we currently have that can do it."
The White House welcomed the study, saying it enriched the mix of Mars options. Moreover, some private experts say the moment is ripe for a major East-West endeavor.
"We're talking about giving them all this economic aid," said Chris Faranetta, an official at the Space Studies Institute in Princeton, N.J., a private group that promotes space exploration and is trying to help Dr. Gubanov market his rocket. "Energia could be the payback. This is what they have to offer."
The notion of a Soviet bailout by the West, once dismissed as a waste of money, has risen in respectability and could well be the top issue at the London economic summit meeting later this month.
But skeptics say a payback with Energia, however appealing in theory, is extremely unlikely in practice.
"The Soviets are too naive to realize that we spend aerospace money in our own country as a matter of policy," said James E. Oberg, the author of "Red Star in Orbit" and an expert on the Soviet space program.
"We want to enhance our own industrial capacity," he said. "It's not in the cards that we're going to realign our whole program to foster their political stability, even though it's probably the most rational thing to do."
Starting around 1987, the Soviet space program, once wrapped in extreme secrecy, began a crash effort to sell a diverse line of goods and services to all who had the money. The blitz was complete with slick brochures and managers eager to cut deals, offering everything from launching services and communications satellites to space photographs that rivaled those from spy satellites.
But the effort was stymied by Soviet inexperience and by political resistance in the West. The United States banned the launching of most of its payloads atop Russian rockets, ostensibly for reasons of security. With the deepening economic crisis in the Soviet Union, however, officials there have redoubled the push, most recently with the campaign of Dr. Gubanov.
He carries considerable weight as a prominent official at the height of his career after four decades in the inner sanctum of Soviet rocketry.
Born in Leningrad on March 14, 1930, he studied at the Aviation Institute in Kazan and in 1953 joined the secretive Yangel Design Bureau (later renamed the Yuzhnoye Bureau) in the Ukrainian city of Dnepropetrovsk, near the Black Sea. Yangel was a nerve center of the cold war, devising many of the missiles that threatened the West with nuclear annihilation, including the SS-4, the SS-7, the SS-9, the SS-18 and the SS-24. The fearsome SS-18, dubbed "Satan" in the West, can deliver 10 or more nuclear warheads with great precision half way around the world. Its abolition has long been the principal goal of American arms negotiators. The SS-24 is a new, solid-fueled missile similar to the American MX that is based in underground silos and on trains.
Dr. Gubanov rose rapidly through the ranks at Yangel, helping design several weapons and variations of them to loft military and scientific satellites into space.
Never, Dr. Gubanov said in an interview, has he witnessed the launching of one of his creations. Instead he always monitored their performance from the safety of a bunker.
 
Fueled by Liquid Hydrogen
 In 1982 he left the military bureau to become chief designer of the Energia, working in Kaliningrad outside Moscow. The pinnacle of his career came on Nov. 15, 1988, he said, when Energia flawlessly lifted the Soviet space shuttle Buran into space. He was technical director of the overall endeavor.
"For every rocket man," he said, "the first flight of his child is very, very important."
Designed to loft both shuttles and unmanned cargo craft, Energia is the first launcher in the Soviet Union to burn liquid hydrogen, a high-energy fuel crucial for boosting heavy payloads. The rocket's four main engines burn liquid hydrogen, and its four strap-on rockets use room-temperature kerosene, which is about half as efficient. A similar arrangement was used on America's moon rocket, the Saturn 5.
Speaking two weeks ago at a rocket conference in California sponsored by the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, a professional group based in Washington, Dr. Gubanov outlined how Energia's elements could be rearranged to boost or lessen its power. For instance, it could be configured with eight strap-on booster rockets to hurl 200 tons of payload into orbit. So, too, he said, a cut-down version known as Energia M with only two strap-on boosters could loft payloads up to 35 tons.
In an interview, Dr. Gubanov sketched a range of possible East-West ventures that might use Energia, including the lofting of huge solar-power satellites to beam energy to Earth, the building of NASA's space station and the mounting of manned expeditions to the Moon and Mars.
"The young people will hate us for not making a decision to go to Mars," he said. "To have on our planet this technology, and not use it for all the countries, is not good. Everybody should get together."
Dr. Gubanov dismissed Western speculation that the Energia program might be canceled if no international clients were found, saying a more likely outcome would be a reduction of program size to focus on smaller vehicles such as Energia M.
Dr. Gubanov has pitched his wares at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, the group most likely to employ his services. But NASA has shown little interest.
The agency, struggling to develop its own heavy-lift launcher and advanced technologies, has shied away from all but minor cooperation with the Soviets. A key question, officials say, is whether the Soviet Union is politically stable enough for long-term teamwork, which in the case of a Mars mission would go on for decades.
"It's premature to think of a joint Mars program, given the uncertainties over the budget, the technology and need to re-establish our working relationship with them," said Debbie Rahn, a spokeswoman at NASA headquarters in Washington.
Samuel W. Keller, NASA's associate deputy administrator, said of the West's use of Energia: "If we already had 10 years of cooperation with the Soviets, you might come up with a different answer than you would today," adding that "supplier reliability" was a key issue.
But other experts say shifting political winds might tip the balance more rapidly. Aviation Week & Space Technology, a respected industry publication, said in its current issue that the Federal Government was preparing a plan in which Soviet astronauts would ride aboard the American space shuttle in exchange for a Soviet launching of American astronauts to the Mir space station. The plan, it said, might be made public during the summit meeting later this summer between President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union.
Some experts foresee a possibility, however slim, of an East-West accord in the near future that might include the use of Energia.
"As a political decision, it would make a great deal of sense," said Dr. Jerry Grey, head of science and technology policy for the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics. "But as an engineer, I'd hate to carry it out. Just matching up payloads to the rocket would not be easy. Everything has to be compatible. All things considered, it's hard to see this as a realistic alternative."

HEADLINE: THE DOCTOR'S WORLD;
Little-Known Doctor Who Found New Use For Common Aspirin

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN, M.D.

 BODY:
DOCTORS have long tried to find new uses for old drugs, and in this quest centuries may pass before someone discovers hidden benefits in standard medications. Yet even when important new uses are found, it may be decades before the benefits are confirmed and widely recommended.
A case in point is aspirin, which is one of the oldest and most commonly used drugs. In a new use documented only in recent years, aspirin is now recommended for millions of Americans who are at risk for the prevention and treatment of heart attacks and strokes. 
 And only in recent weeks has the modern generation of doctors begun to appreciate that the new use derives from observations made by Dr. Lawrence L. Craven, a general practitioner in Glendale, Calif., more than 40 years ago. Dr. Craven noted an unusual incidence of bleeding complications among children who chewed gum containing aspirin to relieve the pain from a tonsillectomy.
Probably no other new use for an old drug took longer to discover, has had a greater impact on public health, and has had as fascinating a history.
The history of aspirin and related compounds can be traced to two Greek physicians, Hippocrates, who lived from 460 to 377 B.C., and Galen, who lived from 130 to 200 A.D. These physicians recommended that their patients treat a variety of ailments by chewing willow bark, which contains salicylic acid, a close chemical cousin of aspirin.
Aspirin, which is acetyl salicylic acid, was first synthesized in the 19th century, but it lay dormant on the shelves of the Bayer Company in Germany until it began to be used in a few patients just before the turn of the century. But no one seems to have seen aspirin's potential against heart attacks and strokes until Dr. Craven began his studies in the late 1940's, according to an article in the June issue of The Archives of Internal Medicine by the journal's editor, Dr. James E. Dalen, of the University of Arizona in Tucson.
One reason such a link could not have come much earlier is that doctors began to diagnose heart attacks in patients who lived through them only after 1912. Before then, nonfatal heart attacks were passed off as indigestion, gallbladder attacks or other problems.
Little is known about Dr. Craven, who was a graduate of the University of Minnesota medical school.
The crux of his discovery was his observation of the bleeding among children who chewed aspirin gum after tonsillectomies. Noting reports that aspirin affected blood's ability to clot, he inferred that aspirin would be safer than dicumarol, an anti-coagulant that doctors had begun prescribing for heart attack patients in the 1940's.
Dr. Craven recommended an aspirin a day for healthy men between the ages of 45 and 65, particularly those who were overweight and led sedentary lives. He made the same recommendation for people who had recovered from heart attacks.
His advice was based on studies of nearly 8,000 patients. He reported the studies, from 1950 to 1956, in obscure medical publications, including the Mississippi Valley Medical Journal. Dr. Craven was astonished by his own findings: no detectable cases of heart attacks and strokes among those studied.
It was a time when the statistical techniques used in modern clinical trials were just being pioneered, and Dr. Craven was aware that he lacked a comparison group. Before he died in 1957 at the age of 74 from angina, a year after publication of his final article, Dr. Craven invited others to test his thesis with more sophisticated techniques. Larger studies did come, but it took more than a decade for them to start.
The reasons for the delay are not clear but they partly reflect the tendency of scientists to insist on understanding the biological mechanism for a treatment before studying it.
 Dr. Craven's reports help refute the dogma that discoveries come only from full-time scientists working at research institutions and demonstrate that inquisitive doctors can do research in any setting.
But observations alone are not enough to change medical practice because they may be wrong and may have resulted from unrelated and confounding factors. Also, therapies based simply on observation may turn out to be more hazardous than beneficial.
Paradoxically, aspirin poses risks of bleeding that can cause strokes, and aspirin can also cause gastrointestinal symptoms. But studies have shown the benefits generally outweigh the risks.
Although Dr. Craven noticed the bleeding that his tonsillectomy patients suffered, many doctors overlook similar clues that abound in everyday medical practice.
Doctors do detect many other clues, but they usually do not take the next steps of reporting the observation and starting studies to document the effect. Those are the crucial steps that help distinguish the gadfly from the true scientist.
The link between rubella (German measles) and birth defects is among the crucial findings that astute practitioners have made. In 1941, by studying a small cluster of cases in Australia, Dr. N. M. Gregg first noted that the rubella virus could cause cataracts, deafness, heart deformities and mental retardation. Until then, doctors considered rubella another harmless childhood disease.
Medical dogma holds that many discoveries result from taking observations made by clinicians at the bedside into the laboratory. There, by seeking the biological mechanisms and explanations for the observations, researchers come up with new therapies that are then brought back to the bedside for testing.
Although that process appears to have been at play in the recognition of aspirin as a treatment against heart attacks and strokes, the lack of credit to Dr. Craven is striking. A spot check of several pioneering studies of the aspirin link found none that credited Dr. Craven, although his papers were included in the standard international index of medical reports.
The omission possibly reflects a well-known bias of scientists in research centers to overlook contributions from practitioners, despite the dogma that advances often come from observations at the bedside.
Another factor that may have contributed to the delay in confirming Dr. Craven's findings is the economics of the drug industry. Because the patent on aspirin had long expired, experts say that drug companies had less incentive to push research on its benefits than they would on a new drug that they could have sold at a much higher price.
To help overcome the problem, Dr. Silvio Garattini, who heads the Mario Negri Institute in Milan, Italy, a non-profit pharmacology center that says it is independent of the drug industry, has recently suggested that drug companies be issued new patents for finding important new uses for old drugs.
Practitioners who make what they believe are important observations must still persuade editors of medical journals to publish the findings.
Dr. Dalen, the editor of The Archives of Internal Medicine, which is published by the American Medical Association, said in an interview that he did not know whether Dr. Craven's reports had been rejected by more prominent medical journals. Dr. Dalen said he wondered whether wider publication might have led to quicker confirmation and postponed the deaths of hundreds of thousands of Americans from heart attacks and strokes.
Yet Dr. Dalen said he was uncertain whether he would have published Dr. Craven's article if it had been submitted to his journal. The journal rejects most of the 500 letters it receives from doctors each year, Dr. Dalen said, adding that "every time I reject one that relates to a proposed therapy, I wonder if it is one that should lead to further studies."

HEADLINE: HORSE RACING;
Big Belmont Weekend Lacks Proper Crowd

BYLINE: By Joseph Durso

 BODY:
They tried hard to get you to go to the race track in New York over the Fourth of July weekend.
They imported champion horses. They staged landmark races. They matched Meadow Star against Lite Light in the battle of the royal fillies. They printed 25,000 lapel buttons bearing pictures of the fillies looking like politicians. They even matched their owners like heavyweight contenders in newspaper ads, Carl Icahn against M.C. Hammer, the financier against the rap singer. They even had the Hammer dancing in the aisles en route to the winner's circle. 
 But they didn't have many people watching.
On the final day of the long holiday weekend at Belmont Park, the horses were strutting in the paddock before the Dwyer Stakes, which has been run for three-quarters of a century and has been won by Man o' War, Gallant Fox, Johnstown, Whirlaway, Damascus and a herd of other champions. And one of New York's prominent horsemen, who owns a champion himself, looked around the elegant but tranquil scene and asked: "Where are the people?"
"I know where they were," said Gerry Lawrence, executive vice president of the New York Racing Association. "They were on the New York Thruway. I was driving down from Saratoga on Sunday, and the Thruway was jammed with all those people who weren't at the track."
Lawrence was allowing himself a bit of gallows humor. But he conceded that the question of the lost multitudes has been asked for years in racing circles, and lately with increasing urgency.
Horse racing is a betting sport, but you no longer have to go to the race track to bet. You can do it from the offtrack betting shop next to your corner drugstore, or from your favorite casino, or from a plush lounge that's wired into the track, or even by telephone from your home, office or Mercedes.
So, you can bet and also go to the beach or to the family barbecue, which may be what people were doing when this particular holiday weekend opened Thursday at Belmont with the Suburban Handicap, the 105th running of a classic race won last year by Easy Goer, the toast of the town. On the grounds: 18,664 people.
On Saturday, they offered the show-stopper: Meadow Star against Lite Light, the return match between the top fillies, with Icahn and his $150,000 on the line against Hammer and his $200,000. And there was the Hammer stripping off his shiny aquamarine leather shirt and dancing for joy when Lite Light won by seven lengths, reversing the famous photo finish of a month ago. On the grounds: 17,472 people.
Hammer draws more than that for a concert, without his horse. The Yankees drew 11,000 more than that into Yankee Stadium the same day for their game against the Baltimore Orioles. The St. Louis Cardinals, playing in a city about one tenth the size of New York, drew 30,000 more than that for their game against the Chicago Cubs.
On Sunday, they rang down the curtain on Belmont's weekend with the Dwyer Stakes, a headline race that featured Fly So Free, last year's champion 2-year-old colt and the favorite in this year's Kentucky Derby. He ran third before 14,304 spectators.
"For years racing was recession-proof," Lawrence said. "People always came out to get rich quick. Now they've got casinos and lotteries where you can get rich quick.
"I also think, with this economy, that people are changing their recreation habits, even their vacation habits. People who used to go away for two weeks may now be taking day trips. And the day they take it may be the Fourth of July. We're looking at a changing pattern."
But when you race Meadow Star against Lite Light and bill it as the battle of the ages, where do the people go?
"If they want to place a bet," Lawrence said, "they may go to their OTB parlor and skip the drive to Belmont, the bridge tolls, the traffic. In that sense, our business is gaining: People are betting more money. But we still have to find a way to draw more of them to the race track, whether they bet or not. We have to find a way to make it more entertaining."
More entertaining than Meadow Star against Lite Light? Well, it took them two minutes to run the mile and a quarter Saturday. So, maybe you have to offer more. One month earlier, the Belmont Stakes featured Hansel and Strike the Gold and Best Pal, and it was preceded by four other stakes races with stars like Fly So Free and Farma Way and Festin and Jolie's Halo. On the grounds: 51,766.
But you can't run blockbusters every day, so racing is left with its changing patterns. The omens are there: The 12 largest betting days at New York race tracks all were recorded since 1980. The 12 largest crowds at New York race tracks all were counted before 1980.
They can't all be stuck on the Thruway.

HEADLINE: $2 to Enrich Democracy

 BODY:
Democracy is priceless but running for President is costly. Representative Al Swift of Washington offers a sensible way to pay for both -- a $2 increase in the taxpayer checkoff for Presidential campaigns.
Public funding was an urgent necessity when Congress adopted it in 1974. President Nixon's scandal-ridden 1972 campaign had debased private fund-raising; the integrity of the Presidency was in tatters. To protect that integrity now, it is just as urgent that the Federal campaign fund be rescued from running dry. 
 The 1974 law had a fundamental flaw, unnoticed at the time. The fund pays out more each time for campaigns and party conventions, to offset inflation. But there is no parallel provision for increasing the fund's income.
Taxpayers feed the fund $1 each time they check the "Yes" box at the top of their Federal tax returns. Lately that has been bringing in about $33 million a year. If the checkoff had been indexed for inflation, the fund would now be brimming. As it is, there may not be enough money to fully finance next year's campaign, and there definitely won't be enough for 1996.
Running out of money is not the only threat to Presidential campaign financing. Congress must also plug the loophole that lets sewer money gush into the national campaign -- indirect contributions to Presidential candidates via state party organizations. But in a session where President Bush and his party have dug in to block the expansion of public financing to Congressional campaigns, it is particularly important that the existing Presidential fund not be wiped out.
Representative Swift, chairman of the House Elections Subcommittee, would replenish the fund by raising the checkoff to $3 and indexing it in the future. His sound bill would also allot funds to primary candidates before the parties get money for their conventions -- not afterward, as the law now provides.
Finally, and most urgently, the bill would undo a recent Treasury Department decision that shortchanges next year's primaries. The Treasury plans to count only money on hand on Dec. 31 in setting 1992 allocations. Mr. Swift would also count checkoffs at tax time next spring, when people will be paying more attention to the elections.
Public financing's opponents, mostly Republican, contend that the fund is a flop, noting that two out of three taxpayers check the "No" box. But the 33 million taxpayers who checked "Yes" in 1988 constituted nearly half the 69 million who voted for President.
The Presidential fund has collected and distributed $500 million for the four elections since 1974. That's half a billion of campaign financing with no special-interest strings. Far from being a flop, it's a clear win for the public interest.

HEADLINE: Some Housing Is Better Than None

 BODY:
Andrew Cuomo, founder of HELP for the homeless, wants to build affordable housing on East 13th Street in Manhattan. He has a detailed plan that qualifies for available public funds and has won community backing. Ordinarily, it doesn't make sense to build subsidized housing on prime Manhattan real estate. But this plan warrants approval by the Dinkins administration.
Generally, the city is better off selling valuable property and using the proceeds and the taxes to build more low-income housing on less costly land. That's what the Koch administration tried to do with this city-owned site that runs from 13th to 14th Streets, between the old Luchow's restaurant and the Palladium. But the city failed to sell it even when the economy was booming. It has been occupied by a parking lot and vacant buildings since the early 80's. 
 Mr. Cuomo proposes using city and state housing funds to build 100 apartments, with support services, on the 13th Street side of the property -- 50 for homeless families, 50 for the working poor. The city could still make money by selling the 14th Street side for commercial development.
The Housing Authority chairman, Laura Blackburne, has talked of building 200 apartments on the property but it's not clear where the money would come from. And because her idea calls for more density, it would require a time-consuming zoning change that would probably attract opposition.
In healthier times, the city would be wise to try selling the site for the highest price. But waiting for the economy to rebound means depriving people who need housing now. One hundred families could soon be living on East 13th Street if City Hall backs Andrew Cuomo's sensible plan.

HEADLINE: Observer;
Let 'Em Eat Photo Ops

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BAKER

 BODY:
Washington's serenity is amazing. What do these Bush people take? They'd faint if offered pills or smoke, and you can't get Peruna anymore unless you know somebody with a great cellar. So how do they manage to stay way out in space treating the wrack and ruin with this magnificently cool indifference?
 Whole states are going broke, cities bankrupt, booming unemployment -- boy, there's a dull word -- and Washington's response? Jim dandy, double-peachy photo ops: President at Mount Rushmore. President at good, old-fashioned, salt-of-earth, Middle Western Fourth of July parade. President saluting heroes of gulf war. President setting up 10-second spots for next year's Monster Battle of TV Commercials, a.k.a. the 1992 Presidential campaign.
 
 Should the Feds do something about the wrack and ruin? Sure, but you can bet this crowd won't. They hate domestic problems. Press them about people sleeping in the streets or 34 million Americans without medical care, and they talk public-relations cant about "points of light."
 Besides, refusing to concede that domestic problems should concern them is justified by the wisdom of the philosopher Reagan. "Government is the problem," he declared. George ("Read My Lips") Bush hews faithfully to this Gipperesque principle, and with sound reason.
 It was Federal government that led the states, cities and counties into the present pickle. They used to get back a lot of the money their voters sent to Washington. Then, obedient to Reagan philosophy ("Government is the problem"), Washington adopted a new policy. Basically, it said, "Your buck stops here."
 The theory was that once you sent your buck to Washington, it became a government buck. And since government was the problem, terrible things would result if any fragment of this tainted money got back to its source. People would get hooked on good schools, fancy police work, clean water and such.
 The government buck had to be disinfected, as it were, to prevent it from infesting the country. So it was sent to the Pentagon, which used it to buy goods for countries like Panama and Iraq, where its evil effects wouldn't matter much, since they needed to be taught a lesson anyhow.
 Still the problem that government had caused long before Reagan made everyone see the light was gnawing at the national vitals. States, cities, towns, counties had become dangerously accustomed to getting their tainted bucks passed back.
 So when Washington said, "The buck stops here, for your own good," the states, the cities, the towns and the counties were not altogether sincere when they said, "Mighty art thou, O Gipper and O Bush, and we thank thee for not burdening us with the terrible problem-causing buck which we have rendered unto thee."
 (All right, governments don't speak such language, but wouldn't they be more lovable if they did?)
 Why were they not altogether sincere? Because if the buck stopped in Washington, they couldn't replace it with the buck necessary to keep state, city, town and county voters contented unless they raised state, city, town or county taxes. Disaster! Because Reagan and Bush, preaching hellfire against evil government, had persuaded people that tax-raisers must be destroyed.
 The states et al. had to avoid raising taxes without cutting services taxpayers demanded. In short, they had to pass a miracle once Washington, having decided that domestic governance was bad for people, got out of the business and turned it over to states, cities, towns and counties.
 The end of all this is predictable: Hordes of governors, mayors and county supervisors will be voted out of business in 1992. At the same time the usual 95 to 98 percent of Congress and President Bush will enjoy re-election, on ground that by doing nothing about the wrack and ruin they are saving us from that awful government that is the problem.
 All right, much of this is ham-handed irony. I don't apologize. Stating some of the truly silly arguments conservatives invoke to explain why "government is the problem," such as the theory that welfare breeds unemployment, would make me indictable for high-school sarcasm.
 In Washington there are people who believe such stuff, those cool, cool, serenely re-electable Washington cats.

HEADLINE: Teaching American History Without Blinders

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Arguing About America" (news analysis, June 21), on "One Nation, Many Peoples," the blueprint presented to the New York State Education Commissioner for revising how United States history is taught, misunderstands the argument. 
 The goal is not simply to edify ethnic groups or diversify the curriculum. Nor is it the old mythmaking with a new complexion. It seeks to understand both slaveholders and enslaved people, lynch victims and lynch mobs, women and men, working people and employers, the rich, the poor and how all of these relationships are interconnected to American culture, the economy, politics, power and tradition. The intention is not to add more color to the painting, but to revise the painting altogether.
As early as 1935, W.E.B. Du Bois showed that African-Americans were not peripheral, but central to the history of the Civil War. More recently, such historians as Nell Irvin Painter, Eric Foner, Vincent Harding, David Roediger and Sylvia Frey have written compelling narratives that call into question any efforts to write or teach American history without seriously considering the centrality of women, people of color and working people. Thus, while the proposed revision of the curriculum might be regarded as radical, it is not new.
When you argue that "the peddlers and shoemakers . . . seldom demanded that their cultures be taught in the school curriculum," you miss a fundamental point about the relationship between race and power. Even partial cultural assimilation into that social construction called white America benefited those who had the proper skin qualifications; people of color, no matter how much they sounded or acted like mainstream Americans, could not escape their appearance. Besides, how many eighth- or ninth-generation German or French descendants know or even care about their European heritage?
By sidestepping questions of race and power, and by ignoring history altogether, you and several dissenting members of the report panel blame people of color for failing to pass down their own traditions. But the poorly funded, overcrowded black schools of the segregated South taught African-American history in one form or another, and so did many black parents and community institutions. Indeed, historical lessons were frequently inscribed in culture, from folklore and toasts, to quilts and biblical interpretations.
But through most of the 20th century African-Americans, especially in the urban North, also tried to broaden the scope of public school curriculums through organizations such as the Association for the Study of Negro Life and History, founded in 1915 by the historian Carter G. Woodson, the originator of Black History Month. These efforts were intended to teach the entire country that the contributions of African-Americans to the United States and the world make them deserving of full citizenship and equality. With racism and sexism on the rise again, this argument has an oddly compelling resonance.
In the end, the issues are too important for those engaged in the debate to obscure genuine efforts toward historical corrective with rhetorical slogans such as "political correctness."
As the historian Nathan Huggins once wrote, "The problem for Afro-American and women's history is that they are so essential to American history that it is perverse to think of it without them. A white American history and a male history ought to be, common sense tells us, unthinkable."
 
ROBIN D. G. KELLEY
Assoc. Prof., History and African-
American Studies, U. of Michigan
Ann Arbor, Mich., June 21, 1991

HEADLINE: How Japan Feels About the Persian Gulf

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Leslie H. Gelb, in "Whining, Excuses, Hysteria," an otherwise rational column on United States-Japan relations (June 23), makes a totally erroneous statement about the policies of Ronald Reagan's Presidency. Mr. Gelb contends that the United States is telling Japan "to go on a consumer binge and increase government deficits, or, in effect, to adopt the self-destructive polices of the Reagan Administration." 
 The policies of President Reagan reduced tax rates so that consumers would have more control over how their hard-earned money was to be spent, but it certainly never advocated or encouraged binges. Rather, it provided sound fiscal policies that benefited all Americans during the longest peacetime economic expansion in modern history.
Likewise, increasing deficits was neither the objective nor the outcome of Reagan policies. It was the failure of Congress to cooperate with the Administration in a bipartisan effort to control the growth of Federal spending that led to significant deficits -- a pattern that occurred both before and after Ronald Reagan's tenure in office.
It is unfortunate that a sound analysis of Japanese-bashing should be tarnished by such a transparent and unfair attempt to bash a successful President.
 
EDWIN MEESE 3D
President
Reagan Alumni Association
Alexandria, Va., June 24, 1991

LENGTH: 2047 words

HEADLINE: Apple Growers Bruised and Bitter After Alar Scare

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEATTLE, July 5

 BODY:
Four generations of the Bernath family tended a small apple farm in the foothills of the Cascade Mountains, surviving drought, winter cold and the vagaries of the market. Last month, a bank foreclosed on them, forcing the Bernaths to give up their 54 acres and move to the city.
What brought them down, they say, was the most unlikely of storms. The Bernaths awoke one morning two years ago to hear that apples, the very embodiment of healthy food, were being called potentially cancerous if sprayed with Alar, a chemical that regulates growth. 
 The Bernaths had never used Alar, but that did not spare them from the panic that plunged apple prices so low the family could not meet its monthly payments. Many scientists, while acknowledging studies that indicate Alar could cause cancer, have since concluded that because the risk is so low and because fewer than 15 percent of apples were sprayed with Alar, the Alar crisis was greatly overblown. But farmers from upstate New York to Michigan to the Pacific Northwest are still wondering what hit them.
 
Growers Sue Alar Critics
 They may yet find out, if a lawsuit filed in a state court in Yakima County ever goes to trial. Angered by what they say was an orchestrated scare, apple growers here have filed suit against the Natural Resources Defense Council, the nonprofit environmental group whose analysis led to the news storm; Fenton Communications, a public relations company hired by the council to direct the news campaign, and the CBS News program "60 Minutes," which broadcast an illustration of a skull and crossbones over an apple in its report on Alar.
The farmers have charged them with product disparagement, an injury that lawyers from both sides say could be extremely hard to prove. And while the lawsuit may hinge on issues of free speech, it has raised questions about food scares, which have buffeted American consumers in recent years with numbing regularity.
Alar, (pronounced AL-lahr) trade name for daminozide, a chemical used to keep fruit firm and full-colored beyond its natural shelf life, has not been used since 1989, when growers voluntarily stopped using it in the face of a public outcry. Growers say their work is somewhat harder and labor costs higher, but the price of apples and the size of the crop have recovered to the levels common before the Alar scare.
Alar's journey from orchard to broadcast notoriety to courtroom tells much about the public's attempt to understand which chemicals constitute a true health hazard in the food supply. Faced with conflicting scientific reports, consumers are subject to "scare of the week" stories by environmental groups and self-serving reports made by the chemical industry, said people on both sides of the issue.
"Until we have some better way to weigh the risks of these things, there's always going be another Alar scare," said Dr. Joseph D. Rosen, a professor of food science at Rutgers University, whose study, "Much Ado About Alar," appeared in the fall 1990 issue of Issues in Science and Technology, the official journal of the National Academy of Sciences. He concluded, "There was never any legitimate scientific study to justify the Alar scare."
Even Dr. Rosen, who was among the critics challenging a Federal ban on Alar as an overreaction, acknowledges that the scientific debate has shifted little in the more than two years since the "60 Minutes" report. Experts who say Alar poses some risk of cancer still hold that view; others, who have doubts about the way cancer risk is assessed, still seek to emphasize those doubts.
CBS executives will not comment on specifics because of the pending lawsuit, but they say their broadcast was a fair and accurate rendering of an issue with widespread public interest. And officials of the Natural Resources Defense Council, while expressing regret that the Alar outcry may have hurt some farmers, say the Government is to blame for not doing a better job of regulating pesticides and other food chemicals.
"We didn't set out to hurt apple farmers," said Frances Beinecke, deputy director of the group. "The original report was about pesticides in more than 20 kinds of food. What happened was, the media simplified it and focused on apples. We are concerned and not happy about the consequences to those growers who were hurt."
Although there are no precise figures on how many farmers may have been forced out of business by the Alar scare, or how much other factors like bad weather and poor-quality fruit contributed to the losses, the United States Department of Agriculture said Washington apple growers lost at least $125 million in the six months after the initial uproar. The Washington growers produce about 60 percent of the nation's apple crop.
 
Regaining Consumers' Trust
 Jim Clements, who has a 300-acre apple orchard in central Washington, says the panic over Alar broke a bond of trust between farmers and consumers. The growers' lawsuit, seen as a chance to present the farmers' case, is attracting support around the country.
"The whole farming community is behind us," said Mr. Clements. "Pesticides, what we put in our food, deserve scrutiny. But we got hit with a knockout punch, and the result was that many innocent people went under."
Of all the foods that have come under scrutiny in recent years, few have attracted as much attention or emotion as apples. Production and consumption of apples more than doubled over the last two decades as the fruit was touted as a perfect snack, low in calories, high in natural sugar. Since the early 1970's, a small percentage -- no more than 15 percent and down to 5 percent in 1988, according to Government estimates -- of apples were sprayed with Alar, made by Uniroyal Chemical Company, based in Middlebury, Conn.
In 1973, a private study found that lab mice fed very high doses of Alar developed tumors. The report triggered a review by the Environmental Protection Agency, which noted errors in scientific procedure and said the data were not sufficient to justify banning Alar.
 
Inconclusive Tests, but a Ban
 That study and a follow-up used doses for mice that were 35,000 times the highest estimate of the daily intake by schoolchildren, considered the group to be most at risk. Of course, all cancer studies are done at levels well beyond human intake. But the Alar tests went beyond the environmental agency's threshold for studies, Dr. Rosen said.
The Government asked Uniroyal to provide other studies, which showed similar results at very high doses. By law, the E.P.A. must ban use of any chemical that could cause more than one cancer case per million people over a lifetime. Extrapolating from the high-dosage studies, the agency said Alar posed a cancer threat to 50 in a million people over their lifetimes. On Feb. 1, 1989, the agency announced that it was banning Alar. Noting that the test results showed no immediate health threat, it said growers could use the chemcial for 18 more months.
"Few realized that its conclusion was based essentially on a questionable interpretation of one study," wrote Dr. Rosen in his National Academy of Sciences report.
The E.P.A. announcement prompted some attention in the news media, including a front-page article in The New York Times. But there was no great public outcry.
At the same time, the Natural Resources Defense Council was preparing a study of the harm posed to children by pesticides in food. The group did no laboratory studies of its own but reviewed the existing findings that Alar posed some risk of causing cancer and that children eat proportionately more apples than adults. The council concluded that Alar could cause cancer in thousands of children.
The group hired Fenton Communications, a public-relations concern that has had many liberal and leftist clients, to publicize the report, "Intolerable Risk."
Fenton offered the study to "60 Minutes" as an exclusive. On Feb. 26, 1989, CBS broadcast a report by Ed Bradley in which Alar was called "the most potent cancer-causing agent in the food supply today," a contention that has been challenged by some scientists. The next day, the environmental group's report was released at news conferences around the country, and the actress Meryl Streep was enlisted to help get the message out.
The following month, schools in New York and Los Angeles canceled supplies of apple juice, supermarkets under public pressure removed apples from their shelves, and farmers, unable to sell their produce, dumped tons of apples in ditches or gave them away to organizations for the homeless.
Alarmed at the panic, the Federal Government issued a statement saying it was safe to eat apples. But apple prices fell to their lowest in years -- around $7 for a 42-pound box, well below the $12 break-even level -- and remained depressed for most of 1989. Seeking to regain the apple's healthy image, growers announced a voluntary ban on the use of Alar.
Later, in a memo sent out to various parties, and published in The Wall Street Journal, David Fenton, the president of Fenton Communications, told of his publicity strategy. He did not return phone messages for an interview for this article.
 
Giving Story a Life of Its Own
 "Our goal was to create so many repetitions of N.R.D.C.'s message that average American consumers (not just the policy elite in Washington) could not avoid hearing it, from many different media outlets within a short period of time," he wrote. "The idea was for the 'story' to achieve a life of its own, and continue for weeks and months to affect policy and consumer habits."
The apple growers in this state, who are among the last of the nation's true family farmers, with orchards averaging just over 40 acres, saw shipments to Asia, their primary export market, slump along with domestic sales.
"The Alar thing just killed us," said Cathy Bernath. "No money was coming in, so we had to go to the bank to get next year's crop in shape. That put us in a hole that we never recovered from. What made me especially mad was that we had never used Alar."
Two reviews of the Alar findings, one by Britain's Advisory Committee on Pesticides, the other by the California Department of Food and Agriculture, have concluded that the cancer risk from the amount of Alar normally used on apples was minuscule.
In an interview, Dr. Rosen called the Natural Resources Defense Council "irreponsible" and added, "I don't know if they knew that the results on which they based their study were discredited, but they had to know the arguments on the other side of the issue."
The scare came about, said Lawrie Mott, a senior scientist for the environmental group, because news organizations distorted and simplified the findings. "Our report did not lack context or perspective," she said. "But most of the press reports did."
 
Debate and Bitterness Linger
 Citing the pending lawsuit, "60 Minutes" producers said they could not talk about the case. "CBS believes the broadcast highlighted an important public health question," the network said in a statement. "It was well researched and well documented."
Network lawyers are trying to get the lawsuit, filed last November in Yakima County Superior Court in Washington State, moved to a Federal District Court. The suit may take years to come to trial.
If the case goes to court, "it may require that we chart some new ground," said Scott Jonsson, a Portland, Ore., lawyer hired by the apple growers. "We need to prove that the defendants recklessly disparaged the product, apples."
In the meantime, the debate over Alar continues. The Government has never concluded whether it posed a serious cancer risk. Farmers who did use it say they now realize they can get along fine without it. Prices for apples have stabilized, and grower groups say they think they have won back most of the consumers they lost.
The ill feelings remain. "We farmers are taking a hard look at what chemicals we're using, and that's a legitimate concern," said Tom Hale, president of the Washington Apple Commission, which represents growers. "But you never really get over the bitterness of that image that was created, that we were somehow trying to poison children."

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on July 9 about apples and the chemical Alar misstated the response to telephone calls seeking comment from David Fenton, a public relations executive. His office indeed returned the calls; his secretary said he was on vacation and unavailable.
A front-page article on July 9 about the use of the chemical Alar on apples misstated the Federal law governing Environmental Protection Agency decisions on banning chemicals believed to cause cancer. The law requires the agency to balance the risks and the economic benefits of such chemicals. It is an agency goal to ban chemicals that could cause more than one cancer case per one million people over a lifetime. The error was pointed out by readers as early as July 11; this correction was delayed by a succession of editing lapses.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
More Fishing, Fewer Fish

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
IN medieval European villages the common pastures belonged to everyone -- and thus, economists love to explain, to no one. Overgrazed and poorly drained, the land was far less productive than privately held acreage.
This "tragedy of the commons" has an obvious modern parallel in the perilous neglect of the world's tropical rain forests. But according to Eleanor Dorsey, a staff scientist at the Conservation Foundation of New England, common ownership also explains an economic and environmental mess that is closer to home. 
 Any American with a down payment on a boat is welcome to toss a net into the rich fishing waters off New England. And in Ms. Dorsey's view, far too many of them take advantage of the offer. Boats equipped with the newest-fangled fish-finding technology are now landing just half the tonnage caught in 1960. That is why the foundation is suing the Commerce Department to protect the region's rapidly depleting fishery -- and why many economists think the only long-term solution to the problem of overfishing is to privatize the harvest.
The fishery's current woes can be traced to the Magnuson Act of 1976, which drove foreign trawlers from a 200-mile zone along the coast. With fishing reserved for Americans, the domestic catch doubled in four years, attracting hundreds of new boats to New England waters.
The bonanza proved short-lived. Landings of diverse species of groundfish have fallen by two-thirds since the 1980 peak, and the harvest is still on the decline. A fishery that by Federal estimate could sustain a 360-million-pound catch is now producing less than 200 million.
Who is to blame? Government scientists are supposed to keep track of the marine environment and set safe targets for fishing. But the law leaves it to seven regional councils to advise the Commerce Department on how to contain the catch.
These industry-dominated councils generally limit the total fishing effort by limiting the length of the season for individual species. In Alaskan waters, for example, halibut are fair game for only a few frenzied days each year. But the New England council has never hammered out a politically acceptable formula for saying no.
The only constraint on New England fishing is a minimum mesh size for nets -- a rule that has not prevented the hard-working fleet from stripping the fishery bare. The State of Massachusetts estimates that overfishing reduced the region's income by about $350 million annually during the late 1980's.
Ms. Dorsey is not about to offer suggestions on how to limit the catch. But other experts are less shy. Lee Anderson, an economist at the University of Delaware and a member of the Middle Atlantic council, thinks the way to get individual fishermen to guard the natural resource is to give them a direct stake in its future productivity.
The Middle Atlantic council privatized the harvest of two varieties of clams this year. Owners of individual boats have been assigned permanent quotas in proportion to their past catches. These quotas can be bought and sold, giving owners the choice of amassing sufficient rights to keep their boats working full time or to bow out of the business with a fat severance bonus.
Economic logic suggests that most boat owners will eventually take the money and run. To keep the catch at sustainable levels last year, individual boats were only allowed to harvest a total of 144 hours. Thus just 15 or 20 vessels could have done the work of the entire 140-boat fleet.
The Middle Atlantic council is not the first regulator to experiment with individual transferable quotas: Canada has privatized its Pacific harvest of both halibut and sable fish, a scarce species mostly exported to Japan. Nor is it likely to be the last. The North Pacific council is planning to follow Canada's lead with the same two species.
Applying a similar plan to New England would be more complicated because boats net a dozen different species in proportions that vary by chance. But a workable solution is not beyond the realm of imagination or technology.
Owners might, for example, trade quotas after the fact, buying extra rights at the dock to cover unanticipated catches. Trading could be managed by computer, the way the stock exchanges automatically match buy and sell orders for I.B.M. and General Motors.
Commerce Department officials number among the believers: The department's National Marine Fisheries Service has begun lobbying the regional councils to adopt transferable quota plans. The immediate question, though, is whether the courts will force action where regulators, Federal and regional, have been too timid to insist.

HEADLINE: Europeans Propose Cut In Farm Output and Aid

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: STRASBOURG, France, July 9

 BODY:
The executive commission of the European Community today approved a farm proposal that could restart world trade talks that have been stalled since last December.
The plan, which must still be acted on by the 12 member nations, would revamp the community's agriculture program by slashing production and cutting subsidies to farmers. 
 The proposals "represent the most fundamental reshaping" of the common agricultural policy "since its inception 30 years ago," the commission said in a statement.
 
Impasse at Trade Talks
 Lack of an agreement on a farm proposal helped bring an end to the world trade talks last year. The United States and some other farm exporters wanted the community to cut farm supports and eliminate export credits so that farmers in the United States could better compete with their European counterparts.
But the community proposed less substantial cuts than the United States was looking for, and the four-year, 108-nation effort to lower world trade barriers collapsed.
The plan announced today is an attempt to sever the link between production and guaranteed prices, which has encouraged farmers to grow more to earn more. This has resulted in millions of tons of surplus crops and soaring budget costs.
The plan would slash cereal prices by 35 percent, milk prices by 10 percent and beef prices by 15 percent. Farmers would be compensated for the big price cuts, with direct assistance geared more toward small- and medium-sized farmers.
Farmers who are at least 55 years old would be eligible for a new early retirement program.
The commission estimated the proposal would cost about $4.2 billion in its first year and less in subsequent years. It would take effect in 1993 and be fully in place by 1996.
The world trade negotiations are expected to come up at next week's economic summit meeting in London of the leaders of seven industrialized nations. Last month, trade ministers of two dozen nations called for the negotiations to end by December.
The talks were started in Uruguay in 1986 in an effort to rewrite world trade rules and lower barriers in 15 areas, including textiles, agriculture and manufactured goods and services. The talks are being held under the auspices of the Geneva-based General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, a forum for liberalizing world trade.

Split on Patents and Names
 BRUSSELS, July 9 (Reuters) -- Delegates at world trade talks are close to an agreement on an accord to end the piracy of intellectual property, but tough problems still remain. The chief negotiator for the European Community, Hugo Paemen, said today that there were disagreements on whether pharmaceuticals should receive patent protection and whether names for products like wines and foods should be protected against copying.
