HEADLINE: U.S. WEIGHS MOVES ON CHINESE TRADE

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 9

 BODY:
On the eve of a vote on the issue in the House, the Administration is still trying to decide whether to make a series of concessions to persuade a hostile Congress to extend normal trading privileges to China for another year.
The House is now expected to vote overwhelmingly to renew the so-called most-favored-nation status for China, but with conditions for future renewal, such as the improved observance of human rights, that the White House has promised to veto. Instead, the Administration is leaning toward making a series of promises, including a possible major shift on United States policy toward Taiwan, that would satisfy some Congressional objections without being set in legislation. 
 At stake is not only the level of Chinese-American relations but also President Bush's reputation for consistently being able to persuade Congress to support his foreign policy positions.
 
Private Sector of Economy
 Many Democrats and some Republicans have contended, sometimes heatedly, that China's poor human rights record, arms exports and ballooning trade surplus with the United States justify limits on Chinese access to the American market. But the Administration has countered that raising tariffs would seriously hurt American-Chinese relations and would hurt the private sector of the Chinese economy, the group the United States would most like to see succeed.
Congressional leaders and Administration officials say that President Bush is likely to veto any of the alternative measures now being circulated on Capitol Hill. These bills and resolutions would either attach conditions to the renewal of normal trade relations with China, such as requiring human rights improvements and an end to Chinese support for the Khmer Rouge guerrillas in Cambodia, or cancel it outright. There are enough votes at least in the House to override a veto of any of the measures, the officials agreed.
The Senate is expected to vote next week, and the outcome has been less clear there than in the House. Senate Republicans are more nearly united in support of the President while some Democrats support a renewal if the Administration agrees to other changes in economic policy toward China and Taiwan. Chinese and Administration lobbyists have been slowly lining up votes among farm state legislators in both houses by highlighting China's position as the biggest export market for American wheat last year.
An announcement on concessions is expected within the next several days, a senior Administration official said. At least some concessions are likely, said the official, who insisted on anonymity.
 
Concession on Taiwan Proposed
 One concession proposed to the Administration is for the Administration to drop its opposition to Taiwan's immediate admission to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, a group of countries that agree to abide by a set of free-trade principles.
Senator Max S. Baucus, the Montana Democrat who is the chairman of the Senate Finance subcommittee on international trade, organized a bipartisan group of 15 senators who sent a letter on June 19 to President Bush asking for this and several other concessions in exchange for their support for normal trade status for China.
But a spokesman for the Chinese Government, which has long insisted that it is the sole legitimate government of all China including Taiwan, condemned any United States support for Taiwan's position in an interview on Wednesday, calling it "totally unacceptable," even though Taiwan has applied to join the GATT as a customs territory rather than as a sovereign country.
 
U.S. Policy Change Sought
 The Commerce Department, Treasury Department and the office of the United States Trade Representative have long advocated in interagency talks a change of the American policy toward Taiwan. The State Department and, to a lesser extent, the National Security Council have been opposed on the grounds that this would infuriate China and result in lasting damage to a strategic relationship with the world's most populous country.
Another, less sensitive concession called for by Mr. Baucus and his allies has been for the Administration to take broad legal action against Chinese import barriers. This issue has also divided the Administration, with some officials contending that there are so many barriers that it is better to tackle them with a series of small measures.
"You look at China and say, 'What's wrong with China?' and you fill up books," the senior Adminstration official said.
Other concessions urged by Mr. Baucus and more widely supported within the Administration include new requirements that China prove its exports are not produced by prison labor, a renewed effort by the United States to block loans by multilateral agencies to China and the negotiation of strict controls on Chinese exports of arms and nuclear technology.

HEADLINE: Fed Decides Not to Trim Money Targets

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 9

 BODY:
Signaling that a strong recovery from the recession is at least as high a priority as reduced inflation, Federal Reserve policy makers voted last week not to change their target range for growth in the nation's money supply next year.
The decision, made behind closed doors at a two-day meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee on July 2 and 3, was confirmed today by Government officials. 
 Some policy makers advocated setting a slightly lower range for money growth to emphasize the goal of reducing inflation. But they were outvoted by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and others who argued that they should not risk retarding the recovery, officials said.
The decision, to be announced by Mr. Greenspan in testimony before a House subcommittee next Tuesday, was first reported today by The Wall Street Journal.
The Fed's target in 1992 for growth in M-2, the most common money supply measure, will be 2.5 percent to 6.5 percent, the same as this year.
The decision not to lower the range to between 2 percent and 6 percent, as some officials urged, was largely a symbolic one. No one expects the growth rate of M-2 (primarily cash, checking, savings and money market accounts and small certificates of deposit) to fall as low as 2 percent or to rise as high as 6.5 percent.
But the action gives the financial markets an indication of the Fed's priorities. In theory, a larger increase in the money supply leads to lower interest rates and stimulates the economy but also runs the risk of more inflation. A smaller increase limits inflation but also restrains economic growth and results in higher interest rates.
Economists said today that the decision showed that the Fed would be careful next year not to strangle the recovery even if that meant the inflation rate would not come down further.
Some members of the Open Market Committee, like W. Lee Hoskins, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland, have argued publicly that the Fed should work more rigorously to reduce the inflation rate, which has been around 4 percent for almost a decade. Presumably they were the ones who advocated lowering the money supply target.
 
Pressed by Administration
 Mr. Greenspan, on the other hand, has been under pressure from the Bush Administration to cut interest rates and promote a stronger economy in the short run. Mr. Greenspan's term as chairman expires on Aug. 11. While it is widely expected that he will be given another four-year term, the White House has not announced the reappointment.
Some Fed watchers in Washington and on Wall Street suggested that Mr. Greenspan and his allies on the board were reluctant to tighten the money supply while his future as chairman was still being decided, but there is no concrete evidence of that.
The policy makers themselves would not comment on their meeting, and the officials who knew about the decisions provided only sketchy accounts of who said what.
The Open Market Committee consists of the five Fed governors -- there are two vacancies -- and the presidents of the 12 regional Federal Reserve Banks. All members of the committee may participate in the deliberations, but only the governors and five of the bank presidents can vote.
 
Speedups and Slowdowns
 Until now, the Fed has reduced the money supply target each year since 1988, when the growth range was 4 percent to 8 percent. Within the range each year, there have been a number of speedups and slowdowns in M-2 growth, but since early 1990, the growth rate has been at the low end of the target range.
Since July 1990, when the recession officially began, the money supply has grown by only 3.6 percent, almost a full percentage point less than the rate of inflation over that period. Robert H. Chandross, chief economist at Lloyds Bank in New York, said in his latest newsletter to his bank's customers that this was the lowest rate of M-2 growth during any recession in the last three decades.
Mr. Chandross is one of many economists who say the Fed contributed to the onset of the recession by keeping money too tight.
 
'Most Evidence' Cited
 Another is G. Thomas Woodward, a research economist at the Library of Congress, who maintained in a paper last winter that "most evidence seems to point to Fed policy as the reason for the slowdown in economic activity."
Mr. Greenspan, on the other hand, has blamed the uncertainty following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and credit restrictions imposed by banks for the downturn.
The prevailing view on Wall Street is that the Fed policy makers decided at their meeting last week not to change interest rates for the time being. That was the unanimous position taken by the Open Market Committee at its meeting in mid-May. A summary of the proceedings at the May meeting was released by the Fed on Friday.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Bid by United For Pan Am Routes Seen

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
United Airlines is expected to make a proposal today to buy Pan Am's Latin American and Caribbean routes as well as some of the carrier's European routes in which Delta Air Lines has already expressed an interest, industry executives said yesterday.
The offer could touch off a bidding war between United and Delta. Delta has said that it is not interested in the Latin American and Caribbean routes but that it wants Pan Am's European routes, shuttle service and 45 airplanes. Delta currently serves some major European cities and is particularly strong in Germany. 
 United could also end up making an offer for some of Pan Am's airplanes, which could mean that some of Pan Am's crews could be hired. The industry executives, who spoke on condition that they not be named, gave no details of the proposal.
 
Welcome Competition
 A competition for the European routes between two major carriers would be welcome at Pan Am, which has been operating under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection from creditors since January.
Thomas G. Plaskett, the president and chief executive officer, has been seeking a way for to close the carrier as gracefully as possible. He is trying to save as many jobs as he can for his 22,000 workers and to guarantee creditors the best price in the sale of most of the carrier's assets.
His main strategy, said several people who have advised him, is to have most of the airline's assets sold before the carrier is forced to liquidate, which could be as early as this fall.
"Everyone has been looking to the winter when Pan Am wouldn't make it through," Edward Starkman, the airline analyst for Paine Webber said. He added that the combination of the recession and the gulf war was too much for Pan Am, even depleting its cash hoard of $400 million that it received from the sale of its London routes to United last fall.
He added that it was not Mr. Plaskett's fault that Pan Am was in its present position. "He deserves a lot of credit for keeping the airline as pretty as it's been by making some strategic sales," Mr. Starkman said.
 
Progress in Phase-Out
 Last week, Mr. Plaskett made progress in his phase-out strategy by getting Delta to consider making a bid for the European routes, the shuttle and the airplanes.
If a deal is reached, Delta said it might be able to offer jobs to 6,000 Pan Am workers. The jobs would probably go mostly to those connected with the airline's overseas operations.
Now Mr. Plaskett will turn his attention to completing an asset deal with United.
His aim, said those who have worked with him on the strategy, is to be able to present a plan to Judge Cornelius Blackshear of the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of New York under which most of Pan Am's assets would be sold and the rest of the airline liquidated.
Mr. Plaskett also hopes to have the unsecured creditors committee approve his plan before he presents it to the bankuptcy court, the people said.
Pan Am filed for bankrupty protection on Jan. 8. It had hoped to be able make a comeback with the $400 million cash infusion from the London-route sale, a $150 million loan from the Bankers Trust Company and a reorganization of its European routes around a hub in Frankfurt.
The gulf war, however, disrupted international air traffic and doubled fuel prices. Operating costs soared at Pan Am, where many of its Boeing 747's are old and inefficient. Pan Am's traffic, for example, fell 20.6 percent in first six months this year.
As Mr. Plaskett seeks to bring down the curtain on the carrier that opened the Pacific to air travel, pioneered the jet age and was so well respected that it was considered the carrier that represented the United States around the world, he is largely standing hat in hand.
The main leverage he holds in his talks with Delta and United is that it is in their interest to make offers acceptable to the court and the creditors soon, because if they wait too long they may have to bid on them in the free-for-all of a liquidation.
 
Potential for Savings
 Selling most of its assets before a liquidation saves the huge cost of the liquidation, could bring higher prices for the assets, and would insure that a part of Pan Am's work force continues to have jobs. Under a liquidation, much money would to be spent preserving the airline's assets and keeping on enough people to oversee the asset sales.
In the case of a shutdown of the carrier, customers would be protected, since Pan Am signed a $100 million agreement with United Airlines last fall that would guarantee reimbursements for ticket holders.
The carrier is now in the midst of what is normally the height of its travel season when it generates most of its cash. But its traffic has continued to be disappointing. It was down 11 percent in June, compared with June last year.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Increases Slightly; Gold Declines Moderately

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar edged higher yesterday as traders expressed some optimism in advance of this week's meeting of Germany's central bank.
Gold fell moderately, dropping $1.50 an ounce, to $369.40, on New York's Commodity Exchange. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $369.00 an ounce, off $1.20 from late Monday. 
 Currency dealers said traders generally did not believe that the German Bundesbank would raise interest rates at the meeting of its policy-making council tomorrow.
A report yesterday of lower-than-expected German inflation fueled optimism that the Bundesbank would not tighten credit as a way to counter German price increases, said John Duffy, manager of foreign exchange for Oesterreichische Landerbank in New York.
Caution, however, is keeping the dollar in a tight range. The German mark, as all other currencies, is supported by higher interest rates.
In addition to the Bundesbank meeting, traders are wary ahead of the meeting of leaders of the Group of Seven industrialized nations on Monday.
"There is still a longer-term bull trend that seems to prevail," said Betsy Reetz, a currency dealer for Union Bank of Switzerland in New York. "But there are a few things casting a shadow over the dollar right now,"
In London, the British pound fell to $1.6215, from $1.6275 late Monday. Sterling was also lower in New York at $1.6233, less expensive than late Monday's $1.6345.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.15 yen, to a closing 138.60 yen. Later, in London, it also was quoted at 138.60 yen. In New York the dollar closed at 138.76 yen, slightly higher than late Monday's 138.55 yen.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's prices, included: 1.8175 German marks, up from 1.8058; 1.5759 Swiss francs, up from 1.5584; 6.1660 French francs, up from 6.1325; 1,352.55 Italian lire, up from 1,345.75, and 1.14825 Canadian dollars, up from 1.14565.
In the precious metals market abroad, gold fell in London to a late bid price of $369.15 an ounce, down from $370.40 late Monday. In Zurich, the metal fell to a closing bid of $368.75 from $370.15.
Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $1.82 to close at a bid $369.33.
Silver fell in New York to $4.431 an ounce on the Commodity Exchange, down 3.6 cents from late Monday. But the metal was steady in London at a late bid price of $4.46 an ounce.

HEADLINE: West Urges Bulgarians to Shut Reactors

BYLINE: By MARLISE SIMONS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, July 9

 BODY:
Alarmed by leaks in emergency equipment and by the danger of flooding and fires, Western experts have urged Bulgaria to shut down its Soviet-made nuclear reactors for repair as soon as possible.
The specialists, who inspected Bulgaria's sole nuclear-power-generating complex last month on behalf of the International Atomic Energy Agency, said in a report that four of the six reactors there were so full of hazards that "continued operation would be imprudent." 
 They said that conditions at the complex at Kozlodui, 130 miles north of Sofia, the Bulgarian capital, have worsened in recent weeks because the Soviet specialists responsible for safety and operation left Bulgaria after a wage dispute.
Specialists have warned of the possibility of an accident exposing people living nearby to radiation -- there are apartments two miles away -- but so far there have been no reports of radioactivity being released into the atmosphere.
Inspectors did, however, find releases of radioactive steam within the plant; it was not disclosed how serious these releases were nor was it immediately clear whether the health of anyone at the plant had been endangered.
At a special meeting in Vienna today, officials from six Western nations, including the United States, met with Bulgarian and Soviet specialists on the safety problems at the Bulgarian plants. But they failed to reach agreement on how much help the West would provide or what steps Bulgaria was willing to take.
 
Not Up to Western Standards
 "We think safety standards can be raised, but at enormous expense," said Klaus Topfer, the German Environment Minister. But even if improved, the reactors could not meet Western safety standards, he said.
Western experts have long worried about the lack of safety of the oldest type of Soviet-designed nuclear reactor. There are about 20 of this type still in operation in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe, including Bulgaria's four.
They are pressurized water reactors, of a design different from the Soviet Union's ill-fated Chernobyl plant. Germany closed five such reactors last year in the eastern part of the country, the former East Germany.
The findings in Bulgaria have set off a near-panic among specialists, as the report has circulated in Europe.
A spokesman for the International Atomic Energy Agency called the findings "without precedent" and said the inspectors discovered numerous oil, steam and water leaks. He said the report cited unsealed and loose electrical cables and valves with missing wheels. Also cited was severe shortage of staff members.
Ferdinand Frantzen, an agency safety specialist, told the journal Nucleonics Week that radioactive steam was escaping within the plant at a high rate.
Most significant, the system meant to cool the reactor core in an emergency was found to be leaking.
"It's a miracle there has been no accident so far," said a German nuclear specialist in Bonn familiar with the inspection. "But the place is a disaster waiting to happen."
Bulgaria has asked the West for $ l billion to modernize the oldest reactors and insists that it can shut down only parts of the plant because the country depends on nuclear energy for as much as a third of its electricity.
In Vienna today, Bulgarian nuclear officials promised that they could temporarily switch off two of the reactors in about a month and make fast improvements on two others at an immediate cost of about $50 million.
President Zhelyu Zhelev on Monday ruled out closing the Kozlodui plant altogether, saying that would mean "the collapse of our entire economy." Moreover, the President said, "there is no immediate danger of an accident."
The four reactors causing the greatest concern are known by the designation VVER, Model 230. The 440-megawatt machines were built in the l970's. Bulgaria says two are working normally, one is shut down for refueling and one works at half-capacity because of oil leaks.

HEADLINE: Caution on Helping Soviet Economy Is Emphasized by Industrial Nations

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, July 9

 BODY:
When leaders of the seven leading industrial nations meet with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev here next week, they almost certainly will promise him aid that will not necessarily cost a lot of money but will signal the West's intent to play a constructive role in helping the Soviet Union become a free-market democracy, American and European officials say.
The immediate things they might give include a big increase in expertise to help the Soviets draw up and put into effect plans for changing their economy and overhauling specific sectors, especially oil and gas and agriculture; an easing of trade restrictions, and perhaps an increase in providing financing to buy goods. 
 The offer of expertise almost certainly will include a promise of associate membership in the International Monetary Fund, American officials said. They were confident that Japan, the one holdout on the associate membership idea, would go along, although the Japanese still appear to be tying their consent to progress in persuading the Soviets to return the northern islands in the Japanese archipelago, which were seized at the end of World War II.
 
Other Forms to Be Discussed
 There are other forms of assistance that will be discussed by the leaders of the Group of Seven industrial nations -- the United States, Japan, Germany, France, Britain, Italy and Canada -- and of the European Community, who will also be at the summit meeting. Because of big differences among the seven, however, it appears unlikely that there will be any immediate promises on these things made to Mr. Gorbachev at the July 17 meeting.
One is a stabilization fund of perhaps $5 billion to $8.5 billion to support the Soviet ruble when the Soviets go through the process of making it convertible into Western currencies, reining in its rapidly expanding money supply, freeing prices and slashing subsidies. Another idea of some Europeans is a promise to provide emergency food supplies to allay Soviet fears that they will suffer famine or rocketing food prices as they go through agricultural changes.
 
Rescheduling May Be Asked
 The stabilization fund and food program would only be expensive if the Soviets tapped them. Poland never drew upon its $1 billion stabilization fund.
Some Western officials think Mr. Gorbachev may ask for a rescheduling of his country's hard-currency debt, which, including interest due, totals an estimated $62 billion to $65 billion. But given the Soviet Union's struggle to service this existing debt, he may not be interested in a big increase in trade credits, which could be tied to the purchase of goods that the Soviets do not particularly want.
American officials think Mr. Gorbachev will make one or two big requests in London, whether for a stabilization fund, debt restructuring or a high-profile program for giving the Soviets help in, say, modernizing their oil and gas industry, which is now grossly inefficient and plagued by leakages.
Mr. Gorbachev today said that one request would be for Western investment in industry. An aide said the possibilities included oil and gas and light manufacturing. It was not clear whether Mr. Gorbachev wanted these to be in the forms of loans or equity investments by Western companies or investors.
 
Several Things Required
 American, British and Japanese officials stress that several things must happen before they consider helping. One is for Mr. Gorbachev to present a serious plan for economic changes that includes commitments to things like private ownership and property, enforceable business contracts and investor-owned enterprises whose shares can be traded. The second is for him to demonstrate by action that the Soviet Union has the intent and the internal support to put a plan for changes into effect.
A third could be for him to make some concessions to the West on other fronts. For Japan, this could mean giving back the disputed islands. For the United States, it could mean ending or greatly reducing the Soviet support of the Communist regimes in Afghanistan or Cuba or putting into effect big cuts in the size of Soviet military forces or production, American officials say.
But one American official said the Bush Administration neither expected nor wanted Mr. Gorbachev, when he comes to London, to make a dramatic offer on military cuts that are tied to an upfront Western commitment to provide large-scale aid for economic changes. "If he is foolish enough to call for something grandiose and to try to lay this child at the Western doorstep, it's not going to be taken in because by definition it's not serious" in terms of showing a commitment to economic change, he said.
 
Promises Made Previously
 Mr. Gorbachev said this week that he would present Western leaders with a plan for economic changes that has the backing of nine of the 15 Soviet republics, including Russia and the Ukraine. But it is unclear how radical the plan is and Mr. Gorbachev has promised before to take the plunge and then pulled back, Western officials say.
The United States, Japan and Britain have been the most insistent that Mr. Gorbachev not be promised large-scale aid. The Germans, Italians and French have been more sympathetic.
Even Germany's Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, who has been perhaps the most enthusiastic advocate -- and provider -- of large-scale aid, concedes that the summit meeting will produce no such package.
A State Department official said: "The political objective is to have the meeting with Gorbachev happen in a way that the conclusion seems positive, that Gorbachev has explained some of his difficulties, it is heard with sympathetic ears and he is given the chance to put one foot through the Western economic door: that is associate membership in the I.M.F. And I imagine there will be renewed offers, perhaps precise offers, of technical assistance. I don't think it's going to go much further than that."
 
Advantages of Membership
 Associate membership in the I.M.F. and its sister organization, the World Bank, a new status at the institutions, would enable their experts to help the Soviet Union draw up and put into effect plans for becoming a free-market economy, with a Western-style financial system and overhaul specific sectors of its economy. It also would enable Soviet personnel to be trained by the two institutions but would not entitle the Soviets to get money from them.
Defenders of associate I.M.F membership say it is important because then the monetary fund could help devise a Soviet plan for economic change and monitor its being put into effect. Such I.M.F. involvement, and World Bank involvement with individual projects, would give Western investors and individual governments the confidence to invest in the Soviet Union once it began putting a plan for change into effect.
Critics of associate membership question whether it would pull in the needed amount of financial help fast enough. One is Jeffrey Sachs, one of the Harvard economists who, along with Soviet economists, helped to write a radical plan for Soviet changes.
 
$100 Billion in Aid
 Known as the Yavlinsky plan after one of its Soviet authors, Grigory A. Yavlinsky, the plan proposes that the West provide at least $100 billion in aid over five years in installments tied to Soviet progress in becoming a free-market democracy.
On Monday, David Mulford, Treasury Under Secretary for International Affairs, said the Bush Administration opposed the Yavlinksy plan. Because its program for economic change is tied to large-scale Western aid, "the Yavlinsky package is really not a working proposition, although the economic pieces of it are constructive and important and certainly can be used by the Soviet Union as it develops its economic reform program," he added.
Echoing a view widely held in the Bush Administration and by the British Government, Mr. Mulford said the Soviet Union did not need huge amounts of Western aid but required aid in exploiting its wealth of natural resources more efficiently.

HEADLINE: Bush Is Said to Approve Military Base Closings

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 9

 BODY:
President Bush has decided to approve a Federal commission's recommendation to close 25 military installations and consolidate or reduce 48 others, Administration and commission officials said today.
The President has invited members of the commission that decided on the base closings to come to the White House for a ceremony on Wednesday morning. 
 Congress will have 45 days to accept or reject the report after Mr. Bush endorses it, but has no power to change any element without rejecting the entire report. It is considered unlikely that lawmakers in whose districts bases are to be closed will be able to persuade enough of their fellow legislators to overturn the bill.
Mr. Bush said last week that he would rely on Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's advice on the commission's work, which was completed only hours before its July 1 deadline.
 
'A Good Piece of Work'
 Mr. Cheney wrote Mr. Bush last week offering his assessment of the base closing report and recommending that it be approved. His spokesman, Pete Williams, said today that Mr. Cheney considered it "a good piece of work."
The panel, known as the Defense Base Closure and Realignment Commission, voted to close all but four of the installations that Mr. Cheney recommended for closing in April. That would eliminate 80,000 military and 37,000 civilian jobs. The closings proposed by the commission would cost $4.1 billion from 1992 to 1997, but save about $1.5 billion a year after that.
The commission also voted streamline the Army Corps of Engineers, eliminating 2,600 jobs for an annual savings of $112 million.
On Monday, members of Congress from Pennsylvania and New Jersey filed suit in Federal District Court to block the closing of the Philadelphia Naval Shipyard and Naval Station. The eight members of Congress were joined in the suit by the State of Pennsylvania and the City of Philadelphia. The suit charges the Navy, the Pentagon and members of the base closing commission with violating the law in ordering the shipyard closed.
 
Some Lawmakers Still Upset
 Last week, nine Senators and Representatives wrote Mr. Bush, asking him to urge the commission to reconsider the decisions to list Carswell Air Force Base in Texas, Castle Air Force Base in California and Loring Air Force Base in Maine, saying they were add to the list in a "highly irregular finale."
Senator Arlen Specter, a Pennsylvania Republican who is a plaintiff in the Philadelphia suit, said he remained "aghast" at the outcome of the base closing process and is distrustful of the Pentagon's role.
He said the decision would force him to look twice at Pentagon requests for money for the B-2 bomber "and other big-ticket items."
"My opinion of the credibility of the Department of Defense right now is not very high," Senator Specter said.
But such objections were apparently to no avail. Many other members of Congress have said they are resigned to the base closings as proposed and have begun focusing their efforts on finding new uses for the sites and new jobs for those left unemployed.
The commission voted to save four bases that were on Mr. Cheney's original list: Whidbey Island Naval Air Station in Oak Harbor, Wash., Fort McClellan in Anniston, Ala., Moody Air Force Base in Valdosta, Ga., and the Naval Training Center in Orlando, Fla,
Among the largest bases the commission voted to close were Fort Ord in Seaside, Calif.; Fort Devens in Ayer, Mass.; the Philadephia sites; Long Beach Naval Station in California, and Carswell Air Force Base.

HEADLINE: Stocks Mixed as Dow Declines by 14.76

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stock prices turned mixed yesterday as investors seemed to shy away from the blue chips and concentrated on some of the smaller high-technology stocks. Trading picked up just a little.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 14.76 points, to 2,947.23, and the broader Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell 1.83, to 376.11. But the Nasdaq composite rose 4.13, to 483.64, as big money continued to pour into the little over-the-counter stocks. 
 In spite of the additional hour of activity since mid-June, trading on the New York Stock Exchange rose only slightly, to 151.8 million shares, from 139.1 million the day before. Every day of slow trading means that Wall Street brokerage firms have to work exceptionally hard to stay in the black. The old rule of thumb was that brokerage firms needed at least 150 million shares a day to make money, but today brokers need a lot more just to break even.
Even professional program traders took a breather. Birinyi Associates, which monitors computer-driven programs, said it spotted only two big sell programs starting around 2:30 and that they knocked 24 points off the Dow.
Among the big O-T-C movers were several technology stocks -- T2 Medical, up 4, to 51; Centocor warrants, up 3 1/2, to 53 1/2; Cytogen, up 3 1/4, to 63 1/2; Borland International, up 2 5/8, to 49 5/8, and Alias Research, up 2 3/8, to 18 5/8.
Millipore, though, another strong technology stock traded on the New York Stock Exchange, slid 5, to 35 3/4, after announcing Monday that second-quarter sales will be "below our expectations." Jonathan W. Osgood, technology analyst for Alex. Brown & Sons, downgraded his rating on the stock from "strong buy" to "buy."
Asked why the market seemed to be dragging its feet, Peter J. Canelo, chief investment strategist for County NatWest Securities, argued that the stock market "has held up rather well despite a weak bond market and a shaky Japanese market."
He maintained, moreover, that "earnings are coming over the next four weeks and that's pretty much paralyzed investors."
Bond prices, which often help to determine what happens to stock prices, are responding to fears over next month's big Treasury refinancing and the huge stock selloff in Tokyo, he said, fears that Mr. Canelo called "overdone."
He argued that while the Government would indeed borrow huge amounts of money, the public was not because of what he called "the weak economic recovery."
Still, bond dealers said there were fears that today's $9 billion Treasury note auction could hurt prices as dealers mark them down to sell the notes. A weak bond market could weaken stock prices, too.
As for concern that the Japanese might dump their American stock holdings to meet obligations in Japan, Mr. Canelo called such fears "unjustified." He noted, for one thing, that while the Japanese market has been "horrible" over the last two months, "our market hasn't done anything."
For another, he said, speculators who would supposedly dump American stock do not own any and institutional investors that do probably want to keep them to benefit from the strong dollar.
Although the Nikkei index of 225 stocks recovered almost 2 percent in Japan yesterday, the Dow bounced ahead and behind before dropping in response to program selling late in the day.
In one of the few strong gains, J. P. Morgan rose 1 3/8, to 53 1/2, in brisk trading. Losses of a point or more came in Chevron, United Technologies, I.B.M., Merck and and Philip Morris.
Intel, again topping the Nasdaq active list, rose 1 1/8, to 45 1/4, on 2.8 million shares. Bloomberg Business News reported that Abbey Joseph Cohen, co-chairman of the investment policy committee at Goldman, Sachs, said its analysts recommended Intel among high-tech stocks it felt should be overweighted.
Others included Hewlett-Packard, up 7/8, to 54; AST Research, up 3/4, to 23 1/2; Dell Computer, up 1, to 28 1/2; Apple Computer, up 1/8, to 46 7/8; Exabyte, up 3/4, to 15 5/8; Convex Computer, up 1/4, to 14 5/8; Micron Technology, up 3/8, to 12 3/8, and Advanced Micro Devices, up 3/8, to 11 7/8.
Among other Goldman, Sachs recommendations were Sun Microsystems, up 7/8, to 29 5/8; Microsoft, up 7/8, to 67 7/8; Silicon Graphics, up 1 1/2, to 32 3/8; Cadence Design, up 1 1/8, to 18 5/8, and Sequent Computer, up 3/8, to 9 3/4. Sun and Microsoft also made the Nasdaq active list, raising the total to six of the top 10.

HEADLINE: Connecticut Budget Slugfest: Will Veto Be Vetoed?

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, July 9

 BODY:
Propelled by a wave of anger, frustration and desperation, Connecticut's legislature moved today to try to override Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s veto of the legislature's budget plan.
If the lawmakers succeed, it would be yet another counterblow in the five-month tussle with the Governor over an income tax. 
 Like so much of what has happened in the state's budget struggle, overriding a governor's veto and imposing a budget over his vehement objections would be uncharted territory for a legislature that has historically followed the chief executive's lead. But to some who openly dislike Mr. Weicker, that has an appeal in its own right.
Others say the effort is doomed by deep divisions in the majority Democratic Party and by the awareness among leaders that forcing a budget on Mr. Weicker could burn whatever bridges of communication are left between the legislative and executive branches.
A preliminary count in a House Democratic caucus fell short of the margin needed to override. An override vote requires a two-thirds majority in both the House and Senate.
"An override is bad for the state, bad for the General Assembly, bad for the Democratic Party, and I intend to speak against it," said Representative Jonathan Pelto, a Democrat from Storrs who is also the political director for the party and the deputy majority leader in the House. "But I'm realistic enough to know we don't have any other options, either."
A vote to override would resurrect a plan to resolve Connecticut's projected revenue shortfall without an income tax. Instead, existing taxes would be increased by $1 billion. The 8 percent sales tax would be extended to an array of new purchases, from haircuts to car repairs.
Mr. Weicker, who in February proposed an overhaul of the state tax system and an income tax, vetoed the legislature's counterproposal on July 1, only a few minutes after the start of the fiscal year at midnight. He said the lawmakers' fiscal plan would deepen the recession.
The Senate had approved the package 24 to 12, and thus assumedly has the votes to override the veto; the House approved it 83 to 66 and would need 18 converts to reach the two-thirds level of 101 votes to override.
 
Democrats at Crossroads
 If the Republicans, the minority party in both chambers, vote overwhelmingly to override, as they did for the legislative counterproposal, the burden to reach two-thirds would fall on the Democrats.
"We just need to do something and get out of there," said Representative Doreen Del Bianco, a Democrat from Waterbury who voted against the legislative counterproposal but who finds herself torn on the second go-around.
Ms. Del Bianco, who supports an income tax, noted that with no apparent movement toward any other budget plan, interest costs of $100,000 a day from last year's unresolved deficit were piling up. On the other hand, she said the legislative sales-tax plan did not really work.
And then there are lawmakers like Joseph S. Raia and Alex Knopp. Both are House Democrats and both were opposed to an income tax, but they switched their votes at the end of June under pressure from party leaders and voted for a compromise income tax. The compromise died later in the Senate, and both said today that they were soured by the experience and would likely never vote for an income tax again.
"There were a lot of repercussions in my district," said Mr. Raia, a Democrat from New Britain who indicated he would vote to override the Governor's budget veto. He voted earlier in favor of the legislative tax package.
Mr. Knopp, a Democrat from Norwalk, who voted against the legislative package, said he would vote to override even though he thought the lawmakers' package contained elements that might hurt his district.
Mr. Weicker said at a news conference that if the lawmakers did override his veto, he would order the General Assembly back into session at the first sign that the plan was not generating enough revenue.

HEADLINE: KREMLIN TO LOOK FOR INVESTMENTS AT LONDON SUMMIT

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, July 9

 BODY:
President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today that he would be seeking Western investments in the Soviet economy rather than outright financial aid in his lobbying for help next week at the summit meeting of leading industrial countries.
The Soviet leader will also be offering a specific plan at the meeting on July 17, a plan that will focus on basic Western concerns like demilitarizing the Soviet economy, making the ruble convertible on the open market with other currencies, and suggesting some initial investment possibilities for foreign countries, his spokesman said. 
 Denying an earlier assertion by Prime Minister Valentin Pavlov that Mr. Gorbachev would not be presenting a detailed plan, the Presidential spokesman, Vitaly N. Ignatenko, said Mr. Gorbachev was working on his own economic recovery program and would be presenting it by way of a speech as well as a written document at the London industrial summit meeting.
 
No Plea for Money Expected
 No mention of specific sums was likely to be in Mr. Gorbachev's outline of his hopes for industrial help, Mr. Ignatenko said, insisting the Gorbachev plan would be comprehensive and based on a variety of sources, including the list of suggestions submitted to the Kremlin by a group of Soviet and Harvard academics on how to encourage Soviet economic recovery.
President Boris N. Yeltsin of the Russian republic, stressing the "mandate" and solidarity that Mr. Gorbachev will carry to London from the leaders of most of the nation's republics, said the Soviet and republic leaders had agreed in advance that "Gorbachev will not ask for money."
"The aim of the trip is to say firmly that the center and nine republics are committed to radical reform, transition to a market-based economy, to diverse forms of ownership and privatization," Mr. Yeltsin told news reporters.
With such a mood of domestic political truce in hand for the moment, President Gorbachev seemed ebullient about his mission as he spoke at a press conference with Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez of Spain, and outlined his approach to the "major event" awaiting in London.
 
Investment Possibilities
 Asked how the atrophied Soviet economy could absorb additional debt beyond its obligation estimated at $55 billion, Mr. Gorbachev cited the United States' national debt -- which Washington estimates at $3 trillion -- and said the Soviet obligation was commensurate with its resources and its record as a good credit risk.
Investments from foreign countries is his goal, he said, so that output can be increased and debt serviced. That will be "the principal direction of our economic cooperation with other countries," Mr. Gorbachev said.
His spokesman, Mr. Ignatenko, cited investment possibilities like oil and gas resources, light industry and banking reorganization as examples the Soviet President might point to as promising foreign investments. In advance of the London meeting, Mr. Gorbachev noted, the Soviet Parliament passed a law intended to ease some of the longstanding disincentives to foreign investors, allowing them full control of enterprises rather than limiting them to minority holdings.
The Soviet Union in recent years has had difficulty enticing major Western companies to invest significantly in the Soviet Union because of the nonconvertibility of the ruble, and the political chaos that made it difficult for companies to know if they should be doing business with individual enterprises, republics, or the central Government.
 
Disputes With Republics
 By promising to set a date when the ruble will be convertible, and assuring the foreigners more control over their activities in the Soviet Union, Mr. Gorbachev seems to be appealing for much more direct involvement of the West in the Soviet economy, which has faltered badly.
President Gorbachev, underlining his main selling argument as he prepares for London, stressed that the issue reaches well beyond Soviet borders, with "enormous global benefits" likely to accrue from a successful market transition aided by other countries.
He also cited the recent civil unrest and military fighting in Yugoslavia as a lesson for Soviet separatists on the need to retain a creative union rooted in democratic constitutional law.
"The people in our republics are watching very closely what's going on in Yugoslavia," he said.
Touching on his own continuing negotiations with the sovereignty-hungry republics over rewriting the Soviet nation's union treaty, Mr. Gorbachev said he hoped that the final consideration of proposed amendments would be completed in a week or two with final approval following without delay.
But as he heads to London, several critical differences remain unsettled with the republics. Most important there is the issue of taxation, with the republics insisting that the central Government should no longer be the dominant tax funnel and should be dependent on the republics for allocation of tax support.
That is only one issue in one area of the complex web of national reconstruction that Mr. Gorbachev is attempting in the nation's economic and political life. Repeatedly at his news conference, the Soviet President expressed confidence that the task eventually would prove successful.

HEADLINE: Support for Pretoria Sanctions Weak

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 9

 BODY:
Congress will probably not try hard to stop President Bush from lifting a wide range of trade and investment sanctions against South Africa, Administration and Congressional officials said today.
Several Democratic lawmakers were strongly critical of the President's move, which is expected to be formally announced on Wednesday, but the critics were skeptical that anything could be done to block it. 
 "They will be removed, and it will be tragic," said Representative William H. Gray 3d, the Pennsylvania Democrat who is the majority whip. "If you lift them too soon, you lock in apartheid."
The South African Government has been dismantling its legal system of racial separation, but discrimination, including denial of voting rights to the black majority, persists.
The State Department has concluded that South Africa has met all five conditions specified by law for the removal of many sanctions, an Administration official said Monday evening. These sanctions include a ban on many imports from South Africa; a ban on the sale of oil, computers, munitions and nuclear technology; and a provision that taxes paid by American companies in South Africa cannot be deducted against Federal taxes.
Federal sanctions that cannot be lifted without Congressional action, such as a 1983 law that bars United States support for loans by the International Monetary Fund to South Africa, would not be affected. Nor would there be any direct effect on state and local laws limiting dealings with companies doing business in South Africa.
Representative Howard Wolpe, a Michigan Democrat and former chairman of the House Africa subcommittee, said lifting sanctions would be premature while obstacles remained to the creation of democracy in South Africa. But he added, "As long as there is continued, demonstrable progress in South Africa toward the removal of the obstacles, I think Congress will adopt a wait-and-see attitude."
Mr. Wolpe said he had spoken to several colleagues today and knew of no broad-based effort in Congress to extend sanctions if Mr. Bush takes action.
 
Carter Favors Lifting Sanctions
 Many Republicans and some Democrats today supported the impending move. "I think now is the time to start removing those sanctions," former President Jimmy Carter said today at a news conference in Atlanta.
While new American investment in South Africa has been banned since 1986, a lifting of this ban is unlikely to prompt an influx of American money. Many American cities and states have their own restrictions on dealings with companies that operate in South Africa, and these restrictions would continue to discourage investment even after Federal sanctions are lifted.
"The companies that used to be in South Africa, they're not considering going back in," said Alison L. Cooper, the senior analyst at the Investor Responsibility Research Center, a non-profit group in Washington.
But trade in gold coins, steel and minerals, banned by the 1986 law that imposed most of the sanctions, is more likely to resume, said Timothy H. Smith, the executive director of the Interfaith Center on Corporate Responsibility, a New York-based group of Christian churches.
Because many anti-apartheid campaigners argue that change in South Africa has not yet gone far enough, any company that does invest in South Africa now "will clearly become a target of the U.S. anti-apartheid movement," said Richard V. Knight, a spokesman for the American Committee on Africa, a New York-based group.
The White House contended last month that that South Africa had already met four of the five conditions specified in the 1986 legislation that authorized most of the sanctions. These four conditions called for South Africa to legalize anti-apartheid groups and allow their participation in politics; lift state-of-emergency regulations; abolish certain discriminatory laws; and enter good-faith negotiations with black leaders for a new constitution.
 
Release of Political Prisoners
 The State Department has now concluded that South Africa is in the process of meeting the fifth condition, the release of all political prisoners.
But Mr. Gray, the House majority whip, said that several conditions had not been satisfied.
Some people detained under the state of emergency have not been released, not all political prisoners have been freed, black participation in politics is limited by the lack of voting rights for blacks and good-faith negotiations have not begun, Mr. Gray said.
Representative Edolphus Towns, the Brooklyn Democrat who is the chairman of the Congressional Black Caucus, said that he also did not believe the conditions had been met. But he added that any legislative challenge to the President was unlikely to succeed.
"I'd be the first to admit that the coalition we had at one point has broken down," Mr. Towns said.

HEADLINE: New York Losing Weapons Against Poverty

SERIES: The Budget Fallout; A periodic look at the effects of New York City's financial plan on various agencies and services.

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER

 BODY:
New York City's new budget means that Ethany E. Watley, an 80-year-old widow who uses a wheelchair because of arthritis, no longer has a daily lunch delivered to her home in East Harlem.
It means that Trina McNair, a young mother who lives in Brooklyn, lost the caseworker who helped her get prenatal care and who would have found day care for her newborn twins. 
 It means that Ronna Weiss, a psychologist, had no drug treatment to offer the scared, pregnant crack addict who came to North Central Bronx Hospital for help this week.
 
Cuts Despite Fiscal Maneuvers
 Though last-minute fiscal maneuvers saved services like shelters for homeless women and free medicine for the uninsured working poor, the budget that took effect on July 1 severely reduced many other social programs.
Mayor David N. Dinkins and the City Council restored $51 million to avert some of the harshest proposed cuts in health, housing and social services, but the city still cut spending in those areas by $263 million.
Hardest hit were some of the city's most innovative programs that were intended to break the cycle of poverty for children. Successful initiatives to reduce infant deaths and prevent lead poisoning of children were deeply cut. So was a planned expansion of drug treatment for pregnant women, and so were school health programs and inspections of day care centers.
 
An Even Worse Landlord
 Many other services to the poor were cut, too. For example, the city will now crowd more homeless people into fewer shelters and no longer provide special social services for homeless families placed in permanent housing. It also ended home-delivered meals for 1,000 of the frail elderly.
And the city will be an even worse landlord to 125,000 residents of city-run housing. Tenants will have to live with holes in their walls, broken-down lobby doors, grimy, chipped paint and dripping faucets. The city Department of Housing Preservation and Development will have even fewer managers to respond to a backlog of requests for repairs that already numbers 100,000.
"We're falling further and further behind," said William E. Spiller, deputy commissioner for property management at the housing agency.
In the last few months, as politicians jockeyed over the cuts, directors of many programs have lived with maddening uncertainty as they received mixed signals about financing.
 
'Enormously Frustrating'
 One example is the city's program to reduce infant mortality. After the program was eliminated in the Mayor's proposed budget, the Health Department sent layoff notices to most of the program's employees. Now, with half the money restored, managers are scrambling to regroup.
"It's been enormously frustrating," said Ellen Lovitz, Deputy Health Commissioner. "We'll get letters out as quickly as possible to people who will be called back to work."
Advocates for the programs continue to hold on to the slender hope that municipal unions will agree to wage and benefit concessions that can be funneled to social services.
But city agencies are operating on the assumption that they will not get any more money, and so they are performing financial gymnastics to come up with the funds internally.
One such agency is the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation. Without an extra dollar from the city, it will keep open most of the 28 pharmacies that provide free prescriptions to the uninsured, as well as walk-in medical clinics. All were about to close.
That the corporation, the largest municipal hospital system in the nation, was able to find the money in its own nooks and crannies suggests how carelessly it spent money when times were flush, critics said. The corporation plans to raise $10 million by collecting private insurance and Medicaid payments that it is entitled to.
 
Hospital System Accused of Waste
 Steven J. Matthews, a spokesman for the corporation, said it planned a system to collect the money even before the fiscal crisis. But Kildare Clarke, associate medical director for emergency services at the Kings County Hospital Center, said the corporation had wasted huge sums of money and should have improved its inefficient collecting of revenue years ago.
"If this was a private corporation, a lot of senior executives would have been fired," he said.
A city government trying to trim the fat is also cutting a lot of muscle. The most devastating and fiscally shortsighted cuts are in programs for children, said advocates and city officials.
"What's so sad," said Jane Knitzer, who heads the Citizens' Committee for Children, "is that we're embarking on a path with perfectly predictable consequences -- more damaged children who will bounce around in foster care."
 
Fewer Lead-Paint Inspections
 The city will inspect thousands fewer apartments for lead paint, which can cause brain damage in children.
The Department of Housing Preservation and Development, which is losing more than one-fourth of its code inspectors, is discontinuing about 1,000 apartment inspections a year in neighborhoods with high reported levels of lead poisoning. The Health Department lost about half the money that paid for 4,500 inspections last year.
The city also halved the financing for a program that helped reduce infant mortality rates in poor neighborhoods, where babies die at rates as high as those in some third-world countries.
Last year, the infant mortality initiative paired 5,800 pregnant women and mothers of babies with caseworkers and public health nurses.
Trina McNair, 25, who had twins three weeks ago, has not heard recently from her caseworker, Patricia Prescott, who has been laid off.
Mrs. Prescott had helped Ms. McNair get prenatal care and accompanied her to the hospital when she was treated for syphilis. "The twins could have been born blind or dead," the caseworker said last month, before she was laid off.
Instead, Ms. McNair's babies are healthy. She had been counting on Mrs. Prescott to help her in the next year.
"I was talking to her almost every day when I was pregnant," Ms. McNair said. "She'd give me a call. I'd call her. I was hoping she could help me find day care. I'm going back to work in August. I'm very sad to hear she's laid off."
 
Less Help for Pregnant Addicts
 The city's sharp scaling back in its planned expansion of drug treatment is also bad news for children. About 1,200 fewer pregnant women and 600 fewer mothers of young children will get help than expected.
A frightened young crack addict, six months pregnant, came to the North Central Bronx Hospital this week to be treated for syphilis. Ronna Weiss, director of the hospital's substance abuse program, said she chased the trembling woman as she tried to flee the hospital Monday evening.
Ms. Weiss coaxed her back to the hospital and bought her a hamburger and french fries at a coffee shop, but had no drug treatment to offer.
"We have literally 350 of these women a year, and there's no program for them," Ms. Weiss said. "It's unbelievable, but almost every substance abuse program will not take a pregnant woman." Few drug programs nationwide will do so either, largely because of liability problems posed by high-risk pregnancies.
 
Fewer Meals for the Elderly
This year, programs for the elderly, usually protected in the budget because of their voting strength, were also hit. About 5,000 fewer people will be able to get free meals in senior centers, in addition to those who will no longer get home-delivered meals.
Mrs. Watley, who has lost her home-delivered meal, needs the service because she is physically infirm. Leg spasms caused her to fall four times in the last two weeks, and twice she called the police to help her up, she said.
The 80-year-old widow has lived for 25 years in a second-floor apartment at First Avenue and 114th Street. In the living room is an orange-striped couch, where two teddy bears sit near yellow pillows she crotcheted. A book on a small end table is titled "Life Does Have a Purpose."
 
The Series So Far
 The first article in this series about the impact of the New York City budget appeared last Thursday. It described how the city's Police and Fire Departments were spared the brunt of the budget cuts that have sapped other city agencies.

HEADLINE: Personal Health

BYLINE: By Jane E. Brody

 BODY:
DO you come home from work physically or emotionally drained with little energy or enthusiasm left for dealing with family or personal matters?
Do you find it hard to get out of bed in the morning knowing what you face at work that day? 
 Do you often suffer from headaches, backaches, digestive upsets or insomnia that you trace to distress at work?
Have you noticed that you are drinking too much alcohol, smoking too many cigarettes, or becoming dependent on drugs that pep you up or help you sleep?
You may be among tens of millions of American workers who are suffering from job-related stress, a problem far more common than either workers or their employers realize.
At a time when many people are suffering the effects of unemployment, it may seem inappropriate to talk about stress on the job. But as a recent national survey revealed, cutbacks in personnel and shrinking employee benefits are major contributors to what the survey researchers called a national epidemic of job stress.
 
Survey Findings

Among a random sample of 600 full-time American workers in all types of jobs, 72 percent said they suffered from three or more stress-related conditions very often or somewhat often. These include exhaustion, anger or anxiety, muscle pain, headaches, insomnia and gastrointestinal disorders. Some workers were often beset by as many as eight or more stress-related ailments.
Scott Knowlton, disability manager for the Northwestern National Life Insurance Company, the Minneapolis-based company that sponsored the survey, said, "We are seeing twice the incidence of stress disabilities in our caseloads over just 10 years."
The growing problem of job stress also exacts a toll on employers by increasing job turnover and absenteeism and decreasing productivity.
Seven of 10 workers surveyed said that excessive job stress was cutting into their productivity, and nearly one in five said they missed one or more days of work last year because of workplace stress.
Fully one-third seriously considered quitting last year to reduce their stress, and 14 percent actually did quit or change jobs within the past two years because of workplace stress. Furthermore, 35 percent of new employees said they had left their previous jobs because of stress. Many of the stressed-out employees who stayed on the job presumably functioned at less than an ideal level.
A report on the survey quoted several people's expressions of concern. "I feel run down all the time," said a blue-collar worker from Wisconsin. "I can't concentrate. I make more mistakes on the job."
A professional from the same state said, "The only thing I can do is hang on where I am and suffer through it."
A business executive from California was even more blunt: "Burnout makes me feel tired, angry and fed up. I am less productive, and I have no job loyalty."
 
Causes of Job Stress

A dozen major causes of job stress were identified through the survey, which was conducted for the insurance company last January and February by N. K. Friedrichs & Associates , an independent research company in Minneapolis. The surveyors interviewed a representative sample of 600 American full-time adult workers who are not self-employed. The survey had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus four percentage points.
The researchers said they were surprised to discover that a hiring freeze and forced time off without pay, common in the recession, did not significantly increase worker burnout.
But three of the four leading factors related to burnout involved changes typical of current economic conditions: a substantial reduction in employee benefits; merger, acquisition or a change of company ownership, and a reduction in the size of the work force or elimination of positions at the company.
The leading identified cause of burnout -- "little personal control allowed" in doing one's job -- is prevalent at all times, irrespective of the economy.
Other factors associated with burnout and an increased likelihood of suffering stress-related illnesses included major departmental reorganizations and frequent requirements for overtime work. More than half the workers suffering burnout said their employer did not have supportive work and family policies and did not have effective lines of communication with manangement.
Forty-nine percent of burned-out workers said their employer did not provide health insurance coverage for mental illness and chemical dependency and 39 percent complained of inflexible work schedules.
On a more personal level, more than half the workers rated as most stressful either having too much work to do or having to work with the public. Blue-collar workers were more likely than white-collar workers to cite their bosses as a major source of job stress.
 
Possible Solutions

The survey findings suggest some important messages to both employers and employees.
As many people have realized in rearing children, there are often situations in which parents, instead of dictating a course of action, could offer children a choice and an opportunity to decide for themselves. This gives children an emerging sense of power and control over the course of their lives. Similar circumstances often prevail in the workplace, even for highly stereotyped jobs like assembly-line work. Workers can be permitted to at least participate in decisions that affect the quality of their work lives. They should know that management listens to them and takes them seriously.
The strong link between cuts in employee benefits and the occurrence of stress-related illness and burnout among workers suggests a need for a more humanitarian approach to employment. Nine of 10 workers said that health plans should cover treatment of stress-related illnesses, including emotional disorders and chemical dependency.
Indeed, based on 3,896 disability cases, the Northwestern National Life researchers calculated that the average cost of rehabilitating an employee disabled because of stress was $1,925. If they are not rehabilitated, experience has shown, companies will need to hold in reserve an average of $73,270 or more to cover disability payments for employees disabled by job-related stress.
Workers in the stress survey also indicated a strong need for more consideration of family and personal needs in establishing work schedules and policies. Especially now with both parents working outside the home in so many families, workers want more flexibility in their hours, paid or unpaid time off to help out at home, company assistance in child care and the opportunity to share jobs.
The survey showed that employers who offer stress-reduction or exercise programs have more employees with healthful habits. In these companies employees lived more healthfully whether or not they participated in the company-based programs. Furthermore, those with more healthful habits reported higher productivity, lower turnover and less absenteeism. In other words, a company's small investment in worker health can pay off in big bottom-line dollars.
 
 
 
JOB STRESS: RATING YOUR WORKPLACE
 
Stress Producers

 
Three points each:
1. Company has recently been purchased by another company.
2. Reductions in workforce or layoffs have occurred in the last year.
3. Department or employer has had a major reorganization.
4. Employees expect that the company will be sold or relocated.
5. Employee benefits were significantly cut recently.
6. Mandatory overtime is frequently required.
7. Employees have little control over how they do their work.
8. Consequences of making a mistake on the job are severe.
9. Workloads vary greatly.
10. Most work is machine paced or fast paced.
11. Employees must react quickly and accurately to changing conditions.
12. Personal conflicts on the job are commonplace.
 
Two points each:
13. Few opportunities for advancement are available.
14. Employees deal with lots of red tape to get things done.
15. Staffing, money or technology is inadequate.
16. Pay is below the going rate.
17. Sick and vacation benefits are below the norm.
18. Employees are rotated between shifts.
19. New machines or ways of working have been introduced.
20. Noise or vibration levels are high or temperatures keep changing.
21. Employees are generally isolated from one another.
22. Performance of work units is generally below average.
 
One point each:
23. There are few or no windows or natural lighting.
24. Employees have little or no privacy.
25. Meal breaks are unpredictable.
26. Work is either sedentary or physically exhausting.
TOTAL:
 
Stress Reducers

 
Three points each:
1. Management takes significant action to reduce stress.
2. Mental health benefits are provided.
3. Employer has formal employee communications program.
4. Employees are regularly given information on coping with stress.
5. Employees have current and clear job descriptions.
6. Management and employees talk openly with each other.
7. Employees are free to talk with one another.
8. Employer offers exercise and other stress-reduction classes.
9. Employees are recognized and rewarded for their contributions.
 
Two points each:
10. Work rules are published and are the same for everyone.
11. Child care programs are available.
12. Employees can work flexible hours.
13. Perquisites are granted fairly based on level in the organization.
14. Employees have access to the technology they need.
15. Employees and management are trained in resolving conflicts.
16. Employees receive training when assigned new tasks.
17. Employer encourages work and personal support groups.
18. Employees have a place and time to relax during the workday.
 
One point each:
19. An employee assistance program is available.
20. Each employee's work space is not crowded.
21. Employees can put up personal items in their work areas.
22. Management appreciates humor in the workplace.
23. Programs for care of the elderly are available.
TOTAL:
 
Scoring
 Subtract total points for stress reducers from total points for stress producers. The result may range from minus 50 points for no stress to 60 points for extremely high stress. The Northwestern National Life Insurance Company is developing a standard scoring method to allow for comparison of stress levels.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Airline Entrepreneur Faces Daunting Task

 BODY:
As he sets out to create a new airline from the scraps of the bankrupt Eastern Airlines, John R. Mitchell acknowledges that he is contending with heavy skepticism.
"If everyone could see the heart of the deal and could know everything we know, they wouldn't be so skeptical," Mr. Mitchell said yesterday, one day after announcing plans to invest $550 million to start up an airline to serve 12 East Coast cities from Atlanta beginning in November. 
 "I'm sure the industry is going to be skeptical until we fly that first flight," said the 34-year-old Mr. Mitchell.
To characterize the initial response from the aviation industry as "skeptical" would be charitable to the new start-up. Most are openly scornful.
"It just doesn't make any sense," said Kevin Murphy, aviation industry analyst with Morgan Stanley & Company. "A third of the industry already is in bankruptcy. The marketplace has spoken."
Eastern ceased operations on Jan. 19 after failing to recover from the effects of a March 1989 strike by unionized machinists. The company had been trying to restructure under bankruptcy protection since the early weeks of that strike.
Mr. Murphy noted that the new airline would have to compete with Atlanta-based Delta Air Lines in its home market. "Going against the likes of Delta is a daunting proposition," Mr. Murphy said.
The project has also met with a cool reception from officials in the Atlantas Aviation Department, which controls 33 gates at Hartsfield International Airport abandoned by Eastern. The new airline hopes to acquire rights to some or all of those gates.
"For a group with no employees, no gates, no flights and -- as far as we can tell -- no money, they have just not been very forthcoming about their plans," said John R. Braden, a spokesman for the Aviation Department. "I think it's time for them to put their cards, if they have any, on the table."
Mr. Mitchell said the proposal he had advanced in cooperation with a group of 170 pilots, most of them former Eastern employees, would make economic sense. The new airline would fly only small, two-engine jets bought from the Eastern bankruptcy estate, and each plane would have only two pilots and would fly only short routes with high yields, he said.
Mr. Mitchell said he had been brought into the deal by the Eastern pilots group because of his expertise in raising foreign money. Mr. Mitchell said he had sought financing from companies in Mexico and the Middle East. But he acknowledges that aviation law in the United States will require him to raise 51 percent of the airline's equity from domestic sources.
Mr. Mitchell is a 1978 graduate of the University of Cincinnati. He established the Sterling Financial Group in Atlanta in 1982. He has previously worked as vice president of mergers and acquisitions for the Atlanta-based Andover Group. While there, he arranged acquisitions of nine manufacturing and distribution companies in the Southeast.

HEADLINE: Yields Mixed On C.D.'s and Bank Funds

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts were mixed for the week ended yesterday.
According to The Bank Rate Monitor, an interest-rate publication, fewer financial institutions are lowering rates. For example, last week the New York, Chicago, San Francisco and Boston market averages for six-month certificate were unchanged from the week before, while movements in other markets were only one basis point up and down. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. 
 Analysts at The Monitor said that the lack of movement in bank yields might indicate that the current rate cycle was near its end. But the foundation for a new cycle has not materialized, they said, adding that the pace at which rates will rise in the next cycle will depend on the strength of the economic recovery.
At the Treasury Department's weekly auction on Monday, average discount rates were narrowly mixed and still at their highest levels since the beginning of June. The three-month bill slipped a basis point, to 5.58 percent, while the six-month bill was unchanged at 5.71 percent.
Analysts said savers should take into account the rise and fall in rates that tend to occur at the end of a recession and stay with maturities ranging from three months to a year.
The largest yield changes in banks in the New York area this week were at Citibank, which lowered the yield of its money-market account by 13 basis points, to 5 percent, at First Nationwide, which raised the three-month certificate of deposit by 15 basis points, to 5.5 percent, and the European American Bank, which raised the yield on its six-month C.D. by 11 basis points, to 5.76 percent.
Among commercial banks, the average money-market account fell by 2 basis points, to 5.17 percent, while the three-month and six-month certificates of deposit each rose one basis point, to 5.47 percent and 5.65 percent, respectively.
Depositors at savings institutions saw the average yield on a money-market account rise one basis point, to 5.55 percent, while a three-month certificate remained unchanged at 5.75 percent. The yield on a longer, six-month maturity, rose by one basis point, to 6.01 percent.
By comparison, at the 20 large banks around the country outside the New York market the average money-market yield was unchanged at 5.24 percent from the previous week, while the average yield of a six-month certificate fell one basis point, to 5.73 percent.
