HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
The Dark Side of Disunity

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
Americans seem fated to ignore the dark shadows of idealism in foreign policy. Yugoslavia is the most recent case in point.
 Some of America's finest essayists and talk-show artists are doing a devilishly effective job of selling a cleverly unshaded argument. Their pitch is that America's basic choice in Yugoslavia (and the Soviet Union) boils down to this: self-determination, freedom and democracy versus order, stability and dictatorship. 
 If that were the real choice, the decision would be easy. But it is not.
 Self-determination has its dark side -- virulent and oppressive nationalism. Stability and order have a positive side -- a context for peaceful change.
 The fact that Croatia and Slovenia have freely chosen to separate themselves from Yugoslav and Serbian domination does not suggest, or guarantee, a free and democratic future for their citizens. Croatia is known more for its Nazis than for its democrats. Slovenian leaders are largely unknown quantities. The Balkans are not exactly a tinderbox of democracy.
 Yugoslavia is rife with ethnic inequality, with the Serbs at the top of the food chain. But separated republics could treat their minorities still more unfairly. Perhaps the large Serbian population in Croatia has more to fear from an independent Croatia than Croatia does from Serb-dominated Yugoslavia. Minority rights are every bit as essential to democracy as majority rule.
 The economic effects of separation could also be devastating. Slovenes and Croats expect that after independence their standard of living could plunge by one-third. Many who voted for separation might then vote with their feet and flee westward, creating enormous problems in Eastern and Central Europe. Many who stay might find themselves freely electing dictators to restore order.
 As a practical matter, where should self-determination begin and end? Why can't the Serbian minority in Croatia vote to join Serbia? Why can't the Germans in Poland elect annexation to Germany? Why shouldn't northern Italians freely choose to separate themselves from southern Italy? If the Russian republic can declare its independence from Moscow, why can't Russia's own 16 autonomous republics freely establish their own sovereignty?
 Fragmentation could have frightful consequences. Most new states would quickly become economic basket cases, begging for aid and loosing refugees on their wealthier neighbors. The opportunities for mischievous diplomacy and war would multiply as the new states jockeyed to survive.
 None of this is to say that the U.S. should forsake its commitment to self-determination, for which Americans died in two World Wars, a conviction that springs from our own revolutionary heritage. It is to plead that our actions -- like those that we and the European Community are now pursuing in Yugoslavia -- be tempered by common-sense guidelines:
* We cannot and should not stop peoples from seeking self-determination. But we can and should employ our influence to urge extended cooling off periods -- as was just arranged between Slovenia and Yugoslavia. This gives time for all to reflect on the risks as well as the rewards of independence.
 * We have to make plain that spilling blood or provoking bloodshed is no way to gain our support. Economic and political pressures are fair instruments; killing is not.
 * We have to insure that the parties understand we will not help bail them out of whatever economic mess they create. If they simply act unilaterally, they will have to fend for themselves.
 * We ourselves have to understand that there is no one, final answer to the problem, and that those states closest to the problem generally must be the principal diplomatic midwives.
 It is no accident nor is it merely an act of selfishness that every European state except Germany and Denmark opposes uncontained, unilateral self-determination in Yugoslavia. And to them all, stability and order are not abstractions. For them, nasty nationalism and dictatorship loom in the shadows of self-determination unchecked by reason and history. Americans ought to hear out these European worries and appreciate our State Department's own agonies before we start leading the self-determination parade.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Yugoslav Marriage Needs a Trial Separation

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Psychodrama in Yugoslavia" (Op Ed, June 27), Srdja Popovic portrays the popular movement in Slovenia and Croatia as a manifestation of dangerous and irrational needs of adolescent nations. In his view, these movements must be repressed or contained by force of more mature statesmen. He fails to address the question of whether or not these psychological needs have roots in serious and justifiable grievances. 
 Considering how the Yugoslav project started 70 years ago, the maze of ethnic rivalries engulfing Yugoslavia is unsurprising. In lieu of the land of Southern Slavs, imagine a country comprising Israel, Lebanon and Syria. Imagine that this state came into being during the disintegration of a large empire, as an extension of Syria, which contributed in blood to the empire's defeat. Syrians, proud of fathering the new state, dominate the government and army. The capital is in Damascus.
Would it really be so surprising, or manifesting national immaturity, if Israel or Lebanon wanted the Syrian-dominated state reorganized, threatening to secede if the status quo remained? And would it be strange if Syrians viewed the weakening of control from Damascus as a betrayal?
Mr. Popovic wants the Yugoslav Gordian knot to be cut by the sword of the Army. But the blood spilled by the predominantly Serbian and Communist military leadership would only seal the fate of the Yugoslav idea in the long run. The West should not support a forced continuance of a bad marriage, but a "temporary separation" of feuding Yugoslav ethnic groups. Such a separation would allow strong nationalist passions to subside, while putting a halt to mutual accusations of exploitation.
At the same time, economic realities would soon begin to press toward larger integrations. A fertile soil would thus surface for genuine bonds of commonality among Yugoslav nations to emerge. A road to such a separation would be for the political leaders to agree to some sort of confederation. The West should exert pressure on these leaders to move toward a looser union, rather than unwittingly encouraging a military dictatorship.
 
MIRJAN DAMASKA
New Haven, June 27, 1991
 
The writer is Ford Foundation Professor of Law at Yale Law School.

HEADLINE: Dinkins Alters Banking Rules on South Africa

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY

 BODY:
On the day President Bush announced an end to five years of United States sanctions against South Africa, Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday announced broad new rules that would limit city business with banks that have ties to South Africa.
Saying that South Africa had not made enough progress toward introducing democratic reforms, Mr. Dinkins declared that banks would be rated on compliance with the new rules. 
 The City Council's Government Operations Committee a year ago unanimously approved the bill on which the rules are based. At the time, city officials conceded that the handful of banks without ties to South Africa would not be large enough to handle most city transactions, but they said the measure would prompt discussion and perhaps changes in the practices of bigger banks.
"The rules keep the pressure on the Government of South Africa by telling our banking community that doing business with an apartheid system is a severe liability at home," Mr. Dinkins said. "Alternatively, if a bank demonstrates its opposition to apartheid through meaningful action, the City of New York will recognize that commitment and reward it."
The new rules, issued by the city's Department of Finance, will provide a guideline for city agencies to use when deciding where to deposit city funds.
To qualify for the top rating, a bank cannot have an office, plant or employees in South Africa or investments there; cannot provide loans or trade credits to South Africa; cannot have deposits from South Africa, and cannot have licenses or agreements allowing the use of the bank's trademarks, copyrights or patents by the South African Government.
The guidelines also say that banks must have divested all outstanding debt owed them by the South African Government or its entities.
In 1990, the city had deposits in 20 banks with an average balance of $250 million and obtained banking services costing $40 million, according to the Mayor's office.
The rules were published in yesterday's City Record and will become effective in 30 days.
"While the Bush Administration believes the end of apartheid is near and the time has come to lift U.S. sanctions against South Africa, I am proud that New York City is moving forward with plans to put in place a set of regulations that is so broad in spectrum," Mr. Dinkins said. "It is our firm belief that without these measures on the local, state, Federal and international levels, the pursuit of democracy in South Africa will be stalled."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices of Treasury Securities Up

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities inched higher in thin trading yesterday, buoyed by a successful auction of new seven-year notes.
Bids on the $9 billion issue produced an average yield of 8.26 percent, a bit higher than had been anticipated and well above the 7.93 percent average yield at the last seven-year note sale on April 10. 
 Retail demand for the new securities was quite light, which left dealers holding more of the issue than usual. Those conditions often lead to a slide in prices after the Treasury releases the auction results. That did not occur yesterday.
"The market did better after the results were published, in part because the market's worst fears about the sale were not borne out," said William V. Sullivan, Jr., a senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds. "The history of seven-year auctions has been to disappoint. This sale failed to do that."
Market participants apparently saw value in the new securities, because by late yesterday the notes were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 8.21 percent, well below the auction level.
Despite the price improvement, some traders said the fact that so much of the issue remains in dealers' inventories remains a worry.
"Everyone is trying to breathe a sign of relief, but if activity stays as light as it is then yields may have to move higher," in order to sell the securities, one government securities trader said.
 
Reappointment of Fed Chairman
 Alan Greenspan's reappointment as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board was announced after traders had gone home, and consequently had no impact on movements in prices. The issue, however, was raised earlier in the day at a White House press conference, where President Bush told reporters that he would make a decision on the reappointment "soon."
"Our market trades on the expectation that Greenspan will be reappointed," Mr. Sullivan said.
Louis v.B. Crandall, chief economist at R.H. Wrightson & Associates, an economic consulting firm, said: "The shock would have been had he not be reappointed, and the Administration knew that. The last thing the market and the economy needs right now is more uncertainty."
While many economists have expressed surprise that the decision to reappoint Mr. Greenspan took so long, the fact that the process was so drawn out may have raised the Fed chairman's credibility in the fixed-income markets, Mr. Crandall said.
"Just a few months ago, after he was appointed chairman of the comission to study the advisability of cutting the capital gains tax, the word on the Street was that Greenspan was too close to the Administration," Mr. Crandall said. "This whole reappointment episode has made his relationship with the Administration look a little less cozy. That is probably good for the Fed."
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, prices began to rise shortly after results of the seven-year auction were announced.
By late in the day, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 95 27/32, up 6/32, to yield 8.50 percent, down from 8.52 percent late Tuesday.
 
10-Year Note Offering
 Among Treasury note issues, the 8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 97 27/32 late yesterday, up 5/32, to yield 8.32 percent. The 7 7/8 percent five-year notes were offered at 99 5/8, up 1/8 point, to yield 7.96 percent. And the 7 percent two-year notes rose by 2/32 point, to an offered price of 100 5/ 32, to yield 6.91 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates eased slightly.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.55 percent, down three basis points, or three one-hundreths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by one basis point, to a late offered rate of 5.67 percent. And one-year bill rates dipped by three basis points, to a late rate of 5.87 percent.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, traders said that prices of most issues were up by about 1/8 point in very quiet trading.
Continued strong demand from retail investors helped to push up prices in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds.
Prices of most widely quoted issues improved by 1/8 point to 1/4 point, traders said.

HEADLINE: School's Budget Cuts: Looking for Magic

SERIES: The Budget Fallout: A periodic look at the effects of New York City's financial plan on various agencies and services.

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER

 BODY:
When school opens in New York City on Sept. 11 more classrooms will be strained to the breaking point. Fewer teachers will be around to offer art, music and the electives that give high school its pungency.
Fewer guidance counselors will be available to help the most aimless and unruly youngsters, and ragged textbooks will have to make it through another year patched together by tape and glue. 
 These are the current prospects.
But even after both the city and state last week settled on budgets that will require school cuts of $464 million, much remains uncertain because some potential fiscal sleights-of-hand could spare some of the worst ravages.
The administration of Mayor David N. Dinkins is negotiating with its labor unions to gain up to $600 million in concessions on salaries, benefits and work practices. Some of that money could be funneled to schools. There could be also be a further infusion of cash from the Municipal Assistance Corporation that floats bonds on behalf of the city.
For many Board of Education officials, though, the only lingering question is whether life will be miserable or merely bleak. Some deprivations have already begun.
In recent weeks, between 3,500 and 4,270 teachers have taken advantage of a retirement incentive program intended to save $50 million by eliminating those who are most highly paid. But their departure will not only shrink the teaching force but also bring many new teachers without any experience into the system. At the same time, the money once available to provide on-the-job training is depleted.
"We're getting more and more people who are coming in absolutely green," said Frank Arricale, superintendent of District 11 in the northeast Bronx, who worries he may have to eliminate his 30 teacher trainers. "If you want to do more than babysit, you have to train them in how to teach."
The budget crisis also threatens to abolish experimental programs that have been keeping children in school. School District 18 in the East Flatbush and Canarsie sections of Brooklyn deploys "health aides" in each school who, under the supervision of a part-time pediatrician and two nurses, to make sure children receive checkups and vaccinations.
One child displaying tantrums, said Dr. Harvey Garner, the district's superintendent, was discovered to have a heart defect that was soon corrected. A tubercular third-grader has been badgered to make regular clinic visits that his family might not pursued so rigorously.
At Edward R. Murrow High School in Brooklyn, known for its magnet programs in journalism, law and sociology, some elective courses will be eliminated and others will be more crowded, said the principal, Saul Bruckner. Students will not be allowed to take so many subjects as they do now, forcing those who fail courses to spend an extra term or two before they can graduate.
 
Deep Cuts at CUNY
 Money that pays teachers to call parents of truants is gone. Fewer clerks are available to help pull together college applications. The school's eight guidance counselors will each have to advise more students because the number of students is rising but the number of counselors is not.
The picture is almost as grim at the City University of New York, with more than 200,000 students at 21 colleges and graduate centers. Some time later this month, the university's trustees are expected to raise the $1,450 tuition by $400 at the senior colleges and $300 at the community colleges.
The increases are smaller than the $500 that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo proposed, which sparked a shutdown of much of the university last spring. But coming on top of reductions in state financial aid, the tuition increases may still discourage some impoverished students from enrolling.
 
Opportunity Lost
 University officials are most concerned about the decimation of one campus, New York City Technical College in downtown Brooklyn. Officials say that a 50 percent cut that was imposed by the state and that the city cannot afford to make up will mean the elimination of 31 of 38 two-year degree programs. These programs, enrolling 4,500 of the school's 11,000 students, train X-ray technicians, dental hygienists, eyeglasses makers, nurses and restaurant managers.
"We're talking about first-generation college students who have an opportunity to really change their lives," said Dr. James W. Merideth, the college president. "We're talking about nursing students coming off welfare and going into $35,000-a-year jobs."
The John Jay College of Criminal Justice has also been stripped of funds for its two-year programs in police work, correction and security, endangering the career plans of 2,000 of its 8,500 students.
The foreboding hanging over the city's 984 public elementary and secondary schools was heightened this week by a status report from Stanley S. Litow, the Deputy Schools Chancellor for Operations.
 
Lack of Alarm
 Cutting $464 million from a $7 billion budget, he said, would require the elimination of 7,181 jobs, including 3,006 teachers, 312 assistant principals, 312 guidance counselors, 565 secretaries, 128 security guards, 428 paraprofessionals, and 2,112 school aides.
The internal memo was sent to City Hall and to such power brokers as Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, as an unblushing appeal for rescue. But City Hall officials view Mr. Litow's figures with something less than his alarm.
The Mayor's acting press secretary, Leland T. Jones, described them as "placeholders" -- figures that should not to be taken literally but which suggest the scope of raw job cuts if no other measures are taken.
But Mr. Litow contended that he was not crying wolf. His list, he said, was compiled from estimates made by the city's 32 district superintendents and the high school superintendents.
"It would be the gravest mistake to understate the results of this budget," he said. "If this litany of things doesn't spell devastation, it's hard to imagine what does. It means the school programs will be radically different than what we've had in New York City, and keep in mind that New York's is not as good as what other districts in the state have."
The Schools Chancellor, Joseph A. Fernandez, said again yesterday that he was considering suing the city for violating the Stavisky-Goodman Law, which requires the city to spend as much on education in a particular year as the average of the previous three years. But former school officials say the law is difficult to invoke because the city can manipulate statistics to assert that it is not in violation.
Mr. Litow predicted that the school system would have 4,000 fewer teachers than the 65,884 it did for the past school year. With enrollment expected to grow by 25,000 students to 980,000, average class size is expected grow by three students, he said. The average number of students per class last school year ranged from 24.8 students in primary grades to 30.4 in high school.
In addition, he said, there would be a $19 million cut -- about 63 percent -- in money for textbooks, library books and equipment, and a $20 million cut in staffing for after-school and extracurricular activities.
These cuts will be translated down to the local level sometime in the next two weeks when the district superintendents are given their September allocations.
Mr. Arricale, the Bronx superintendent, said he expected to cut close to $5.6 million from his $60 million budget, a figure he said is far more painful than it might seem.
"Fifty million of the $60 million is mandated -- a teacher for every classroom, a principal for every school," he said.
With the remaining $10 million cut in half, he said, he will lose 15 assistant principals and 40 guidance counselors. If youngsters cannot get help from guidance counselors, he warned, more of them will be referred to the special eduication classes for the emotionally disturbed, where guidance is mandated.
Dr. Bertrand Brown, superintendent of District 5 in Harlem, said the possibility that he may have to dismiss between 30 and 40 teachers reminded him of the hardships of the city's last fiscal crisis, when the school system laid off 14,000 teachers.
"We'll be back into the 1970's," he said. "We'll start at ground zero."
The prospect of a last-minute cavalry charge bringing additional money is by no means certain. Mr. Rohatyn said in an interview that the Municipal Assistance Corporation would not turn over $1 billion over the next four years -- the proceeds from the refinancing of its maturing bonds -- unless the city comes up with a long-term financial plan that indicates that its books will be balanced permanently.
"Obviously I'm very sympathetic to his problems," he said of Mr. Fernandez. "On the other hand, M.A.C. doesn't know whether it will be in a position to play any role. We would certainly need a credible city plan to give our bondholders assurance of repayment."
To establish such a plan, he said, the city would need to obtain agreements from its unions to reduce wage scales and economize on other contract terms. That process is filled with snares.
For one thing, the city wants the United Federation of Teachers, which last year helped avert layoffs by agreeing to a partial wage deferral, to join these negotiations. But a union spokeswoman, Susan Amlung, argues that "our position is we gave already."
 
The Series So Far
 The most recent article about the impact of the New York City budget appeared yesterday. It described how social services would be severely reduced under the new spending plan. A previous article said the city's Police and Fire Departments were spared extensive cuts.

HEADLINE: BUSH LIFTS A BAN ON ECONOMIC TIES TO SOUTH AFRICA

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 10

 BODY:
President Bush today lifted the American economic sanctions imposed on South Africa in 1986, saying Pretoria's moves to end its system of racial separation and white minority rule were "irreversible."
Mr. Bush said the State Department had advised him that with the release of all political prisoners in recent weeks, President F. W. de Klerk had met all five conditions laid down by the sanctions legislation and therefore by executive order he was immediately ending the ban on trade with South Africa, bank loans to its Government, new investments there and airline connections. 
 But Mr. Bush noted that though he was ending the Comprehensive Anti-Apartheid Act, several other separately legislated American sanctions will remain in force. Those include limitations on South Africa's lending from the International Monetary Fund or the Export-Import Bank, a ban on all exports to South Africa's military and police, a mandatory United Nations arms embargo on South Africa, and a ban all intelligence sharing.
 
Pretoria's Eroding Isolation
 Mr. Bush's announcement at a White House news conference came only a day after the International Olympic Committee ended a 21-year ban on South African participation in Olympic competition. That and the end of American sanctions go a long way toward ending the international isolation of South Africa.
Before signing the executive order, Mr. Bush called Nelson Mandela to notify him. While Mr. Bush said he told Mr. Mandela that lifting sanctions now was "the right thing to do in order to encourage continued change," the African National Congress leader responded that Mr. Bush should have waited for more progress in dismantling apartheid before he acted.
That view was echoed with passion and anger by top Democratic leaders, the Congressional Black Caucus and the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, who dispute, among other things, the State Department's assessment that all political prisoners have been released.
 
Override of Veto Is Unlikely
 But opponents of the President's decision almost certainly do not now have the two-thirds majority of both houses of Congress that they would need to reimpose sanctions over a Presidential veto.
Mr. Bush, who as Vice President opposed the original sanctions legislation as politically useless and economically harmful to the black majority, said that since the five conditions had clearly been met, he had no choice but to fulfill the law.
He pointedly added, "During the past two years we've seen a profound transformation in the situation in South Africa -- I really firmly believe that this progress is irreversible." [Excerpts from the news conference, page A10.]
The President, referring to the fact that negotiations between South African blacks and whites to establish a nonracial, multiparty democracy are still incomplete, said that "much remains to be done -- let's be very clear on that point -- and we will use all available means to encourage this process through its successful conclusion."
Pressed as to how he intended to do that without the leverage of broad economic sanctions, Mr. Bush could not point to anything specific, other than to say that he would personally discuss the situation by telephone Thursday with President de Klerk, whom he believes is committed to transforming South Africa into a multiracial democracy, and would "indicate to him, we expect progress to continue."
Apparently in an effort to blunt some of the criticism from blacks in the United States, Mr. Bush announced that he had ordered a doubling of American assistance to black South Africans, from $40 million to $80 million, for housing, economic development and education programs.
The Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, Herman J. Cohen, said the Administration hoped that the lifting of sanctions by the Federal Government would also spur colleges, universities, states and local governments to immediately rescind their sanctions on South Africa, like divesting stock in multinational companies with factories there.
 
Looking for a Test Case
 Mr. Cohen said the Justice Department would be "studying possible methods" to push institutions in that direction, including possibly bringing a test case against some institution that refuses to comply.
The Justice Department, he said, "will be looking into the legal implications of states and local governments carrying out their own foreign policy with respect to South Africa."
Speaking of cities like New York, and universities that have imposed their own sanctions, Mr. Cohen said, "We would like very much for them to follow what the Federal Government has done."
Congress imposed economic sanctions on South Africa in 1986, after a bitter political battle with President Reagan, whose initial veto of the bill was overridden. The legislation banned all trade with South Africa, including the import of South African gold and other minerals, coal, textiles and agricultural products, prevented South African Airways from flying into the United States, and blocked American banks from lending money to the South African Government or making new investments there.
 
Sanctions and Investments
 Mr. Cohen said that in 1986, 250 American companies had investments in South Africa worth a total of $2.5 billion. After nearly six years of sanctions, there are only 125 companies worth about $1 billion.
When asked today whether in retrospect the sanctions worked and he should have supported them from the start, Mr. Bush equivocated.
"I can't say that sanctions had no effects," he said. "But far more important than sanctions was the fact that you had a forward-looking man of Mr. de Klerk's stature."
The end of sanctions appeared increasingly likely during the last two years, as one condition after another was apparently met.
 
State Department's Decision
 Those were: lifting the state of emergency that gave the Pretoria Government extraordinary police powers; legalizing democratic political parties; repealing the Group Areas Act, which stipulated those areas of South Africa where blacks could live, and repealing the Population Registration Act, which stipulated that all South Africans register their race at birth and accorded them different rights on that basis for the rest of their lives, and beginning serious political negotiations with "truly representative" black leaders to establish a democratic political system.
At the end of June, the State Department sent a team to investigate whether the fifth condition -- the "release of persons persecuted for their political beliefs or detained unduly without trial" had also been fully met. The South African Government had committed itself to such a full release by April 30.
After examining hundreds of case files, the State Department informed Mr. Bush on Friday that it had determined that all political prisoners -- according to its definition -- had been freed. That referred to people jailed or detained for trying to express their political beliefs, but not those incarcerated after receiving due process for crimes of violence -- even if politically motivated.
The African National Congress argues that that definition excludes many legitimate political prisoners.
Randall Robinson, President of the anti-apartheid organization, TransAfrica, argued that independent human-rights groups, like the South African Human Rights Commission and Amnesty International, affirm that there are at least 850 legitimate political prisoners remaining in South African jails.
Representative Ronald V. Dellums, the California Democrat who was the leading author of the sanctions legislation, said that in view of the still incomplete constitutional negotiations between leaders of black organizations and Mr. de Klerk, South Africa's black majority still "cannot vote and cannot hold office," so the country is still a long way from being a nonracial democracy, with one-man, one-vote.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Bush's repeal of the sanctions imposed by the Comprehensive Anti-Apartheid Act coincided with the decision by the International Olympic Committee to readmit South Africa to the Olympics. HEADLINE: Greenspan Named for New Term As Chairman of Federal Reserve

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 10

 BODY:
President Bush announced tonight that he would nominate Alan Greenspan to another four-year term as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.
The announcement was expected here and on Wall Street. But with Mr. Greenspan's current term expiring Aug. 11, mild jitters developed in the financial community in recent weeks when no word from the White House was forthcoming. 
 Appearing with Mr. Greenspan in the White House pressroom about 6 P.M., Mr. Bush said, "The respect that Alan Greenspan has around the world and in this country, particularly in financial marketplaces, is unparalleled."
Asked about his occasional complaints and those from other top Administration officials that Mr. Greenspan retarded economic expansion by keeping interest rates too high, the President said the chairman was "strongly committed to growth."
 
Influence Over Rates
 The nation's large budget deficit prevents the President or Congress from using tax and spending policies to influence the economy, and that leaves Mr. Greenspan far and away the most important economic policy maker in the Government. By controlling the money supply, the Federal Reserve has considerable influence over interest rates, a main factor in the state of the economy.
Mr. Greenspan's goal as chairman was to achieve what he and other economists often called a "soft landing" after the rapid economic growth of the mid-1980's. During his term, economy showed slow but rather steady growth until last summer, when the recession began. The inflation rate has remained in the neighborhood of 4 percent.
Speaking to reporters after his renomination was announced, Mr. Greenspan repeated what has become almost a mantra for him when he is asked about his views on the economy. He said he would "try to maintain the maximum sustainable long-term economic growth that is possible." Keeping inflation under control, he continued, is a "necessary condition" to achieve the goal of maximum growth.
Mr. Greenspan, who is 65 years old, is unusually popular in Congress, and his confirmation is unlikely to be a problem. A spokesman for Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., the Michigan Democrat who heads the Banking Committee, said the committee would hold confirmation hearings as soon as it received the formal nomination papers from the White House.
Mr. Bush did not announce today whom he intended to nominate to fill the vacant seat on the Federal Reserve Board created by Martha R. Seger's resignation last spring. Senior officials said the White House had settled on Susan M. Phillips, a former chairwoman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, but apparently the final background checks have not been completed.
The Banking Committee, however, did vote today to confirm Lawrence B. Lindsey, a White House economist, to fill another vacancy on the board and to promote David W. Mullins Jr., a current member, to be vice chairman. Senator Riegle and four other Democrats voted against Mr. Lindsey, whom they view as too conservative.
The full Senate is expected to vote on those nominations this week or next, and confirmation is not in doubt.
On Wall Street, leading market strategists said they were reassured by Mr. Greenspan's reappointment and believed it indicated monetary policy would continue on its current course.
"This is a reaffirmation of support by the Administration for the monetary policy that is in place," said Henry Kaufman, president of Henry Kaufman & Company, an investment advisory firm in New York. "I think the markets would have been greatly distraught if the chairman had not been reappointed."
Milton Friedman, the Nobel Prize-winning economist and critic of Federal Reserve as an institution, said of the central bank, "As long as it exists, Alan is as good a person as there is."
In addition to naming Mr. Greenspan to another four-year term as chairman, Mr. Bush nominated him for an additional 14-year term as member of the Federal Reserve Board. But governors rarely serve their full terms, and no one expects Mr. Greenspan to continue on the board when he is no longer chairman.
 
Replaced Volcker
 Mr. Greenspan, a professional economic forecaster and consultant who was chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers in the Ford Administration, took his seat as Fed chairman on Aug. 11, 1987, replacing Paul A. Volcker, who had served the previous eight years.
Mr. Greenspan has run the Fed in a much more collegial way than Mr. Volcker did, encouraging other governors to express their views. At times, that has made it appear as if the central bank was speaking with more than one voice. But Mr. Greenspan has never been in the minority on a vote and, so far as is known, the Fed policy has been basically his.
The Greenspan style has been not to impose sweeping changes but to make regular small adjustments in the interest rates the central bank controls, particularly the Federal funds rate. That is the rate banks pay each other for short-term loans and often serves as a benchmark for commercial rates.
 
Worried About Inflation
 That rate was 6 1/2 percent when Mr. Greenspan became chairman. Worried about inflation, he allowed it to rise steadily until it reached almost 10 percent in the spring of 1989. Since then, he has slowly driven the Federal funds rate down to 5 3/4 percent, where it now stands.
The most controversial aspect of Mr. Greenspan's tenure was his judgment to leave the rate unchanged from December 1989 until July 1990. The economy hardly grew at all during that period, and many economists felt he should have lowered rates to give it a lift.
In part, Mr. Greenspan was hamstrung by his promise to lower rates if the President and Congress agreed on a way to reduce the budget deficit. With the politicians deadlocked for months, Mr. Greenspan had little room to maneuver.
 
Blame for the Recession
 Records now show that the recession began in July. Mr. Greenspan has attributed the downturn primarily to the uncertainty that followed Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in August and on the unusually tight lending policies at banks. Many economists, however, hold Mr. Greenspan and the Federal Reserve primarily responsible for the recession.
Once the President and Congress struck the budget deal in October, the Fed began to drive down interest rates on an almost weekly basis.
Mr. Bush's renomination of Mr. Greenspan almost certainly means that the Bush Administration has decided that the recession is a short and mild one that the President can weather politically. Had the recession been long and deep like the one in 1982 and 1983, Mr. Greenspan would probably have been made a scapegoat, much the way the owners of baseball teams fire their managers in a losing season.
In the months ahead, Mr. Greenspan will be faced with the question of how much to encourage the economy to grow during what most forecasters believe will be a rather tepid recovery. The first sign of Fed policy came last week when, according to Government officials, policy makers decided not to change the targets for money supply growth for 1992.
Some Federal Reserve officials wanted to lower the range slightly to signal the markets that the Fed was determined to wring inflation out of the economy. The decision that was made seemed to indicate that the central bank regarded a strong recovery as at least as important as reducing inflation.

HEADLINE: Raising Hurdle for Coliseum, Judge Orders Clean-Air Plan

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS

 BODY:
A Federal judge ruled yesterday that a massive, long-disputed skyscraper project in Columbus Circle can go forward but will be halted if New York City fails to come up with a plan by late next year to meet Federal air-quality standards in all five boroughs.
The ruling creates another hurdle for a project that has been hobbled by lawsuits and declining economic conditions. It has been revised and scaled down twice since it was proposed in 1985. The ruling also appears to hold the project hostage to force the city to meet the federally imposed deadline by November 1992 to specify how it will control air pollution. 
 The judge, Shirley Wohl Kram of Federal District Court in Manhattan, dismissed many of the claims against the project. But opponents said that the order she issued could be fatal to the office, commercial and residential complex because the city has been unable to meet earlier deadlines for a plan.
"If you were a developer planning to spend X hundreds of millions of dollars, would you do it with that threat hanging over your head?" said John T. Van Der Tuin, a lawyer who represented two coalitions, a travel agency and three individuals in the civil lawsuit filed against the city and the developers last year. "My conclusion is that it will not be built."
City officials gave a mixed reaction to the ruling. Victor A. Kovner, the city's Corporation Counsel, said he was pleased that the judge approved the start of the project but added that "we are very troubled that the judge has found the city in violation of the Clean Air Act."
 
Talk of an Appeal
 "We will in all likelihood seek appellate review on that issue," he said.
Representatives of the developer, Boston Properties, owned by Mortimer B. Zuckerman, said they could not comment because they had not yet read the decision. At present, Mr. Zuckerman has agreed to buy the 4.5-acre site from the city if the project is approved. But he has not yet signed an agreement with any large tenant.
The latest blueprint for the project calls for a 752-foot-high, twin-towered structure to be built at the southwest corner of Central Park. The sale of the city-owned land for the complex would mean $338 million in revenue at a time of severe fiscal distress. Because of the slumping real estate market, questions had arisen lately about who would occupy the office space.
The project has fueled controversy since its inception. The original proposal would have built a 925-foot-high tower whose shadow, opponents claimed, would have blocked much of the sunlight over Central Park. That plan was defeated in court.
In reaching her opinion on summary judgment, which both sides had requested in lieu of a trial, Judge Kram reviewed the history of the city's compliance with Federal air-quality rules. She did not seem to find it encouraging.
"The city officials' intentions, or indeed the amount of money they have allocated to the problem, unfortunately do not necessarily bear any relation to the likely success of this program," Judge Kram wrote. "By all indications, the city is well on its way to missing the Nov. 15, 1992, deadline, as it has missed each of the others set for it by Congress."
"The city is depending on income from this project to put towards subway improvement and other public programs," the judge wrote. "The public's interest in funding these other city undertakings must be considered as well.
 
$15 Million Minimum Fine
 "Nevertheless, the court will not permit the city to persevere, undeterred, in its violation of these congressionally mandated and agency-implemented deadlines," she said.
The judge included an order that would stop work on the project unless the city meets a deadline of Nov. 15, 1992, for an air-quality plan. She also set a $15 million minimum fine for the city and the developers, which "will be followed by additional fines until such time as the city and the project sponsors fully comply with their statutory obligations."
In discussing air-quality requirements, the judge focused on carbon-monoxide levels already present in New York City's air. Under rules put into effect last year by the Environmental Protection Agency, new projects must figure out a way to help control air-quality violations even if they did not cause them, especially in "hard-core hot spots," like 59th Street near the site. 
On other specific complaints in the lawsuit, Judge Kram ruled in favor of the defendants or dismissed the complaints. For example, on a question of whether there were plans to enlarge a garage at the site, she found in favor of the city, which had moved to dismiss the claim. On the question of whether a conflict of interest existed because a former Metropolitan Transportation Authority employee, Robert Selsam, went to work for Boston Properties, Judge Kram dismissed the claim because the plaintiffs did not specify what relief they wanted.
Other points raised in the lawsuit include the sale of city Industrial Development Authority bonds for the complex. The plaintiffs, who included two coalitions, three neighborhood residents and a travel agency that would be displaced by the construction, had said the Industrial Development Authority was illegally involved in a residential project. But the judge ruled that the plaintiffs had no standing to raise the issue, and dismissed the claim.

HEADLINE: Newmark & Lewis to Close 11 Jersey Stores

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH

 BODY:
Newmark & Lewis Inc., the New York area's biggest retailer of electronics and appliances, will close 11 of its 14 stores in New Jersey because of poor business and high operating costs, the company said yesterday.
There had been persistent reports in the appliance industry that Newmark & Lewis was about to close the stores because of continuing losses from slumping home-appliance sales. Asked yesterday about those reports, Warren G. Hyman, Newmark & Lewis's co-chairman and co-chief executive, confirmed that the company had placed advertisements today in New Jersey newspapers announcing the closings and a liquidation sale of floor models. 
 Newmark & Lewis bought the 14 New Jersey stores in May 1990 by acquiring Brick Church Appliance Inc. for $7.8 million.
The stores to be closed, which represent about 25 percent of Newmark & Lewis's total sales, will leave the chain, based in Hicksville, L.I., with 56 stores in the New York area. The company's inability to turn around the former Brick Church stores reflects the severe pressures of cost-cutting, low margins and slow sales that have afflicted many appliance and electronics retailers around the nation.
In the last two years consumers have sharply curtailed their purchases of televisions, washers and dryers, and other household durables.
One of the country's largest electronics chains, Highland Superstores, based in Plymouth, Mich., recently took steps to stem losses by closing more than 30 stores in several states and eliminating six vice-presidential positions. Highland in the first quarter, ending April 30, had sales of $170.1 million, down from $185.3 million the year before. Its net loss increased sharply to $90.1 million from a loss of $6.6 million a year earlier.
But Circuit City Stores, the industry's largest electronics chain, has begun solving its problems. Circuit City reversed its 1990 quarter loss of $43 million with a net profit of $8 million in the first quarter. Sales rose to $562.1 million from $490.1 million.
Mr. Hyman said yesterday that Newmark & Lewis was closing the stores because of "the severity of the retailing climate in the Northeast and the fact that we want to consolidate our assets."
"A major problem," he said, "was the high cost of advertising and distribution in New Jersey."
He said that the stores in Paramus, Wayne and Jersey City would remain open. Those being closed are in Edison, Greenbrook, Marlboro, Tinton Falls, Toms River, Union, Hanover, Orange, Rahway, Rockaway and Newark. All the properties are leased by Newmark & Lewis.
The closing stores have a total of 60 to 80 employees, and a company spokesman said some of them would be offered jobs at other Newmark & Lewis locations.
Newmark & Lewis had a net loss of $5.26 million in the quarter ended April 30, compared with a loss of $1.14 million in the corresponding period in 1990. Sales were up for the more recent period, rising to $55.1 million, from $52.2 million the year before.
But in a filing with the Securities and Exchange and Commission this week, the company said that same-store sales in the recent quarter fell 15.2 percent, "reflecting the deepening economic decline of the Northeast."
In the fiscal year ended Jan. 31, the company reported sales of $246 million, compared with $238 million the year before. But net profits amounted to only $71,000, compared with $2.36 million in the prior year.
Newmark & Lewis told the S.E.C. that its 14 New Jersey stores had sales of $61.3 million for the year ended Jan. 31, translating into a net annual loss for the group of $1.96 million. The company said it was taking a $3 million write-off for the 11 stores to be closed.
Some competitors said Newmark & Lewis's New Jersey stores farthest from New York City were plagued by the highest distribution costs.

HEADLINE: Patricia Robbins Beatty, Wrote Children's Books on the West, 68

BYLINE: By JOAN COOK

 BODY:
Patricia Robbins Beatty, an award-winning author of 50 children's books, died on Tuesday at the Riverside (Calif.) Community Hospital. She was 68 years old and lived in Riverside.
She died of lung cancer, a spokeswoman for the family said. 
 Mrs. Beatty's books were generally admired for their evocation of both the humor and the harsh realities of the American West in the 19th century. Her more recent novels, including "Charley Skedaddle" (1987), which won the Scott O'Dell Award for Historical Fiction, dealt with the Civil War.
She was born in Portland, Ore., and spent much of her childhood in the Northwest, sometimes living on Indian reservations. She graduated from Reed College in Portland and became a children's librarian and a high school teacher of English and history.
She began to write when her children were small and drew on her knowledge of the Quileute Indians for her first book, "The Indian Canoe Maker," published in 1960 by Caxton Press. Eleven books that followed were written in collaboration with her first husband, Dr. John L. Beatty, a professor of history at the University of California at Riverside, who died in 1975.
In 1974, she received an award for a distinguished body of work from the Southern California Council on Children's Literature. In 1988, she established the John and Patricia Beatty Award through the California Library Association to encourage the writing of children's books about the culture and heritage of California.
A forthcoming book, "Jayhawker," the story of a young abolitionist during the Civil War, is to be published by Morrow Junior Books in October.
She is survived by her second husband, Dr. Carl Uhr, a professor of economics at the University of California at Riverside; a daughter, Alexandra Beatty, and two grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
A Plan for Saving the Children

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT

 BODY:

When the Bough Breaks
The Cost of Neglecting Our Children
By Sylvia Ann Hewlett
Illustrated. 346 pages. Basic Books/HarperCollins. $22.95.
Yes, another Cassandra come to warn us about what we are doing to the children. But Sylvia Ann Hewlett doesn't only wring our hearts in her passionately argued "When the Bough Breaks: The Cost of Neglecting Our Children." She tries to wring our pocketbooks as well. And she makes some very good sense. 
 Surveying the wreckage of the homeless poor and the untended rich, Ms. Hewlett points out some of the obvious landmarks. More and more American women are going to work these days, either out of financial need or in a search for psychic self-fulfillment. The consequences for their children, she insists, are often malign. Parental neglect leads to emotional instability, which in turn produces poor performance at school, which in the longer run weakens the work force, making America less competitive in the world economy.
While the children suffer this parental neglect, the state, in its rush to Reaganomics, has abdicated its responsibility to provide a safety net, she argues. "True, some children continue to be raised in supportive communities by thoughtful, attentive parents, but the larger fact is . . . an anti-child spirit is loose in the land."
As an economist and a former director of a labor-management think tank, the Economic Policy Council, Ms. Hewlett has gathered persuasive evidence to back up her argument. And where concrete illustration fails, she pelts us into submission with statistics.
The case she makes has dire implications. As the national work force shrinks, owing to the end of the baby-boom generation, employers are growing increasingly dependent on women and minorities. So we are caught in the proverbial vicious circle. In the short run, the problem of neglected children is exacerbated. In the long run, a consequently weakened work force is less and less able to fill increasingly demanding jobs.
Ms. Hewlett has imaginative solutions to these problems. But they depend on reversing certain trends in contemporary American culture, and here her book gets into difficulty. She blames the declining status of our children on a national spirit of "Now-now-ism," an unwillingness to sacrifice for the future.
She blames a new "therapeutic mentality," which "focuses on the self, rather than on a set of external obligations." She blames no-fault divorce laws that allow fathers too easily to escape paying for support of their children. She blames the political right for overvaluing the family, and thereby denying its need for state aid. She blames the left for undervaluing the family, by putting too much emphasis on individual fulfillment.
All of which may be valid so far as it goes, but it doesn't go very far. By calling the search for self the "therapeutic mentality," she sullies legitimate forms of psychotherapy, which demand transcendence of the self. More important, she has failed to grasp the root of whatever it is that has driven our age to self-indulgence, whether it be the bomb or the death of God or the accelerating pace of technological change or simply sunspots.
But then Ms. Hewlett has a tendency to simplify things. She writes of Tom Wolfe's recent novel about New York as if its title contained no irony: "Despite the excesses of the 1980's, when this nation built a great 'bonfire of the vanities.' . . ." Of course, that's exactly what this nation didn't do. And after a passage describing the profoundly complex problem of crack babies she appends the comment, "All of which could so easily be avoided." Oh, yes, so very easily.
Still, if one could reverse the flow of history by waving a wand, or by shouting from a rooftop, or by writing a book, her prescription would have enormous appeal. It would profit corporate America, she insists, to create a family-friendly workplace. Such policies would improve recruitment, reduce absenteeism, diminish turnover, increase productivity and enhance company image. In fact, they already have, she concludes, to judge from many coporate programs that have recently been started.
But "a thousand points of light" will not suffice, she writes. "Government cannot pass the buck and pretend that business can somehow 'fix' the problem of underachievement and failure among our children." So Ms. Hewlett calls for a Federal plan involving a "National Task Force on Children," "parenting leave," "prenatal and maternity care," "child care," "educational reform," "housing policy," "tax reform," "workplace policy," "divorce reform" and "volunteer efforts." Such a plan would not only pay, she argues, it would also be "the right thing to do."
Despite her evangelical tone and an occasional shallowness in her reasoning, what is compelling about Ms. Hewlett's case is her argument that America's greatest weaknesses of the moment could be turned to its advantage. Any investment now would eventually pay for itself and then some, she reasons. As Benjamin Franklin observed in Poor Richard's Almanack (1758), "What maintains one vice would bring up two children." Ms. Hewlett lends new life to this simply practical remark.
Some three decades later, in 1791, Georges Jacques Danton, the revolutionist, told the French Convention, "The time has come to establish the principle that children belong to the Republic before they belong to their parents." Ms. Hewlett's book revivifies this observation too. She wants a new revolution to happen. But she wants its cutting edge to be not the guillotine, but the restoration of the family.

HEADLINE: SOCCER;
Brazil Coach Inherits Tradition and Little Else

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO

 BODY:
After a decade of decline, when money, talent and fans were in short supply, Brazilian soccer has taken the first step in its effort to dominate the sport worldwide again.
The short-term goal is to win the 1994 World Cup, to be held for the first time in the United States. With that in mind, but with little in the way of resources to make it happen, the Brazilian Soccer Federation has placed its hopes on a new coach and hired Paulo Roberto Falcao to guide the team. 
 After enthralling fans in Brazil and Italy with his elegant style on the field in the 1970's and 80's, Falcao was appointed coach of Brazil's national soccer team late last year. Fans hope that he can do for soccer-crazy Brazil what Franz Beckenbauer did for West Germany in 1990: switch from star player to coach of a World Cup winner.
 
Those Were the Days
 But the 37-year-old Falcao has an uphill battle ahead of him. The country that produced three World Cup champions and some of the most creative soccer in the world now finds its game in deep crisis.
The days when Brazilian players were distinguished by their ability to use their feet for dazzling dribbling, their brains for sudden improvisation and their souls for almost poetic touches are gone.
These days, the Brazilian national team dazzles only for its inability to score goals or even make easy passes.
"There is a lack of talent here and in the rest of the world," Falcao admitted in a recent interview as his car made its way through a traffic jam in downtown Rio. "The country's unstable economic situation led clubs into financial crisis. They have no money to invest in the juniors category, where potential talents are developed."
 Moreover, leaders of the soccer federation have been criticized for putting more effort into keeping their positions in the organization than improving the team, as well as for the erratic nature of their scheduling. For example, schedules have been changed at the last minute, an enormous logistical imposition in a country so large.
The federation "is the stepmother of Brazilian clubs," says Marcio Braga, president of Flamengo, Rio's most popular team. "There is no way of making a strong team without strong clubs. Falcao has the skills to do a very good job, but he arrived at a very bad moment."
Modest enough to recognize that Brazil is no longer a soccer powerhouse, Falcao is working to put together a Brazilian team that blends physique and technique. The European style of playing -- faster and more physical -- has imposed itself on the game, obliging Brazil to de-emphasize its artistic style.
 Falcao is hampered by the fact that many of the best Brazilian players have gone to play in Europe. These clubs will not release the players for the Brazilian national team's warm-up games. So he is experimenting with different players from different clubs each time the national team plays a game. So far, however, the results have been less than impressive.
In 10 warm-up games for the current America Cup tournament in Chile, there were two victories, two defeats and six ties. There were signs of progress last month when Brazil beat Bulgaria, 3-0, in its best game since Falcao took over.
On Tuesday night, Brazil played its first match in the America Cup and defeated Bolivia, 2-1, at Vina del Mar, Chile. It will face Uruguay tonight in its next first-round game of the tournament.
"These scores don't bother me," Falcao said of the warm-up matches. "My goal is to win the 1994 World Cup. Until then, I have plenty of time. Meanwhile, I must work with what I have, and what I have are good players who need to be trained. Practice plays, step by step, until they know them by heart. Then -- and only then -- will they be able to create individual moves."
Falcao speaks from experience. In 1982 in Spain, he played in the midfield on the Brazilian World Cup team that was widely acclaimed as the competition's most talented. But it lost in the semifinals to Italy, the eventual champion. "At the time, we were efficient but not effective," Falcao says.
Falcao was born into a poor family in Brazil's southernmost state of Rio, Grande do Sul. During his childhood he played soccer on the street before joining the Internacional club, where his coach nicknamed him "the little maestro."
He became a professional at Internacional in 1972 and led the team to three national championships and three state championships.
In 1980 he moved to Europe, joining A.S. Roma in Italy for $3 million, and in 1981 led the team to its best showing in four decades. His performance during his four-year stay in Rome not only opened the Italian market to Brazilian players -- causing trouble for the national team he now leads -- but also earned him the nickname King of Rome.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Brazil's coach, Paulo Roberto Falcao. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Business and the Law;
Trying to Assess Court Nominee

BYLINE: By Barnaby J. Feder

 BODY:
IF Clarence Thomas is confirmed as an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court, he will be the only member of the current Court to have worked in a major company. For two and a half years in the late 1970's, Judge Thomas was an in-house lawyer at the Monsanto Company.
That background is one reason that business groups have high hopes that Judge Thomas, President Bush's nominee to replace Thurgood Marshall, will be a stronger voice for their interests. 
 Mr. Thomas's brief career as a judge provides a scanty track record, and much of the guessing about him is based on his seven years as head of the Equal Opportunity Commission under President Ronald Reagan. During those years, the commission sharply reduced the number of class actions it filed under anti-discrimination laws, focusing instead on individual claims that were far less burdensome to industry.
One hope of the business community is that Judge Thomas, if confirmed, could help put more business cases on the docket. Four of the nine Justices must vote to hear a case before it is added to the court's calendar, and it is widely assumed that business cases were not a high priority of Justice Marshall.
"We have trouble getting some important cases heard," said Stephen Bokat, general counsel for the United States Chamber of Commerce. "This may make a difference."
How Judge Thomas's business background influenced him is unclear, but some lawyers who have appeared before him in the Court of Appeals on business cases in the last two years say he has demonstrated a grasp of the commercial details. "He asked a lot of real-world questions," said Richard Leighton, a Washington lawyer who represented Alpo Pet Foods Inc. in an appeal of complicated litigation with the Ralston Purina Company.
Judge Thomas's opinion in the Alpo case overturned a $10.4 million award against Ralston that had been based on its profits. He laid out an alternative approach to measuring damages that could eventually result in a higher award for Alpo.
The ruling also limited an injunction that had prevented Ralston not just from advertising its disputed claims that its pet food produced stronger bones in dogs but also from presenting papers on the theoretical basis for the claims at scientific conferences. And the opinion set out an extremely tough standard for proving that a company had willfully violated the Lanham Act, the Federal statute governing the advertising in the case.
"It's turned out to be the leading Federal case on false advertising damages and the subject of several Lanham Act seminars," Mr. Leighton said.
The Alpo case suggested that Judge Thomas might be sensitive to inhibitions on academic and commercial speech. So did his support of the opinion in May by Chief Judge Abner Mikva, one of the District of Columbia Circuit's noted liberals, overturning legislation backed by the Bush Administration that would have banned televised broadcasts of indecent material. Siding with broadcasters and civil liberties groups, the court said the Constitution's protection of free speech required that some window of time when few children would be viewing should be available for such broadcasts.
The Alpo case was the first indication that suggests that Judge Thomas may have conservative views about the use of punitive damages in commercial cases. He later sided with Judge James Buckley in a 2-to-1 ruling opposed by Judge Mikva that set aside a $50 million punitive damages award against Korean Air Lines in connection with the downing of a plane in 1983 by the Soviet Union.
As an appeals court judge in Washington, most of the non-criminal cases Judge Thomas has heard have involved litigation over decisions -- or refusals to make decisions -- by Federal agencies. He has a mixed record in cases where business and Government interests have clashed.
His votes suggest, for instance, that publishers and broadcasters stand little chance of winning his support in efforts to get Government agencies to turn over information under the Freedom of Information Act. On the other hand, he strongly rejected the Government's efforts to impose a heavy burden of proof on two oil drilling equipment companies that their merger would not be anti-competitive. In another case, he joined two colleagues in rejecting the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission's decision that a contract between two power companies was so unambiguous that the agency did not have to hold a hearing on a dispute between them.
"He was quiet for a long time and then weighed in heavily, quoting from memory a portion of the contract that challenged the agency's attorney," said Bernard Wruble, a Washington lawyer who represented the Cajun Electric Power Cooperative in the case.
In another case that some lawyers say indicated a pro-business stance, Judge Thomas last month upheld the Federal Aviation Administration approval of plans to expand an airport near Toledo, Ohio, which would clear the way for an air freight company to move there from South Bend, Ind. His opinion said the agency had not abused its authority in accepting an environmental impact statement that focused solely on the Toledo area.
The case was not the only one in which Judge Thomas read environmental laws narrowly. In Cross-Sound Ferry Services Inc. v. Interstate Commerce Commission, he said Cross-Sound had no right to get the I.C.C. to review the environmental impact of a new company, Viking Starship, that planned a ferry service across Long Island Sound.

HEADLINE: De Klerk's Victory;
Without Resolving the Issue of Power, Pretoria Regains World Acceptance

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, July 10

 BODY:
With the lifting of American economic sanctions against South Africa today, President F. W. de Klerk has received the most significant foreign endorsement yet of his contention that the dismantling of apartheid that he began last year will not be reversed.
 By leading South Africa back into international acceptance after years of isolation for its racist policies, Mr. de Klerk is fulfilling his promise to whites that the respectability gained will outweigh their loss of privilege over the black majority. 
 Yet the pressure is being relaxed on Pretoria when black South Africans still have no vote and no power in a Government that remains white-dominated, a contradiction that the African National Congress and other proponents of continued sanctions were quick to point out today.
 
Impact of U.S. Move
 Political and business analysts here say that the impact of Mr. Bush's decision is more likely to be more immediately apparent on the political climate here than on foreign trade and investment, even though expectations that the sanctions would be lifted sent stocks soaring today on the Johannesburg stock exchange.
"It is a re-entry and acceptance back into the international community," said Wayne Mitchell, the executive director of the American Chamber of Commerce here. "It's going to build business confidence."
The white euphoria, however, was not shared by the African National Congress and other black organizations, which warned that the lifting of sanctions was premature and could embolden the Government to drag its feet on a transition to majority rule. They pointed out that blacks have no vote yet and have been left impoverished by apartheid.
 
Benefits to Blacks Stressed
 But Mr. de Klerk, in a statement tonight, stressed that blacks would benefit from an expanding economy unfettered by sanctions.
"The removal of these sanctions," Mr. de Klerk said, "will contribute to the revival of our economy to the benefit of all South Africans -- especially those disadvantaged South Africans who have borne the brunt of sanctions, including many of the unemployed."
Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha, who read Mr. de Klerk's statement to a news conference, said the most important thing about Mr. Bush's message was its psychological impact in Africa and worldwide.
"It is his expression of his belief in the irreversibility of the process of change in this country and his belief that the time has come for South Africans to be encouraged to go to the negotiating table and draw up a new constitution," Mr. Botha said.
The lifting of sanctions by Washington is an awkward setback for the African National Congress, which wanted the sanctions maintained. At its national conference last week, Nelson Mandela said the congress needed sanctions as a weapon "until a democratic constitution has been adopted."
The congress, in a statement read by its new secretary general, Cyril Ramaphosa, said Mr. Bush's decision was premature because political violence continues to inhibit free political activity and because many political prisoners remained in jail.
"Progress should be judged not only by fine words but by actual deeds, and such progress cannot be determined by the South African Government nor accepted on its word alone," Mr. Ramaphosa said.
The more radical Pan-Africanist Congress called Mr. Bush's announcement "a sugar-coated poison tablet" and said it would press for other sanctions to continue "until all vestiges of white racist minority rule have been removed and the masses of our people have placed in power a government which truly represents them."
The South African Council of Churches, which is aligned with the African National Congress, also criticized the American action.
"Unfortunately, the struggle is not over yet and we fear that the premature lifting of sanctions will mean that one of the major incentives motivating the South African Government to change, will be lost," said the council's secretary general, Frank Chikane.
But the leader of the more conservative Inkatha Freedom Party, Chief Mangosuthu Gatsha Buthelezi, described the American action as the best news in years. Chief Buthelezi has long opposed sanctions.
Since Feb. 2, 1990, President de Klerk has legalized the African National Congress and other anti-apartheid organizations, released Nelson Mandela and other political prisoners, lifted the national state-of-emergency regulations, drastically curtailed security legislation, invited black leaders to negotiate the country's future and secured the repeal of major apartheid laws.
The Bush Administration contended that by doing so, Mr. de Klerk fulfilled the conditions for the repeal of the Comprehensive Anti-Apartheid Act, though he maintained that he was not moving to get sanctions lifted.
Mr. Botha said he hoped other countries now would follow suit and lift their own sanctions.
Earlier this year, the European Community announced plans to lift its bans on imports of iron, steel and gold coins, but this was subsequently blocked by Denmark's refusal to go along with the other 11 member nations.
South Africa's trade with the rest of Africa has already reached $4 billion a year. At its summit conference in Nigeria last month, the Organization of African Unity also said it would review its sanctions policy "should the South African Government adopt measures which lead to positive, profound and irreversible change towards the abolition of apartheid."
Japan, which has an annual trade turnover with South Africa of about $4 billion, also promised to review its sanctions policy after the apartheid legislation was scrapped, but Tokyo was believed to be waiting for Washington to make the first move.

HEADLINE: Penelope Leach

 BODY:
To The Home Section:
In "Growing Up with Help from Penelope Leach" [June 13], Carol Lawson wrote that Dr. Leach has been criticized by members of the American child-care establishment for saying that "something like full-time mother care for several months is best for a new infant." 
 Actually, the two experts you quoted did not refute this point, but simply stressed that such care is not often possible due to economic and other pressures.
I, however, appreciate Dr. Leach's clear and unapologetic focus on what is best for an infant.
How tragic it would be if we all dismissed her advice on the basis of its "impracticality" rather than its substance!
 
NISHA ABKARIAN SHRIER
