SECTION: Section A; Page 14; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1537 words

HEADLINE: Small Towns Grow Lonelier as Bus Stops Stopping

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEDALIA, Mo.

 BODY:
Until the strike came, the silver and blue Greyhound Americruisers rumbled in from St. Louis and Kansas City and helped keep this shrinking city of 19,800 connected to the world outside. About 50 people a month boarded the bus at the two-room brick station that Jim and Rita Fairfax built four years ago.
Today, the bus station is a laundromat. Mary F. Pummill, a widow who is legally blind, once could walk to the station and get a bus any day of the week. Now she has to rely on a twice-a-month shuttle bus primarily for elderly people when she wants to see her doctors in Columbia, about 60 miles away. Charlotte Williams, who retired to Sedalia from Chicago three years ago, said she now gets rides from friends to bus and train stations 30 miles away or more or pays high taxi fares. 
 "If you're here and you don't have somebody to take you somewhere, you're here," said Mrs. Fairfax, whose husband has moved a bail bond business into the building.
Sedalia, home of the Missouri State Fair and reputed birthplace of Scott Joplin's ragtime rhythms, was a stop on a 110-mile route across Missouri that Greyhound abandoned on March 2, 1990, the day its drivers went on strike for higher wages. Overnight five small cities lost all service, probably for good, and the state capital of Jefferson City, which is also on the route, has next to none.
 
Rural America Hardest Hit
 The strike, which immediately wiped out a dozen or so similar routes linking small American cities and towns, continues to this day. Nonunion drivers handle the trips that Greyhound still makes. The bus company estimates that 95 percent of the passengers it served when the strike started still take the bus.
But most of those passengers live on the East and West Coasts. Industry analysts say the company has abandoned about 400 of the 3,800 places that it regularly used to serve. Small independent operators have taken over some routes, but service to others has been lost.
Some bus routes were bound for extinction anyway, and the strike simply hastened the inevitable. "Where it's declined is in rural America," said Robin Diamond, spokeswoman for the American Bus Association, "and the reason is that the population just isn't there to support the bus."
Even those communities that were directly affected by the strike have not been crippled by it. Rather, the Greyhound walkout simply joins the array of other social and economic forces that have turned the downtowns and courthouse squares of these little places into somnolent artifacts. Long gone in Sedalia are the good-paying jobs along the now-desolate railroad sidings here. So are other jobs on increasingly mechanized farms.
Most passengers on the Sedalia route were transients, college students, the poor and elderly, Amish farm families, inmates on leave from prisons or servicemen on leave from Whiteman Air Force Base. They could not drive or did not have cars.
Now they can take taxis or hitch rides to a station in Boonville, 40 miles away, but the bus that stops there can't take them to their friends and relatives who live along the old route through here. An Amtrak train stops here, but it goes to none of the other abandoned towns on the route, and it usually costs more.
Mayor Steven J. Dust of Sedalia has heard little alarm -- perhaps, he speculated, because people who need the bus do not know how to make themselves heard politically. Or perhaps, he said, they had come to accept the writing on the wall, with the erosion of interstate bus service over many years.
Until the early 1980's four buses, two going east along Highway 50 and two west, went through Sedalia. Then the service was halved. And months before 6,300 Amalgamated Transit Union drivers walked out, Missouri granted Greyhound approval to end its service here in late 1989 on the ground that it was a chronic money loser.
 
Number of Routes Halved
 The company will not say how many American communities have been stranded. But as examples of other deserted routes it mentions a 90-mile stretch of Route 40 in Indiana; a 100-mile run in Wisconsin from Ashland to Minocqua; and one in Alabama running 75 miles south on Route 43 from Eutaw, southwest of Tuscaloosa, to Thomasville. Along each line, typically, five or six towns lost the bus.
These recent closings are just the latest by the bus industry that have reduced the number of sites where buses stop from 20,000 two decades ago, to 15,000 in 1983, to around 9,000 now, according to industry estimates.
The old Missouri route started about 75 miles west of St. Louis, along Interstate 70, turning south on Highway 54, with a stop in Fulton, the first of the abandoned cities but still close to the interstate.
The toll of the loss starts to build where the bus turned west at Jefferson City onto Highway 50. There, at the station Greyhound abandoned, an independent company provides two buses a day, one heading north and one south, but nothing goes east and west on the old Greyhound route.
 
Forgotten Villages
 From the capital this time of year, the bus would roll west past prairie hills and farms; past fields now dotted with four-foot-high rolls of freshly harvested hay; past emerald-green, half-grown corn; past motionless ponds and patches of oak, alongside the Union Pacific tracks carrying 50-car freight trains.
It made regular stops in California, Tipton, Sedalia and Knob Noster, site of the Whiteman Air Force Base. It also made flag stops, letting people wave it down, at villages of a few hundred people, like Saint Martins, Centertown, McGirk, Syracuse, Smithton, Dresden and La Monte.
At Tipton, a highway sign announces "a friendly place to live and work" with a population of 2,377. Geneva Fischer, a 66-year-old widow who recently retired after 35 years as office manager of The Tipton Times, the local weekly newspaper, is among Greyhound's stranded.
Mrs. Fischer said she is fearful of driving and does not feel competent to drive anywhere but around Tipton. Without the bus service, she sees her son from Jefferson City when he drives over, but she rarely sees her sister in Sedalia, whom she used to visit every month or so. "Now we use the telephone mostly," she said.
 
Competition From Airlines
 The demise of bus service here and in many rural communities occurred for many reasons. One was the spread of the interstate highway system in the 1950's and 60's, which drew development and businesses from small downtowns to highway interchanges. Another reason was the deregulation of airlines in the 1970's and bus lines in the 1980's. And the formation of Amtrak in 1971 brought a slow resurgence of passenger rail service.
Over some big-city to big-city routes, airlines drove fares even below those of buses. To survive, the bus companies drove down their own fares, leaving them with less of a cushion from high-profit routes in the populous West and East to maintain the more costly service in the thinly populated Middle West.
Except for cars, though, the intercity bus still covers much more ground than the competition. A study two years ago by Robert R. Nathan Associates, an economics consulting firm in Washington, found that compared with 10,000 communities where buses stopped in 1987, the last year studied, scheduled airlines reached 477 and Amtrak 498.
"Roughly a third of Greyhound passengers begin or end a trip in a rural or small town area," said Frederic D. Fravel, a transportation consultant in Bethesda, Md., who did a study of the industry for Greyhound last year. "There is a market out there, and that market hasn't disappeared. If the industry could hold costs down, it could probably make money." Government subsidies approaching the magnitudes given airlines and Amtrak to service rural areas would help, he said.
 
'A Managed Shutdown'
 For Charlotte Williams, Sedalia seemed a desirable retirement spot after a career as an administrator for Swift and Company in Chicago. She determined that from Sedalia, she could take the bus to visit relatives in other parts of Missouri and in Texas.
Living in Chicago, Miss Williams said she never felt a need to drive, so she never learned. She can still get back to Chicago by train, but otherwise she is now largely confined to Sedalia unless she wants to hire a taxi to drive her 30 miles to the nearest bus stop.
Miss Williams blames both the company and the public authorities. Citing Greyhound's slow reduction in service before the abandonment, she said: "I think it was a managed shutdown. And I think the city of Sedalia just sat back on its haunches and let it happen."
But how can a city official persuade a company that it ought to keep picking up four dozen people a month? Inevitably, the demise of Greyhound service invites questions here of the conflicting interests of private gain and public need.
"As a business person, I am absolutely convinced that the economics of bus service to Sedalia, Mo., simply do not work any more," said Mayor Dust, who is also a builder.
"But I think there are people who lost a great deal of mobility," he said. "I think it has left a group of people in our community without any public transportation at all."

SECTION: Section A; Page 20; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 527 words

HEADLINE: Iraq's Nuclear Menace

 BODY:
Ever so grudgingly, Iraq now admits that it was conducting a secret uranium enrichment program, thus tacitly conceding it was hellbent on making nuclear arms. Worse yet, it's still trying to conceal a starker truth, that it has come closer to making a bomb than the U.S. suspected.
That shocking news, from knowledgeable Iraqi defectors, reveals that Saddam Hussein remains a regional threat despite the crushing defeat that was supposed to have neutralized him. Even a single nuclear bomb in the hands of a ruthless dictator is menace enough. A nuclear production capability, if undetected, could multiply the risk of attacks and of nuclear blackmail. 
 The newly understood danger is rightly prompting the U.S. and its Persian Gulf war allies to reconsider how best to disarm Iraq of its terror weapons once and for all. But the dismaying fact is that no sure-fire method exists. Bombing Iraqi nuclear facilities during the war failed to destroy all the nuclear materials.
Trying to eliminate Saddam Hussein might backfire. If he feels himself a target, the Iraqi strongman will have little incentive to hand over his nuclear materials. The best answer is to gain international support for more vigorous inspection and for keeping the pressure on Iraq.
The latest revelations surprised many intelligence experts. Before the war, Iraq was judged to be 5 to 10 years away from a full-fledged nuclear arsenal and bomb-making capacity. The more imminent threat came from 100 pounds of known weapons-grade nuclear material that was checked periodically by international inspectors; by worst-case assessment, it could have been turned into a bomb in a year or less.
What's new is that Iraqi informants have told U.S. intelligence of a clandestine electromagnetic process Baghdad was using to separate weapons-grade material. The process has already produced about 90 pounds of uranium, some of it highly enriched. That's enough to make a bomb. And it shows that Baghdad is still lying when it claims to have produced only one pound of enriched uranium clandestinely.
The need to keep nuclear weapons out of Iraq's hands grows more urgent. But none of the three main options look very promising. Bombing nuclear sites, while superficially attractive, is no more likely to eliminate Iraq's nuclear capability than it did during the gulf war. Iraq has been squirreling away uranium and other nuclear material, making it difficult to target. And some of Iraq's nuclear facilities are concealed and hardened.
Another, facile option is to overthrow or kill Saddam Hussein. The U.S. has tried decapitation and failed. And even success wouldn't stop his successor from building the bomb.
The least bad choice is more aggressive use of inspections to find and remove nuclear facilities and material. More inspectors might help. So would rewards for informants. And the international coalition can press Iraq to comply by maintaining tight economic sanctions and, if that fails, threatening renewed bombing of military targets.
Saddam Hussein has to know that the world is ready to resume bombing rather than see him get away with bomb-making.

SECTION: Section A; Page 20; Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 409 words

HEADLINE: Help, Someone, Make New York an Affordable Place to Live

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The annual Rent Guidelines Board follies have closed (news item, June 25) without satisfying anyone. Nor could they have, in today's economy in New York City. On one side are the landlords, whose property taxes are undoubtedly going up, and on the other are the renters, many of whom have been in the same six-room apartments since marriage after World War II, through child rearing and now retirement. 
 Whoever is paying less than $1,000 a month for a one-bedroom apartment has obviously had it for more than 10 years. And those paying more are finding themselves in what were originally built as large studio apartments with sleeping alcoves that have been partitioned to make bedrooms with wall-to-wall bed, so landlords could get higher rents.
The board hasn't decided yet whether it should include the thousands of apartments originally built as condominiums in its vacancy figures. All of these buildings have become rental space by default, thanks to the high prices asked for them. As we all know, these were all planned and ground was broken for them when there were many more affluent New Yorkers. The Battery Park City project, South Street Seaport, Worldwide Plaza were all begun and built when "yuppies" flourished, and there was an influx of people into the city.
Now that many have fled New York, we see signs that haven't been seen since the early 1970's: "For Rent" in building windows and rental agents at high-rise apartment buildings. Today landlords, unlike the situation even two years ago, are willing to pay brokers' fees for renting apartments. Warehousing is now a losing proposition.
Greed is obviously built into today's rentals; landlords stuck with "sponsor" apartments are trying to recoup their costs, plus. Even though rents have gone down on "luxury" apartments, they are still expensive, and rent-controlled tenants are still sitting in oversized, low-price apartments. And who can blame them?
Despite the increase granted for the new leases, many landlords will be unable to raise the rents because even 4 percent will turn out to be the breaking point for many tenants. So, we are back to the usual -- high rents and immovable tenants. It would seem the only solution is a commission of impartial people who could come up with a plan to help landlords as well as tenants, and make New York City a desirable and affordable place to live.
 
YVONNE R. FREUND
New York, June 27, 1991

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
GTE in Pact to Build Soviet Phone Service

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The GTE Corporation said yesterday that it had entered into an agreement with American and Soviet interests to build and operate a telephone and facsimile service linking Moscow with North America, Western Europe and Asia.
Details on the value of the venture, to be called Sovintel, were not disclosed. 
 The American portion of Sovintel is a partnership called Sovinet, which consists of the GTE International Communication Services Corporation, a GTE subsidiary, and San Francisco/Moscow Teleport, a private company.
GTE said Northern Telecom Inc. of Canada would provide digital switchboards and other materials for the digital-network service, which will begin commercial operation in November.
Sovintel said it expected its primary users to be executives from the United States, Japan and Europe. Users will have to pay hard currency to use the service, rather than rubles, Sovintel said.
GTE said Sovintel would "help speed the Soviet economic transition by servicing pent-up demand among worldwide corporate representatives in Moscow for instant, high-quality communications."
The venture initially will use microwave and satellite communications to link four hotels in Moscow and the city's Expocenter with public telephone networks in the rest of the world.
The five locations will be equipped with digital switches and microwave links for connection with Sovintel's international gateway, GTE said.
In trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, GTE's shares rose 12.5 cents, closing at $29.75.

HEADLINE: Volcano Is Unforeseen Third Party in Talks on Bases in Philippines

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 10

 BODY:
An Air Force assessment that the Mount Pinatubo eruptions have probably caused irreparable damage to American installations threatens to make moot a long-running dispute between the United States and the Philippines over extending the leases of two major military bases.
Since World War I, the Subic Bay Naval Station and Clark Air Base have been the hub of American military operations in Asia, and have provided jobs for hundreds of thousands of Filipinos, either directly or in bars and massage parlors around the bases. The bases' demise could put an end to an important vestige of the colonial past. 
 But today, with the end of the cold war, many military analysts think the bases' strategic value has declined, and, according to an Administration official, their repair could cost hundreds of millions of dollars.
Anti-American protests and a year of difficult negotiations to extend a 1947 base treaty had already put the future of the bases in doubt. With the leases expiring in mid-September, the Administration has offered to pay $360 million in annual compensation for an extension of 10 to 12 years. Manila is seeking $825 million a year for a seven-year extension. A new round of negotiations is scheduled for Manila next week.
Both sides say the bases would be phased out after the next extension. But now that an Air Force survey team has found that Clark Air Base is probably too severely damaged by the volcanic eruptions to be rehabilitated, officials in the Administration and Congress are beginning to reconsider whether the United States needs any extension at all.
 
'Quite Pessimistic'
 The Administration official, who is involved in the negotiations, said the Air Force assessment, which is being prepared in a report that may be released next week, "is quite pessimistic," possibly "devastating." Officials said it was possible that Washington and Manila could come to an agreement on Subic Bay alone, although heavy damages there would complicate negotiations at that base as well.
American geologists are studying the viability of the continued use of the bases in preparation for the next round of negotiations, scheduled for the second half of this month. An American military damage-assessment team completed a separate survey of Clark Air Base last week, and is currently analyzing its findings at Pacific command headquarters in Hawaii.
About 300 Philippine contract workers are making preliminary efforts to clean up Clark, using shovels and earth-moving equipment to clear miles of drainage ditches. But Pentagon officials noted that most of their work was related to packing household goods of the base's 14,000 American evacuees.
"My sense is that there's absolutely no way for Clark to be reopened," said Representative Patricia Schroeder, Democrat of Colorado and the head of the House subcommittee on Military Installations, after a tour of the South Pacific region. "Congress is going to have an awful lot of trouble being convinced to spend millions of dollars to clean up a base near a volcano."
 
'Alternate Facilities' Urged
 She said the question of retaining Subic Bay was still open.
"The Congress will be reluctant to spend a few billion dollars to fix up facilities that we will be obligated to leave over the next several years," said Representative Stephen J. Solarz, the Brooklyn Democrat who is chairman of the House subcommittee on Asian and Pacific affairs. "We always could develop alternate facilities."
Several members of Congress said it was too early to assess the damage, but they predicted that the eruption would have a profound affect on the way the United States views the Philippines.
"This will move us away from a discussion of the bases as the sole reason we are involved in the Philippines," said Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana, a Republican member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, arguing that the United States should try to foster democracy and stability.
Clark Air Base, which is 12 miles from Mount Pinatubo, may never be viable again, as some geologists warn that the volcano could remain unstable for years to come. Clark is the primary refueling and service stop for the C-130 and C-5A aircraft that transport supplies to American forces in the Indian Ocean and Western Pacific, but it is a measure of changing Pentagon thinking that the fighter wing assigned to the base was withdrawn before the volcano even erupted. Pentagon strategists hope that the adjacent Crow Valley training range, the location for most extensive United States air bombing practice runs in Asia, could be retained even if the air base is closed.
The Subic Bay Naval Station, which is 35 miles away from Mount Pinatubo and sustained less damage, provides the Seventh Fleet with an extensive network of petroleum storage sites, supply depots and repair bases. A senior Navy officer described the base as "one-stop shopping."
 
Subic Seen as Mainstay
 American naval strategists say that Subic could remain the mainstay for the Seventh Fleet's repair, training and storage needs but that its services would be less valuable without the coordination from Clark. They also say that the Subic Bay services could be duplicated by the combination of those offered in Singapore, Guam and Japan.
A senior Navy officer involved in developing Asia strategy said that the Pentagon still believed that the Philippines offered the best location in the Pacific for the protection of sea lanes and access to potential flash points, "but few people here think we can't live without them." He added, "A lot depends on how much time it will take to write off the investment we will have to make to get them back up to speed."
For all the advantages it bestowed, the American presence in the Philippines has fostered an ambivalent relationship, with even many of those who benefit resenting the Americans for their sense of dependency on United States dollars and military protection.
Public opinion polls show that 60 percent of Filipinos would like the Government of Corazon C. Aquino to work out an arrangement with Washington to keep the bases. Some Filipinos say they need the American military presence to protect them against the Communist insurgency and possible army coups, and indeed Washington deployed fighter aircraft from the bases to help put down an attempted army revolt in December 1989. But the primary reason for the popularity of bases is economic. Nearly 80,000 Filipino are employed at the installations and hundreds of thousands of others depend on the bases for their livelihoods.
Nevertheless, the guerrillas use the bases as a nationalist issue, and many in the Manila elite, particularly intellectuals, say the Philippines will never emerge fully from its colonial past with tens of thousands of American soldiers and their dependents in the country.
Some members of the Aquino Government favor phasing out the bases as soon as possible, and whatever agreement is reached will probably face heavy opposition in the Philippine Senate, which will have to ratify it.
Rear Adm. Thomas Mercer, the top American military commander in the Philippines, said this week that the bases would be repaired. But State Department and Defense Department officials in Washington dealing with the Philippines disputed his conclusion. They said it was likely that operations at the two bases would be reduced or phased out more rapidly.
The Philippine Government is taking an even tougher public line on the negotiations despite the decreased value of the bases. "In the light of the events, the Philippines may have to upgrade the compensation because we suffered more than the Americans did," said the chief Philippine negotiator, Foreign Secretary Raul Manglapus.
"If we are to change the compensation at all, it will be to upgrade it, not reduce it," he said, insisting that scientists had assured him Mount Pinatubo's major eruptions were over.
Administration officials characterized Mr. Manglapus's comments as the posturing of a poker player who has picked up an unwanted card. "If I were the foreign minister of the Philippines," said a senior American Navy official, "I'd say the same thing."

HEADLINE: For Singapore Air, a New Direction

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
Making long-range plans and meticulously carrying them out are high among the strengths of Singapore Airlines executives and they have used those attributes often in making the carrier one of the world's most successful.
Now they're at it again, laying the groundwork for what could be their biggest challenge yet: the company's first flights from New York to Singapore, scheduled to begin in 1993. 
 "It's 24 months away, but you have to begin to plan for it now," said T. A. Hwang, senior vice president for American operations. "You cannot run an airline on a day-to-day basis. It takes 20 months to train a pilot and a number of years to train an engineer."
The training looks to be the easy part. More daunting for the airline and Mr. Hwang will be the task of changing some ingrained travel patterns to get travelers to consider going to East Asia by way of Europe.
"It's going to be difficult," conceded Mr. Hwang, who is based in Los Angeles. "Traditionally people have thought that they must go West to go East."
Then, again, the airline has for years persuaded travelers that it makes sense to fly to Singapore first even though their destinations are Hong Kong, Calcutta or Jakarta.
Such moves have long been a necessity for Singapore Airlines. Its home nation, with about three million people, supplies only about 20 percent of its traffic. So the airline has had to be able to draw travelers to many points in East Asia to support its growth and large size.
One way Singapore has done that and kept ahead of its competitors is by improving its highly regarded cabin service and amenities every few years. But Mr. Hwang acknowledges that it has become harder to find ways to distinguish its service from such strong competitors as Japan Airlines, United, Northwest and emerging challengers like All Nippon from Japan.
In fact, after adding amenities like telephones and creating a little more legroom, all the airlines have found it harder to outdo one another within the restricted space of an airplane. Singapore Airlines is now putting in an information system that tells flight attendants whether one of their frequent business travelers wants his Scotch on the rocks or prefers a certain wine.
Singapore Airlines has been profitable every year since it was founded in 1972. That includes its 1990-91 fiscal year, ended March 31, in which the airline earned $507 million. That included a time when even many of the world's stronger airlines had huge losses in the first quarter of this year as the war against Iraq cut travel and drove up fuel costs.
"It's a hard company not to like," said Rose Ann Tortora, an airline analyst for County NatWest. "It has so much money and pays so many of its bills ahead of time."
The airline has become synonymous with high-quality service in repeated surveys of business travelers, something that has helped it weather declines.
 
Preparing the Way
 For the New York service, Singapore is already preparing the ground carefully before making a move.
In the United States, Singapore Airlines now flies out of Los Angeles, San Francisco and Honolulu. When it begins service from New York it will probably be out of Kennedy International Airport. Service is not now planned from any other East Coast cities. The flights will stop in Frankfurt, which already is a European hub for Singapore, but passengers will not have to change planes.
No other airline now offers direct service from New York to East Asia via the Atlantic, although passengers can fly carriers like Lufthansa from New York to Singapore, connecting with Singapore Airlines' European hub. But the fares are much higher than on the Pacific route, making it unlikely that many travelers will choose the European route.
To help overcome the initial reluctance by travelers to travel to Asia via the Atlantic, Singapore will soon file for fares that are much lower than existing ones between the two cities for passengers who stop in a European city. The lower fares could take effect this year if Lufthansa or other connecting airlines agree. The idea is to try to get Asia-bound travelers used to flying in that direction in preparation for Singapore Airlines' 1993 service.
The distance to East Asia via the Atlantic is similar to the Pacific route and even shorter in the case of Singapore. But the business-class and first-class fares between New York and gateways in Europe are very high, sometimes higher than the leg from Europe to Singapore, which is a much greater distance.
 
Air Fares Compared
 A first-class round trip from New York to Singapore via the Atlantic, for example, costs $9,464. That is 67 percent higher than the same trip from New York via the Pacific, which costs $5,772.
The business-class fare via the Atlantic is $5,996 round trip, much higher than the range of $3,842 to $3,864 via the Pacific.
The disparity is not as great in discount fares, which run $1,400 to $1,500 round trip via the Atlantic, compared with $1,390 to $1,640 via the Pacific.
Singapore plans to file fares via the Atlantic that will be at about the same level as on the Pacific route. For the fares to go into effect, however, other carriers that fly the trans-Atlantic leg will have to adopt them. They may be reluctant to do so since it would dilute their own revenue.
Still, Richard Gomez, vice president of the Eastern division and Latin America, whose office is in New York, said that some major carriers would adopt the fares to attract extra traffic to their gateways in Europe at a time of low traffic and heavy discounting.
Direct comparisons of Singapore with other carriers is difficult. The Government of Singapore owns 54 percent of the airline, although there is little interference from the Government in operations. An additional 12 percent is owned by Singapore employees, while the rest is traded publicly.
 
Small Domestic System
 The airline does not have a big domestic route system like United States carriers, where fares are not regulated and competiton is more intense. Fares on international routes are set by the governments involved and governments usually act to protect their own carriers.
Ms. Tortora, the County NatWest analyst, said that other government-owned airlines like Air France had found it difficult to compete.
Change is now measured in small increments and refinements in service that most competitors are quick to match.
For example, seats are being installed in business class with four more inches of pitch. That will allow travelers to push them farther back for a more restful flight during 10 to 12 hours aloft.
The airline is also considering putting in small television sets in the back of seats. So far Mr. Hwang said management was not satisfied with the four-inch screens now available and were waiting for six-inch screens instead.
 
Lower Labor Costs
 Singapore does have a major advantage over competitors like Air France in lower labor costs.
Its flight attendants' salaries begin at $1,200 a month, a high wage in Singapore, where a factory worker averages about $500 a month. The salary is similar to what beginning flight attendants are paid by United States airlines under lower entry-level salaries that unions accepted to help upstart domestic carriers compete at the beginning of deregulation. American salaries rise quickly in subsequent years, however, and at many carriers the workers reach parity with other employees after a few years.
But the Singapore jobs are still in great demand, airline executives say.
"We get a lot of applicants and whittle it down," Mr. Gomez said. One drawback, though for the flight attendants, called "Singapore Girls" in the airline's long-running ads, is that they work under five-year contracts. The contracts can be renewed only three times. They cannot stay more than 15 years unless they are willing to take a job on the ground.
 
Learning Everyone's Name
 The contracts allow the airline to enhance its cabins with service proferred by young and attractive flight attendants who are trained to learn everyone's name on a flight -- even in coach. Singapore has a cabin crew of 19 for each Boeing 747, compared with 15 for carriers in the United States.
Most of the airline's 20,400 employees are also sent for retraining every year to make sure that service levels are kept high. The airline is the largest employer in Singapore.
Mr. Hwang said that the airline's viability and growth depended on Singapore's central location, enabling the carrier to offer convenient flights to most of the large Asian cities.
The airline has also fostered an image of safety by operating the most modern fleet in the world. The average age of its fleet of 44 planes, mostly wide bodied, is four years and seven months.
Airplanes are sold after 10 years and the new planes at the rate of four to five a year are continually being brought into service even when traffic falls off as in the recent Persian Gulf crisis. With a cash reserve of $1.13 billion, the carrier has a huge cushion to ride out downturns while keeping its expansion plans on track.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Declines Marginally As German Rate Talks Near

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell marginally against most currencies yesterday as speculation intensified about German interest rates in advance of today's meeting by officials of Germany's central bank.
Currency traders said the dollar's slight fall was partly the result of profit taking, but also reflected jitters that the German Bundesbank might raise key interest rates after its policy-making council meets. Higher rates in Germany would make the mark worth more against the dollar and other currencies. 
 Mike Faust, a foreign exchange analyst for MMS International Inc., said the speculation was fueled by comments yesterday from Bundesbank officials that key German rates should rise to curb inflation.
"If you were lookng for a rate hike tomorrow, you had to be a little bit encouraged," he said.
The Japanese yen held its own against the dollar in the face of that nation's embarrassing brokerage scandal. Yesterday, Japan's Finance Minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto, said he would take a pay cut and discipline subordinates for failing to adequately police the stock market.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose 0.06 yen, to a close at 138.66 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a lower rate of 138.50 yen, and in New York, the dollar bought 138.59 yen, slightly less than late Tuesday's 138.76.
The British pound was the only major currency that weakened against the dollar. In London, the British pound held steady at $1.6215. But in New York, sterling closed at $1.6223, slightly less than late Tuesday's $1.6233.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday, included: 1.8130 German marks, down from 1.8175; 1.5710 Swiss francs, down from 1.5759; 6.1520 French francs, down from 6.1660; 1,350 Italian lire, down from 1,352.55, and 1.1481 Canadian dollars, down from 1.14825.

HEADLINE: Airline Traffic Posts 12% Drop

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: GENEVA, July 10

 BODY:
Dampened by war and recession, international passenger traffic on 200 leading airlines fell an average of 12 percent in the first five months of the year, an industry group said today.
Airlines also lost $2.5 billion from January through March, the group, the International Air Transport Association, said. 
 The Persian Gulf war, which increased fears of terrorism, curtailed international travel early this year.
But the recession in the United States and several other industrial countries continues to cut into business travel, the airline industry's greatest profit source, the group said.
"I cannot yet talk about light at the end of the tunnel following the gulf crisis," said Gunter Eser, the agency's director general.

HEADLINE: India's Chief Urges U.S. Investment

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, July 10

 BODY:
The newly elected Prime Minister of India urged the United States today to erase "old perceptions" about India, and expressed blunt interest in increasing sharply American economic and political links.
The Prime Minister, P. V. Narasimha Rao, said in an interview that "the sky's the limit," in terms of potential American investment. Mr. Rao expressed hope that trade with the United States would "improve vastly." 
 And he said that closer United States-India political ties were crucial, especially in the aftermath of the turmoil in the Soviet Union and the dissolution of the Soviet grip on Eastern Europe.
"We will do everything to make the relations closer," Mr. Rao said of the United States and India, adding that the "old perceptions" by the United States that India was hostile to Washington and leaned toward the Soviet Union were outdated and irrelevant.
 
Changing Perception of India
 Although relations improved somewhat under former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi and his successors, Mr. Rao's positive comments about India-America ties were the most explicit so far and reflected India's yearning for a closer alliance with the United States and the rest of the West.
"The perception of India in the United States has been one of a Soviet ally, being closer to the Soviet Union, so close that the United States did not like it," he said. "After some years, this perception has slowly changed, although I cannot say it's changed completely."
"We have tried to convince the United States that India's friendship with one country is never at the expense of another country," Mr. Rao said. "I see relations with the United States as vastly improved now and coming still closer. I see a bright future in these relations. In every way, we would like to improve our relations in several fields of cooperation."
American officials in New Delhi expressed delight at Mr. Rao's comments -- his first to an American reporter since becoming Prime Minister less than three weeks ago.
 
India's Gulf War Stance
 An American Embassy official said tonight, "It sounds very positive and we look forward to working with Mr. Rao in achieving the objectives he outlined."
Ties between the United States and India had been marked by strain and even anger in the 1970's and the early 1980's, partly because India saw the United States as leaning toward Pakistan, partly because India's foreign policy and ideals often supported the Soviet bloc and seemed eagerly critical of the United States, and partly because India was strongly suspicious of American or multilateral business investments, seeing them as essentially rapacious.
Even in the Persian Gulf war, India angered the Bush Administration by refusing to give American military planes permission to refuel at Bombay International Airport.
"That was temporary and I don't think that will have a lasting impact," said Mr. Rao this afternoon.
 
'The New Situation'
 Seated in his spacious office in the red sandstone Parliament building, built in the heyday of the British Empire, Mr. Rao wore a white kurta shirt and trousers, with an elegant embroidered silk shawl over his shoulders. At 71 years old, and in uncertain health because of a heart ailment, the Prime Minister appeared somewhat frail but spoke in a firm voice and responded to questions rapidly.
Mr. Rao seemed especially eager to strike a positive note about India's relations with the United States, virtually acknowledging that ties had been marked by strain and misunderstanding over the years.

HEADLINE: Legislators Try for a Compromise In Connecticut Budget Deadlock

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, July 10

 BODY:
Lawmakers spent today crunching numbers, hoping to find some new combination that might break the deadlock over the state budget. And with the last few weeks littered with dead tax plans, there were plenty of options to pick over.
One plan that floated through the Capitol was being pitched as a compromise between the last compromise -- which died in the Senate last week -- and the proposal favored by the Democrats in the Senate, the ones who killed that last compromise. 
 The new, improved compromise would contain an income tax, thus mollifying Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., who has all but insisted on one. But the income tax would be much smaller, 3 percent to 4 percent, than either the Weicker income tax, which peaked at 6.75 percent, or the last doomed compromise, which carried a flat income tax rate of 4.75 percent.
It would not lower the state's 8 percent sales tax as much as those earlier plans, or eliminate entirely the separate taxes on dividends, interest and capital gains. Those new provisions were aimed at placating factions among the majority Democrats who have complained that overindulgent tax cuts of one kind or another would benefit wealthy families at the expense of middle-income taxpayers who would carry the main burden of a wage tax.
 
To Stimulate the Economy
 Connecticut has no broad-based tax on wages, but its other taxes are among the highest in the nation, especially the 8 percent sales tax, the 13.8 percent corporate profits tax and the interest and dividends tax, which peaks at 14 percent.
Mr. Weicker, a former Republican who was elected last November on his newly created Connecticut Party ticket, has identified as a central goal of his administration the lowering of those other taxes in an effort to stimulate the economy; the difference would be made up with the new income tax. In the last six weeks, the Governor has vetoed two legislative budgets that solved the state's revenue shortfall through non-income tax means, primarily an expansion of the sales-tax system.
But hardly anyone expressed much hope of any immediate breakthrough, now 10 days into the new fiscal year without a budget.
On Tuesday, majority leaders in the House tried to push Democrats to consider overriding Governor Weicker's veto of a budget that passed last week, but they couldn't even get support to try a vote on the floor. A planned House session today was canceled because there was nothing concrete to debate.
Lawmakers said an override vote might still be revived, however, if the new compromise fails to win support in the Senate over the next few days.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Trustee Chosen For Monarch

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BOSTON, July 11

 BODY:
Harrison J. Goldin, the former New York City Comptroller, has been appointed to serve as bankruptcy trustee for the Monarch Capital Corporation.
Mr. Goldin's appointment on Tuesday came two weeks after Monarch agreed to file for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. In late May, state insurance regulators seized control of the company's Monarch Life Insurance Company subsidiary. 
 In addition, Judge Herbert P. Wilkin of the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court has allowed the state to begin seeking offers for the life insurance company.
Monarch Life, which has about 250,000 policies, has continued to make payments on annuities and other insurance products. Monarch Capital once held $6 billion in assets before a declining economy lowered its real estate portfolio.
Mr. Goldin served as Comptroller for 16 years before establishing his own firm, Goldin Associates.

HEADLINE: Utah Driver's Long Fight for Her Name on a License

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SALT LAKE CITY

 BODY:
Wendy Jean Alldredge says she knows that life can sometimes be galling. But this took the cake.
After her divorce in 1988, she went to the Utah Driver License Division to change the last name on her driver's license from Jorgensen, her former husband's name, to Alldredge, the name she was born with. 
 She was told she would need her former husband's permission.
"This rubbed me the wrong way," she said, "to say the least."
When license officials told her to call her former husband, she retorted: "What my ex-husband thinks is irrelevant." Instead, she called a lawyer.
She filed suit against the Utah Driver License Division, charging discrimination against divorced women. But a Utah court and a Federal Appeals Court have rejected her claim.
Ms. Alldredge, a 36-year-old unemployed cashier and the mother of three children, said she had never before considered herself a feminist.
 
Sharp Change in Outlook
 "But this whole thing has made me look at things a little differently," she said. "If a poor woman like me has to fight just to get her own name back, I think we're in a sad situation."
Utah, like other states, allows a change of name at the time of divorce. But the Driver License Division says a woman cannot unilaterally change her name after the divorce; it requires an amendment of the divorce decree, which means getting the former husband's consent.
"It's offensive that she should have to ask her ex-husband," said Brian M. Barnard, Ms. Alldredge's lawyer. "It's obviously a sexist practice. It's part of the old, outdated notion that women become property of men upon marriage."
The license division said sexism was not the issue. Rather, they said, they were guarding against fraud.
Ms. Alldredge noted that with copies of her birth certificate and divorce decree, she has been able to change the name on her taxes, Social Security card and bank checks.
She and her lawyers said that the license division allows a woman to take her husband's name after marriage even though the marriage license does not specify a name change.
"But that's different," said Brian Gough, a spokesman for the division. "It's a tradition to take the husband's name in marriage."
Mr. Gough also acknowledged that other states have changed policies to allow name changes, after "the woman's lib thing."
The case has provoked indignation among women's groups. "It's just another example of the patriarchal society of Utah," said Rebecca J. Elliott, the executive director of the National Organization for Women in Utah.
The case hit close to home for Ms. Elliott. Fifteen years ago, she was a divorced woman attending college in Indiana. She had kept her husband's name because she had a child. But as her graduation drew near, the issue troubled her.
"I just didn't want his name on my diploma," she said, adding that she had no legal trouble making the name change.
 
Undeterred by Setbacks
 Ms. Alldredge said recently that she was planning to continue legal action. Her latest setback came a few months ago when a United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit, in Denver, upheld the Utah restriction by a 2-to-1 vote.
"A divorce decree without a specific name-changing provision is not an acceptable name change verification, " the majority opinion said.
In a dissent, Judge Monroe McKay wrote, "I can conceive of no legitimate interest which the State of Utah might have in making it simple for a woman to adopt a husband's name but difficult for her to shed it."
Ms. Alldredge, who married when she was 17 years old, attributed the ruling to "old-fashioned male judges who believe in a double standard."
She said her three children have supported her fight. Indeed, her 17-year-old daughter, Connie, now wants to change her name to Alldredge.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Wendy Jean Alldredge, who filed a discrimination suit after Utah authorities said she could not change her married name on her driver's license without her former husband's permission. (Tim Kelly for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Issues Rise as Rates Dip

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The reappointment of Alan Greenspan as chairman of the Federal Reserve helped to start a mild rally in the credit markets yesterday, as prices of Treasury securities rose and interest rates fell a bit.
Also lifting the markets were expectations that an inflation report expected today would show that price pressures were under control during June. 
 Yet another factor, analysts said, was a sharp rally in the dollar, which followed a decision by the German central bank not to raise interest rates.
Most economists are forecasting that today's report on producer prices will show that prices at the wholesale level were flat to down slightly last month, in large part because of a drop in energy prices. Excluding food and energy costs, the index probably rose by only one-tenth of a percent to two-tenths of a percent, according to most forecasts.
 
Rally Expected to End
 Based on the forecasts, "a lot of people are scared to be short in front on the numbers," one government securities trader said. But the trader said yesterday's rally was unlikely to continue for long.
"If the P.P.I. number is as expected, the market will resume its downward path," he said. "There is a lot of supply coming, and the danger is that the economic fundamentals could turn bad just as the quarterly refunding auctions get started."
Expectations are that the Treasury will sell $30 billion or more of new notes and bonds at the refunding auctions, which are to take place in early August. Concern about the amount of securities to be sold, and the market's ability to absorb the new paper, has been building for weeks. But some market participants said the worries were overblown.
"The new supply will be healthy, but not insurmountable," said Stephen A. Maher, executive vice president and general manager of the fixed income division at Nikko Securities International.
"I think we'll see a good response to the new issues, especially if bond yields are around 8.5 percent at that time. At those levels, I'm not so sure the Japanese won't be good buyers."
 
Interest in Notes
 Interest in the new seven-year notes, which were sold at an average yield of 8.25 percent on Wednesday, continued strong yesterday.
By late in the day, the new securities were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 8.15 percent, down from 8.21 percent late Wednesday.
The Bundesbank decision not to raise short-term rates came as something of a surprise. Some analysts had taken the view that the central bank might raise rates as a way of stemming the rise in the dollar.
A rate increase later on remains a possibility, but not for at least another month because German monetary policy makers go on vacation until mid-August.
"I think the world believes the Germans will revisit the issue of whether they will raise rates when they come back in August," said Brian J. Fabbri, chief economist and managing director at Midland Montagu Economics.
"But the direction around the world is for lower rates. And the more other countries lower their rates, the less reason Germany will have to raise their own to achieve the same benefits."
The improvement in Treasury prices began shortly after the German decision not to raise rates was announced, and continued through most of the day.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered in late trading yesterday at a price of 96 11/ 32, up 1/2 point, to yield 8.46 percent, down from 8.5 percent late Wednesday.
Among Treasury note issues, the 8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 98 5/32, up 10/32, to yield 8.27 percent. And the 7 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 7/32, up 2/32, to yield 6.87 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates were little changed.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.54 percent late yesterday, down one basis point, or one one-hundredth of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates dipped by a like amount, to a late offered rate of 5.66 percent.
A number of new corporate debt issues were priced in the investment-grade corporate bond market, including $150 million worth of two-year notes for CIT Group Holdings.
The 7.5 percent notes, which mature July 15, 1993, were priced at $100, or par, 58 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 percent two-year notes at the time of pricing.
Salomon Brothers acted as lead manager for the offering. The securities, which are noncallable for life, are rated A by Moody's Investors Service and A-plus by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Participants in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate issues said that prices of most securities rose by 1/8 point to 1/4 point in fairly brisk trading.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, prices of most widely quoted securities improved by 1/8 point to 1/4 point, traders said.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve Board said yesterday that M-1, the narrowest measure of the nation's money supply, rose by $3.5 billion during the week ended July 1, while its broadest measure, M-3, fell by $9.1 billion. M-2, the monetary aggregate most closely followed by the Fed, was unchanged.
With the exception of the big decline in M-3, analysts said the money numbers were in line with expectations. The report had no impact on prices in the credit markets.

HEADLINE: Bonior of Michigan Is Picked as 3d-Ranking House Democrat

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 11

 BODY:
House Democrats today elected Representative David E. Bonior of Michigan as whip, marking the fourth major shift in the Democratic Congressional leadership in five years.
After weeks of intense, behind-the-scenes campaigning, Mr. Bonior, a low-keyed insider tactician who served four years as chief deputy whip, defeated Representative Steny H. Hoyer of Maryland, chairman of the House Democratic Caucus. The vote, by secret ballot in a closed meeting of the Democratic caucus, was 160 to 109. 
 Mr. Bonior, 46 years old, will succeed Representative William H. Gray 3d of Pennsylvania after Mr. Gray leaves, probably in September, to head the United Negro College Fund. The whip is the third-ranking leader in the House, and the position has sometimes been a stepping stone to the posts of majority leader and Speaker.
In a preview of his role as a more visible Democratic spokesman, Mr. Bonior attacked the Bush Administration. "There is a tremendous frustration out there in this country," he said. "The frustration of a country in a deep -- and it is deep -- and prolonged recession, faced with an Administration whose only response to this is: It's no big deal." He also assailed the Administration for, in his view, not confronting the issues of health care, unemployment and the proportion of children living in poverty.
The choice today is not seen as having any particularly ideological implications. Both candidates are rather liberal, and the principal issue dividing them was Mr. Bonior's opposition to abortion. The race turned on more personal and political factors, from friendships to regional loyalties.
Mr. Bonior (pronounced BON-yer), a Vietnam veteran who is the son of an automobile worker, built on the 97 votes he received in 1989, when he was defeated by Mr. Gray in a hard-fought race for whip. He began campaigning for the job earlier than Mr. Hoyer, when speculation first arose that Mr. Gray was planning to resign, initially to seek the Pennsylvania Senate seat left vacant by the April death of Senator John Heinz in a plane crash.
At a news conference with other members of the leadership, Mr. Bonior recalled that the "the last couple of years have been difficult years for me." He noted his unexpectedly narrow re-election victory of 53 percent in 1988, as well as his loss to Mr. Gray.
"Out of those experiences," said Mr. Bonior, who is in his eighth term representing Mount Clemens, a Detroit suburb, "I learned something. I went home to my district nearly every weekend. I went to town hall meetings, to barbecues, to rotary clubs -- after 20 years in politics went back to knocking on doors."
Speaker Thomas S. Foley of Washington commended both candidates. "I think that we are a stronger party and a better focused and organized party and a more confident party because of this leadership contest," Mr. Foley said. "And this is an unusual thing to be able to say, frankly."
Beginning with the retirement of Speaker Thomas P. (Tip) O'Neill of Massachusetts in 1986, House Democrats have weathered turnovers in leadership. Mr. O'Neill was succeeded by Jim Wright of Texas, who resigned in 1989 after questions about his financial practices, and was succeeded by Mr. Foley. About the same time, Representative Tony Coelho of California resigned as whip rather than face an investigation of his investments. Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri was elected to succeed Mr. Foley as majority leader in June 1989, when Mr. Gray was elected whip.
Mr. Gray, the first black to serve in the House leadership, presented his successor with a whip today, telling him, "May you whip all those votes into line and pass all the legislation that's important to the leadership."
Mr. Bonier proved his skill at counting votes. He has predicted for days that he had support from about 160 colleagues. Mr. Hoyer had insisted that the race was neck and neck.
Mr. Hoyer said after the vote that the Democrats "were fond of us both and respected us both." He added, "They felt that Dave Bonior was the better candidate for majority whip."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Posts Broad Gains On Job and German Reports

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar soared against the German mark and other major currencies yesterday in response to a rosy United States report on unemployment claims and to news that Germany would not immediately raise interest rates.
Currency traders said they were relieved by the German decision after days of intense speculation that the Bundesbank might take drastic steps to hold the line on inflation. 
 The dollar initially fell when the Bundesbank's policy-making council said it would move to tighten monetary policy. But the reaction was more than offset by a subsequent announcement that the bank would forgo an immediate rate increase. In New York the dollar jumped more than two pfennigs against the mark, which like other currencies is supported by higher interest rates in its home country.
Further bolstering the dollar was a Government report of a sharp decrease in the number of Americans filing for state unemployment insurance in the last week of June. Claims fell to 388,000 in the week ending June 29 from the previous week's 423,000, the Labor Department reported.
In addition, traders said the dollar was supported by unconfirmed rumors that the United States was considering an air strike against Iraq in retaliation for the recent discovery that Saddam Hussein has far greater nuclear capability than United States officials first thought.
The dollar is considered a safe harbor in times of turmoil.
In London, the pound fell to $1.6065 from $1.6215 late Wednesday. It also fell in New York, where sterling fetched $1.6045, less than late Wednesday's $1.6223.
Overnight in Tokyo, the dollar rose 0.01 yen, to a closing 138.67 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a lower rate of 138.55 yen, and in New York, it closed at 138.65 yen, slightly more than late Wednesday's 138.59 yen.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday, included: 1.8345 German marks, up from 1.8130; 1.5900 Swiss francs, up from 1.5710; 6.2175 French francs, up from 6.1520; 1,363.00 Italian lire, up from 1,350.00, and 1.1483 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1481.

HEADLINE: Weaker Monthly Showing for Many Top Retailers

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH

 BODY:
Sales of America's biggest retailers turned erratic in June, reducing a euphoria that had been building from a strong showing in May that the recession was ending.
Retailers said yesterday that their total June sales held up, but nine of the 20 biggest reported lower or flat same-store sales from the levels a year earlier. In May, 13 of the 20 said that same-store sales rose. In total sales, for example, Sears, Roebuck & Company and the J. C. Penney Company were up 2.9 percent and 7.5 percent, respectively, but they had same-store declines of 3.8 percent and 8.2 percent from the year before. 
 During May, American consumers purchased considerable warm-weather clothing, as well as air-conditioners and fans, because of soaring temperatures in many parts of the country. This big trend removed some business that would have been transacted in June, retailers and analysts said, so that last month, at least in part, suffered from the strong May buying.
 
Recession Not Over Yet
 The slower June, they said, means that a clear end to the recession, at least in retailing, awaits a sustained improvement in spending.
Wal-Mart Stores, the nation's largest-volume retailer, continued its big thrust with an overall sales gain of 34 percent in June, to $3.49 billion, and an 8 percent advance in same-store sales. For the five months through June, total sales were up 37 percent, to $16.2 billion, and same-store sales rose 11 percent.
Wal-Mart edged ahead of Sears and K Mart in sales in February and has continued to increase its lead. In June, K Mart Corporation, the second largest in sales, reported a 6.8 percent gain in sales, to $3.28 billion, and a same-store gain of 2.2 percent. Year-to-date sales rose 8.9 percent, to $13.6 billion, with a same-store rise of 4.5 percent.
Sears's Merchandise Group, its stores and catalogue businesses, remained the industry's third-largest retailer, with June sales of $3.16 billion. Its year-to-date business declined 2.1 percent, to $13.28 billion. The cumulative same-store sales were down 2.7 percent from the previous year.
 
Sears Chairman's View
 Edward A. Brennan, Sears's chairman, said: "While double-digit increases continued in computers, women's fashion accessories and footwear, accompanied by strong sales in sportswear for both men and women, these gains were offset by slow sales in appliances and furniture. However, we are beginning to see a slight increase in customer demand for big-ticket durables, which should continue as the economy improves."
K Mart's chairman, Joseph E. Antonini, noted that the unusually warm May weather may have robbed June of some of its potential. "In May, aided by ideal weather conditions in the East and the Midwest, sales were strong, rising 8.5 percent on a comparable-store basis," Mr. Antonini said. "Clearly, this strength in May borrowed from June business."
If the weather element was excluded, he said, K Mart's May-June business was up 4.9 percent in same stores, ahead of the company's comparable first-quarter gain of 4.3 percent.
 
Mixed Results at J. C. Penney
 J. C. Penney's higher June sales totaled $1.21 billion, but the year-to-date sales were down 4.1 percent, to $5.41 billion, with a same-store drop of 5.4 percent.
The Woolworth Corporation's domestic sales rose 2.5 percent in June, to $474 million, although its same-store sales dipped six-tenths of 1 percent. Its cumulative sales rose 2.3 percent, to $3.72 billion, while same-store sales for the year to date were down 1.2 percent.
The big department store chains also had total gains but small improvements in same-store sales for June. The Dayton Hudson Corporation had a 9.3 percent sales gain in June, to $1.38 billion, but a 1.2 rise in same stores. The May Department Stores Company was up 6.1 percent, to $917.6 million, in June but was down nine-tenths of 1 percent in same stores.
One analyst, Kurt Barnard of New York, said the year-to-year comparisons were difficult. "Stores were up against unusually strong sales in June last year and couldn't hope to match them, given the recessionary environment," he explained.
But despite June's erratic trend, the apparel chains performed the best, indicating continuing consumer interest in seasonal clothes.
"I estimate that the apparel retailers had an average overall sales gain of 10 percent," said Cathleen W. Mackey, vice president for equity research at Dillon, Read & Company, New York. "But their same-store gains weren't uniformly good. One problem, I think, is that retailers held back too much on inventory, losing some of their summer business. An exception was the Limited stores division of the Limited, which had good stocks and so enjoyed its best monthly gain in more than a year."
The Limited Inc. had a total June gain of 20 percent, to $537.1 million, and a same-store gain of 8 percent. Its year-to-date sales were up 18 percent, to $2.26 billion, with same-store sales rising 4 percent.
The Gap Inc., also enjoying strong recent growth, had 23 percent higher sales in June, to $205 million, an 8 percent gain in same-store sales, and 24 percent higher cumulative sales, to $693 million, with a same-store rise of 8 percent.

Other Retailers' Sales
 By The Associated Press -- Following is a list of the sales figures reported yesterday by other of the nation's largest retailers:
 Melville Corporation's overall sales were up 19 percent for the five weeks ended July 6 and up 21.1 percent for the year. Same- store sales were unchanged for the five weeks and up seven-tenths of 1 percent for the year.
TJX Companies, up 8.5 percent for the five weeks ended July 6, up 15.8 percent for the year. TJX does not report same-store sales percentages.
United States Shoe Corporation, up 6 percent for the five weeks ended July 6, up 5.9 percent for the year. Same-store sales fell seven-tenths of 1 percent for the five weeks and two-tenths of 1 percent for the year.
Merry-Go-Round Enterprises Inc., up 29 percent for the five weeks, up 29 percent for the year. Same-store sales rose 7 percent for the five weeks and 10 percent for the year.

HEADLINE: New Jobless Claims Fall by 35,000 in Week

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 11

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing new claims for unemployment insurance fell by 35,000 in the final week in June, the Labor Department said today, pushing the total number to the lowest level since last September.
Economists said the decline, which was sharper than expected, showed that the labor market was improving as the economic recovery began. 
 The Labor Department said first-time applications for unemployment benefits fell to 388,000 for the week ended June 29 from 423,000 a week earlier.
"If this level is sustainable, and I believe there is good reason to think it will be, it obviously suggests the labor market is firming as the recovery gathers momentum," said Stephen Roach, senior economist at Morgan Stanley & Company.
The last time claims fell below 400,000 was in the week ending Jan. 5, when they dropped to 396,000, Mr. Roach said.
 
Number Getting Benefits Falls
 Economists also pointed to the large decline of 119,000 in the total number of people receiving benefits under state programs. The total fell to 3.4 million for the week ending June 22, the latest period for which data are available.
Christopher Rupkey, a financial economist at Mitsubishi Bank Ltd., said that the drop significantly reduced the total number of people receiving benefits from the week ended June 15, which is the week used to calculate the unemployment rate in June. The Labor Department reported last Friday that the unemployment rate climbed to 7 percent in June from 6.9 percent in May.
Mr. Roach said the claims data suggested that some companies were probably starting to recall workers. "That will add to income and consumption, the dynamics that add fuel to the recovery," he said.
The Labor Department said the latest decline brought jobless claims to their lowest level since the week ended Sept. 1, 1990, when 386,000 claims were registered.

HEADLINE: Fiscal Woe Takes Toll On the Arts

SERIES: The Budget Fallout; A periodic look at the effects of New York City's financial plan on various agencies and services.

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS

 BODY:
Increased admissions fees, staff layoffs, reduced hours and canceled days of operation: for New York City's cultural institutions, these are just some of the consequences of last week's severe budget cutting.
Last week, after the city's fiscal maneuvering had finally run its course, $24 million had been cut from the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs. The figure amounts to 28 percent of the department's $87 million budget for 1991. 
 For most of the city's better- and lesser-known cultural organizations, this means a reduction of one-fourth to one-third of the city's support for their operating expenses. Many staff members fear that even if they evade more severe cuts in the future, the current budget formula may become the status quo in the years to come.
 
Hoping It's Temporary
 The city's Cultural Affairs Commissioner, Mary Schmidt Campbell, said the city is still strongly committed to the arts. "I don't think that something fundamental has changed in our attitude toward cultural groups," she said. "We see our cultural organizations as a centerpiece of the city. We are hoping that this will be a temporary constraint in funding."
But many arts administrators, grappling with grim options for service reductions in 1992, fear that the unprecedented slashing of the arts budget represents a fundamental, and potentially devastating, change in the centurylong relationship of the city to its museums, theaters, botanical gardens, performance groups and other cultural ornaments.
The city has a long tradition of being an active partner in its cultural institutions, spending more on the arts than any other municipalitiy in the nation, city officials said.
Arts administrators say the change not only threatens the long-term survival of these institutions, but also the vitality of the neighborhoods that they have anchored, and the very position New York has as the cultural capital of the nation.
 
The Econimics of Art
 Furthermore, they believe that the future of the city's economy is linked to its cultural resources. "What would New York be without its cultural institutions, and who would ever want to come here without them?" said Harvey Lichtenstein, president and executive producer of the Brooklyn Academy of Music. "It's like Paris without the Louvre, London without Covent Garden."
In the final hours of last week's so-called doomsday-budget compromise, a strong push to restore arts financing was under way. The 28 percent cut in the department's budget was actually 19 percent less than the reduction in the executive budget offered by Mayor David N. Dinkins on May 10. That document had proposed an arts cut of 47 percent.
As grateful as they are for the $11.5 million that was restored, administrators in cultural organizations throughout the city were stunned by the new budget.
"No one is saying we shouldn't have shared in the cuts along with everyone else," said Dr. Alan J. Friedman, director of the New York Hall of Science in Queens. "But cuts of a fourth or a third will cause severe disruption of operations. This level of damage is really questionable."
For the staffs of hundreds of arts institutions and cultural agencies throughout the five boroughs, putting the cuts in effect is now a nightmarish occupation.
The New York Botanical Garden has already lost 35 percent of its security force in this, its centennial year. But the new 1992 budget cut of $1,626,769, or 31.6 percent of its city financing, means a "loss of 45 or 50 positions," said Gregory Long, president of the New York Botanical Garden. Those job losses primarily affect security guards, gardeners and maintenance workers.
The New York Botanical Garden is planning to close down part of its 250 acres -- the equivalent of closing a museum floor or wing -- because "we can't keep the whole property safe with fewer guards," Mr. Long said.
Some of the budget cuts seem aimed at creating even greater deficits. Not only will the New York Hall of Science in Queens lose $377,599 of its $1,407,056 city budget, but it also stands to lose $540,000 from a National Science Foundation Grant because the city has cut the "matching money" that must be put up by grant recipients.
The City Center theater in Manhattan, which has been dark since April and will not open until October, will be operating even less in 1992: fewer than 20 weeks, said Eugene Matta, director of capital planning.
As for the Brooklyn Academy of Music, which had 300,000 admissions last year, the 27.8 percent cut of $663,499 in its 1992 city budget means scaling back operations, and mounting "a lot of productions that are smaller in scale," Mr. Lichtenstein said.
The Brooklyn Museum, which sustained a cut of $2,046,134 from its $6.3 million city budget, is considering various reductions in services. The museum may be forced to close for part of the summer and may rotate temporary layoffs among the staff of 240.
A cut of $132,048 in the 1992 operating budget will force the Staten Island Children's Museum to curtail its hours and services. It will also bring about some "heartbreaking" layoffs, said Kate Bennett-Mendez, the executive director. One of the most efficient cleaning people on the staff, Laura DeFranco who has Downs syndrome, had to be let go on Friday, Ms. Bennett-Mendez said, "because she was our most recent hire."
 
Workers 'Losing Heart'
 Beyond the reductions that will be noticeable to the public, Mr. Long said, "We are in danger of losing a core of talented workers and managers at this and other institutions."
"They are losing heart," he said. "They would be a tremendous loss."
Beyond the impact on the institutions, many arts administrators fear the new budget will erode civic stability as well.
"Whole neighborhoods will be totally affected by the decline of our cultural institutions," said Mr. Long of the Botanical Garden. "For example, our gardens are a center of excellence and pride for the neighborhoods around us. Their streets are safer, there is less graffiti. Their businesses, and their property values, have benefited. All of that will be endangered if our property is abandoned and vandalized."
 
Hard-Pressed Foundations
 Some of the arts groups are counting on fund raising to make up the difference. The Brooklyn Academy, for example, Mr. Lichtenstein said, will try to raise $600,000 "from emergency fund raising, just to keep ourselves at the lowest operating level."
But increased corporate and foundation sources of income may not be available. "Arts institutions are turning more and more to the private sector, but donors and foundations are extremely pressed," said Sara L. Engelhardt, president of the Foundation Center in Manhattan, a nonprofit national organization that provides information for grant seekers.
Many corporate foundations have cut back because of the recession, she said, and increasingly, "the arts will compete with human services for money."
Money from the Deparment of Cultural Affairs goes to different budgetary groupings. One, the so-called Cultural Institutions Group, is a roster of 31 cultural institutions in the five boroughs in city-owned buildings or on city-owned land, including organizations like the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Bronx Museum. The department also finances more than 450 arts programs around the city, including the Dance Theater of Harlem and the Big Apple Circus.
Partnership Feared Endangered
Some cultural administrators are deeply concerned about the long-range implications of the 1992 budget. "The brilliant concept of public and private partnership that New York pioneered is endangered," said Mr. Long, who is also chairman of the city's Cultural Institutions Group.
He referred to the pact that was struck, he said, in 1877 between New York City and the American Museum of Natural History, in which the city agreed to provide the land, the buildings, the maintenance and the security, while the museum agreed to pay for assembling the collections and scientific staff.
This set the pattern, Mr. Long said, for the development of the Metropolitan Museum of Art (1878), the New York Botanical Garden (1891), The New York Zoological Society (1895), the Brooklyn Museum (1897) and the Brooklyn Children's Museum (1899). In this century, the pact governed the creation of dozens of other arts organizations.
"The phrase 'public-private partnership' is a trendy buzzword these days, but here in New York is the best working example of it you can think of," Mr. Long said. "It's worked so well for a century that it's made New York the cultural capital of the world. Yet now that public-private formula is being undermined."
 
The Series So Far
This series on the impact of the New York City budget began on July 4. The first article described how the Police and Fire Department were largely spared extensive cuts. On July 10, an article described how social services would be hard hit. Yesterday, an article described how schools would be severely strained.
