HEADLINE: U.S. and Florida Settle Suit on Everglades Water

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., July 11

 BODY:
The Federal Government and the State of Florida reached a tentative agreement today in a bitter lawsuit accusing the state of not enforcing its own environmental laws to safeguard the Everglades.
The agreement comes after two and a half years of intense resistance that cost the state $6 million in legal fees. 
 Under its provisions, Florida's Department of Environmental Regulation and the local water management district assumed responsibility for cleaning up polluted water before it flows into two large sections of the Everglades controlled by the Federal Government, Everglades National Park, at the southern tip of the Florida peninsula, and the Arthur R. Marshall Loxahatchee National Wildlife Refuge, just west of here.
 
Plan for Artificial Marsh
 The water is to be filtered through a huge artificial marsh that the state is supposed to create to the south of Lake Okeechobee, the headwaters of the Everglades. Water tainted with phosphorus and other nutrients from vegetable and sugar cane fields will be purified before it joins the main flow of water that sustains the Everglades.
The agreement, which the state has indicated it will sign, was annnounced at the West Palm Beach County administration building by the United States Attorney General, Dick Thornburgh, and Gov. Lawton Chiles.
It could influence attempts to protect other national parks and areas in other states where pollution from nearby roads, factories or residential developments damages the air, land and water within the parks' boundaries.
A lawyer for the Sierra Club Legal Defense Fund, Robert G. Dreher, called the agreement the most serious attempt to deal with this type of pollution in the nation. "We are going to see this used in efforts across the country to control runoff pollution," he said.
Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr., in a statement from Washington, called the agreement "the beginning of a new era of partnership designed to meet the goal of responsible stewardship of our public lands."
Mr. Thornburgh said the agreement was a significant step in the efforts to save the Everglades. The Federal Government has begun a huge project to repair the Everglades by restoring the natural flow of the Kissimmee River and elevating highways so water can flow freely beneath them.
 
Huge Buffer Zone
 Today's agreement calls for the creation of a marsh or buffer zone of at least 34,700 acres to remove as much as 70 percent of the phosphorus entering the Everglades.
It also binds the state to meeting its own water quality standards by 2002. By that time farmers will have to reduce the amount of phosphorus they discharge by 25 percent. And a long-term monitoring program will ensure that the measures work.
The long stalemate between governments was broken earlier this year when Governor Chiles, who during his election campaign last year promised to settle the suit, admitted that Everglades water was polluted.
"For three years the state has spent milions of dollars and diverted government's financial and human resources debating legal technicalities of this suit," Mr. Chiles said at today's news conference. "Now we can finally devote our full attention to cleaning up the Glades."
Mr. Chiles said he wanted to consult with leaders of agricultural and environmental groups and local governments before the state signed it.
The South Florida Water Management District, which controls the flow and diversion of water through the area, plans to vote on Aug. 6 on whether to accept the agreement. Judge William M. Hoeveler of Federal District Court also must review it.
 
Skepticism Is Voiced
 Farmers and some environmentalists were skeptical about whether the agreement would resolve what they see as a headlong conflict between progress and the environment.
Joe Podgor, a representative of Friends of the Everglades, a group founded by Marjory Stoneman Douglas, the author who sounded some of the earliest warnings over the condition of the Everglades, denounced the agreement for shifting the burden of the cleanup from the big sugar growers to taxpayers.
"It should have been 100 percent farmer money to pay for the damage," Mr. Podgor said.
Representatives of the large sugar and vegetable farmers continued to deny responsibility for the damage.
"There has never been an evidentiary hearing presenting facts that show damage to the Everglades," said Bill Earl, a lawyer for the Florida Sugar Cane League, a growers' association.
According to testimony elicited by United States Attorney in Miami, Dexter W. Lehtinen, who initiated the suit in Federal court in October 1988, the level of phosphorus from argicultural fertilizers is 10 to 20 times higher in areas below Lake Okeechobee than in more remote areas of the Everglades.
The phosphorus accumulates in sediment, increasing the number of algae and depleting oxygen from the marsh. Native sawgrasses die out and are replaced by stands of cattail and other non-native plants, disrupting many animal species.
Mr. Lehtinen, a native of Florida who grew up hunting and fishing in the Everglades and a former state legislator, said that Florida had passed effective environmental laws but that they were not enforced to protect special interest groups, including farmers.
"There is an assumption that economic growth eventually degrades the environment and there is nothing that can be done about it," Mr. Lehtinen said in an interview. "This agreement will demonstrate that that assumption is wrong."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Profits Up At Morgan, Wachovia

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Two of the nation's strongest banks, J. P. Morgan & Company and the Wachovia Corporation, yesterday reported solid second-quarter results, reflecting their avoidance of the risky lending that has hurt many competitors.
Earnings were up 11.6 percent at Morgan and 5.7 percent at Wachovia. 
 The banks are at the head of the class because of a reputation for conservatism and adherence to strict credit quality standards, analysts said.
Morgan, based in New York, and Wachovia, with headquarters in Winston-Salem, N.C., are considered conservative lenders, and their strong results come at a time when many banks are suffering because of high-risk loans that have soured.
Morgan's performance was helped in part by gains in its securities trading. The Federal Reserve Board last fall granted Morgan limited powers to underwrite both debt and equity securities because of its strong financial position. Most United States banks are prohibited from doing so by the Depression-era Glass-Steagall Act.
Chris Kotowski, bank analyst for Oppenheimer & Company, said Morgan and Wachovia are among the four strongest banks in the nation, along with the Republic New York Bank Corporation and NBD Bancorp of Detroit.
Following are the details of the banks' results:
 
J. P. Morgan
Morgan, the nation's fourth-biggest bank, reported earnings of $231 million for the second quarter, or $1.17 a share, compared with $207 million, or $1.06 a share, for the period last year.
"The quarter's results reflected good performance across all of our business activities, despite a weak economic climate," said Dennis Weatherstone, Morgan's chairman.
The bank benefited from increased revenues from net interest income and service fees, as well as from its securities trading.
Net interest revenue was $354 million, up 20 percent from the comparable quarter last year. The bank saw a 26 percent gain in revenue from miscellaneous trading, including dealings in commodities, securities and "swaps" of futures contracts and complex financial instruments, a growing business on Wall Street.
"They have worked very hard in the last few years to expand their trading base," said Judah S. Kraushaar, bank analyst for Merrill Lynch & Company.
Morgan's total nonaccrual loans, those delinquent in interest payments, declined 28 percent, to $629 million from the year earlier, mainly because the bank charged off as bad debt $322 million of Brazilian and Argentine loans in the second quarter.
On the New York Stock Exchange, Morgan's stock fell 75 cents, to $52.125 a share.
 
Wachovia
Wachovia, the nation's 29th-largest bank, posted earnings of $79.5 million, or $1.12 a share, compared with $75.2 million, or $1.06 a share, a year ago.
Benjamin Bishop, analyst for the Allen C. Ewing Corporation in North Carolina, said the results were "right on target."
The bank's nonperforming assets, including foreclosed real estate holdings and delinquent loans, totaled $161 million as of June 30, less than 1 percent of the bank's loan portfolio and foreclosed property.
Its Tier 1 capital ratio, an important gauge of a bank's ability to absorb sudden operating losses, was a healthy 9.1 percent, more than double the 4 percent minimum.
Wachovia, with $25.6 billion in assets, agreed in late June to acquire the South Carolina National Corporation, with $7.1 billion. The $800 million stock-swap deal would put Wachovia into the top 20 of the nation's bank holding companies.
Wachovia's share price rose 62.5 cents yesterday to close at $58 on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: PAN AM IS SELLING OVERSEAS ROUTES AND ITS SHUTTLE

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
Pan Am, the nation's pioneer in commercial aviation, all but gave up its long fight for survival yesterday by agreeing to sell the European, Asian and African routes that helped make it famous, as well as its East Coast shuttle.
The buyer is Delta Air Lines, the nation's third-largest carrier behind American and United. If the $260 million deal is completed, Delta will join a handful of other carriers with vast international route networks that are expected to dominate the industry in the next decade. 
 And Delta's acquisition of the shuttle, which connects New York with Boston and Washington, would make the airline a much greater threat to the smaller carriers that now operate in the Northeast market. These carriers include Northwest Airlines, which is in the process of buying the competing Trump Shuttle, and Continental Airlines, which is the biggest carrier in the New York market.
 
Intensified Competition
 Travelers going through New York may therefore see intensified competition that results in improved service. And the replacement of Pan Am by a vigorous carrier like Delta could mean a similar change for service across the Atlantic.
The sale is a blow to the approximately 10,000 Pan Am workers in the New York metropolitan area. Delta said it would offer jobs to about 6,000 of Pan Am's 22,000 workers. But most of these are expected to be workers overseas, at the other end of the international routes.
If Pan American World Airways is forced to shut down this fall, as expected, ticket holders are protected under an earlier agreement between Pan Am and United that provides $100 million for reimbursement for unused tickets. And Delta said it would honor Pan Am tickets on the routes it acquired for travel through Feb. 1, 1992.
 
Frequent-Flier Programs
 While nothing definitive has been worked out on what will happen to Pan Am's frequent-flier program, a Pan Am spokesman, Jeff Kriendler, said he expected Delta to come up with a way in which miles could be redeemed on Delta's system.
Analysts called the $260 million price a great bargain for Delta; the deal includes 45 airplanes, the coveted shuttle routes and an international network of routes that includes cities in Europe, the Soviet Union, Africa, the Middle East and Asia. Other bidders could still emerge and top the price negotiated by Delta before the deal goes through.
Pan Am suspended service to South Africa voluntarily in 1985 before the anti-apartheid embargo were imposed on that country. Mr. Kriendler said it was not known what Delta would do about seeking the authority to fly to South Africa.
For Pan Am, whose rise and fall in the past half-century has tracked that of other once-prosperous American industries, the sale means the end is near. If the routes are sold to Delta as negotiated, all that will remain of the carrier will be its Latin American routes and a small system within the United States. Just this week United has been negotiating with Pan Am to buy the Latin American routes; other bidders are also on the scene.
"This is the end game," said Edward Starkman, an airline analyst for Paine Webber, of Pan Am's most recent deal. "It has been coming for a decade."
Analysts said that Thomas G. Plaskett, the chairman of the Pan Am Corporation, was trying to carry out an orderly liquidation of the airline, to avoid a hasty fire sale after the carrier runs out of cash later this year.
Unable to compete after the industry was deregulated in 1978, Pan Am has been forced to sell assets including its headquarters building above Park Avenue in midtown Manhattan, its Pacific routes and last fall its London routes to raise enough case to keep flying. Pan Am has bought more time for itself through yesterday's agreement by having Delta provide $60 million in cash as soon as the sales agreement is approved by the judge overseeing Pan Am's bankruptcy case, Cornelius Blackshear. The carrier sought protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code in January.
 
 Approvals Are Needed

Pan Am is expected to seek approval for the sale at the United States Bankruptcy Court Southern District of New York in a couple of weeks. The sale also needs the approval of Pan Am creditors and the boards of both airlines. And it needs clearance from the Department of Transportation and the various European governments.
The Europeans are expected to be tough in the negotiations since they will demand new rights for their carriers serving the United States in return for allowing a powerful carrier as Delta into their countries.
Julius Maldutis, an airline analyst for Salomon Brothers, estimated that the fastest that approval could be granted would be about 45 days. But he said the $60 million might not be enough to keep Pan Am operating that long.
Founded in 1927, Pan Am grew and thrived when the industry was highly regulated; it dominated the market for international travel and seemed to some people to be the quasi-official United States carrier. It inaugurated service across the Pacific, ordered the first Boeing 747 and was widely known for its Clipper service. But it faltered under the pressures of deregulation. And in the last year it has been devastated by the decline in international traffic caused by the Persian Gulf war and the recession. Its operating costs soared as fuel prices doubled.
 
 Strong Are Surviving

The Pan Am-Delta deal would continue the trend of strong carriers buying the valuable rights to routes from weaker carriers like Pan Am and Trans World Airlines.
Of the 45 airplanes in the deal, 21 are modern Airbus A320's, which Delta can use on the European routes.
Mr. Maldutis said Delta would get a bargain on the assets, which analysts had valued at $500 million to $900 million. Donald J. Trump paid $365 million just for the Eastern Airlines shuttle in 1989. The Eastern shuttle's traffic had been cut severely by a strike by Eastern's unions. Mr. Trump has had problems winning back market share from Pan Am.
The Pan Am shuttle, acquired from New York Air in 1986 for $76 million, is healthy.
Delta already has a strong presence at La Guardia with its own modern terminal, which will make it a formidable competitor to the Trump Shuttle. Northwest Airlines has been in negotiations to buy the Trump shuttle but so far has not reached an agreement.
The sales agreement was worked out on Wednesday between Ronald W. Allen, the chairman of Delta, and Mr. Plaskett in Pan Am's board room.

HEADLINE: Court Upholds Welfare Curb When Children Leave Family

BYLINE: By RONALD SULLIVAN

 BODY:
Reversing lower-court decisions in two cases, a state appeals court yesterday upheld New York City's policy of cutting off most welfare payments to parents whose children are in foster care.
City lawyers had argued that a change in policy could lead parents to hand some of their children over to foster care in order to have more welfare money for the rest of their family. 
 In supporting the city's position, the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court said it would be wrong for families to receive full monthly welfare payments under the Aid to Dependent Children program and also ask the taxpayers to pay for the foster care of their children.
 
Fiscal Crisis Noted
 The court said its rulings in both cases reflected state law, which permits such cutoffs, and were "bolstered by the recognition of the fact that the state and the city coffers are finite."
"In the perilous economic circumstances now confronting our city and state," the court said, "the governor, the mayor and elected state and local representatives are faced with many valid and oft-times competing demands for services and benefits."
The courts "must be wary of imposing their vision of the fairest allocation of funds," the ruling said.
Lawyers for the families in both cases said they would appeal the ruling. They said about 30,000 families in New York City depended on welfare payments while their children were in and out of foster care.
"Any policy that cuts off such benefits simply is stupid," said Russell Smith, the lawyer for one of the plaintiffs. "It sabotages families that are trying to keep themselves together."
 
Injunction Challenged
 Mr. Smith's client, Grace Campfield, had sued after the city cut off her benefits when she allowed her two children to be placed in foster care because she had emotional and addiction problems. Acting Justice Elliott Wilk in State Supreme Court barred city officials in January from ending the benefits. However, the effect of his injunction was nullified when the city appealed it.
"As a consequence," said Mr. Smith, "she was thrown out out of the welfare hotel where she was living and is now living in the streets."
In his Jan. 10 ruling, Justice Wilk said that "rather than taking all reasonable steps necessary to facilitate the return of children from foster care," the the city's policy "actually impedes reunification."
State law permits parents to receive a housing allowance for six months after their children go into foster care and for two months before their return. The rationale is that foster care is temporary and a housing subsidy helps prevent the breakup of the home.
But the law requires the cutoff of all other welfare benefits on the ground that the parents can take care of themselves.
Assistant City Corporation Counsel Leonard Koerner described the dual welfare and foster-care benefits as "double payment and thus inconsistent with the law."
In its argument to the appeals court, the city said it "envisioned a scenario in which a poor family with several children could either maintain all their children at the poverty level or place one or two in foster care and use the additional welfare funds received in their absence to improve the living standards of the others."
In the other case, the appellate court allowed the city to cut off welfare benefits to a Bronx woman whose two children and four grandchildren were taken from her in 1987. They were placed in foster care after a Family Court judge found that she had badly burned the hands of three children by holding them over a stove flame.

HEADLINE: Neighbor Is Charged in Killing of Woman, 75

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG

 BODY:
A neighbor was charged yesterday in the killing of a 75-year-old widow on the Upper East Side, in a case that the police said was not a bias crime but a crime of opportunity.
The neighbor, a 32-year-old unemployed plumber named Charles Ocasio, beat and strangled the woman, Helen Clewell, when she resisted during a robbery attempt that began when he noticed that her door was ajar, Joseph R. Borrelli, the chief of detectives, said last night. 
 Mrs. Clewell was found dead about 11 P.M. Tuesday inside her apartment, 6H, at Rupert Towers at 1763 Second Avenue, between 92d and 93d Streets in Manhattan, the police said.
A note containing references to the Ku Klax Klan was found near her body. Chief Borrelli said that Mr. Ocasio, who lives with his mother in Apartment 6T, left the note behind "to kind of throw us off."
On Wednesday, investigators had classified the killing as a bias crime because of the note, even while suggesting that it might have been planted to divert attention. While the note referred to hatred of blacks, Jews and Hispanic people, Mrs. Clewell was a white Roman Catholic.
"He did not intend to kill the woman," Chief Borrelli said. "He probably intended a quick in-and-out to grab whatever he could in a burglary."
But Mrs. Clewell interrupted him and was "very combative and put up a very fierce struggle."
After knocking Mrs. Clewell unconscious, the police said, they believe Mr. Ocasio strangled her and then repeatedly stabbed her with two knives that were found in the apartment near her body.
Chief Borrelli said detectives believed from the start that they would find their killer somewhere in the building because its tight security would have made it very difficult for a stranger to gain entrance.
Despite initial reports that Mrs. Clewell's purse was missing from the apartment, Chief Borrelli said it had been found there.
"What he did take we don't feel amounted to too much," he said, declining to be more specific or to say what stolen items might have been recovered.
News of the arrest of a fellow tenant caused a commotion last night in the lobby of Mrs. Clewell's building.
"I'm such a nervous wreck," one woman told her neighbors.
"The lady was my friend," the doorman told residents. "She was a simple person. She never mixed with anyone. She had such a quiet voice. Such a soft soul she was."

HEADLINE: Auctions

BYLINE: By Rita Reif

 BODY:

Two Masks Go Home
 Two of the three American Indian ceremonial masks that were auctioned at Sotheby's in New York on May 21 -- despite protests by two tribes -- were returned last week to their tribal owners. 
 Elizabeth Sackler, president of the Arthur M. Sackler Foundation in New York, said by telephone from Santa Fe, N.M., this week that three members of the Hopi nation, including the chief of the Kachina clan of the First Mesa, seemed very pleased when the masks were returned at a meeting in Santa Fe on July 4. Miss Sackler said the masks were going to Walpi, Ariz., a Hopi pueblo.
Miss Sackler bought the two Hopi masks and a third one that is probably Navajo at Sotheby's sale for a total of $39,050. She said at the time that she intended to return them to their original owners. She has written to members of the Hopi tribe and also to the secretary of the Dineh Spiritual and Cultural Society of the Navajo nation, inviting representatives to examine the mask.
During the meeting, Miss Sackler said, she told the Hopi chief she had received many letters and phones calls since it was reported that she would return the masks. Because the public response was so positive, she said, "I decided to create a foundation that might help in the return of other ritual objects to the American Indian nations to whom they belong."
The foundation, to be called the American Indian Ritual Object Repatriation Foundation, will be at 463 East 57th Street in Manhattan and will help collectors, foundations, art dealers, museums, individuals and corporations to return ritual objects to American Indian nations or assist in the financing of such efforts. Since it is to be a nonprofit organization, Miss Sackler said, those who participate will be considered donors of these objects, which would make them eligible for a tax deduction.
"The foundation would do all the research and correspondence necessary to insure the return of each object to its rightful owner," Miss Sackler said.
 
An Unearthed Blessing
 An 18th-century Italian painting of Roman ruins that was discovered last year in the attic of a Long Island parish house was sold recently at Christie's in New York for $242,000 -- six times the auction-house estimate. The Episcopal church where it was found was the consigner.
"I don't believe anybody who looked at it at first had any inkling of its value," said the Rev. Dr. Charles G. Newbery, rector of St. John's Lattington Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, in a telephone interview. "We had no idea how long the painting was in the attic or where it came from. Initially we thought it might be sold at our church fair. But the trail finally led to this auction."
The decision about selling the painting was made only five months ago, when two representatives of the church took it to Christie's. "They came to find out what the painting was," said Rachel Kaminsky, who heads Old Master paintings at Christie's in New York. "It was very dirty -- it had not been cleaned probably for 50 years or longer -- and there was some flaking around the edges. I told them immediately, 'This appears to be a work by Panini. In order for Christie's to sell it, we would have to have this attribution confirmed by Fernando Arisi, a Panini expert.' "
The church representatives agreed, and a transparency of the painting, which measures more than 2 feet by 4 feet, was sent to Mr. Arisi in Piacenza, Italy. In his reply in early March, Mr. Arisi confirmed Ms. Kaminsky's view, that it was a mature work, signed "IPP," a monogram of Giovanni Paolo Panini.
Auctioned on May 31 as "A Capriccio of Roman Ruins With Figures," the painting was given what Ms. Kaminsky said was a conservative presale estimate of $40,000 to $60,000 because of the recession and its size. "We were a bit nervous about what might happen in the sale," she said. "We wanted to be as conservative as we possibly could."
"The sale of the painting was quite exciting," Dr. Newbery said. "It represents a very great challenge to us. I have often thought of people who win money in the lottery. Sometimes they decide they can help other people with it. We have a tremendous opportunity to use the money wisely. But I am not the sole person to decide how this should be done."
 
A Gainsborough Record
 Gainsborough's newly discovered chalk drawing of a woman walking in a garden with a small child was sold on Tuesday for $991,760 at Christie's in London. The price, a record for an English drawing sold at auction, was well above the presale estimate of $650,000. The buyer was John Morton-Morris of Hazlitt, Gooden and Fox, London dealers.
 
Bronze From Benin
 At last month's sales of tribal art in London, a 17th- or 18th-century Benin bronze from western Africa, depicting a horse and rider, was sold for $811,475 at Sotheby's . The buyer was identified as a European collector. The price, which fell within the house estimate of $595,000 to $850,000, was the highest paid at these sales.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Industrial Policy The Korean Way

BYLINE: By Sylvia Nasar

 BODY:
TODAY'S formula for economic success stresses free trade, unfettered markets and minimal governments. Yet the true Horatio Alger story of the third world, South Korea, gave government bureaucrats an unfashionably large role in shaping its economy. Does that mean the reformers have it all wrong? Hardly.
True, Seoul pursued industrial policy before anybody in Washington invented the term. "There really was a Government-business partnership in which Government very much had the upper hand," said Stanley Fischer, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Korea's authoritarian Government threw a protectionist blanket over infant industries, regularly butted into financial markets to control the flow of credit, and, time and again, bullied business into doing what it wanted. 
 Indeed, one of President Chung Hee Park's first moves in 1961, when Korea's remarkable transformation was just beginning, was to throw some of the country's corrupt capitalists into jail. Larry E. Westphal, an economist at Princeton, said President Park refused to release the executives until they agreed to invest their ill-gotten gains in Korea's new export drive.
Busybody bureaucrats might have strangled Korea's economy, as they did the once-prosperous Argentinas and Ghanas of the world. Instead, Korea, dismissed as an economic basket case by American benefactors in the 1950's, pulled itself out of poverty faster than almost any country ever has -- faster than the United States, Britain or even Japan. In four decades, South Korea's living standards have risen almost tenfold. With an income similar to that of Ghana and India at the time of the Korean War, Korea has since moved into the company of entry-level industrial countries like Czechoslovakia, Portugal and Greece.
The real lesson, World Bank economists say -- and the reason things turned out differently from the way they did in India or Ghana or Argentina -- is that Korea's meddling was "market friendly," "outward oriented" and less pervasive than appears at first glance. Korea's bureaucrats, said Jagdish Bhagwati, an economist at Columbia University, "left a lot to private initiative."
For starters, Korea forced its infant industries to export, thus exposing them to the discipline of market competition. Goodies like cheap credit, tax breaks and outright subsidies were tied to achieving specific targets. Most of the time, when companies failed to thrive even with coddling, they were allowed to fold.
In India, by contrast, the Soviet-style planning bureaucracy created a Kafka-esque system of licensing and import controls that effectively shielded monopolies from domestic as well as foreign rivals. Not surpisingly, India's share of manufacturing in its economy has not grown for more than a decade. Moreover, its inefficient monopolies reaped fat profits at the expense of Indian consumers, who were forced to buy shoddy, high-priced goods. India's big manufacturers enjoyed profit margins of nearly 21 percent in the early 80's, six times the average for Korea's capitalists.
Korea also took a series of steps to guarantee that its actions to protect infant industries did not discourage exports. After the mid-60's, Seoul kept its exchange rate low. Moreover, Korea's exporters generally received exemptions from import tariffs and had access to credit subsidies. In many developing countries, on the other hand, import restrictions drastically distorted the domestic price system in favor of production for the domestic market.
Korea's meddling, pronounced as it was, was light compared with that of many governments. "On a 1 to 10 scale, with the U.S. 1 and Africa 10, Korea is a 3," said Andrei Shleifer, an economist at Harvard. Take the size of government. Government spending as a share of the economy is under 20 percent. Or trade barriers. In Pacific Rim countries, about a fifth of all goods are subject to tariffs or quotas. In India, half to three-fourths of all goods are covered.
Finally, "The Korean Government has always been a Government of do's," Mr. Bhagwati said. "One thing leads to another. The Indian Government, by contrast, has been a Government of 'don't's.' " While Seoul nagged business to meet export targets, New Delhi required some companies to get 200 licenses before they could send a single shipment overseas.
The Indian system "stifled a lot of initiative with enormously detailed controls and restrictions," Mr. Bhagwati said. "We didn't get as much out of our investment as we could have."
Most economists doubt that Korea's industrial policy can easily be duplicated. "Experience indicates that more nations fail than succeed with industrial policies," said Lawrence H. Summers, chief economist at the World Bank.
But Korea's lessons have not been lost on India, which took some tentative steps to open up its economy in the early 80's. Result: India's economy expanded briskly in the last decade while per capita incomes rose three times as fast -- at 3 percent a year -- as in earlier decades.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 13, 1991, Saturday

 CORRECTION:

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
NBC Is Closing News Bureau in New York

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT

 BODY:
In a striking effort to cut costs, NBC said yesterday that it was closing its New York bureau, which has a news staff of 11.
That announcement comes a day after NBC said it planned to close its Miami news bureau, which has a total staff of 13. The closings in New York and Miami will reduce the number of NBC news bureaus in the United States to seven. 
 In addition, the Frankfurt news bureau will be closed and the staff of the London bureau has been reduced. NBC has also reduced its employees in Boston and Pittsburgh.
NBC is owned by the General Electric Company, and a number of NBC employees said they felt that G.E. had been particularly aggressive in its cost-cutting efforts.
NBC did not disclose how much it would save by closing the news bureaus.
The mood at the New York bureau was grim yesterday. "The network news bureau is being decimated," one employee said. Another said, "This is the end of an industry." Both spoke on condition of anonymity.
The cutbacks will mainly affect the New York bureau's correspondents and producers. It was unclear how many of them would remain with NBC. The bureau will close at the end of September.
Several NBC news employees said that as the network closed bureaus and laid off people, it was changing from a news-gathering organization to little more than a news-production company that gets its news from outside sources.
"We have to use material from outside vendors and affiliates because we will no longer have the capability of producing our own material," an NBC staff member said.
Some NBC employees also complained that while the cutbacks were taking place, Robert C. Wright, NBC's president and chief executive, and his staff had recently moved into new offices at the network's headquarters in 30 Rockefeller Center. A company spokeswoman, Betty Hudson, said the remodeling of the offices was started two and a half years ago when the network's profit outlook was brighter. But a news executive said NBC had been feeling financial pressures for at least that long.
NBC, like ABC and CBS, has been buffeted for the last year by a weak advertising market. In addition, the increasing number of rivals on cable channels has steadily eroded all three broadcast networks' shares of the television audience.
NBC's latest cutbacks came as CBS and ABC also moved to cut costs. Earlier this week, ABC announced that it would lay off 100 employees.
Michael Gartner, the president of NBC News, was on vacation and could not be reached for comment. An NBC spokeswoman, Peggy Hubble, said that while the cutbacks were tied in part to television's current economic realities, NBC was also taking into account that the networks were working more closely to gather news and that local stations were doing more of the news-gathering work. "We are focusing on analysis and interpretation of news," she said.
Don Brown, executive vice president of NBC News, said it was misleading to talk about "closing" bureaus. He said that some correspondents would remain in place in New York and that in Miami, NBC's local affiliate employed an aggressive journalist who would also be working for the network. "We are doing things now the way we did things in the 1970's when there were few local bureaus," he said.
"NBC Nightly News" is currently No. 3 in the ratings among the three network newscasts. But Mr. Brown said the network was continuing to provide quality news programming. He said NBC was adding news programs, including "Expose," to its lineup.
At NBC's New York bureau, the cutbacks will affect its correspondents and producers because they work exclusively for the network news. The camera crews and other technical people will not be directly affected because they generally work for a variety of different programs, several people at the bureau said.
NBC had said its New York station, WNBC, would absorb the network correspondents and producers, who would then do assignments for both local and network news.
"They told everybody you have jobs, but we don't know where," an NBC News employee said.
But as of yesterday, the network said it was unsure where those people would work.
"People are scared to death," a longtime NBC employee said.
One correspondent said he had been told that he was being dismissed. "They told me that they could not find a place for me in the organization," he said. "I don't have a contract. They are trying to reduce head count, so I am an easy target."
Some of the New York producers and correspondents have contracts, so they will be retained.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 13, 1991, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day yesterday about NBC cutbacks misidentified the source of the news announcement in some editions. It was NBC itself, not its parent, the General Electric Company.

HEADLINE: Beijing Journal;
The Russians Are Coming and Buying and Selling

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, July 12

 BODY:
Like a lot of tourists, Dmitri sauntered through a popular street market on a steamy afternoon, bargaining with the merchants over silk shirts and shorts. But unlike most visitors, he will not see the Great Wall, Tiananmen Square or the Forbidden City.
In fact, when Dmitri struck his bargain, it was for a dozen shirts. As he pushed them into a huge, overstuffed nylon sack, he pulled out a handful of cheap watches to sell to the shopkeeper. 
 Dmitri, who would not give his last name, is from Kiev, and he is part of a telling new phenomenon: a wave of Soviet citizens and Eastern Europeans for whom Beijing is just a stop on the capitalist road to riches.
This is a terminus of a route traversed by the trans-Siberian railway and Aeroflot jetliners carrying groups of Soviet people puffing on American cigarettes, carping about conditions back home and sweating their way to wealth.
 
Return With Silk
 The Russians and other Europeans bring cash or the few things obtainable back home: cameras, watches and the like. They return with the fabled products of the East, mostly silk. Given the shortages of such goods in the Soviet Union, it might as well be gold.
As explained by Dmitri, who was on his second trip, it is easy to turn a $1,000 investment into $2,500.
"Since the crisis, it's almost impossible to find anything to wear," said Peter, a Russian student who also would not give his last name. "We come here and buy anything. It doesn't really matter because we can get so much money for it in Moscow."
The bustle is a product of a striking asymmetry that says much about the shifts rending the Communist world -- of a Soviet Union that is loosening political and social controls but whose economy is collapsing, and of a China whose citizens suffer travel and other restrictions but can trade freely in abundant consumer goods.
 
An Open Market Thrives
 The key site for this drama is the open market between the American Embassy and the Jian Guo Hotel near central Beijing, on Xiushui East Street.
First there are the Americans and Europeans in bright T-shirts and sunglasses, who flit breezily from stall to stall, bargaining half-heartedly. For the Russians and the few Eastern Europeans, however, it is all business.
There are husband-and-wife teams, clusters of college-age youths, the odd diplomat and the "professionals," who ply the trade for their livelihoods.
These pros generally work in pairs and carry a weary air that comes from their frequent encounters with the routine and Beijing's beer.
"I know a guy who comes every two weeks with $1,000 in cash, but to do this you have to be part of an organization, if you know what I mean," Peter said.
 
The Tell-Tale Bags
 These refugees from Soviet food lines are recognizable by their large nylon bags, empty if they have just arrived, swelled into massive burdens if they have finished trawling through the 150-yard line of stalls.
And language is no problem. When they stop to negotiate, the peddlers engage in spirited conversations using the new commercial lingua franca: a Japanese pocket calculator.
Each side punches out a bid or offered price, often accompanied by a string of curses in a tongue the other cannot comprehend. They pass this battery-driven communicator back and forth until its luminous figures spell agreement.
"They are nit-pickers," said Zhang Xiao Dong, a merchant who, like his neighbors here, owns his stall. "They never stop pushing, and sometimes they'll come back the next day and try to return something if they found a better price."
Some of the Chinese seem to take pleasure in the humbling of their former big brothers in the Communist world. Three Russians, a woman and two men, tried recently to peddle music boxes, children's watches and cut-glass goblets.
"You must be really poor trying to sell us this junk," one shopkeeper said with a scowl, to a cackle of agreement from several other Chinese observing the action.
An hour later a Chinese merchant put his cupped hands to his eyes whenever Russians passed by -- a sign he was looking for the binoculars some of the visitors bring. On a recent afternoon, a stout Russian with a handlebar mustache sold two gold rings to a shopkeeper, and was given his choice of American dollars or yuan, the Chinese currency.
Peter explained the economics of these trips. First, the traders must obtain passports, a commodity that costs about 10,000 rubles, he said. No visa is required for Soviet citizens visiting China. A round-trip air ticket between Moscow and Beijing costs less than $200.
Many of the Soviet tourists lodge at the Guo Tai Hotel, a short walk from the outdoor market. It is preferred because it has minibus service to and from the airport, breakfast is included in the rate, and the menus are in Russian. It costs $15 a night.
Rail is used by the younger and stronger merchants with time on their hands. The trans-Siberian train leaves Wednesday, Friday and Saturday at 8:32 P.M. To watch people bolt for the rail cars once the doors open is to witness the truth in Dmitri's comment: "This is not a joke. Believe me, it is work."
Some of the Russians force their enormous bags through the windows of the waiting room onto the platform. It would be easier to load a camel.
With one hand they wrestle with their massive luggage, while lugging in the other sacks full of beer and watermelons to cool their wilted frames once the train gets under way. To the growing number of Soviet tourists here, that is what China is all about.

They then buy Chinese goods like silk shirts and jackets for resale at a profit back home. A transaction between Russians and Chinese took place in a Beijing market. (James Sterngold/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Your Taxes;
Can I.R.S. Rules Ever Be Simple?

BYLINE: By Robert D. Hershey Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
If the term tax simplification does not yet rival, say, jumbo shrimp or guest host as an easily identified oxymoron, it must be gaining fast.
For one thing, legislation aimed at making things simpler is proliferating. In addition to the consensus simplification bill (HR 2777-S 1394) introduced recently by the chairmen and ranking minority members of the House Ways and Means Committee and the Senate Finance Committee, there were already a half-dozen others. 
 Separate measures backed by the Ways and Means chairman, Dan Rostenkowski, deal with pensions (HR 2730), mutual funds (HR 2735) and items the Chicago Democrat deems worthy but that lack full staff agreement (HR 2775). In addition, Representative Rod Chandler has his own pension simplification bill (HR 2641), as do the chief of the Senate Finance panel, Lloyd Bentsen, and a committee member, David Pryor (S 1364). And word has it that Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum will shortly offer a pension bill, too.
It will not be easy to advance a bill, despite the fact that the consensus measure given the best chance of enactment -- the Tax Simplification Act of 1991 -- was intended to be noncontroversial. It was also intended to meet the test, set in the 1990 budget agreement, of not affecting total revenue.
Specialists are now finding some provisions downright contentious, such as how the bill treats a large class of taxpayers: investors in partnerships with at least 250 members, many of whom are suffering big losses from the recession.
One feature of the bill calls for certain limitations on deductions and credits to be applied at the partnership level. This means, among other things, that the partners will no longer get deductions of up to $3,000 a year for capital losses and that any subsequent Internal Revenue Service audit adjustment will affect only current partners rather than those who were part of the group during the year at issue. The partnership would not be allowed to report a capital loss; any tax benefit would have to come as an offset to subsequent gains by the partnership.
"If you've got an economic loss it should belong to you," contends David A. Berenson, national director of tax policy at Ernst & Young, the big accounting firm. "We should not create differing rules for gains, as compared to losses, under the banner of simplification." He added that the proposed change would also reverse longstanding efforts to integrate the tax system more thoroughly.
At the same time, the bill moves in the opposite direction by liberalizing the restrictions governing the 1.2 million closely held and mostly small companies that choose to be taxed under Subchapter S of the Internal Revenue Code. "S" corporations would be allowed to have more than one class of stock, thereby making family businesses easier to pass along and allowing them to have subsidiaries.
Since simplification is always at war with equity, as Mr. Rostenkowski tirelessly points out, even a supposedly noncontroversial bill creates winners and losers. The odds against passage become formidable when such a vehicle can be subjected, as in the Senate, to virtually any amendment.
 
 Pension Fund Rule

Senator Bentsen has asked Congressional tax aides to study a possible relaxation of restrictions on pension-fund investments. Mr. Bentsen, pointing to what he called overreaction by regulators to banks' excesses in real estate, said he would like to see pension funds -- the "perfect" vehicle for long-term, often illiquid commitments -- raise their stakes in this area. Dutch funds have long had large real estate portfolios, and British funds have raised theirs substantially over the last 15 years.
Still, Mr. Bentsen said at a conference here this week that he did not intend to try to ease the passive-loss restrictions imposed in the Tax Reform Act of 1986. Any changes, which would probably have to be retroactive, would generate new inequities, he said.
 
 Footnotes
 The Internal Revenue Service fails to impose proper penalties for negligence or substantial underpayment in about one-third of cases in which they are warranted, according to a survey by the General Accounting Office. About 85 percent of the errors are in the taxpayer's favor.
A bill introduced by freshman Representative Mike Kopetski, an Oregon Democrat who lost a 1988 run for Congress by 700 votes, would provide a tax credit of up to $100 for campaign contributions to those who challenge incumbents.

HEADLINE: Head of U.N. Mission in Baghdad Asks Council to Relax Sanctions

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 12

 BODY:
The head of the United Nations mission assessing Iraq's humanitarian needs called on the Security Council today to relax sanctions so Iraq can obtain the money to import food, medicine and other essential supplies, saying that otherwise the country is heading for "a major catastrophe."
"Iraqi funds must be used soon," the United Nations envoy, Prince Sadruddin Aga Khan, said. 
 The Security Council's sanctions committee is scheduled to meet in New York again next Monday to consider an Iraqi request to be allowed to sell about $1 billion worth of oil on international markets to finance the purchase of humanitarian goods.
 
Richardson Given Message
 The Iraqi Defense Minister on Thursday gave a message to Elliot L. Richardson, the former Attorney General who is a member of the United Nations mission, saying Iraq wants better relations with Washington and has assured the United States that it also seeks peaceful relations with all Middle East nations including Israel.
The Defense Minister, Hussein Kamel, who is President Saddam Hussein's cousin and son-in-law and is widely considered the second most powerful man in the country, asked Mr. Richardson to convey the message to the American Government.
Mr. Richardson was unwilling to disclose details of the message or to assess its significance.
But those familiar with the conversation say Defense Minister Kamel emphasized that Iraq now wants to see a more stable and peaceful Middle East and favors steps to control the buildup of arms in the region.
At the end of his mission's visit to Iraq today, Prince Sadruddin said he would present a plan in Geneva on Monday under which the United Nations could relax sanctions so Iraq gets cash to pay for essential imports while insuring that the money is correctly spent and the goods are fairly distributed around the country.
"Sanctions were never designed to make people suffer the way they are suffering now," Prince Sadruddin said at a news conference, adding, "We need to design an acceptable formula for easing them."
He said Iraq could get access to foreign exchange if the Security Council allows it to sell limited quantities of oil again or if the United States and other nations release money from the overseas bank accounts they have blocked.
Asked about the Bush Administration's contention that Iraq still has secret caches of gold and foreign currency around the world sufficient to pay for such imports, Mr. Richardson replied that Iraqi officials had assured him that this was untrue.
About $5 billion worth of foreign Iraqi assets are now blocked. While there are several hundred million dollars more in foreign accounts of private Iraqi individuals and companies, the Government argues that it has no control over these.
The message given to Mr. Richardson appears to be the latest of a series of conciliatory gestures Iraq has made as the Security Council approaches a decision on whether to ease sanctions.
After weeks of stalling, Iraq finally acknowledged this week that it had been operating a clandestine uranium enrichment program that might permit it to obtain nuclear explosives in violation of its obligations under the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty.
 
U.S. Charges Deception
 But the Bush Administration has asserted that this new list of Iraq's secret nuclear material is still incomplete.
Today Iraq allowed Prince Sadruddin, whose family is the traditional leader of a Shiite Muslim sect, to visit the 95-year-old Grand Ayatollah Khoi, the most senior Shiite cleric in Iraq, who is living under house arrest in the southern city of Khufa.
The Grand Ayatollah told him that several members of his family and many of his followers either had disappeared or were in prison.
On Thursday, after long negotiations, Iraq also permitted Prince Sadruddin to set up a United Nations humanitarian presence in the southern Iraqi marshes after withdrawing the army from the region. This followed United Nations accusations that Iraqi forces were blockading dissident Shiite refugees in the marshes and shooting them.
Presenting the mission's assessment of Iraqi nutritional difficulties, Sir John Moberly, a former British Ambassador to Baghdad, said low-priced Government rations account for only a third of an average family's needs.
As a result, people are being forced to sell jewelry, furniture and television sets to buy extra rations on the free market, where prices have soared hundreds of percent since the end of the Persian Gulf war. But many are now getting to the end of these resources.
Before the gulf crisis began, Iraq had been spending some $2 billion a year on importing 70 percent of its people's food needs. With Iraq's lack of money for such imports now, Sir John said, the mission had noted "signs of impending famine" around the country.
Similarly, the mission's medical experts pointed out that Iraq had spent some $500 million a year on foreign medical supplies before sanctions were imposed.
But the total volume of medical aid Iraq is now receiving is worth less than a fifth of this amount and mainly concentrated on the needs of children. As a result, there is a steady deterioration in medical conditions throughout the country, with many hospitals shutting down operating rooms, X-ray machines and sophisticated equipment because of a lack of supplies.
 
U.S. RESPONDS COOLLY
 WASHINGTON, July 12 (Special to The New York Times) -- The Bush Administration took a cool view today of a proposal by the head of a United Nations mission for the easing of sanctions against Iraq.
A State Department official pointed out that Baghdad had yet to comply with a request from the sanctions committee for a report detailing Iraq's foreign currency reserves, adding that no action could be taken by the United Nations body on sanctions until that information became available.
On Thursday, the Administration said that since March 22, when sanctions were relaxed to allow shipments of food to Iraq, a total of 1.1 million tons of food had been sent. "That makes one ton for every 18 Iraqis," a State Department spokesman said.
Administration officials said they had not seen the letter given to Mr. Richardson by the Iraqi Defense Minister and would not comment on it until they had reviewed its contents.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollars Sold In 'Ambush' By Group of 7

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The United States and its economic allies yesterday executed an "amubush" in the foreign exchange market, with waves of coordinated selling that knocked the value of the dollar down as much as 2.4 percent. The move also appeared to be a quid pro quo for the German decision on Thursday not to raise interest rates.
The coordinated action seemed to dispel, for now, a belief that the strong dollar was of little or no concern as the United States and its allies prepared for the seven-nation economic summit in London next week. Yesterday's pre-emptive strike showed that the Group of Seven -- which also includes Japan, Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada -- was still paying attention. 
 After the swirl of dollar selling that began in Europe and included several interventions by the Federal Reserve, traders and analysts were seeing all sorts of clues that led to several conclusions:
One, that in exchange for not raising interest rates, the German Bundesbank appeared to get a promise from the Bush Administration and the Fed to resist a further rise in the dollar. Raising interest rates would support the mark by making mark-denominated securities more attractive. So, when the dollar rose Thursday and again this morning in Europe, these central banks and others in Europe repeatedly intervened.
Two, that the Bush Administration, which has been pushing for lower global interest rates to help the American recovery, got some relief when the Germans held off. Britain cut rates yesterday, and France could soon follow suit.
Both conclusions seemed to add to the downward pressure on the dollar, which closed in New York trading at 1.7895 marks, down from 1.8339 Thursday. Against the Japanese yen, the dollar fell to 136.35 yen, down 1.7 percent, from 138.65 yen.
 
 Aggressive Selling by Fed

The clues that people were pointing to included the apparently aggressive dollar selling by the Federal Reserve. Jack A. Kessler, senior vice president at the Chase Manhattan Bank, said the intervention was forceful because the Fed continued to sell dollars as the currency was falling. Another sign was the unusual confirmation from Bush Administration officials that the Fed had intervened.
And there was the swap at the end of June between the Bundesbank and the Fed of possibly $1 billion in currencies. This operation, market analysts contended, gave both the Fed and the Bundesbank more ammunition for pushing the dollar lower.
"This development is more significant than I thought this morning," said Nicholas P. Sargen, director of international bond research at Salomon Brothers in New York. "The Fed's involvement raises the idea that there was broader Group of Seven coordination."
Added Liliana Nealon, vice president of the Union Bank of Switzerland, "I think they wanted to pre-empt the meeting and show a spirit of cooperation."
But a broader question remains: whether the United States and its allies are really unhappy with the current level of the dollar, which is still up more than 20 percent this year, and want it to fall much lower than where it ended yesterday.
Comments this week from Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady indicated that the United Sates was not worried. In an interview Thursday night on the Cable News Network, he said he did not expect his summit colleagues to pressure the United States for a lower dollar. He said the current level of the dollar should not hurt American exports and did not represent a "breakout" from the trading range of the last four or five years.
And while the Bundesbank prefers a stronger mark, its recent actions did not indicate that it was seriously worried as long as the dollar did not move much higher, said Gabriele Lamers, an international economist at Deutsche Bank in New York.
Richard Witten, a partner for foreign exchange at Goldman, Sachs & Company in New York, said the ambush would not sap the dollar's strength.
But the intervention could work for a while, he said, and it did announce the return of the Group of Seven. "The dollar was moving too fast," he continued. "If there was not intervention today, the dollar would have been at 1.85, and this kind of negates the idea of the Group of Seven in charge. So they did what any central bank would do. They intervened."

HEADLINE: Pan Am Will Leave Memories, and Job Hunters

BYLINE: By SARAH BARTLETT

 BODY:
With the anticipated demise of Pan American World Airways, New Yorkers are witnessing the undoing of not just an important employer, but one whose triumphs and tribulations had in many ways become a part of their lives.
For some, there were memories of large seaplanes bobbing beside what is now the Marine Air Terminal at La Guardia Airport and bitter debates over the desirability of a 59-story building looming over the city's grand Grand Central Terminal. 
 But for others, the effect is far more immediate and wrenching: thousands will likely lose their jobs and face the prospect of searching for new ones in the midst of what is still a raging local recession.
"Right now, I'm living day to day and hoping for the best," said Kenneth Kwan, a 59-year old-customer service agent who has worked for the airline for 26 years. "It's possible that I will lose my job, in which case I don't know what I'll do. I really don't even want to think about it."
Although the profit-starved airline has been shrinking for years, it still employs about 10,000 people in the New York metropolitan region. Delta Air Lines, which on Thursday agreed to buy many of Pan Am's overseas routes and its East Coast shuttle, has indicated that out of Pan Am's total work force of 22,000 it is likely to retain only 6,000 -- and many of those will be people connected to the airline's international routes.
Neither airline has indicated exactly how many Pan Am employees in the New York area will be kept on. But about 5,000 of them work in the airline's large maintenance center at Kennedy International Airport, which Delta is not acquiring. It is unlikely, therefore, that many of those working in that center will be needed, since Delta is expected to maintain its newly acquired planes at its own hub in Atlanta.
Despite the personal hardship they are likely to encounter, many employees yesterday still harbored the feeling that Pan Am was something special. Pointing to his uniform, a pale blue work shirt inscribed with his name and the company logo, one ramp agent who has been with the airline for just a year said: "I'm going to miss the logo. It's like as old as Coca-Cola or something. It makes me sick to lose it."
This is the airline, after all, whose Yankee Clipper set off from Long Island in 1939 on the first commercial trans-Atlantic flight, stirring Americans across the country and lending credence to the notion that America dominated the world in aviation. And it is the one that featuredsported a heliport atop its headquarters building, until a propeller fell off in 1977 and killed a passer-by below.
A professor of economics at New York University, Mitchell Moss, says that while New Yorkers may like to reminisce about Pan Am's historical significance, the airline has been in decline for so many years that this changing of the guard is a welcome development.
"Just because it's been associated with New York doesn't mean it's an asset," he said. "We're trading up: New York is getting a better carrier."
While Delta's expansion in New York may be good news for the region over the long haul, it is the near term that many employees are worried about. They are, after all, entering the job market at a time when the city's unemployment rate is 8.7 percent and when the market for airline workers is shrinking.
In January Eastern Airlines laid off 1,500 of its New York City employees. And many airlines are still suffering from a decline in traffic that resulted from the national recession and fear of traveling during the Persian Gulf war.
In May, the number of workers in New York City's airline industry was 50,700. That is down from 54,500 at year's end and from 54,300 in May of last year, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
"I'm nervous and upset," said Kathy Kallman, who has been a flight attendant with Pan Am for 11 years and is based in Miami. "If I lose this job, I'll probably get out of the business. I can't start out at the bottom of the list again, no way, not with two children."
For at least one airline, the prospects for jobs are not bright. "U.S. Air has had a hiring freeze on since the middle of last year," explained Susan Young, a spokeswoman for that airline. And if and when it gets ready to hire again, she added, managers have promised to recall those who were previously laid off.
 
Career Counseling at Airport
 New York State's Department of Labor opened a career center at Kennedy Airport last December and has been counseling workers laid off by Eastern. Philip Stroh, who oversees that office, says that people at the lower end of the pay scale who are willing to be flexible will eventually find work.
Baggage handlers can be redirected to warehouse jobs, reservations agents to the real-estate and financial services industries and airplane cleaners to other cleaning services, he said. But it is bound to take time, and he is worried about the sheer numbers.
Using those techniques, "may be we've put 100 people to work since last December. But that won't tackle the thousands," he said.
After all, the job market is already flooded with the 6,300 workers who were laid off at the end of June by the Dinkins administration because of budget problems. And they came on top of the 117,000 who have lost their jobs over the last two years.
Job opportunities are not expected to materialize until the local economy begins to grow again. And no one knows when that will be. "I don't see anywhere a sign of a turnaround or a resumption of growth," said Regina Armstrong, an economic consultant for the Regional Plan Association.

HEADLINE: Dow Rises 21.02 in a Seesaw Day

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stocks gave Wall Street investors and traders a case of the heebie-jeebies yesterday, before ending with a strong gain.
Keeping up its erratic pace of the last week, the Dow Jones industrial average bounced around for most of the session before ending at 2,980.77, up 21.02 points for the day and 48.30, or 1.6 percent, for the week. 
 The broader Standard & Poor's 500 also rose 1.6 percent for the week. But the smaller stocks, as measured by the Nasdaq composite, rose almost 4 percent for the week. High-technology stocks, particularly those in biotechnology, contributed substantially to the over-the-counter market's strength.
Traders seemed at a loss to explain the market's erratic performance. Uncertainty over the sluggish economy, the direction of interest rates and corporate earnings seemed to be the main reasons.
Still, trading activity on the New York Stock Exchange rose to 174.8 million shares, from 157.9 million the day before, while rising stocks exceeded those that declined by 2 to 1. Taking advantage of the market's volatility, program trading was particularly heavy, even though the ultimate impact was small.
Birinyi Associates, which monitors such trading, said that it tracked four buying waves and five selling flurries for an hour and a quarter of activity, but that such trading had dropped the Dow fell less than five points by the end of the day.
Commenting on the frustration of traders watching the market's gyrations, Peter G. Grennan, senior vice president of Shearson, Lehman Brothers, said: "It was up and down all day long. It puts people off balance. If you're bullish, you think you're all right, and the next hour you wonder what happened to make it go down, and there wasn't any news.
"If you can see through the volatility, forget about the volatility," he said. "You'll see that for the past week the O-T-C's begun to outperform the S.&P. 500."
"It usually means that the market's O.K.," he said, adding that it could "work itself higher and still has a chance to continue the summer rally started two weeks ago."
"It's been a rough start," he continued, "up and down, up and down. The uptrend's there, but the volatility is masking it."
 
A Jump at the Opening

In one short burst, the Dow took off on the opening bell, rising 15 points. By 11:30 the blue chips had sunk 20 from where they were. They recovered most of the slide in the following two hours, held steady for a while and then headed up, only to drop a bit near the close.
In two of the day's strong movers, an Alabama Supreme Court ruling on hazardous waste toppled Waste Management Inc. and its partly owned subsidiary, Chemical Waste Management Inc.
Leading the Big Board active list, Waste Management fell 2, to 35 1/4, on 5.5 million shares. Chemical Waste, No. 2, fell 2 3/4, to 18 1/4, on 3.9 million shares.
In another big move, Triton Energy rose 3, to 23 1/2, on 1.9 million shares. Thomas Driscoll, energy analyst at Salomon Brothers, said the stock would outperform the market. Reuters reported that traders attributed the move to remarks to analysts yesterday by British Petroleum about Colombian oil discoveries. It said Triton held about 20 percent of the properties and that they might yield more than a billion barrels.
British Petroleum rose 2 3/8, to 69 5/8, in brisk trading. Royal Dutch Petroleum rose 2 3/8, to 79 3/8. The Royal Dutch rise may have been related to remarks at the B.P. meeting about a promising Royal Dutch/Shell field in the Gulf of Mexico.
Among the Dow industrials, five stocks accounted for almost 60 percent of the day's upturn -- Coca-Cola, up 1 7/8, to 57 3/4; Merck, up 1 1/2, to 119 7/8; Philip Morris, up 1 1/4, to 67 3/4; I.B.M., up 1 1/8, to 99 3/8, and J. P. Morgan, up 1 1/8, to 53 1/4.
In the tech group, Digital Equipment rose 3 1/8, to 65 7/8. It is joining with a Brazilian partner to make computers in Brazil.
SciMed Life, maker of disposable medical products, rose 3 5/8, to 80. Reuters said Edward Mutsch of Piper Jaffray attributed it partly to short-sellers who had sold borrowed stock in expectation of paying less for it later but were forced to buy it back now because it was going up. He called the stock undervalued.

HEADLINE: Drexel Suit by Southmark

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: DALLAS, July 12

 BODY:
 he Southmark Corporation today demanded more than $200 million from Michael R. Milken and other former officials of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., saying their greed forced the company into bankruptcy.
In a lawsuit filed in the Federal District Court in Dallas, Southmark said that Mr. Milken, who is serving a 10-year Federal prison term, and others at Drexel overburdened the real estate development company with debt and then led it into highly speculative investments. That was "solely to satisfy the greed of the Milken group and other defendants," Southmark said in the suit. 
 Southmark recently emerged from bankruptcy proceedings and is liquidating its assets to pay creditors what amounts to less than 10 cents on the dollar. It filed for bankruptcy protection in July 1989 after two years of financial difficulties. In the third quarter of 1989, Southmark lost $1.04 billion.
The Texas economy collapsed in the mid-1980's along with energy prices, bursting the oil-producing state's bubble and sending real estate values into a tailspin. Southmark managers, who were just taking over from the former chairman, Gene Phillips, and the former vice chairman, William Friedman, blamed the previous management.
But in the lawsuit, Southmark lays the blame on Drexel officials and particularly on Mr. Milken, who transformed the firm's high-risk, high-yield bond department into a Wall Street powerhouse in the 1980's.
Mr. Milken was sentenced to 10 years in prison last November after pleading guilty to six charges of illegal securities trading in April 1990. He also agreed to pay $200 million in fines and to make $400 million in restitution. Drexel, which pleaded guilty to six felony counts of securities fraud in 1988, filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code in February 1990.

HEADLINE: June Producer Prices Fell by Unexpected 0.3%

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 12

 BODY:
Producer prices fell last month, the Government said today, easing inflation fears but underscoring the shaky nature of the economic recovery.
The Labor Department said the Producer Price Index, a measure of prices charged wholesalers for processed and manufactured goods, fell an unexpected three-tenths of a percent. 
 Falling prices are a sign that demand is weak and costs are under control. The broad-based decline was led by cheaper food and energy costs.
In May, producer prices rose by six-tenths of a percent.
 
 Rate of Minus 1.5 Percent

The drop brought the pace of inflation at the producer level so far this year to an annual rate of minus 1.5 percent, compared with an 8.2 percent oil-driven increase during the Persian Gulf crisis in the last half of 1990.
But fears that the economy will falter as it begins to emerge from the recession were fueled by the Commerce Department's report that retail sales fell two-tenths of a percent. May sales also were revised downward to an eight-tenths gain from the previously reported 1 percent increase.
"This pushes the evidence a little bit more toward a weak recovery and the possibility that the Federal Reserve will have to ease credit some more," said Robert McGee, chief economist at the Tokai Bank in New York.
 
Outlook Bullish to Brady

Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady was nonetheless bullish about the economic outlook. "The conversations I've had with industrialists in this country indicate that June was a better month than May," he told reporters.
Mr. Brady said the recession had hit bottom and that the economy was on its way up. He also said he was "particularly pleased" with the drop in producer prices, which "seem to indicate that inflation is at a much more controllable rate."
But some analysts fear that the return to modest growth, signaled by an upturn in the housing market and a pickup in factory production, will be short-lived, and that relatively high interest rates will cause a downturn later this year.
 
Leeway Seen for Fed

While this is not the predominant view, economists said the calming of the inflation rate did give the central bank leeway to stimulate growth if the recovery appeared threatened.
The yield on the 30-year bond has climbed in recent months, in part because of fears that the recent Fed easing may reignite inflation. The Fed's chairman, Alan Greenspan, has cited the high rates as a factor restraining the central bank's monetary policy.
Donald Ratajczak, head of the forecasting unit at Georgia State University, said that, with a couple of more months of good inflation figures, 30-year bond yields should fall. "There is no reason for long bonds to be above 8 percent," he added. The benchmark 30-year bond closed today with a yield of 8.43 percent, down from 8.46 percent on Thursday.
