HEADLINE: A High Court Victory, But an Empty Pocket

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS

 BODY:
Of all the stories of those who have won victories in the United States Supreme Court, Sheldon B. Toibb's surely ranks among the most bittersweet.
Last month, the Court ruled 8-to-1 that individuals can seek court protection under Chapter 11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code, which is normally reserved for faltering businesses. That decision should help some bankrupt individuals keep valuable assets like stock. A Chapter 7 filing, the main option previously for individuals, requires selling or giving up such holdings. 
 "One person said: 'God bless. You've really saved me,' " Mr. Toibb recalled.
 
Victory Seems Hollow

But for Mr. Toibb, a round-faced, high-strung man of 41, the victory seems hollow. The asset he went to the Supreme Court to protect, 400 shares in the Independence Electric Corporation, may be worthless. What remains is largely invective for those who helped drive his case to the nation's highest court: Mr. Toibb's onetime business partners, G. William Miller, the former Treasury Secretary who is chairman of Federated Department Stores, and Sidney J. Brown, a Washington-area developer.
In 1983, the three men, intrigued by Mr. Toibb's vision of cheap power and millions in profits, formed Independence Electric to build hydroelectric plants in the Southeast. But so far the company has not produced the energy to illuminate a single light bulb, leaving instead a legacy of bitterness and at least $249,000 in unpaid bills.
Mr. Miller and Mr. Brown both say that Independence Electric is an episode they are putting behind them. But for Mr. Toibb, unemployed and living with his parents in St. Louis for the last five years, it is one he cannot forget. Some see Independence Electric's story as a tale about the hazards facing the uninitiated whose hopes overreach reality.
"It has been an unpleasant situation in the extreme for all participants and a classic situation where the chemistry of the parties did not gel," said Stuart Eizenstat, the former domestic policy adviser to President Jimmy Carter and a lawyer, whose firm worked for the company.
The three principals were an odd mix. While Mr. Miller moves easily among the world's financial leaders, Mr. Brown has made his fortune in the scrappy world of real estate. Mr. Toibb said he viewed them as "father figures" who would make his dreams come true.
His plan to build hydroelectric plants began in 1980 when he was a lawyer at the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission. The climate for alternative energy seemed bright. Oil prices were high and utilities had to buy power from alternative producers at favorable rates.
Mr. Toibb envisioned building dams in the Southeast and selling the electrical output to utilities in Florida, where energy needs were skyrocketing.
"We'd generate power cheaply," he said, "and it would be cheaper for a utility to buy from us than build a new oil-fired plant."
 
'A Brilliant and Ingenious Plan'

In 1981, he quit his position to develop his plan, showing it in 1983 to Mr. Eizenstat, who had hired Mr. Toibb during the Carter Presidential campaign to lobby Jewish organizations. "It was a brilliant and ingenious plan," said Mr. Eizenstat, who offered to help find investors.
Mr. Miller, who had formed his own merchant bank after resigning his Treasury post, was the first to climb aboard. He contributed $100,000 and served as the company's unsalaried president. Mr. Brown, whose development projects included the Beltway Plaza mall in Greenbelt, Md., invested $1 million. He received a 60 percent interest; Mr. Miller, 16 percent, and Mr. Toibb, 24 percent, and an annual $50,000 consulting fee.
"I look forward to working with you to build a major new enterprise that will serve the energy needs of our country," Mr. Miller wrote to Mr. Toibb in March 1983.
 
 Souring of Relationships

Soon, however, Mr. Toibb said he was being criticized by Mr. Miller for, among other things, suggesting too many studies of dam sites. "He told me I didn't know anything about business and that I ought to go dig ditches," Mr. Toibb said.
He said he was soon asked not to use an office in Mr. Miller's bank in Washington and, in return, fired off one of many long memos, this one accusing Mr. Miller of ignoring the company. "Miller is being selfish and is a quitter," he wrote to Mr. Brown in December 1983.
But Mr. Brown backed Mr. Miller, and his relationship with Mr. Toibb also soured. One problem involved a 1985 plan to raise more money and sweeten the deal by giving free stock to Mr. Miller and Michael H. Cardozo, his business associate and the company's unsalaried treasurer.
 
Threat of Lawsuit

Mr. Toibb opposed the move, arguing that his stake was being cut while Mr. Brown's was not. Mr. Brown said his $1 million investment entitled him to keep his stake and that Mr. Toibb's stubbornness was ruining the company.
"He was constantly haranguing everybody -- why weren't we doing this or doing that," Mr. Brown said.
Mr. Toibb threatened to sue, arguing that his partners were trying to squeeze him out. Buyout proposals also went back and forth.
One outside consultant said he viewed Mr. Toibb as talented but inflexible. "Both Miller and Brown became increasingly disillusioned with Sheldon because he won't compromise," said the consultant, Kenneth McIntyre, a retired engineer who, while working for the Stone & Webster Engineering Corporation of Boston, consulted with Independence Electric.
By 1986, Mr. Toibb's consulting fee had been terminated and Independence Electric was sinking into debt. As oil became cheaper, the prospects for starting up other energy systems faded.
Now, with his business dream apparently over, Mr. Toibb's journey to the Supreme Court soon began. Having long used credit cards to pay for lawyers and living expenses, he returned to St. Louis in September 1986 and filed a Chapter 7 bankruptcy petition. He listed debts of more than $181,000 and assets of $1,370, with his Independence Electric stock given no value.
 
 Effort to Get the Stock

Mr. Toibb's partners moved to get the stock, saying they wanted to prevent his creditors from getting it.
In Bankruptcy Court, Independence Electric offered $5,000 and, then, $25,000, a bid accepted in July 1987 by the trustee of Mr. Toibb's case. Then a month later, Independence Electric's hopes flickered back to life. Federal regulators issued it a dam license, which Mr. Toibb believed could be worth more than $20 million in construction costs.
He said his only option to void the trustee's decision was to convert his bankruptcy into a Chapter 11 case, which he did in October 1987. Two months later, the company got three more licenses.
Mr. Brown next offered $50,000 in Bankruptcy Court for Mr. Toibb's holdings, but the bid was not reviewed. In August 1988, Barry S. Schermer, a Federal bankruptcy judge in St. Louis, ruled that Mr. Toibb, as an individual, was ineligible for Chapter 11, thus starting a series of appeals. Mr. Toibb was represented on a pro-bono basis before the Supreme Court in the case, Toibb v. Radloff, No. 90-368, by Timothy B. Dyk and Peter M. Lieb, of the firm of Jones, Day, Reavis & Pogue.
The relevance of Mr. Toibb's victory is questionable because the company's dam projects have not gotten off the ground nor have the licenses been sold. If construction on the company's three remaining licenses does not start this year, it may lose the permits. Then, only debts will remain; Stone & Webster, the company's largest creditor, has already written off the $249,000 owed to it.
Mr. Miller resigned in 1989 from Independence Electric, which is still searching for new financing, and offered to turn in his stock.
"There was no money left and no visible form of raising money," he said.
 
 Outlook Is Uncertain

Mr. Toibb's outlook is uncertain. He has failed to interest lawyers in pressing a claim against his partners, and should he fail to demonstrate significant assets when his Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceeds, it may well revert back to Chapter 7 where it began.
Meanwhile, he seeks solace pouring through company documents, and he remains convinced that Independence Electric should have made him a multimillionaire. For five years, Mr. Toibb has also been working on a novel, which he describes as a tome about the lack of morality in American business.
"If I could get someone interested in my book," he said, "I'll feel like I've really accomplished something. I'll feel like what happened to me never happened at all."

HEADLINE: Retail Sales Fell 0.2% Last Month

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 12

 BODY:
Retail sales were surprisingly weak in June, falling two-tenths of a percent and arousing fresh doubts among economists about the durability of the recovery.
The decline was broad-based, with automotive products posting the only gains, according to the Commerce Department's monthly report. Without this sector, where the improved sales pace is thought unlikely to be sustained, retail sales tumbled five-tenths of a percent after rising nearly twice that much in May. 
 Economists had been expecting a gain of around five-tenths of a percent.
 
Lack of Propellant Seen

The retail sales data, combined with another Government report today showing a decline in prices paid to American producers in June, indicated that the economy still lacked the means to propel itself solidly out of recession.
The Producer Price Index, published by the Labor Department, showed that finished goods eased three-tenths of a percent in June, with core prices unchanged when the volatile food and energy sectors were excluded. [Page 37.]
Bond prices rose in response to the figures on retail sales and producer prices, but the early bond market gains were somewhat eroded by a plunge in the dollar and rises in commodity prices. [Page 36.]
 
'Flat and Extended Trough'

"The very weak retail sales numbers suggest that the recovery may sputter and that we may be moving along a flat and extended trough," said Mickey D. Levy, chief economist at CRT Government Securities in New York. He cited a lack of growth in incomes and employment, high levels of debt and what he called tight fiscal and monetary policies.
Another downbeat assessment came from Lawrence A. Hunter, deputy chief economist for the United States Chamber of Commerce. "The economy is not undergoing a sustainable recovery," he said. "Falling consumer spending could create a double-dip recession."
On the other hand, Carl J. Palash, senior economist at the New York consulting firm of McCarthy, Crisanti & Maffei, called the June sales results "just a temporary setback" that should be weighed against a sharp May increase.
Exceptionally favorable weather in May appears to have accelerated spring purchases, he and others noted, and the June sales level of $151.9 billion remained higher than April's $151 billion. Many of the nation's department stores on Thursday reported generally sluggish sales in June and cited the same weather-related reason.
Sales of durable goods were unchanged in June, with a 1.1 percent gain for automotive dealers offset by declines of 1.6 percent for building materials, hardware, garden supplies and mobile homes, and eight-tenths of a percent for furniture and home furnishings.
Among nondurables, which posted a decline of three-tenths of a percent, sales at stores selling apparel and accessories tumbled 1.2 percent while those at eating and drinking establishments fell eight-tenths of a percent. General merchandise stores posted a decline of six-tenths of a percent, while sales were off one-tenth of a percent at both food stores and drug stores.
 
Rise at Service Stations

The only gain among nondurables, six-tenths of a percent, was at gasoline service stations.
The gain in car sales was said to have reflected a reluctance by some consumers to defer purchases any longer, but some analysts also pointed to what might be a statistical inaccuracy. This year the Chrysler Corporation stopped publishing 10-day figures, forcing others to estimate them, said David H. Resler, chief economist for Nomura Securities International.
Over all, retail sales last month were 1.1 percent above the June 1990 level, implying about a 4 percent decline in volume. The sales figures are adjusted for seasonal, holiday and trading-day differences, but not for inflation, which at the consumer level ran at 5 percent over the latest 12 months through May.
Today's report also disclosed a downward revision of May sales so that the advance was eight-tenths of a percent instead of the 1 percent rise that was the Commerce Department's original estimate.
 
Downward Revision for May
 The lackluster spring sales, combined with the low inflation rate -- a skimpy 1.5 percent pace for the first half of 1991 -- indicated to many analysts that an economic rebound could no longer be assumed to be under way. "There's still a legitimate doubt about whether what we're seeing is a definable recovery," said Nomura's Mr. Resler.

HEADLINE: Miami Journal;
Boycott Over Visit Of Mandela Lives On

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, July 12

 BODY:
It was just over a year ago that a triumphant Nelson Mandela arrived here to a chorus of protests from many of Miami's powerful Cuban-Americans who were angered by the South African nationalist's support of Fidel Castro.
The dispute was played out in public. The City Commission rescinded a proclamation welcoming Mr. Mandela, and Mayor Xavier Suarez and four other mayors from the region openly criticized Mr. Mandela for not denouncing human rights violations in Cuba. 
 Miami's blacks, who make up about 21 percent of the city's 359,000 residents, took that as a snub of royal proportions, an insult added to decades of economic, social and political injury. In response, on July 17, 1990, a small group of the city's black leaders began an economic boycott against the tourism industry, arguably the region's most important business.
Now almost a year old, the boycott continues, and organizers recently declared their intention to turn up the heat a bit by sending out videotaped messages highly critical of Miami to organizations around the country likely to hold conventions or refer people to the area. The videos will urge them to keep their convention and vacation business away.
Giant cruise ships still glide silently through Biscayne Bay and rental cars still seem to take up more than two-thirds of every parking lot, but the boycott has taken its toll. A spokesman for the boycott group, H. T. Smith, a lawyer, estimated that the campaign has cost the area $27 million in convention business. Officials from the Greater Miami Convention and Visitors Bureau estimate that of more than $200 million in convention business annually, about 19 conventions or meetings worth about $8 million have been canceled.
Whether the organizers of the boycott or the convention bureau officials are correct, the campaign has clearly hurt Miami, which is already suffering from the national recession, and has kept attention focused on the racial tensions that regularly erupt in violence.
The latest tool to be used by the boycott organizers is a dramatic 16-minute videotape that opens with scenes of Miami police officers swinging clubs at a group of Haitians protesting in front of a Cuban store. Such scenes are interspersed with film from South Africa and with grainy black-and-white shots from the 1960's showing police dogs attacking black protesters.
"The boycott is not just about the Mandela snub," Mr. Smith said. "After it happened we sat around asking 'Are we so disrespected that all our public officials can just snub our hero?' The answer was yes."
City officials so far have refused to apologize, even as they concede that they probably mishandled Mr. Mandela's visit. William O. Cullom, president of the Greater Miami Chamber of Commerce, said that while the boycott has hurt the area's economy, it has also brought attention to the needs of blacks, which businesses are beginning to address through special jobs programs.
"It's time for them to declare some kind of partial victory and come to the table and negotiate," Mr. Cullom said.
Mr. Smith said that the boycott has been more successful than he and other organizers had imagined and that he was unwilling to ease up until the demands for an apology and significant economic opportunity, among several political requirements, are met.
Many people doubt the effectiveness of the strategy because invariably boycotts hurt those it intended to help. Tourism and boycott officials disagree on how many blacks work in the hotels and convention businesses. But blacks, who make up 12 to 25 percent of the 274,000 tourism employees, are a sizable group, even if most work in lower level positions. It is estimated that for each $1 million in lost business, up to 34 jobs are lost.
Still, the ability of blacks to sustain a nonviolent protest for a year is seen as a positive sign.
"The tactic of using an economic boycott is a big step forward compared to throwing rocks," said Msgr. Bryan Walsh, director of Catholic Community Services of the Archdiocese of Miami. Monsignor Walsh, who has worked in Miami for 36 years, said he did not support or oppose the boycott, but he said he believed the motivation behind it was valid and its effect among blacks would be longstanding.
"They do have, for the first time, their fingers on the levers of power," he said "and they're not going to give it up very easily."

HEADLINE: ENVOY'S TESTIMONY ON IRAQ IS ASSAILED

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 12

 BODY:
Leading Senators today accused the former United States Ambassador to Iraq of misleading Congress in March when she testified about a crucial meeting with President Saddam Hussein eight days before his forces invaded Kuwait.
The Senators' remarks came after they reviewed several secret cables, particularly one from the Ambassador, April C. Glaspie, summarizing the meeting. The cables were provided by the State Department to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee this week. [Excerpts, page 4.] 
 The legislators say that in contrast to the tough approach she described at Capitol hearings, the cables show her taking a more conciliatory tone with Mr. Hussein.
 
Pell Sees 'Inconsistencies'
 In a letter to Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d today, Senator Claiborne Pell, Democrat of Rhode Island and chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, demanded an explanation of what he called "inconsistencies" between Ms. Glaspie's testimony and the cabled summary, which she sent to the State Department on July 25, 1990, the same day as her meeting with the Iraqi President.
 Senator Alan Cranston, Democrat of California and a member of the Foreign Relations Committee, charged in a statement that "April Glaspie deliberately misled the Congress about her role in the Persian Gulf tragedy."
Ms. Glapsie's interpretation of the two-hour meeting, as well as the secret reply to Mr. Hussein by President Bush that followed three days later, provide windows into the Administration's conciliatory policy toward Mr. Hussein in the days before the Aug. 2 invasion, despite the buildup of Iraqi troops on the Kuwaiti border.
The information in the cables, first disclosed today in The Washington Post and The Los Angeles Times, is expected to figure in continuing investigations by the intelligence committees of both houses of Congress into whether there was a failure of American intelligence from the months before the invasion through the Persian Gulf war.
Contrary to her testimony that Mr. Hussein had told her he would settle his dispute with Kuwait peacefully, Mr. Hussein made a number of veiled threats during the meeting that he might have to resort to force. But Ms. Glaspie came away convinced that he did not intend to invade Kuwait.
"His emphasis that he wants peaceful settlement is surely sincere," she wrote in her conclusion. "Iraqis are sick of war."
 
Bush Took a Placating Tone
 Another secret cable sent from President Bush to Mr. Hussein in response to Ms. Glaspie's reports took the same conciliatory approach. "We believe that differences are best resolved by peaceful means and not by threats involving military force or conflict," the President wrote in a message that Ms. Glaspie delivered to the Iraqi Foreign Ministry.
Mr. Bush added, "My Administration continues to desire better relations with Iraq." The cables were made available to The New York Times today.
In her appearances before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee and the House Foreign Affairs Committee, Ms. Glaspie portrayed herself as a tough-minded Ambassador who repeatedly warned the Iraqi leader against using force to settle his border dispute with Kuwait, whose protection, she added, was in the vital interests of the United States.
By the end of two days of hearings, a number of initially skeptical Senators and Representatives were praising her as an articulate, forceful career Foreign Service officer who should have been allowed to set the public record straight much earlier.
Indeed, her summary of her conversation in one of the cables stated that she had "made clear that we can never excuse settlement of disputes by other than peaceful means." But the cables do not show her having spoken of Kuwait's "vital" relationship with the United States, and most of her remarks appeared to be aimed at mollifying the Iraqi leader.
Ms. Glaspie concluded that Mr. Hussein was "worried" by joint military exercises the United States was conducting with the United Arab Emirates and would "make a major push to cooperate" with the efforts of President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt to negotiate between Iraq and Kuwait.
Her recommendation was that the Bush Administration curb rather than intensify its criticism of Iraq. "I believe we would now be well-advised to ease off on public criticism of Iraq until we see how the negotiations develop," she wrote.
In his letter on Thursday to Mr. Baker, Mr. Pell said that "no place does she report clearly delivering the kind of warning she described in her testimony to the committee."
"I would ask the department to look into this situation and would also appreciate an explanation as to why no effort was made to correct the public record," he added.
A senior State Department official said that Deputy Secretary Lawrence S. Eagleburger sent a letter to Mr. Pell late today requesting that he and Ms. Glaspie be allowed to appear before the Foreign Relations Committee at the "earliest possible opportunity" to correct any misunderstandings that may have arisen from her previous testimony.
Mr. Eagleburger said that with Secretary Baker leaving Sunday for a 10-day trip with President Bush to the London economic summit meeting, he would be representing the department as the senior official.
Ms. Glaspie herself could not be reached for public comment on the Senators' remarks. Although she no longer is Ambassador to Iraq, she is still technically assigned to the State Department's Iraq desk and will assume a post as ambassador-in-residence at the University of California at San Diego in the fall.
Asked about State Department involvement in Ms. Glaspie's testimony, Margaret D. Tutwiler, the department spokeswoman, said that "a standard testimony preparation" by officials in the Bureau of Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs had been held. "It consisted of going over questions she might be asked," Miss Tutwiler said.
Although Ms. Glaspie told the Foreign Relations Commitee that an Iraqi version of her conversation with Mr. Hussein was "fabrication" and "disinformation," with few exceptions her cables largely parallel the Arabic transcript made available to reporters by the Iraqi Foreign Ministry in September, after the invasion of Kuwait.
One outright contradiction between Ms. Glaspie's testimony and her cables come in her characterization of an inteview that Mr. Hussein gave last year to Diane Sawyer, a correspondent for ABC News. In the Iraqi version, Ms. Glaspie is quoted as telling Mr. Hussein that "what happened in that program was cheap and unjust."
But Ms. Glaspie assured lawmakers that the Iraqis had changed her words. "I said to him I thought the editing of transcripts -- not transcripts, of videotapes -- was cheap and unjust, such as had occurred in the case of Diane Sawyer's interview," she told the Senate committee on March 20. A day later, she praised Ms. Sawyer and acknowledged that her embassy had helped the reporter obtain the interview. "She did American journalism proud," Ms. Glaspie said of Ms. Sawyer.
Nonetheless, in her primary cable to Washington, Ms. Glaspie asserts that she said she "had seen the Diane Sawyer show and thought it was cheap and unfair."
The Senate Foreign Relations Commitee is expected to raise the issue of American policy toward Iraq in general, and Ms. Glaspie's testimony in particular, during the still-unscheduled confirmation hearings of Robert M. Kimmitt, the Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, as Ambassador to Germany.
Mr. Kimmitt, who has been instrumental in crafting the department's policy toward Iraq, did not consult with Ms. Glaspie before her testimony to Congress but reviewed a draft of a brief opening statement that she subsequently did not deliver, a senior Administration official said.
The official added that Mr. Kimmitt and Mr. Baker had told Ms. Glaspie after her Congressional testimony that she had done well under difficult circumstances.

She was greeted by Mr. Hussein, right, at an earlier meeting in Baghdad. (ABC News)(pg. 4)

HEADLINE: 7 Powers In Search Of Policy

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, July 12

 BODY:
When the leaders of the Group of Seven industrial nations meet next week in London, they will tug in sharply different directions over how much aid to give the Soviet Union. These differences could make the London economic summit conference one of the liveliest in years.
Group of Seven officials say the aid most likely to be approved will be technical assistance to move to a market economy as well as granting Moscow associate membership in the International Monetary Fund. 
 But the issue of whether to give much more substantial aid is by no means decided. The scene is set for the seven to debate whether to grant the Soviet Union help on a large scale to assist its troubled transition from Communism toward a market economy. Each country's enthusiasm for financial aid to Moscow seems related to its proximity to the Soviet Union and its likelihood of being affected by emigration flows.
 
Kohl Is the Biggest Booster
 The biggest champion of an ambitious aid package is the German Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, who argues that immediate assistance is needed to buttress Mr. Gorbachev and Soviet reforms. Many German officials fear that the aid that Mr. Gorbachev is likely to take home from London will be so modest that it can be construed as a slap in the face.
Italy and France basically support Bonn's position of giving more help now, but they want a few more strings attached.
On the other side are officials from the United States, Britain, Canada and Japan, who argue that granting large-scale aid will be a waste because the Soviet economy is in such a shambles that the money cannot yet be put to good use.
"Pouring water into a bottomless barrel is useless," Japan's Prime Minister, Toshiki Kaifu, said.
 
National Interests
 Each country has its own specific reasons for its position.
Chancellor Kohl has developed a close friendship with Mr. Gorbachev, and, foreign policy analysts say, he still feels somewhat indebted to the Soviet President for having given the green light for German reunification. What is more, Germany is likely to be hit first and perhaps hardest by any flood of refugees that might result from a Soviet economic collapse.
"It would be foolish for the Western countries to sit back and calmly watch what happens in the Soviet Union, and it would be most foolish for anyone to speculate about a collapse there," said Chancellor Kohl, after meeting with Mr. Gorbachev a week ago in Kiev. "I believe we must help the reforms, not the Germans alone, but all the Western countries. The Soviet Union must provide the essential preconditions, but then we cannot sit on the sidelines."
Some Germans officials say the conditions for reform are already in place. "There is no point for Mr. Gorbachev just turning up for the group photo," said Jurgen Mollemann, Germany's Economics Minister.
 
Getting Down to Business
 The Germans and the Italians have been far more active than other Group of Seven countries in pursuing commercial opportunities in the Soviet Union. German and Italian companies may thus stand to gain more if the Soviet economy receives official help -- and turns around. Conversely, a Soviet economic collapse would likely hurt Germany and Italy more than the other Group of Seven nations.
In Germany there are also fears that if Washington blocks large-scale joint Western aid for philosophical reasons or because of its own deficit problems, the Germans will be called on to pitch in a disproportionate amount.
The Bush Administration is demanding far more reforms from the Soviet Union before it would begin seriously considering large-scale aid. Indeed, some Administration officials, deeply skepticism about Soviet ways, contend that aid might retard the reform process by helping the country hang on to an archaic economic dilapidated system.
"I'd love to see this reform move far enough forward and be for real enough that we could then all pitch in and be of as much assistance as possible in terms of the economic recovery," President Bush said.
 
Japan Wants Islands Back
 As has been the case for months, Japan remains adamantly opposed to granting large-scale aid until Moscow agrees to give back four northern islands that Soviet forces captured toward the end of World War II. Mr. Kaifu, like Amerian officials, says he wants more reforms on the table before putting more money on the table.
The Japanese Prime Minister said an important aspect of reform would be to point the Soviet economy toward civilian production and away from the military. This dovetails with Japan's concerns about Soviet troop levels in northern Asia.
The Italian Foreign Minister, Gianni de Michelis, says aid should be forthcoming, but only on the condition that there first be a new union treaty between the Kremlin and the nine republics that want to remain in the Soviet Union. "Without such a treaty, nothing would be possible because we wouldn't have an interlocutor," he said, perhaps mindful of the fractiousness and disarray in Italy's neighbor, Yugoslavia.
Many French officials say that giving substantial aid to the Soviets now would largely be a waste. But President Francois Mitterrand is loath to give a cold shoulder to two leaders with whom he has sought to develop special relationships: Mr. Kohl and Mr. Gorbachev.

HEADLINE: Despite Praising Farrakhan in 1983, Thomas Denies Anti-Semitism

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 12

 BODY:
President Bush's nominee for the Supreme Court, Judge Clarence Thomas, expressed admiration for the Rev. Louis Farrakhan in speeches eight years ago. But Judge Thomas said today that he never shared any of the clergyman's anti-Semitic views.
The content of the speeches was disclosed today by The Dallas Times Herald. After leaders of Jewish organizations and civil rights advocates expressed concern about Mr. Thomas's remarks, he issued a statement saying he was not an anti-Semite. 
 Mr. Farrakhan, the Black Muslim leader, became notorious in 1984 when he spoke of Judaism as "a dirty religion" and described Hitler as "wickedly great." Leaders of Jewish organizations said Mr. Farrahkan had been making anti-Semitic statements at least since 1972.
In two speeches prepared for his use in 1983, Mr. Thomas, then chairman of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, described Mr. Farrakhan as "a man I have admired for more than a decade." The speeches were for a meeting of the Capital Press Club here on Sept. 19, 1983, and for a meeting of the national Association of Black M.B.A.'s in Atlanta on Oct. 6, 1983.
Mr. Thomas quoted Mr. Farrakhan on the need for self-help among blacks, without mentioning any of the minister's views of Judaism.
 
Texts From E.E.O.C.
 Copies of the speeches were made available by the commission. James C. Lafferty, a spokesman for the commission, said he had no way to determine whether the speeches were delivered as written by Judge Thomas, who now sits on the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.
In his statement today, Judge Thomas said: "I cannot leave standing any suggestion that I am anti-Semitic. I am, and have always been, unalterably and adamantly opposed to anti-Semitism and bigotry of any kind, including by Louis Farrakhan."
Judge Thomas added: "I repudiate the anti-Semitism of Louis Farrakhan or anyone else. While I support the concept of economic self-help, I have never supported or tolerated bigotry of any kind."
 
For Some, Statement Falls Short
 Abraham H. Foxman, national director of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, said Judge Thomas's repudiation of anti-Semitism "was welcome, but unfortunately did not go far enough."
"It is not possible to separate Farrakhan's message from Farrakhan the messenger," Mr. Foxman said. "We hope that Judge Thomas, who has always eschewed bigotry, will publicly acknowledge the danger in attempting to distinguish elements of a bigot's program which might be considered positive from an overt message of vicious racism and anti-Semitism."
Mr. Foxman continued: "As far back as 1972, Farrakhan made public statements reflecting anti-Semitic conspiracy theories about Jewish control of newspapers, radio and television. In the 1970's, he frequently published anti-Semitic articles suggesting that Jews, Israel and Zionism were trying to control the world. Starting in 1984, his anti-Semitic statements became much more frequent and more blatant."
Henry Siegman, executive director of the American Jewish Congress, said Judge Thomas's statement repudiating anti-Semitism failed to dispose of the matter. Before confirming his nomination, the Senate needs to find out why Mr. Thomas expressed admiration for Mr. Farrakhan, Mr. Siegman said, and whether he knew of the minister's anti-Semitism.
 
Exhortation From Farrakhan
 Rabbi Marvin Hier, dean of the Simon Wiesenthal Center, a Jewish human rights organization in Los Angeles, said, "We accept Judge Thomas at his word, that he has never been anti-Semitic and repudiates Louis Farrakhan."
The two speeches, according copies of the texts, included general discussions of the commission and personal observations by Judge Thomas, who said he had lived through "the most brutal experience of discrimination" as a young black in Georgia in the 1950's.
He concluded the speeches by quoting this exhortation from Mr. Farrakhan: "We the poor, we the oppressed, we the blacks, we the Hispanics, we the disinherited, we the rejected and most despised, we will overcome and then together we will be able to say in the words of Dr. Martin Luther King: Free at last, free at last, thank God Almighty, we have united and made freedom a reality at last."

HEADLINE: Black 'Conservatives' United Only by Frustration

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, July 12

 BODY:
President Bush's nomination of Judge Clarence Thomas to the Supreme Court has focused attention on a small group of critics of the traditional civil rights agenda who are identified as black conservatives.
But rather than a cohesive movement, those who, like Judge Thomas, are called black conservatives are a diverse group. Some are conservative, some not. They are defined by the one thing they all have in common -- a frustration with the idea that black people have one agenda defined by civil rights leaders. 
 Just as black people do not speak with one voice, those who part company with the traditional black leadership of groups like the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People or the Southern Christian Leadership Conference do not want to be stereotyped either, they say.
"There's an expectation you're going to hear something from blacks, and when you don't hear it, you get defined as a conservative," said Glenn Loury, an economist at Harvard University. Professor Loury is black and embraces the conservative label, but at the same time he says the grouping of black conservatives is often misleading.
Thus, for example, the writer Shelby Steele, who was hailed by admirers and blasted by critics last year as an outspoken voice of black conservatism, grimaces when asked if he considers himself a conservative.
"Oh, no," said Mr. Steele, an English professor at San Jose State University in California who is a critic of affirmative action and much of the civil rights agenda. Nonetheless, he is a supporter of many social programs for the poor and has voted for Jesse Jackson in California's Democratic primaries. "It's the bane of my life. If you don't identify with the civil rights orthodoxy, by definition, you're a conservative, even though we're pretty much across the board."
Many of those identified as black conservatives credit the civil rights movement for overcoming legal segregation. But most say it has since made black people overly dependent on government programs; that it has developed strategies that help the black middle class more than the black poor, and that it has blamed too many problems of black people on racism instead of stressing individual responsibility in areas like teen-age pregnancy. The dissenters' biggest influence may be in broadening the debate on civil rights rather than in winning over vast numbers of blacks to their cause.
By any estimation, blacks who embrace the conservative label are a sliver of the black population with minimal political power. More than a decade after black conservatives first gained attention as an unexpected Republican group, there is one black Republican in Congress, Representative Gary Franks of Connecticut. Only 3 of 436 black state legislators are Republicans.
 
Gravitating Toward Power?

To many liberal blacks and civil rights figures, the lack of support for conservative candidates reflects the degree to which blacks accurately see conservatives as traditional enemies of civil rights, and the degree to which black conservatives are sometimes viewed as little more than turncoats, gravitating toward white power and money in a conservative era.
"These guys run the gamut from political opportunists to out-and-out hustlers," said Derrick Bell, a liberal black professor at the Harvard University Law School.
But polls consistently show that on numerous social issues like crime, abortion and prayer in schools, blacks hold largely conservative views. Many of those who dissent from the civil rights agenda say the nomination of Judge Thomas is helping to show that the black population is not monolithic.
"If nothing else, the nomination of Clarence Thomas will break the stereotype that if you're black and you're smart and you're prominent, you must be a liberal Democrat," said Stephen Carter, a law professor at Yale University whose criticisms of affirmative action have led him to be identified as a black conservative, a label he shuns. "Mind you, I have nothing against liberal Democrats. I have something against stereotypes."
 
From Many Strands

There are numerous strands tied together under the broad grouping of black conservatives, including the self-help doctrine of Booker T. Washington, the economic nationalism of Malcolm X, the deeply religious traditions of many blacks, and criticisms of affirmative action and other programs that purportedly favor minorities.
Many of the black scholars who first gained attention in the early days of the Reagan Administration for their conservative views, like the economists Walter Williams of George Mason University, Thomas Sowell of Stanford and to a lesser degree Professor Loury of Harvard, fit in comfortably with the conservatism of the Reagan era. They generally believe in free-market approaches rather than government programs; oppose preferential programs for minorities, and say that antipoverty programs have done more to harm blacks than to help them.
But others come from different directions. Robert Woodson, a low-income housing specialist whose National Center for Neighborhood Enterprise in Washington has pioneered many of the strategies favored by Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp, preaches a blend of populism aimed at poor people taking control of the institutions that control their lives.
Mr. Steele and Mr. Carter of Yale, whose "Reflections of an Affirmative Action Baby" will be published this fall by Basic Books, are critics of preferential programs they say subtly demean even those who benefit from them. But like Mr. Steele, Mr. Carter, a former clerk for retiring Supreme Court Justice Thurgood Marshall, does not consider himself a conservative.
 
At Odds With Orthodoxy
 Similarly, when Elizabeth Wright of Manhattan began publishing a quarterly newsletter called "Issues and Views" in 1985, she did not think of herself as a conservative but rather as someone at odds with the civil rights orthodoxy, which included policies like busing with which she disagreed.
Her main theme, echoing the views of Malcolm X, is that blacks made a tragic wrong turn in the 1960's, toward integration and away from economic strategies intended to build up their own communities.
"The civil rights crew diverted us, because it was the easier way out for their clique," she said. "It's easier to beat on the door of the white man to let you into I.B.M. than to go into business with your brother or cousin and open up a little grocery store or hat shop that builds up the black community. That's a long, arduous task, and it doesn't give the prestige so many middle-class blacks crave."
In many ways, Judge Thomas fits the common description of black conservatives, combining conservative instincts on social issues and a philosphical orientation toward individual cases rather than group rights. But his prominence arose more from his position as head of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission than from any contributions he made to conservative thought.
But Judge Thomas, who sits on the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, also represents some of the complexities of those grouped as black conservatives, as evidenced in his fondness for quoting Malcolm X and occasionally chastising white conservatives for their views on race.
Similarly, a report in the Dallas Times Herald that Judge Thomas in 1983 twice inserted laudatory references to Louis H. Farrakhan, head of the Nation of Islam, in the text of his speeches reflects the degree to which the views of black conservatives and black nationalists sometimes overlap.
"Black conservatives are the real nationalists," said Ms. Wright.
Some blacks with conservative views shun the label, not because it does not fit, but because it raises the hackles of many blacks who automatically think of conservatives as enemies of civil rights.
Thus, when Emanuel McLittle of Lansing, Mich., last year started New Destiny magazine, since renamed Destiny magazine, full of conservative opinion and criticism of the civil rights agenda, he adopted the slogan "The Other Side of the Issues" rather than using the word "conservative."
"The word 'conservative' is like a detonator," said Mr. McLittle, a 42-year-old psychologist. "It's something black people automatically respond against."
Mr. McLittle, whose fledgling publication is available only in Los Angeles, Detroit and a few smaller cities, reflects some of the degree to which those labeled black conservatives are willing to tackle subjects once considered taboo. For example, he contends that the rage of black Americans is less a function of the ravages of racism and more a result of their own upbringing and psychological development.
Even the most committed black conservatives, like Mr. Woodson and Mr. Williams, make few claims for the political potential of black conservatives. Mr. Carter ironically quotes Judge Thomas in citing a core problem conservatives face in wooing blacks.
"In one of his Heritage Foundation lectures, he said that the conservative movement will not gain the adherence of larger numbers of black Americans until conservatives become as comfortable standing with black people when they are right as standing against black people when they are wrong," Mr. Carter said.
 
Changing the Debate

On the other hand, conservatives and other critics of traditional civil rights thinking said black conservatives have already had an enormous effect by changing the terms of the debate.
"There are several ways you can influence power," said Mr. Woodson. "One is electoral politics, but ideas have power too."
Mr. Williams said that open discussion of illegitimate births and black-on-black crime, discussion once dismissed as racist, is now fair game, and that broad questions are being raised about the success of government programs for the poor largely because of the critiques of conservative blacks.
"My colleague and friend Tom Sowell says that after we're dead and gone in 2030 or 2040, black people may be the most conservative people on the face of this country because they will have suffered the most from the liberal ideas," said Mr. Williams.
But 40 or 50 years is a long time to wait for vindication. For the short term, blacks outside the civil rights mainstream may have to be content with the role of producing a broader debate among black people.
"People want to see blacks as retrievers: see a bird fall and automatically go get it," said Stanley Crouch, whose essays in his book "Notes of a Hanging Judge" (Oxford University Press) are often harshly critical of the civil rights establishment, but who shuns the conservative label.
He recalled the movie "Breaking Away," in which a white bicycling enthusiast from Indiana becomes obsessed with Italian culture.
"No one said this is an example of a self-hating Midwestern white guy," Mr. Crouch said. "But if that guy's black, people would say, "He's crazy; he hates himself so much, he thinks he's Italian.' The varieties of human choice and thought are not very willingly accepted when the subject is Afro-Americans."

HEADLINE: New Jersey Is Preparing to Seize Mutual Benefit, a Large Insurer

BYLINE: By ERIC N. BERG

 BODY:
Seeking to prevent the largest life-insurance failure to date, New Jersey officials said yesterday that they were preparing to seize control of the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company of Newark. Mutual Benefit, the nation's 18th-largest life insurer, with $13.5 billion in assets, has been reporting deepening financial woes as a result of its heavy investment in troubled real estate.
Senior New Jersey officials said they expected the company to make a formal request for state intervention early next week. But the officials added that the financial troubles of Mutual Benefit, which traces its roots to 1845 and has 400,000 policyholders around the country, had become so dire in recent days that state action was likely with or without a company request. 
 "Things are not improving," a senior official in the administration of Gov. Jim Florio said in an interview yesterday. "Now it has become a matter of protecting the policyholders."
For consumers, a decision by Mutual Benefit to seek temporary refuge would be both good and bad news. It is good in the sense that Mutual Benefit will be stabilized, and the company should then be able to forge ahead with a plan to work through its real estate problems. In the interim, however, policyholders will be seriously inconvenienced.
For example, in addition to a moratorium on the cashing in of individual life insurance policies, the New Jersey insurance commissioner, Samuel F. Fortunato, is expected to issue an order blocking corporate customers from withdrawing any money they invested with Mutual Benefit. And while life insurance death benefits are likely to be paid in full, retirees with annuities could receive smaller monthly checks for a while.
 
Meeting Set for Monday

At Mutual Benefit's headquarters, a spokeswoman said she would have no comment. But a top company executive, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Mutual Benefit's directors would meet early Monday to vote on a resolution that would voluntarily place the insurer in the custodianship of Mr. Fortunato. Mr. Fortunato, in turn, is expected to issue an immediate order blocking life insurance policyholders from cashing in their policies or borrowing against them.
The goal, the Mutual Benefit executive said, is to stanch the flow of cash out of the insurer that has been weakening the company day by day as news of its problems has spread.
When The Record, a newspaper in Hackensack, N.J., published an article yesterday laying out the state's plans, it generated a torrent of calls to Mutual Benefit's headquarters from nervous policyholders demanding their money back. Some Mutual Benefit policyholders even lined up in the company's Newark lobby demanding refunds.
"The preferred thing to do is to nip this in the bud because otherwise certain policyholders will be preferred over others," the Mutual Benefit executive said, referring to how money has been flowing out of Mutual Benefit. "The core businesses of Mutual Benefit are in good shape."
Also of concern to the public is the risk of loss of policyholder money. To date, losses on Mutual Benefit's $5 billion portfolio of real estate loans have whittled its capital -- its cushion against losses -- to less than $500 million. If the value of the company's properties decline an additional 10 percent, the capital would be eliminated. Any future losses would then leave a shortfall that would have to be made up to keep policyholders whole. Unlike most other states, New Jersey has no industry-sponsored guarantee fund that could protect policyholders.
 
 Seeking Wealthy Investor

But Mutual Benefit executives say that bridge may not even have to be crossed. Not only have they been repossessing troubled properties and aggressively trying to find tenants for them, they have also been actively looking for a wealthy partner who would infuse fresh capital into Mutual Benefit. Given that the company's core businesses -- group life insurance and so-called corporate-owned life insurance -- is solidly profitable, the executives hope the money can be raised.
"The real estate problem is not going to take this company over the edge," said Stephen J. Carlotti, Mutual Benefit's chief operating officer, in an interview earlier this week. "This is a situation that can be managed."
But even if Mutual Benefit can be stabilized and rehabilitated, the decision to seek state protection will only deepen the worries of consumers. They were already made anxious after the collapse earlier this year of two large life insurers, the Executive Life Insurance Company and the First Capital Life Insurance Company, both of Los Angeles.
And the announcements by other insurers of sharply lower profits resulting from losses from various categories of investments have only added to the concerns. The lower profits have been reported by big companies like the Travelers Corporation, the Aetna Life and Casualty Company and the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States.
"There is a fear out there about the security of insurance policies, of pensions and of annuities," said Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, the Ohio Democrat, who has held hearings on insurer solvency. "Every time you have a situation like this, in which certain workers might not get their annuities or beneficiaries might not be able to get their death benefits, it strikes fear in the hearts of people."
Unlike Executive Life and First Capital, whose large holdings of high-risk "junk bonds" led to their collapse in the spring, Mutual Benefit holds relatively few junk bonds. Rather, Mutual Benefit's problems relate almost entirely to commercial real estate -- in particular to the roughly $5 billion it lent in the 1980's to developers of office buildings, shopping centers, hotels and apartment complexes. While a few of these properties are in the recession-plagued Northeast, Mutual Benefit issued the bulk of its mortgage loans to developers in the Southwest, the Midwest, and the Middle Atlantic States.
 
 Sought Geographical Diversity

Mutual Benefit's hope was that such geographic diversification would shield the company from large losses, and there is little doubt that Mutual Benefit would be in even worse financial shape if all of its mortgages were on properties in, say, the New York area. But because Mutual Benefit had one of the industry's highest percentages of real estate loans -- about 35 percent of assets, compared with 25 percent for its peers -- the company was hit hard when commercial property values slid nationwide. As of Dec. 31, $407 million, or just under 10 percent of its loans in dollar terms, had been foreclosed upon or were in the process of being foreclosed. By March 31, an additional $100 million in loans was placed in the foreclosure category.
For months, Mutual Benefit executives led by Mr. Carlotti, the chief operating officer, and by Donald F. Haller, the chief financial officer, insisted that Mutual Benefit was doing the intelligent thing by aggressively bringing foreclosure proceedings beginning early last year against delinquent developers.

HEADLINE: Westinghouse Net Off 49.6%; Further Weakness Is Seen

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH, July 12

 BODY:
The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said today that its earnings tumbled 49.6 percent in the latest quarter and that they would stay weak throughout the year, as its recession-hit businesses lagged the nation's economic recovery.
The second-quarter net income of $127 million, a drop from $252 million a year ago, was not unexpected, the company's chairman, Paul Lego, said. 
 But Westinghouse's warning that earnings for the second half of 1991 would be down 25 percent or more from a year ago sent its share price down $1 today, to $25.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.
On a per-share basis, Westinghouse earnings dropped to 41 cents, from 86 cents a year ago. Revenues were $3.174 billion, a notch below the $3.175 billion of a year earlier.
Mr. Lego expressed disappointment about the company's performance.
"Our expectations of an early and strong economic recovery have not materialized," he said in a statement. "That, coupled with the fact that many of our businesses customarily lag the economy, will adversely impact our second half."
Westinghouse, based in Pittsburgh, is involved in a wide variety of businesses, including nuclear power equipment, electronic systems and air traffic control systems.
It owns a number of television and radio stations in its broadcast unit. It also owns a financial services unit, the Westinghouse Credit Corporation, whose earnings dropped 47.3 percent in the second quarter, to $19.5 million from $37 million in 1990.
Operating profits at the financial services unit were off sharply because of underperforming assets and fewer equity profits, the company said. Nor were analysts more upbeat about the unit's future.
"We still have some fairly serious concerns about the financial subsidiary," said Kent Newcomb of A. G. Edwards. Of Westinghouse's per-share earnings in 1991, he added, "They're implying that they're not going to do much better than $2.15, which is well below most estimates."

HEADLINE: U.S. Messages on July 1990 Meeting of Hussein and American Ambassador

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 12

 BODY:
Critics of United States policy toward Iraq in the period before the invasion of Kuwait last August have accused the Bush Administration of failing to give Baghdad adequate warning of the consequences of military action against Kuwait.
At the center of the dispute is a July 25, 1990, meeting between April C. Glaspie, the United States Ambassador to Iraq, and President Saddam Hussein. In September, Iraq released what it described as a transcript of the meeting, but the Administration said the Iraqi document was incomplete and misleading, and in March Ms. Glaspie said it was largely fabricated. 
 Here are excerpts from a July 25 cablegram from Ms. Glaspie to Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, describing her meeting earlier that day with President Hussein, and from a July 28 cablegram from Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger to Ms. Glaspie. The cablegrams were obtained by The New York Times today.
 
GLASPIE MESSAGE
 
SUMMARY
Saddam told the Ambassador July 25 that Mubarak [President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt] has arranged for Kuwaiti and Iraqi delegations to meet in Riyadh, and then on July 28, 29 or 30, the Kuwaiti Crown Prince will come to Baghdad for serious negotiations. "Nothing will happen" before then, Saddam had promised Mubarak.
Saddam wished to convey an important message to President Bush: Iraq wants friendship, but does the U.S.G. [United States Government]? Iraq suffered 100,000's of casualties and is now so poor that war orphan pensions will soon be cut, yet rich Kuwait will not even accept OPEC discipline. Iraq is sick of war, but Kuwait has ignored diplomacy. U.S. maneuvers with the U.A.E. [United Arab Emirates] will encourage the U.A.E. and Kuwait to ignore conventional diplomacy. If Iraq is publicly humiliated by the U.S.G., it will have no choice but to "respond," however illogical and self-destructive that would prove.
 
EXCERPTS
Ambassador was summoned by President Saddam Hussein at noon July 25. Also present were Fonmin Aziz, the President's office director, two note takers and the Iraqi interpreter.
Saddam, whose manner was cordial, reasonable and even warm throughout the ensuing two hours, said he wished the Ambassador to convey a message to President Bush.
. . .
Picking his words with care, Saddam said that there are "some circles" in the U.S.G., including in C.I.A. and the State Department, but emphatically excluding the President and Secretary Baker, who are not friendly toward Iraq-U.S. relations. He then listed what he seemed to regard as facts to support this conclusion: "Some circles are gathering information on who might be Saddam Hussein's successor"; they kept up contacts in the gulf warning against Iraq; they worked to insure no help would go to Iraq (read Exim and C.C.C. [Export-Import Bank and Commodity Credit Corporation]).
Iraq, the President stressed, is in serious financial difficulties, with $40 billion debts. Iraq, whose victory in the war against Iran made an historic difference to the Arab world and the West, needs a Marshall plan. But "you want the oil price down," Saddam charged.
Resuming his list of grievances which he believed were all inspired by "some circles" in the U.S.G., he recalled the "U.S.I.A. campaign" against himself, and the general media assault on Iraq and its President.
Despite all these blows, Saddam said, and although "we were somewhat annoyed," we still hoped that we could develop a good relationship. But those who force oil prices down are engaging in economic warfare and Iraq cannot accept such a trespass on its dignity and prosperity.
The spearheads (for the U.S.G.) have been Kuwait and the U.A.E., Saddam said. Saddam said carefully that just as Iraq will not threaten others, it will accept no threat against itself.
. . .
Saddam said he fully believes the U.S.G. wants peace, and that is good. But do not, he asked, use methods which you say you do not like, methods like arm-twisting.
Iraq will have to respond if the U.S. uses these methods. Iraq knows the U.S.G. can send planes and rockets and hurt Iraq deeply. Saddam asks that the U.S.G. not force Iraq to the point of humiliation at which logic must be disregarded.
. . .
The Ambassador thanked Saddam for the opportunity to discuss directly with him some of his and our concerns. President Bush, too, wants friendship, as he had written at the Eid and on the occasion of Iraq's national day. Saddam interrupted to say he had been touched by those messages.
. . .
Ambassador said there were many issues he had raised she would like to comment on, but she wished to use her limited time with the President to stress first President Bush's desire for friendship and, second, his strong desire, shared we assume by Iraq, for peace and stability in the Mideast. Is it not reasonable for us to be concerned when the President and Foreign Minister both say publicly that Kuwaiti actions are the equivalent of military aggression, and then we learn that many units of the Republican Guard have been sent to the border? Is it not reasonable for us to ask, in the spirit of friendship, not confrontation, the simple question: What are your intentions?
Saddam said that was indeed a reasonable question. He acknowledged that we should be concerned for regional peace, in fact it is our duty as a superpower. "But how can we make them (Kuwait and U.A.E.) understand how deeply we are suffering." The financial situation is such that the pensions for widows and orphans will have to be cut. At this point, the interpreter and one of the note takers broke down and wept.
After a pause for recuperation, Saddam said, in effect, believe me, I have tried everything. We sent envoys, wrote messages, asked Fahd [King Fahd of Saudi Arabia] to arrange Quadripartite Summit (Iraq, S.A.G.[Saudi Arabian Government], U.A.E., Kuwait). Fahd suggested oil ministers instead, and we agreed to the Jidda agreement although it was well below our hopes. Then, Saddam continued, two days later the Kuwaiti Oil Minister announced he would want to annul that agreement within two months. . . .
At this point, Saddam left the room to take an urgent call from Mubarak. After his return, the Ambassador asked if he could tell her if there has any progress in finding a peaceful way to defuse the dispute. . . . Saddam said that he had just learned from Mubarak the Kuwaitis have agreed to negotiate. The Kuwaiti Crown Prince/Prime Minister would meet in Riyadh with Saddam's No. 2, Izzat Ibrahim, and then the Kuwaiti would come to Baghdad on Saturday, Sunday or, at the latest, Monday, July 30.
"I told Mubarak," Saddam said, that "nothing will happen until the meeting." And nothing will happen during or after the meeting if the Kuwaitis will at last "give us some hope."
The Ambassador said she was delighted to hear this good news.
 
EAGLEBURGER MESSAGE
Please deliver the following as an oral response from President Bush to Saddam Hussein's message.
I was pleased to learn of the agreement between Iraq and Kuwait to begin negotiations in Jidda to find a peaceful solution to the current tensions between you. The United States and Iraq both have a strong interest in preserving the peace and stability of the Middle East. For this reason we believe that differences are best resolved by peaceful means and not by threats involving military force or conflict.
. . .
As you know, we will have fundamental concerns about certain Iraqi policies and activities. And we will continue to raise these concerns with you, in a spirit of friendship and candor, as we have in the past. . . .

HEADLINE: Patents;
Superconductors Made In Bulk Quantities

BYLINE: By Edmund L. Andrews

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
A former researcher at the Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, a Federal laboratory in Berkeley, Calif., has patented a new method for making high-temperature superconductors in bulk quantities. The new method is intended to overcome practical problems associated with superconductors, which are materials that conduct electricity with almost no resistance.
New classes of ceramic-like materials discovered several years ago become superconducting at temperatures around 190 degrees below zero centigrade, warmer than previous types of superconducting metals. Researchers are trying to raise temperatures even further to make them economically practical. 
 The new patent covers a method of making a particular class of superconductors known as 1-2-4 materials, which are less brittle than others but are difficult to produce in sufficient purity without making them in extremely thin sheets. The new patent allows these materials to be made in bulk form.
The inventor is also seeking patents that would apply the same method to other kinds of semiconductors.
Previously, superconductors were made by combining yttrium, copper and barium with oxygen in an extremely hot furnace. Unless the materials were produced in extremely thin sheets, however, some of them formed oxides with no superconducting ability.
The key to the new method is using oxygen pumped in through the furnace at extremely high pressure, which apparently forces the components to form an oxide containing all three elements.
Donald Morris, a visiting scientist at Lawrence Berkeley, received patent 5,024,992.

HEADLINE: World Debt Champion

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Economic Crisis Forcing Once Self-Reliant India to Seek Aid" (news article, June 29), you repeat a widely held misconception that India is "the world's third largest debtor after Brazil and Mexico." 
 Since the mid-1980's, the United States has turned from the world's largest lender into the world's largest debtor. Our foreign debt now exceeds that of Brazil, Mexico, India, Argentina, Poland and the Philippines combined.
 
DIETRICH FISCHER
Robbinsville, N. J., June 29, 1991

HEADLINE: The Year the Shooting Eased Up

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
Last year, for the first time, Americans took fewer snapshots than in the year before.
 According to the new edition of the Wolfman Report, an annual survey of the photography industry, photographers took 15.72 billion pictures last year, down from 16.12 billion in 1989. The survey, published yesterday by Popular Photography magazine, also said new camera sales dropped to 18.7 million units, from 20 million in 1989. 
Part of the decline in still photography and camera sales may reflect the growing popularity of video cameras. Sales of camcorders rose 29 percent, to almost three million units last year, and more than 7 out of 10 American homes have videocassette recorders capable of playing home videos. But camcorder sales have been surging for five years, and surveys by the Eastman Kodak Company suggest that within 18 months of buying a camcorder, its customers resume taking almost as many still photos as they did previously.
 
Effect of the Recession
 War jitters after Iraq invaded Kuwait last August and the economic recession were probably the real cause of the decline, industry executives and analysts said. They noted that those events sharply reduced vacation travel.
 "Photography is now so big that it can't avoid being affected by the general economy," said Harold Martin, who has edited the Wolfman Report since its creator, Augustus Wolfman, died in 1974.
 Mr. Martin and many industry analysts expect the general photography market to grow again as the economy improves, although at a modest rate. Sales are still rising for the small 35-millimeter "point and shoot" cameras that focus automatically. Features like built-in zoom lenses, improved flashes and other devices that help amateurs compose better pictures are being added to many cameras.
 But experts say the big question mark is how long before there are any really innovative new products to stimulate sales in the amateur photographers' market.
 Few analysts seem to believe that recenty announced inventions like systems for storing photos on compact disks for display on television will have wide enough appeal to raise sales significantly, at least not for a long time to come.
 "You would have to have a lot of software available to allow people to manipulate and transmit the pictures," said Curt Rohrman, a photography analyst for First Boston. "Just being able to look at them on the television isn't that big a deal."
 But one analyst, Peter Enderlin, said Kodak was working on a new camera and film that might bring sales back to double-digit growth in the middle part of the decade.
 Basing his analysis on Kodak patents and other research, he said he expected the Rochester-based company to market a 35-millimeter camera with a film cartridge that could be dropped into place as simply as a battery slides into a flashlight. The film would also be able to store digital information that would help it adjust to the camera and shooting conditions and make it easier to process.
 Projecting that Kodak would start selling the camera in 1992 or 1993, Mr. Enderlin recently began recommending that investors start buying Kodak stock. He said the new products might raise the popularity of photography with the growing population of elderly citizens, who presumably do not like fumbling with today's film and cameras.
 More convenient photoprocessing is also expected to help. The trend to microlabs -- highly compact, automated film developing centers -- is rapidly expanding the number of retail outlets that can make money by developing film for consumers. The next step may be film equivalent of automated bank tellers, where film is deposited in a machine and later picked up.
 
Photofinishing Costs Unchanged
 Last year, Americans spent $4.57 billion on consumer photofinishing, the same amount as the year before, according to the Wolfman figures. Because of higher prices, the photography equipment business actually grew slightly in value last year, up 2.3 percent, to $21.15 billion. But instant photography, the market segment dominated by the Polaroid Corporation, continued its decline in popularity. The number of new instant cameras sold fell by 20 percent, to 1.4 million, and the number pictures taken fell by 3 million, to 937 million.
 The annual Wolfman industry survey, begun 39 years ago, delves into photography the way Guinness looks at world records. It has the usual microscopic details prized by companies in the business: photo equipment sales at military bases ($126 million); industrial use of X-ray film (86 million sheets); number of rolls of film used by the average skin diver (29.6), and so on.
 For the industry, perhaps the most heartening trend was in the balance-of-trade figures. Imports dropped 1.7 percent, to $5.79 billion, the first decline since 1982, while exports rose 14.9 percent, to $3.62 billion. A number of foreign markets grew robustly. In Germany, for instance, the number of cameras sold rose 15 percent, to 4.1 million, while the number of packs of film sold jumped nearly 16 percent, to 132 million.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY;
Debt-Ridden Resort Closes On St. Croix

 BODY:
Faced with severe losses in the aftermath of Hurricane Hugo and the recession, the Carambola Beach Resort, the largest hotel in St. Croix in the United States Virgin Islands, has closed and gone into receivership.
The closing of the 158-room resort, which opened four years and a half years ago, reduces the number of hotel rooms available in St. Croix to fewer than 1,000. Before the island was devastated by the hurricane in September 1989, there were nearly 1,800 tourist rooms. After the hurricane it took 14 months to repair the upscale, 28-acre resort, which reopened in November 1990. But the 1990-91 tourist season in St. Croix, as in much of the Caribbean, was hurt by the recession and the Persian Gulf war. 
 Carambola was built by the Florida developer George Jacobus's Davis Beach Company on 4,000 acres purchased from the Rockefeller family in the mid-1980's. Its first manager was Rockresorts, which later turned over management to Greenbrier Resort Management. Greenbrier allowed its contract with Davis Beach to run out, forcing the resort to close June 14. Excluded from the receivership was the 18-hole Carambola golf course, which is still operating.
