HEADLINE: Fixed-Rate Loans Gain In Popularity

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
AFTER a decade that unleashed adjustable-rate loans, negative amortization loans, low-documentation loans and dozens of exotic new mortgages on the home-buying public, borrowers have returned en masse to conventional, fixed-rate financing, but with a new twist.
Lenders say the most popular loan now is the traditional standard: the fixed- rate 30-year mortgage. But they also report heightened demand for fixed rate loans with shorter terms -- most commonly 15 or 20 years -- and say a growing number of people who already have mortgages are paying more each month so the loans will be retired early. 
 The shift, coming at a time of slow sales and weak prices across most of the country, appears to reflect a broad change in attitudes toward home ownership and mortgage finance. Where the buyers of the 80's tended to focus on how much they might profit when they sold, today's buyers wonder how much equity -- the paid-up investment in their homes -- they will build by staying put.
"We are seeing a much more conservative borrower psyche," said Larry Dale, vice president and chief of marketing for the Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie Mae, the largest buyer of mortgages from thrifts, banks and mortgage brokers. "It fits with demographic trends."
Analysts say one reason for the new conservatism is the aging of the Baby Boom generation. With a population bulge of people now in their 40's, more people are planning their finances around retirement, and want to be sure their mortgages will be retired by the time they are.
But the recession and the real estate slump are affecting the attitudes of all borrowers, regardless of age.
"The 90's appear to be the stay-put decade," said Joseph Hu, chief of mortgage research for Nomura Securities International, a Wall Street subsidiary of Nomura Securities Company, a Japanese brokerage. Family mobility has been reduced by a slowdown in job transfers and new hiring, he said, and the sluggish housing market has cut down the number of people moving up from one house to another, even within the same communities. One longstanding rule of thumb among mortgage lenders has been that Americans stay in their homes for an average of seven years. Although there is no precise measure for the last decade, "whatever the average is for the 90's, it will be longer," Mr. Hu said.
Thus, as they hunker down for a longer stay, more people are structuring their financial plans around payment schedules on mortgage loans, and calculating how long it will take to gain a large equity stake, or even a little one.
"WE think it is essential to build some equity," said Joann Mardesich, a medical office manager in Inglewood, Calif., who, with her husband, a physician, last month purchased a two-bedroom co-op on Manhattan's Upper West Side. They selected a fixed-rate 15-year loan.
Mrs. Mardesich said the co-op will be used initially by their son, Kevin, a student at New York University. But since all three of the couple's children are living in the New York area, she said she and her husband eventually plan to spend several months a year in Manhattan, and have no plans to sell the co-op before the 15-year term of amortization.
After calculating how slowly they would build equity with a 30-year mortgage, Mrs. Mardesich said, the 15-year loan "seemed like a much better investment."
Although most home buyers are at least vaguely aware of the huge amount of interest they must pay on mortgage loans, the numbers can still come as a shock. In the case of a $100,000, 30-year, fixed-rate mortgage loan, with 10 percent interest, a borrower's total payments would be $315,926, including $215,926 in interest.
In the first 10 years of the loan, the borrower would obtain only $9,162 in equity. But during the last 10 years, making the same monthly payment of $877.57, the borrower would gain $66,407 in equity.
"We are getting a lot more requests for amortization schedules, and a lot more questions from people wanting to know what they have to do to pay off their mortgages by a particular year," said Gregory Samp, president of Sibley Mortgage Corporation, based in Rochester, a mortgage lender in most of New York State and Ohio.
"Equity has become the name of the game," said Paul Havemann, vice president of HSH Associates, a Butler, N.J., publisher of nationwide information on mortgages. "Borrowers have gotten tired of gimmicks."
To be sure, not all of the new forms of mortgages that were introduced in the 80's have been relegated to the scrap heap. And lenders continue to concoct new products for those whose desire simply to afford a home far outweighs their longer-term concerns about building an equity investment.
"There is still a group of borrowers out there excited about getting into a house, and affordability is the number one priority," said Walter Bucbynski, senior vice president of Margaretten and Company, a Perth Amboy, N.J., mortgage banking concern that makes home loans in 17 states.
One form of mortgage introduced over the last two years by Margaretten and most other lenders is the "two-step" loan, a modification of the adjustable-rate loans that swiftly came to dominate the market during the early 80's, but have since fallen into disfavor.
The two-steps are normally offered with five- or seven-year initial terms, when the interest rate is fixed at 0.75 percent or a full percentage point lower than what is charged on 30-year, fixed-rate loans. But after the initial five- or seven-year term ends, the interest rate reverts to a different fixed rate that remains unchanged for the life of the mortgage, and is slightly higher than the prevailing rate on 30-year, fixed-rate loans.
Lenders say the two-step loans are popular among first-time buyers and young families, most of whom plan to move on to another residence before the end of the initial five- or seven-year term.
For borrowers and lenders alike, the two-steps may be proving a safer, more predictable alternative to the type of adjustable rate loans that were popular in the last decade. In 1984 and 1985 the adjustables -- with rates adjusted every six months, every year or every three years -- accounted for over half of the loans extended, according to the Federal Housing Finance Board.
But later in the decade, fierce competition prompted lenders to offer artificially low introductory "teaser" rates on the adjustables. Many also employed lax standards in which applicants could be approved even though their incomes were sufficient to cover only the low first-year level of payments. The result was losses for lenders and a financial squeeze for many home buyers.
In May, the most recent month for which data are available, the Federal Housing Finance Board reported that adjustables -- including the new two-steps -- accounted for 21 percent of all mortgages. Others in the industry, including Fannie Mae and HSH, said most of the applications for adjustable-rate loans were now for the two-step variety.
With fixed-rate mortgages now commanding 79 percent of the market, experts say borrowers are basing decisions on the term of the loan and its payment schedule. The standard 30-year fixed rate loan remains by far the most popular for the simple reason that monthly payments on shorter-term loans can be hundreds of dollars more.
But lenders charge slightly lower interest on fixed rate loans with shorter terms. That means that those who expect to stay in their homes for more than a decade, or who simply want to be sure they are gaining some significant equity during the first few years of their loan, will come out ahead if they take a 15-year or 20-year fixed rate loan.
At Fannie Mae, Mr. Dale said that 15-year fixed rate loans now account for 20 percent of the mortgages now being purchased from thrifts, mortgage bankers and commercial banks, compared to 12 percent a year ago.
Twenty-year fixed rate loans, which have been introduced only this year by most lenders, are far less popular but operate on the same principal as 15-year loans -- they have lower interest rates and are paid off more quickly than 30-year loans, but have high monthly payments.
The differing costs are illustrated by the Federal Housing Finance Board, which provided figures for typical fixed rate mortgages now being offered. Home buyers taking a 30-year loan would be charged 9.5 percent interest and pay $840.85 a month; those with a 20-year loan would pay 9.4 percent and $925.61 a month; and those with a 15-year loan would pay 9.3 percent, and $1,032.19 a month.
The difference between the monthly payments on a 15-year and a 30-year loan -- $191.34 -- is "a fairly nasty spread," said Joseph McKenzie, an economist for the Federal agency. He added that it is probably discouraging most first-time buyers or middle-income families from taking the shorter term loans, particularly those who are determined to buy as much home as they can afford.
One option being offered by a growing number of lenders across the nation is the so-called biweekly mortgage, in which payments are due every two weeks instead of every month. These mortgages have been available for years in some industrial communities of New England and the Middle West, where payments are automatically taken from workers' paychecks.
Lenders say biweekly mortgages are becoming more widespread because they provide a speedier system of paying off a fixed rate mortgage.
By making 26 payments a year, each calcuated at half a full month's payment, at the end of the year the biweekly mortgage holder has paid for 13 full months.
Mr. Dale of Fannie Mae said that 20-year biweekly mortgages were the equivalent of monthly-payment loans with terms of between 22 and 23 years.
For most homeowners who already have fixed-rate 30-year loans and want to increase their equity, perhaps the simplest option is to determine when they want to have their home paid off and then begin a paying additional amounts each month or year to conform to the new schedule. They will continue to pay the original interest rate, which is probably slightly higher than that on a 15- or 20-year loan, but prepaying provides the option of shortening the term of the loan without refinancing.
Mr. Havemann of HSH said this option should be considered by people whose incomes are insufficient for them to qualify for 15-year or 20-year mortgages on the homes they want, but who do qualify for 30-year financing.
"The thing to do is buy the best you can qualify for," he said. "Then you prepay -- you buy the loan down. It comes to the same thing as a 15- or 20-year mortgage."

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:

Reallocation of Shares
 
Question: I own two co-op apartments that have been combined. The certificate of occupancy has been changed and it is now legally considered one unit. But I am still paying two maintenance fees. Am I entitled to a reduction in my maintenance now that I have one apartment instead of two? . . . Janet Reyes, Manhattan
 
Answer: Probably not. But you might check the bylaws to find out how share allocation and maintenance is determined.
In most co-ops, it is determined by a formula that considers size, location in the building and such amenities as balconies and terraces. Even if your work to join the two units has been considerable, most of those variables probably have not changed.
According to Mary Ann Rothman, executive director of the Council of New York Cooperatives, it is not likely that the board of your co-op would be able to justify a reduction in your maintenance.
"There is no easy way around the issue of share allocation and absolute equity when it comes to maintenance distribution," said Mrs. Rothman. "When changes are made, shares just don't dissapear into outer space.
If a board reduced the maintenance in one apartment it would have to have increases somewhere else to compensate for the lost income."
 
 
 
'For Sale' Signs

 
Question: Is it true that in New York City only realty companies and real estate brokers, not homeowners, can post a "For Sale" sign on the front lawn of a house? . . . Ike Friesem, Fresh Meadows, Queens
 
Answer: No. City regulations pertaining to "For Sale" signs in residential areas do not prohibit homeowners from putting out signs themselves. However, there are other regulations regarding such signs. The code permits small signs as long as they are for "the direction or convenience of the public." The sign must refer to the property where it appears and it cannot be more than five square feet (2 1/2 by 2 feet, for example).
 
 
 
Rent Regulation Rules

 
Question: I would like some printed information on New York City's rent control and rent stabilization. Where would I go? . . . Robert Hotman, New Hyde Park, N.Y.
 
Answer: To the offices of the state's Division of Housing and Community Renewal, the agency that has jurisdiction over rent regulation. The main New York office is at Gertz Plaza at 92-31 Union Hall Boulevard in Jamaica, Queens. You can get a copy of the 1990 Guide to Rent Regulations. Although complete, the language is technical and not easy to read without a familiarity with legal language.
More readable, however, are Fact Sheets that the Department of Housing and Community Renewal publishes. There are 24 bulletins providing information on on matters ranging from rent overcharge complaints to the legal procedure for evictions.
The agency is now preparing a new brochure called "Twenty Questions: Answers to Tenants' Most Frequently Asked Questions on Rights and Protections," which it expects to start distributing after Labor Day.
"The new booklet has been designed to be the most up-to-date, acessable and user friendly package of information so far," said Alan Hammerman, a spokesman for the agency. "It will be available both in English and Spanish versions."
There are no charges for any of these materials and they are available in the rent administration offices in each borough as well as at the main office.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: Nonprofit Offices;
New York Proposes a Center for the Tax-Exempts

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
A DECADE ago, with all the businesses whose headquarters it claimed, New York City also called itself home to the American Cancer Society, Girl Scouts of the U.S.A., National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, United Presbyterian Church and Young Men's Christian Association -- among other leading nonprofit groups.
Today, you would have to go to Atlanta to find the Cancer Society, Baltimore to find the N.A.A.C.P., Louisville to find the Presbyterians and Chicago to find the Y.M.C.A. 
 And it seemed until recently that the Girl Scouts might move from 830 Third Avenue to Atlanta, Baltimore, Cleveland or St. Louis.
Last month, the Girl Scouts announced they would stay in New York -- for the time being. But even as Mayor David N. Dinkins and other officials celebrated the decision by that organization to keep 400 employees in Manhattan, the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants was announcing that it would move 600 of its 750 employees from Rockefeller Center to the Harborside Financial Center in Jersey City.
"In 1980, about 4,000 national associations were headquartered here," said Joel A. Dolci, president and chief executive officer of the New York Society of Association Executives. "In the last decade, we've lost 2,000. That's an average of about 200 a year. Although we don't have specific figures, it had a tremendous negative effect on the economy of the City of New York."
Hoping to stem the exodus, the Dinkins administration is shopping for what it calls an Association Center -- a "financially stable" commercial building, preferably south of Fulton Street, with at least 500,000 square feet of space, 400,000 of which must be available within a year, for use as headquarters or back offices by national nonprofit charitable organizations and trade associations.
"I've always felt very strongly that not-for-profits are a business," said Sally Hernandez-Pinero, the Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development. "People take the words 'not-for-profit' too literally. When it comes to the revenues generated for the city, they're a very important force."
"We're very excited with the city's giant step forward to try to do something to salvage the association community," Mr. Dolci said. However, he also sounded a note of caution: "We don't have much time. At least 30 organizations that we're aware of are considering moving out of New York City in the next 36 months."
In requesting proposals, the city's Economic Development Corporation said it "intends to structure a transaction which would reduce or eliminate real-estate taxes, as well as sales taxes on construction materials for planned improvements in the portion of the building occupied by" nonprofit groups.
 At its core, Ms. Hernandez-Pinero said, the proposal is meant to address the fact that when nonprofit organizations rent their space, they have to pay the real-estate taxes passed on by their landlords. Certain kinds of organizations would be exempt from taxes, however, if they owned their space.
One way the city has proposed structuring the center, therefore, is as an office condominium, in which space would be sold -- rather than rented -- to tax-exempt organization. Landlords have another 10 days to respond to city officials. Forty owners attended a recent meeting to learn how to tailor proposals to the needs of nonprofit tenants.
This is not the first time that an Association Center has been proposed. Nine years ago, an effort was begun to build a 1 million-square-foot center, financed by the New York State Dormitory Authority. Prospective occupants, according to Mr. Dolci, included the American Hotel and Motel Association, American Institute of Certified Public Accountants, Cystic Fibrosis Foundation and National Association of Accountants.
"These people were pledged to purchase in a condominium relationship and live together," Mr. Dolci said. "At that time, the authority ran into a little difficulty," he added. It had invested 60 percent of its portfolio with the Lombard-Wall financial concern, which declared bankruptcy in August 1982. "So it put a halt to this project and we, in turn, tried to get the city interested," he said. "But we were not successful."
AT least eight potential occupants for the center in 1982 have left or are leaving New York City. In the case of the certified public accountants' group, executive headquarters will stay at 1211 Avenue of the Americas, between 47th and 48th Streets, although a great majority of employees will be shifted across the Hudson River next year.
"The city does a great job when there is a potential loss of 5,000 workers," Deputy Mayor Hernandez-Pinero said. "I'm not sure we've responded as well when there was a potential loss of 500 workers. We need to be incredibly aggressive, regardless of the number of jobs at risk."
One of the first tests of this new approach came with the Girls Scouts.
The Girl Scout headquarters, a 13-story glass box at Third Avenue and 51st Street, was begun in 1956, to designs by William T. Meyer and Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, and dedicated in 1958, with Gov. W. Averell Harriman in attendance. The Girl Scouts organization owns the structure and occupies almost all of it, about 120,000 square feet.
As the building's age would suggest, it is due for a renovation. And the magnitude of that work would thoroughly disrupt operations within. "That is why we were into this decision," said Mary Rose Main, national executive director of the Girl Scouts. "It's not that we didn't like our location." In May 1990, a site-selection task group was formed to study alternatives to 830 Third Avenue.
Manhattan was one of five contenders for the headquarters site. "We are a national organization," Ms. Main said, "so we don't feel that geographic location is a binding force. Truly, we could be located in any city."
The site-selection committee established several criteria. "Very high on the list was the importance of a diverse work force," Ms. Main said, "so we would be located where we could have all racial and ethic groups represented. And it had to be a place that would give the organization high image and visibility. And we have a lot of traveling staff, so there had to be air accessibility."
Two major strikes against New York, predictably enough, were costs and crime. "When you think about bringing in staff from across the country," Ms. Main said, "it's harder to do in New York. It's the perception of fear and the concern about the financial condition of the city."
In the city's favor was incumbency. "Disruption was a major factor" in tipping the balance to New York, Ms. Main said. "It is most important for our attention, time and resources to be placed on our mission and organization, rather than sites, facilities, bricks and so forth."
Ultimately, the organization decided to remain in New York. "It will be an issue that we review periodically," Ms. Main said, "but at this time we think it's important to be be here and to continue the development of Girl Scouting at a fast pace."
The Third Avenue building is to be sold and the Girl Scouts will look for 120,000 square feet elsewhere. "We are keeping our options very much open." Ms. Main said, "and have not made a decision whether to buy, lease or lease to buy, although we have owned in the past. We've made a decision to remain in Manhattan and most probably in the midtown area. That can be defined broadly, sometimes." Even if the proposed Association Center is developed, it would not happen quickly enough or offer enough space to serve the Girl Scouts' needs, she said.
"The city worked to be supportive in every way," Ms. Main said, "to be sure that we knew about low-cost financing that would be available through Industrial Development Agency. And they are trying to be helpful in being sure that we know about sites and buildings."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Girl Scouts of U.S.A. headquarters at 830 Third Avenue, at 51st Street. (John Sotomayor/ The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living in: Ridgefield

BYLINE: By ROSALIE R. RADOMSKY

 BODY:
RIDGEFIELD won't let go of its Yankee roots.
"On the surface it hasn't changed at all, " said Sue W. Manning, the First Selectman and a 21-year resident. "Houses and shops are pretty much the same. Maybe they're painted a different color, rebricked or have an added tree." 
 But the 35-square-mile Connecticut town, which lies in the Housatonic Valley in Fairfield County, also is "a sophisticated, up-to-date place with a small-town atmosphere," Mrs. Manning said.
To Anne Margolis, a local sculptor, "it's like a college town without a campus." Main Street, she said, "is two blocks of enormous houses and genteel, discreet commercial space."
Lining Main Street are huge sugar maples that property owners tap for syrup every spring. Set back from the thoroughfare, with its lawns and white gazebo, is the five-acre Ballard Park.
Just down the street a woman in a colonial costume gives tours of the Keeler Tavern, built as a home in 1730. It became a tavern in 1772 and during the Revolutionary War was a popular meeting place for patriots -- and thus a prime target for the British. A British cannonball is embedded in a cornerpost.
In 1907, the architect Cass Gilbert bought the inn and turned it into a summer house. The Keeler Tavern Preservation Society purchased it in 1966.
At times, the charm of the colonial past clashes with modern traffic. On weekdays, said Mrs. Manning, 16,000 cars traverse Main Street [Route 35], which converges with Route 33 at the Cass Gilbert Fountain, dating from World War I. The fountain has been heavily damaged by collisions and restored twice, most recently two years ago.
A BLOCK north of the tavern is the Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art, every bit as colonial in style -- it was a grocery for a century, and then a bank -- but now featuring the Gorilla Girls, a feminist multimedia art group from New York, as part of The Art of Advocacy exhibit.
Among the town's residents are Maurice Sendak, author and illustrator of children's books, and the actor Robert Vaughn. And Eugene O'Neill wrote "Desire Under the Elms" while living there.
North of Main Street, at North Salem Road and New Street, is Settlers' Rock, , where five scouts from Norwalk and Milford camped in 1708 when they came to survey the land. Later that year, the first settlers bought 20,000 acres from Catoonah, the leader of the Ramapoo Indians.The town was incorporated in 1709.
The oldest surviving house, completed in 1714 and now privately owned, belonged to the town's first minister, the Rev. Thomas Hawley.
After the Revolution, the town, already known for its inns, built its economy on farming, mills, quarries and a tannery. Later, hatting shops and shirt factories were established. The town also produced butter, beef and pork and became a leading carriage maker.
In the years following the Civil War, Ridgefield became a country retreat for wealthy New Yorkers. High Ridge became known as Publishers Row. Among the resident bookmen were E.P. Dutton and Charles Henry Holt. At the end of the 19th century Italian and Irish immigrants settled in the area to work on public projects and private estates.
The town's greatest growth occurred from 1955 to 1965, when the population expanded nearly fivefold to 23,000. Easy access to Interstates 84 and 684 and to Route 7 drew many newcomers in the 70's following the shift of corporate headquarters to the suburbs.
"We thought it was a nice town to raise a family in, and I don't think we've been disappointed," said Gwendolyn Tierney, one of the 300 members of the Newcomers Club. She and her husband, John, bought a four-bedroom colonial on two-and-a-half acres "in the upper $300,000's" when they moved from Pennsylvania two and a half years ago.
 "I think in general we're slightly less expensive than Wilton, more than Danbury, and comparable to Fairfield," said Chip Neumann, president of the Connecticut Association of Realtors and partner in the family's Harry H. Neumann Associates realty agency.
Many starter homes are converted cottages. A 1,400-square-foot cottage on Rainbow Lake, for example, typically sells for around $200,000. A farmhouse and a barn with 10 stalls and an indoor riding ring on 40 acres in the rural Ridgebury section has a pricetag of $2.9 million.
Ridgefield has five condominiums, the largest with 150 units, and all are within walking distance of Main Street. The units range in price from $100,000 to about $450,000. House rentals start at $1,400 for a three-bedroom split-level, and go to $2,500 for a four-bedroom, 2,500-square-foot neo-colonial.
Apartments, some above storefronts on Main Street, rent from $800 a month for a one-bedroom to $1,200 for a two-bedroom.
Among the town's elegant restaurants are the Elms and Stonehenge, both also offering rooms, and the Inn at Ridgefield.
There are 60 civic and cultural organizations in the town, among them the Guild of Artists, the Workshop for Performing Arts, the Ridgefield Symphony Orchestra and a civic ballet.
Today, some 30 companies, mostly light industrial concerns, operate in Ridgefield. The largest is Boehringer Ingelheim Pharmaceuticals, which has its headquarters in a converted high school. It plans to move to the Shadow Lake area of town by fall.
There is more than 600,000 square feet of retail space in town, most of it in nine shopping centers. One of them, Copps Hill Common, features the Ridgefield Antiques Center representing 30 dealers.
FINANCIAL problems led to the closing of the local movie theater and the Y.M.C.A. last year. Many residents now drive about 10 minutes to the single-screen Cinema theater in Wilton, or for a workout in that town's Y. Five minutes away in Danbury are eight movie screens and the Danbury Fair Mall for serious shopping.
Ridgefield's indoor ice-skating rink is open from November to March.
A total of 3,300 students attend six schools in the Ridgefield system, where sixth-graders sample three languages -- German, Spanish and French -- for a year and then select one for the next two years. Eighth-graders scored in the top 1 percent in Connecticut Mastery Tests in reading and math last year.
Ridgefield High School, which offers 13 advanced placement courses for college credit, graduated 261 students this year; 91 percent plan to attend college. It has 49 intramural teams and 30 extra-curricular programs. The school is one of 24 nationwide public schools participating in Boston's "A Better Chance" program, which provides educational opportunities for minority students in the top 10 percent of their hometown class.
In the last school year, six young women from urban areas in the Northeast participated in the program. They lived together in a Ridgefield house owned by the program, with a resident director and tutor. The program began five years ago.
The Farmingville, Ridgebury, Veterans Park and Scotland elementary schools cover grades k to 5, the East Ridge Middle School grades 6 to 8. One specialty of the elementary schools is the Art Leap program, which introduces pupils to painting and drawing in the third grade.
The Ridgefield Library, built in 1901, has tripled its space with the help of a $1-million gift from an anonymous local benefactor. It has 70,000 volumes and attracts some 730 visitors daily.
The town owns 2,114 acres of open space offering parks, lakes, an 18-hole golf course, Little League fields and horseback, hiking and nature trails. The nine-acre Martin Park has a spring-fed pond and beach and 30-acre Richardson Park borders Lake Mamanasco, which has a boat launch. In addition, there is Pierrepont State Park with 304 acres.

GRAPHIC: Photos: The historic Keeler Tavern dates to 1730. A single-family house on tree-lined Peaceable Street. (Alan Zale for the New York Times)

The Red Petticoat: Local legend has it that Mary Olmsted hung a red petticoat out a window to save her house as the British raged through town during the Battle of Ridgefield in April 1777. The British took it as a sign of support and rode on. Her husband, Capt. David Olmsted, a rebel company commander, called it treason. "Woman," he reportedly shouted, "if I had seen you, I would have shot you dead." One of two 18th century Olmsted houses still standing on Olmstead Lane may be Mary's.

HEADLINE: Court Committee Backs Videotaping

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
A STATE Supreme Court committee charged with finding the best way to preserve court proceedings added a new twist to the debate between official court reporters and audio-tape transcribers, the two groups that now dominate the field, by recommending a third technology -- videotaping -- as the most accurate, cost-effective option.
The committee, which was appointed in March by Chief Justice Robert N. Wilentz, issued its report last month after hearing testimony from judges, lawyers, tape transcribers and court reporters on the advantages and disadvantages of stenographers versus electronic recording. 
 The committee's report, which is subject to public comment for a period of 90 days, after which time it will be acted upon by Chief Justice Wilentz, was accompanied by a minority opinion that criticized the majority's findings.
Critics of electronic recording say the recommendation endorses what is essentially an unproven technology that will embody all the disadvantages of audio recording while adding a few of its own.
 
Recommendation Fulfilled Mandate
 The committee chairman, Judge Herman D. Michels, presiding judge of the Appellate Division of State Superior Court, said the recommendation fulfilled his group's mandate to find the most accurate and economical method of preserving courtroom proceedings.
"We were asked to look at all of the technology, not just stenographic recording," Judge Michels said. "The consensus was that our recommendation provides a workable solution for the future of the courts."
Judge Michels said the majority of the committee believed that electronically recording court proceedings was more economical than using official court reporters. The average cost of an audio-recording system, he said, is about $2,000, while the cost of equipping a courtroom with a video system is about $60,000.
And though electronic recording systems require a human operator to run them, he said, electronic recording systems are still less expensive than live court reporters.
"Videotaping is expensive, but when the expense is amortized over the life of the equipment, it's still cheaper than the official court reporter," he said.
 Notwithstanding those arguments, Judge Michels said, the committee has recommended that the current practice of audio-recording proceedings in municipal courts be continued. In addition, the committee recommended that court reporters continue to be used in most jury trials and in complex, multiparty cases.
That, however, raises questions in some critics' minds.
"Now what does that say about videotape and audio tape?" said Daniel J. Carone, president of the Certified Shorthand Reporters Association of New Jersey in Springfield. "It says that they don't work," he said. "They still want to rely on the court reporter for the complex cases."
Mr. Carone said that while court reporters welcomed new technology -- including advances in their own field that allow for instantaneous computer-generated transcripts of proceedings -- videotaping was an unproven technology in the courtroom. In addition, he said, the problems encountered with audio tape, including equipment failures and indistinct passages, will occur with video and perhaps be exacerbated because of the more complex technology involved. As a result, he said, the committee's recommendation is at best premature.
"I don't think they did their homework on this one," Mr. Carone said.
 Gloria Irwin, who is president of the Transcribers Association of New Jersey in Audubon and a member of the Supreme Court committee, said she agreed with the committee's recommendation but believed that audio recording should be used in addition to videotaping.
"For transcriptions, the four-track method is still the best way of getting everything," she said, referring to the current practice of using four microphones in the courtroom to help identify specific voices.
In any event, Ms. Irwin said, transcribers would still be needed to provide "hard copy" transcripts of proceedings even if only video were used. As a result, she said, transcribers' business is not likely to be adversely affected.
The ranks of court reporters could dwindle, however, if the new technology proves effective. There are currently 199 official court reporters working in the state court system.
But Judge Michels said the committee's report specifically recommended that court reporters be replaced through attrition rather than termination.
"Even if our recommendation is fully implemented," he said, "no reporter is going to lose his or her job."

HEADLINE: After 2 Years, A Compromise Sets Up Rise In Sales Tax

BYLINE: By JAMES FERON

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
THEY had met many times before, County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke, a Republican, and his Democratic political rival, Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, in a futile effort to find a compromise over an increased sales tax that Mr. O'Rourke considered essential to Westchester's fiscal health but that Mr. Brodsky insisted was unnecessary.
This time, in the Skyway Steak House outside Albany, there was a third participant: Assemblyman Gregory P. Young, a Democrat. He was carrying the outline of a compromise in the two-year struggle over the unusual sales tax proposal, which would provide new revenues not only for the county government but also for towns and villages, most school districts and two small cities that do not impose their own sales taxes. 
 "We talked frankly for a couple of hours," Mr. Brodsky recalled, praising Mr. Young as the "engine" that made the meeting work. Mr. O'Rourke also praised the Mount Vernon legislator. "Greg was extremely helpful," he said. "He got Brodsky and myself together in a little hideaway restaurant and we battled it out, ending with a compromise."
The result is that Westchester has received authority from the State Legislature to raise the county sales tax by 1 percentage point, instead of by the 1.5 percentage points that it requested. It must adhere to a cap on spending for items not required by the state, with spending on those items rising by no more than the increase in personal income.
The plan would raise the sales tax to 6.75 percent from 5.75 in Westchester's towns and villages and in the Cities of Rye and Peekskill on Oct. 15. Mount Vernon and Yonkers, which have an 8.25 percent sales tax rate, and New Rochelle and White Plains, where the rate is 7.25, are exempt from the increase.
The tax will raise an extra $67 million a year -- the figure would have been $100 million under the proposed 1.5-point increase -- of which $22 million will go to the county, $33 million to the affected towns, villages and two small cities, and $12 million to their school districts.
 
Review by Board
 Mr. O'Rourke fought hard for the additional revenues, saying they would help offset the impact of cutbacks in state assistance. Mr. Brodsky had argued that the county should be cutting spending rather than looking for additional income through a regressive tax.
Members of the Board of Legislators, who must approve the legislation for it to take effect, began informal discussions last week on how the money is to be spent, and when. Some support the creation of a special fund for the extra sales tax revenue, so its use can be identified, rather than simply placing the money in the general fund.
The Democratic minority leader in the county legislature, Sandra R. Galef, said: "We hope to establish a special fund for the money, to be used in the 1992 budget to lower the property tax. We're not in favor of using it this year because what will happen is the county will restore all the programs they've taken out, and that's not the way to downsize government."
But she said passing a resolution to that effect would not work "because the County Executive doesn't have to follow resolutions."
"We're looking to pass some kind of act" that has the force of law, Ms. Galef said. She said she did not know "what the level of support is, but they need nine votes" from the Board's 17 members. She said there were "only seven Republicans" of the 10 on the board "supporting" the tax increase plan.
The Board Chairman, John E. Hand, a Republican, said he was inclined to avoid establishing a special fund for the new sales tax. "Some legislators say they want to control how the money is spent. Are they going to make the local municipalities do the same thing?"
Timothy S. Carey, a Republican whose district includes Peekskill and the Town of Cortlandt, said he saw the agreement reached by Mr. O'Rourke, Mr. Brodsky and Mr. Young as "no victory at all, because the north county has lost out to the south county."
 
Constitutional Issue
 "The sales tax is not going to be raised in Yonkers, Mount Vernon, New Rochelle and White Plains, but it will be raised basically in the north," he said. If the new revenues are used to reduce the property tax established by the county to balance its budget, he said, "We will have a situation where taxes being raised in northern municipalities are being used, in part, to stabilize property taxes in the south."
Mr. Carey said also suggested that the plan might be unconstitutional. "What we're now going to be having is a county sales tax being raised at different rates in different communities," he said. "Shoppers in areas that do not have their own sales tax will be paying more county sales tax than the people who buy in the cities, where the overall tax rate is higher but the county sales tax share will be lower."
Mr. Carey did like one aspect of the new sales tax. "As the economy heats up, it generates more money; so it has a built-in escalator," he said.
Does that mean county voters can sit back and watch tax revenues rise? "It depends on what the state does," Mr. Carey said. "State-mandated costs now represent 67 percent of our budget; if Albany keeps pushing mandates on us, county taxes will continue to go up, no matter how much the new sales tax brings in."
 
'A Competitive Edge'
 Legislator Daniel P. Thomas, a Yonkers Republican, said merchants in Yonkers might gain "something of a competitive edge, although not as much as they would have if the extra half percent of sales tax had not been removed" in the compromise negotiations.
Legislator Audrey G. Hochberg, Democrat of Scarsdale, said that she was in favor of the new sales tax but that it should be "put in a special reserve which would be controlled by the Board of Legislators."
Another Democrat, Martin L. Rogowsky of Harrison, said he was opposed to the increased tax plan, especially the linked cap on non-mandated costs. "It means the state is telling us we can't spend more than X dollars on parks or bicycle Sundays," he said. "But what about mandated expenses? Why don't they cap those?"
Legislator Katherine S. Carsky, a Yonkers Republican who heads the board's budget committee, said the full 1.5 percentage points "would have been better, but it's going to relieve the property taxpayer in any case, and that will be a big help."
Mr. Brodsky said it was important to note that the spending cap did not apply specifically to each non-mandated cost, but only to the general category of non-mandated costs. "It doesn't mean that every line in the budget gets the same treatment," he said.
 
Budgeting Flexibility
 The cap also will be determined "by the rate of personal income, or how it moves from a base year." The cap moves with the ability of the community to pay for it, he said. "In a recession, personal income is flat, so if personal income rose by only 2 percent, spending on non-mandated items would go up by only 2 percent."
It would not mean, for example, that the county's share of support for the Hudson River Museum or the Council for the Arts would be limited to 2 percent in each case, he said. The county could maintain its subsidy of one cultural organization at the previous level while using that organization's "share" to increase the other institution's support by more than 2 percent.
Mr. Brodsky said he remained opposed to the new sales tax, even with the linked spending cap and a sunset clause that limits its existence to three years. He voted against it on the Assembly floor.
He also brushed aside any suggestion that he had compromised, saying the measure reached the floor after the County Executive "modified his proposal."
 
Here's Another Version
 The County Executive, not surprisingly, had another version of the events leading up to the Skyway meeting. "I went to Mel Miller and explained that we needed it," Mr. O'Rourke said. Mr. Miller, the Speaker of the Assembly, is a powerful "gatekeeper" for legislation reaching the floor.
"He explained the facts of life to me, saying he had a problem in the Westchester delegation," Mr. O'Rourke said, a reference to the continuing opposition to the sales tax proposal by Mr. Brodsky, who represents Greenburgh, and by Ronald C. Tocci, a New Rochelle Democrat.
"He called them together," Mr. O'Rourke said, "and I think he beat them up a little. What came out of that meeting was a directive to Brodsky to come to some compromise. So I agreed to the 1 percent, the spending cap and the sunset clause, and Brodsky agreed to get out of the way.
"Miller would not have done it without Brodsky going along. It was not a denial of his position; I told him from the beginning that he could vote against it, but let us have it. And that in fact is what happened."
 
And a Rebuttal
 Not quite, Mr. Brodsky said.
"Mel Miller always took the position that the delegations themselves had to solve these things," he said. "But this year, at the last minute, he was confronted with requests for state tax increases from Nassau and Suffolk. He knew he couldn't do some and not the others, and he also knew he did not have the time to negotiate a better plan for us.
"So he said to all three, 'Work out what you can; it's likely they'll all go in one bill.'
"He called O'Rourke and said 'It's time to talk,' " Mr. Brodsky concluded. "Then he went to Greg Young, who has been the leading supporter of the tax, and encouraged him to get us together."

HEADLINE: New Yorkers, etc.

BYLINE: By Enid Nemy

 BODY:
Some everyday occurrences cause acute discomfort and embarrassment to many people. Making a fuss over money, particularly comparatively small amounts of money, is generally one of them.
It's always been acceptable to query the accuracy of even a small amount on a bill sent by mail. Not so acceptable was holding up a supermarket line over a small overcharge. This doesn't mean it wasn't done -- many people quite justly insisted on it -- but there was usually both resentment and disdain from a great proportion of the line. 
 But quibbling over supermarket pennies, no matter how justified, was never the most irritating experience in money matters. Even in palmier days when there were fewer worries about money and jobs, right up there in the forefront of irritations, admitted or not, was the business of splitting restaurant checks.
The unspoken resentment about equal sharing of restaurant bills naturally occurred only when one party's order amounted to a good deal more than the other's. It was almost never mentioned, but the person who handed over half the amount of the bill fumed inwardly. He or she was well aware that a club soda didn't approach the price of three glasses of wine. And the $7 dessert that the other party enjoyed still cost the sharer $3.50.
Life being what it is, it was almost always the bigger drinker and more extravagant diner who, at the end of the meal, said airlily, "Why don't we just split this?" Few had the courage to say, "No, you had two drinks and I had one, and you had soup and dessert, and I didn't."
There were, too, more diners than one would imagine who remembered the price of what they ordered and, at the end of the meal, handed over a bill or bills with "This should cover mine." The amount barely covered the food and drink, never mind tax and tip, but it was a rare soul who said anything. It was just easier to go along.
All these things still happen, and many men and women are still going along. But there has been a small breakthrough. If any good is coming out of the current economic clime, a willingness to speak out about money is somewhere on the list.
Recently, two young couples went out for coffee. One person ordered cake as well. When the bill arrived, the husband of the cake-eater said, "It's $14 and the tip makes it $16, so that's $8 each."
"I think ours is less," said one of the non-cake-eaters. "We just had coffee." After what was described as a "surprised look," the other man said: "Oh, sure, that's right. The coffees were $2 each, so with tax and tip that's about $5.25."
"I'd never have done this in the past," said the young man who had questioned the bill. "I might have been irritated, but I wouldn't have said anything. But my wife just lost her job, and I don't know what's going to happen to mine, and I just figured the time had come to say what I should have said years ago."
It's considerably more difficult to speak out when six people or three couples have dinner and the orders vary considerably. No one wants to go back to the old cartoon of "You had the soup and I had the salad and Jack had the pate and . . ." And no one really wants to take out a calculator.
The solution is a variation of splitting the bill: using two credit cards. In this case, the waiter is told in advance that each couple wishes to be billed separately and writes the orders so that the bills are made out appropriately. If it's a matter of salad and coffee, some restaurants might register displeasure, but if the bill is somewhat heftier, there is rarely a complaint.
When individuals dine together, with wildly varying orders and price differences, the same procedure is sometimes followed if each bill comes to a considerable sum. But one woman recently tried her own version of "remember what you ordered." She had dinner with four friends, two of whom drink considerably more than the others and one who usually orders steak, lobster or other expensive items. The woman's own financial situation has remained stable, she said, but she is now more conscious of how she spends money.
Before they ordered, she made an announcement: "Look, I know that everyone is more aware of money these days, whether we need to be or not. I think it would be fairer, instead of splitting the bill among us, if you each mentally add up the price of what you're ordering and give it to me with what you think is right for tax and tip. I'll pay the bill."
There were murmurs of assent and dissent. In the end the easy way -- "Oh, let's just divide it" -- triumphed. But, she said, "I gave them something to think about."

HEADLINE: Challenged and Chastened, Citibank Pursues the Customer

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Citibank once advertised itself to New York consumers as the bank that never sleeps. But it is discovering that rivals have also been staying up late.
While Citibank remains the largest consumer bank in the New York area, its lead has narrowed. Chemical Bank, long the area leader in serving small- and medium-sized businesses, says it is now the primary bank for about 10 percent of the households in the New York area, up from 7 percent five years ago. Manufacturers Hanover has expanded by acquiring 24 branches, with $2.8 billion of deposits, from the failed Goldome Savings Bank. And Chase Manhattan, whose name is highly regarded by wealthy consumers, has launched a series of new products, most recently a package of special services for checking and savings account customers over the age of 50. 
Indeed, from 1989 to the end of March 1990, consumer deposits at Citibank rose only 1.3 percent, as a total of all savings accounts, certificates of deposit of less than $100,000, and money market accounts. That compares with increases of 12.7 percent at Chemical, 20.2 percent at Chase and 11.6 percent at Manufacturers Hanover.
But Citibank is now waging a campaign to invigorate its New York branch system, a push that is a reminder of the increasing importance of the consumer business at a time when banks are suffering heavy losses on commercial real estate loans and weak loan demand from corporations. Apart from the profits to be made from low-cost deposits and high-interest loans to consumers, the large New York banks view stronger consumer deposits as a way to reduce their borrowings of "hot money" in the wholesale markets.
As Citicorp accumulated losses in 1990 of $299 million from real estate and other corporate lending in the United States, Europe and Japan, officials began pushing harder to increase deposits from the consumer business, which provided profits worldwide of $979 million, more than two-thirds of which analysts estimate came from credit cards and the New York branch network.
CITIBANK plans to capitalize on its winning credit card business and its 1,200 automated teller machines to cultivate new business rather than to imitate the offers for high-interest rate deposits or low-interest loans dangled by banks in the crowded New York market.
Citibank's existing stable of customers could represent a promising pool. Allen R. DeCotiis, president of PSI, a Tampa, Fla., research and consulting firm, said that "surveys show that Citibank customers, bar none, are the most loyal and appreciative of their bank." But he added that having well-satisfied customers does not mean Citibank will have an easy time expanding: "The competition is tougher and consumers have become more sophisticated."
Success, if it comes, is not expected to change wildly the balance in the New York metropolitan market, where 4.7 million households hold nearly 30 million accounts. Unlike in consumer electronics, where a hot, new product can propel a company, success in banking is measured by gains of a few percentage points in market share. "It's an inch a day business, with no home runs," said John S. Reed, Citibank's chairman.
Growth of a consumer banking business comes in two ways: by selling new products to existing customers or by attracting new customers. Pamela Flaherty, head of the New York branch system, said that Citibank is still convinced that "expanding our share of the consumer's wallet is the most profitable way to grow." That was the focus of Citibank's marketing in 1990. "But in 1991 and 1992," she said, "we plan to pay more attention to the acquisition of new customers."
Citibank, however, does not expect miracles from the new campaign. Loren Smith, director of marketing for Citibank's New York branch system, says a gain of up to 200,000 customers, each worth more than $100 of profit a year, would be a welcome addition to its existing 1.5 million customers. That would be fewer than the 300,000 customers Citibank attracted when it pioneered the automated teller machines in the late 1970's, or the 300,000 added in the early 80's with the introduction of a combined statement for all accounts.
THE bank hopes to win new customers by making banking more convenient. It is joining the Cirrus network of banks, which has 60,000 teller machines in 20 countries, and this month expanded its 24-hour bank-by-phone service. In addition to simple inquiries about, say, account balances, customers can now make transfers between accounts.
One example of the bank's program to improve branch design is the new megabranch in Grand Central Terminal. The branch, which is open while it is being renovated, is modeled on a major branch at a train station in Chicago. With long hours, from 7 A.M. to 7 P.M., 20 automated tellers, an investment center for securities sales and purchases and a staff trained in all the bank's products, the Grand Central branch, Citibank hopes to attract customers from the suburban towns served by the commuter railroads. Since Citibank entered Chicago seven years ago, its branches have been so successful that it is now neck-and-neck with First National Bank of Chicago as the leading consumer bank.
Another component of Citibank's plan is to use direct-mail marketing and some old-fashioned handshaking at branches to find credit card customers who would be willing to move their checking and savings accounts to Citibank. Mr. Smith noted that about 900,000 of Citibank's roughly 1.5 million credit card customers in the New York area do not have another account with Citibank. And Citibank has found that some 227,000 of them are tantalizingly close to the bank -- living within five miles of a branch. Every month, Mr. Smith added, 80,000 of them go to a branch to pay their card bills.
While some consultants say the likelihood of selling other banking products to credit card customers is slim, Citibank believes it is worthwhile. Among New York consumers who call Citibank their primary bank, those who started with a checking account have at the end of one year an average of about 4.8 accounts with the bank, while those who started with a credit card have about four. Most banks average slightly more than two accounts per customer.
Citibank's automated teller machines remain a key part of its marketing strategy. Rather than using machines to save teller costs, the objective is to use them "to empower customers -- to give them control over their money," Mr. Smith said. Today, Citibank officials say, the machines are so popular that 350,000 of its 1.5 million customers in New York rarely visit human tellers.
And after spending years and millions of dollars on development, Citibank says the machines have new potential. For example, transactions involving Landmark mutual funds, which the bank sells through 160 securities specialists, could eventually be handled by the machines.
For now, the bank is experimenting with displaying on the machines' screen a list of a customer's recently cleared checks -- a feature already available at some other banks. Another idea is to use the machine to solicit business from customers of other banks who use Citi's machines.
Other bankers scoff at the versatility of Citibank's machines, but Mr. Smith says Citibank's customers use the machines more frequently than those of other banks. And he says the machines' ability to handle exotic transactions, like transfers between credit card, loan and deposit accounts, though used infrequently, is a selling point -- "like a smoke detector that only gets used once a year, but provides peace of mind."
While Citibank is more advanced than some in using technology to extract sales information from customer transactions, Mr. DeCotiis, the analyst, said far more progress is needed. "Until you quit using the branch workers as beasts of burden and provide them with the technology and information to use their brain and anticipate the needs of customers," he said, individual banks will continue to be viewed as undistinguishable.
Finally, Citibank's new emphasis on automated tellers and telephone banking will not come at the expense of branch expansion. Mr. Smith says the bank's branch network is still weaker than he would like in the New York, Connecticut and New Jersey counties surrounding New York City: "Our expansion into those areas is a question of when, not whether."

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Opportunity in Bundesbank Inaction

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
The Bundesbank surprised some financial market participants on Thursday by deciding not to raise Germany's interest rates. But, more important, by sitting on the sidelines it offered Britain and France an opportunity to lower interest rates.
The British took advantage quickly. The Conservative Government of John Major reduced its base lending rate on Friday by a half a percentage point, to 11 percent. 
 The French are also expected to cut rates. But analysts said the Government would probably make just a marginal move, only a quarter of a percentage point. "It will not be great, and if it happens, it will have to be quick," said Dominic Freud, a vice president at the Paribas Corporation in New York.
There was little response in the financial markets to the rate cut in London, however, because the decrease had been expected. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-stock index ended down 13.1 on Friday, at 2,497.4. In France, with the market still waiting for some action, the CAC-40 was unchanged at 1,754.29.
The Bundesbank's inaction offers different opportunities for the British and the French for several reasons. In the British case, there is more pressure to cut interest rates now because Mr. Major faces an election within 10 months and the economy is still in a recession.
In addition, official short-term interest rates in Britain, at 11 percent, are still much higher than in France, where they are at 9 percent. The French economy, though stalled, has not suffered as much as Britain. And the British pound is much stronger within the European Monetary System than the franc, giving the British more scope to cut interest rate without undermining the currency.
Analysts are divided on the outlook for German interest rates from here. A majority seems to be leaning to the view that the Bundesbank will still push rates higher in the next several months. If the German rates move higher, there is less chance for lower rates elsewhere, despite the slowing economies. Most analysts who are optimistic about stock markets in Europe are counting on a decline in interest rates to propel markets, especially those in France, Italy and Spain.
But some people think the signal that the Bundesbank sent on Thursday was that rates will not move higher if the dollar does not continue to climb sharply against the mark. The coordinated selling of the dollar by central banks on Friday, which knocked the dollar down 2.4 percent, increased the likelihood the Bundesbank would not act.
Some analysts even suggested that a deal had been made for the Germans to refrain from pushing rates higher in exchange for strong American support in intervening in the foreign exchange market. After the Bundesbank's inaction on Thursday, the dollar shot up to 1.8340 marks from 1.8080. On Friday, after the heavy selling, the dollar ended at 1.7995
"This seems to be a sensible trade-off," said Gabriele Lamers, an international economist at Deutsche Bank in New York. "Yes, I see this as being a deal."
John Lipsky, director of international bond research for Salomon Brothers in London, thinks that the Bundesbank has chosen to raise interest rates in a more indirect way. Rather than simply increasing its official short-term Lombard and discount rates on Thursday, he said, the central bank decided to hold down the growth rate of the money supply enough so that the demand for capital forces up market interest rates. Then, when these short-term rates have risen, the Bundesbank can change its official rates, saying that it has just followed the direction of the market.
This strategy sends a more passive signal to the market, Mr. Lipsky said. But it also allows the Bundesbank to appear that it is sympathetic to the United States' call for lower interest rates around the world on the eve of the annual economic summit meeting in London. But Mr. Lipsky said this approach could also risk higher inflation by being less aggressive.
Another interpretation is that the central bank decided to give Helmut Schlesinger, who will be the new president of the Bundesbank, the chance to raise interest rates when he takes over after the Bundesbank returns from its summer recess. Karl Otto Pohl, the current president, presided over his last meeting on Thursday.
This is, indeed, a tactical consideration. It gives the new boss, who is known to be a hard-liner on inflation, a chance to show how tough he is as he begins his leadership of the Bundesbank.
Nigel Rendell, an international economist at James Capel Inc. in London, is one who thinks the Bundesbank will not raise interest rates. He argues that the German economy is slowing down and that the impact of the weaker mark on inflation in Germany, as reflected in import prices, has not been severe.
But Mr. Lipsky and others argue that the inflationary pressures in Germany are mounting, with inflation expected to move past 4 percent in July. And the Bundesbank needs to send a message that it does not like inflation so that this higher level will not get fed into wage increases for next year.

HEADLINE: A Quirky Loner Goes Mainstream

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK

DATELINE: CUPPERINO, Calif.

 BODY:
When Apple Computer Inc. announced its all but unthinkable partnership with the International Business Machines Corporation earlier this month, some Apple employees coverd up the rainbow-colored apple in front of their building with a new logo - also an apple, but one done in the characteristic blue stripes of i.B.M. It might have been meant as a protest or merely as a joke. But it was certainly symbolic - Apple is changing its stripes.
 The agreement is only one piece, albeit the biggest, of a huge transformation that the personal computer pioneer is undertaking. Long content with being the BMW of the computer industry, suppying finely crafted machines to a relatively small number of fanatic customers, Apple now wants to become a Ford or Toyota, to move into the mainstream. 
 "The company has decided that it wants to be a major player in the computer industry in the 1990's instead of a niche player," said James R. Groff, managing director of Apple's enterprise systems division, in one of a series of interviews in which Apple executives laid out the reasons behind the seeming madness of consorting with a company that has long been considered Apple's polar opposite.
In search of new muscle and respect, Apple seems to be blasting off in contradictory directions, but the aims are clear: increase market share and survive in an industry going through the early stages of what is expected to be a massive consolidation.
On the one hand, Apple is trying to broaden its mass appeal with lower-priced computers and even pocket-sized devices that will be something of a cross between a computer and a Japanese electronic gadget. Rather than sitting on a desk top, the Apple computer of the future might fit in a pocket, transmit and receive messages by radio waves and respond to spoken commands.
At the same time -- and here is where the I.B.M. deal comes in -- Apple is trying to turn itself into a maker of more powerful computers that can fit together in complex networks capable of handling the computing tasks of corporate America. Instead of being a loner, Apple now wants to join the pack in the automated offices of the future.
 
Dedication to Software
 Apple is also determined to exploit its expertise in software and gain the higher profit margins and higher stock market valuation that come from being perceived as a software company.
Its strength is in the operating system software that makes the Macintosh easy to use, and in a joint venture with I.B.M., Apple plans to compete with Microsoft in selling such operating system software. Apple also hopes to build its Claris subsidiary, which sells word processors, spreadsheets and other applications programs, into a major vendor of software for other computers as well as Apple's.
But Apple will continue to sell hardware, though it might have more products made for it by other companies. In particular, the tiny portable devices are likely to be made by Japanese companies, with Apple contributing software and design.
The transformation will be painful. Already, Apple's profits have dipped because it lowered prices on its computers faster than it lowered its costs. This week, it is expected to report a drop in earnings for the June quarter, the third quarter in its fiscal year, even before a $100 million or so charge for layoffs and restructuring.
Nor is Apple assured of success. The agreement with I.B.M. and the plans for consumer electronics are only statements of intention. It still remains to be seen what products will emerge. And some say Apple, which has basically concentrated on only one product line at a time, is shooting off in too many different directions.
The first branch of the new effort requires a corporate culture like that of a Sony, a company able to quickly innovate, to miniaturize, to sell through mass marketers. The other requires a corporate culture like an I.B.M., with constant handholding of large customers. It is not clear that both those cultures can exist in the same company, especially one that now has neither.
And in trying to become either a Sony or an I.B.M., let alone both, Apple risks losing its own soul -- the quirky individuality that has made it innovative and has attracted some of Silicon Valley's brightest engineers.
Indeed, the I.B.M. announcement came on the heels of another development that has disillusioned many of Apple's workers -- the layoff of 900 people as Apple executives quickly, and some employees say heartlessly, reacted to shrinking profit margins that shouldn't have surprised them.
Apple has been known as a place at which employees were treated well, even pampered, with high salaries and California-like perks (bottled water in the lounges, for example). Now, the marching order is efficiency, and the perks are disappearing. "All the reasons to stay here have been going away," said one software engineer. "It's becoming just like any other company."
 
The Triumvirate
 The transition will also be a big test for John Sculley, Apple's chief executive, whose seven-year tenure has consisted, in one sense, of milking revenues from the Macintosh, a legacy of Apple co-founder Steven P. Jobs, who left the company in 1985.
With the I.B.M. agreement, the curtain has lifted a bit on what is likely to come after Macintosh: machines that could leave a Sculley stamp on the company. Mr. Sculley, who calls himself the company's chief technical officer, is devoting his efforts to advanced product development, leaving day-to-day management to two lieutenants -- Michael H. Spindler, chief operating officer, and Joseph A. Graziano, chief financial officer.
So far, the ruling triumvirate has gotten mixed reviews. Some see a new sense of pragmatism, a willingness to join others rather than rely just on themselves.
"What Sculley and Spindler are trying to do is purge the prima donna attitude at Apple," said Reese Jones, president of Farallon Computing Inc., a maker of computer networking products.
Ed Colligan, general manager of Macintosh products for Radius Inc., a San Jose company that makes video products for computers, added: "I think Apple has turned into a much more aggressive company. To a certain extent, it rested on its laurels for a little too long."
But others say Apple still seems to be thrashing about, lurching from shakeup to shakeup and from strategy to strategy.
"They are still really zigging and zagging," said Esther Dyson, publisher of Release 1.0, an industry newsletter. "Things don't look very smooth."
Mr. Sculley has also attracted most of the heat for the recent layoffs, in part because he himself made $16 million from salary and exercising stock options last year. The troops gripe that someone raking in that much should have at least been able to see the need for expense reductions early enough to avoid sharp layoffs.
Mr. Sculley himself, recuperating from the I.B.M. negotiations, was on vacation last week and not available for interviews. But Mr. Graziano, the chief financial officer, said the company could not have reasonably predicted the quick drop in profit margins, which were partly necessitated by the recession.
As for zig-zagging, he said, "I think this was clearly true. I don't think that's true anymore."
Formulation of the new plan began about 18 months ago when "management came to the realization that the proposition that was driving the company was no longer valid," Mr. Graziano said. That proposition had been to sell nonstandard personal computers that commanded premium prices because they were easy to use, despite being somewhat slow.
But Apple's ability to charge high prices began to erode as other companies began to mimic the Macintosh screen display. Desktop computers known as work stations, from Sun Microsystems and others, offered greater speed through use of a technology called reduced instruction set computing, or RISC. And corporate computer buyers were beginning to demand that vendors adhere to standards so that desktops could be hooked together in networks to take on tasks once handled by larger computers.
Apple decided it needed to gain market share by lowering prices, to move to RISC and to conform to standards.
 
An Unfolding Strategy
 The first part of the strategy was unfolded last October, when Apple introduced three lower-priced machines, led by the $1,000 Macintosh Classic. Unit sales jumped 85 percent in the March quarter, compared to a year earlier. But profits dropped because of the lower gross margins on each machine and because sales of Apple's more expensive machines lagged.
Apple is expected to address some of those problems with a burst of new products. A sophisticated printer for desktop publishing is expected in August. In the fall, there will be a Classic using the advanced Motorola 68030 microprocessor instead of the simpler 68000 chip now used. There will also be two machines using Motorola's most advanced, 68040, chip, one of which can be used as a server, a data repository shared by several smaller machines. And there will be three notebook computers -- a hot area in which Apple has so far missed out -- including one made for it by Sony.
But many analysts think these machines will be among the last of the traditional Macintoshes built on Motorola 68000 series microprocessors. After that, Apple will move to RISC chips designed by I.B.M. and eventually toward new operating systems that Apple and I.B.M. together will try to make into a standard. The letter of intent signed with I.B.M. lays out, in essence, a three-pronged path for Apple.
One surprise is that Apple's first RISC computer will be the Macintosh itself, with the Macintosh operating system altered to run on the I.B.M.-designed RISC microprocessor. The idea is that existing Macintosh software will be able to run on the new machines with few or no changes.
With new horsepower from the RISC processor, "I'm absolutely confident on another five years of the Mac," said Roger J. Heinen, vice president and general manager of Macintosh software architecture. System 7, the current version of the Macintosh operating system, will continue to be improved, he said.
Apple will also introduce a line of desktop work stations and servers that run a version of the Unix operating system now used by I.B.M. But they will be fitted with the Macintosh screen display. Both I.B.M. and Apple will sell such machines, which will be able to run programs written for both the Macintosh and the I.B.M. RS/6000 workstation line.
Finally, Apple will move beyond the Macintosh completely with a new operating system, known by the code name Pink, which it is to co-develop with I.B.M. Pink is extremely ambitious. It is to be able to run on a variety of microprocessors and on computers large and small. Also, it is to be able to run programs written for other operating systems, such as the Macintosh and I.B.M.'s OS/2.
But Pink is not expected out for at least three years. Some skeptics say the only reason Apple is sharing Pink with I.B.M. is that it wants to spread its financial risks because the project has bogged down. Working with I.B.M., however, which has a poor track record in operating system software, could slow Apple further.
Even if no products were to come out of the I.B.M. relationship, Apple executives are hoping the endorsement of I.B.M. will help it sell to large corporations by convincing data processing managers that the Macintosh is not a toy, a perception that irks Apple executives no end.
"You can have the greatest products in the world and against that mythology you're not going to be successful," said Mr. Groff.
The outline of Apple's plans for consumer electronics is somewhat less clear, even to Apple itself.
One area of interest is interactive video, sometimes called multimedia. Apple had been exploring, but has now put on hold, a home entertainment system that would combine the innards of a Macintosh with a CD-ROM player, which could play video and sound and would have brought Apple into competition with the likes of Nintendo and Philips.
 
Working on Gadgets
 Apple is also working on a variety of pocket-sized devices to allow computing "anywhere, anytime." It has shown to developers a prototype of a computer that is operated by a stylus instead of a keyboard. Also in the works is a product known as the Mac Companion, a personal information keeper somewhat similar to the Sharp Wizard.
Apple, which spends about $600 million a year on research and development, has a wealth of technology in its laboratories. It is working aggressively on systems that can understand speech and on computers that can communicate by radio. What is unclear is whether Apple, which has been slow in bringing products to market, can get these technologies out faster, or offer better features, than many other companies also working on such devices.
Keeping its innovative edge while also blending in better with others is a tall order. But at stake is Apple's future as an independent company in a consolidating industry. It is in no danger today, but if it doesn't succeed in its transition, Apple could find by the end of the decade that its rainbow-colored logo really will be changed into blue stripes.
 
 
 
TWO WHO ARE FORMING THE STRATEGIES
 Apple's new strategies bear the imprint of two men who now share leadership of the company with John Sculley, the chief executive. They are Michael H. Spindler, chief operating officer, and Joseph A. Graziano, chief financial officer.
Mr. Spindler was named to his current post in January 1990, after having built Apple's European operations into a success. He runs day-to-day operations while Mr. Sculley spends time in Japan and in Apple's laboratories searching for the breakthroughs that will sustain Apple after the Macintosh.
A native of West Germany who joined Apple in 1980 after stints at the Intel Corporation and the Digital Equipment Corporation, Mr. Spindler, 48 years old, is a roll-up-the-sleeves manager who has worked fast to reorganize Apple and bring in new managers but has left the limelight to Mr. Sculley.
Respected but not loved at Apple, he is not possessed of the old-style Messianic Apple zeal and has pushed the company to collaborate with others and cut expenses. Mr. Spindler, currently on a six-week sabbatical, is expected to be the next chief executive, though it is not clear when that will be. Mr. Sculley, who is 52, is believed to want to stay a few more years.
Mr. Graziano, 47, left Apple in 1985, some say as a result of disagreements with other executives, and eventually became chief financial officer at rival Sun Microsystems. But in 1989, after regimes had changed at Apple, he was recruited back with a multimillion-dollar package more befitting for a baseball player than a corporate type. Distressed at what he saw as lethargy at Apple, Mr. Graziano has become an activist, urging Apple to try to realize more value from its software.
Executives say the top three men have a harmonious relationship, a sharp departure for a company known for widely publicized battles between Mr. Sculley and Apple's co-founder, Steven P. Jobs, and more recently for the disharmony between two Sculley lieutenants who resigned last year -- Jean-Louis Gassee, the flamboyant product development chief, and Allan Loren, the gruff marketing and sales chief.
"A lot of the politics that used to be here have sort of been dispensed with," said Mr. Graziano.
Executives say that the new leadership structure has also led to more direction coming from the top, instead of from middle managers and technical people, as had been the case in the past. The alliance with I.B.M. was championed by Mr. Sculley and Mr. Spindler over the objections of many technical people. The recent layoffs were also ordered from the top.
To some, this is worrisome, a sign that a schism has developed between the chiefs and the rank and file. But an employee survey last year found that one of the great demoralizing factors at Apple was a lack of direction from above. And some executives, long fed up with Mr. Sculley's namby-pamby manner, welcome the stronger leadership.
