LENGTH: 1537 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary/July 7-12

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
The Dismantling of Pan Am 

For Pan American Airways, the nation's first international carrier, the sale last week of its routes to Europe, Africa and Asia to Delta Air Lines amounts to an orderly liquidation. "This is the end game," said Edward Starkman, an airline analyst for Paine Webber. Unable to cope with deregulation, Pan Am filed for bankruptcy protection under Chapter 11 earlier this year but has been selling assets for a decade in a desperate effort to keep flying. If the deal is approved by the bankruptcy courts, Delta will have a bargain. For $260 million it will get the routes, Pan Am's Washington-New York shuttle and 45 planes, 21 of which are nearly new Airbus A-320's. And if everything goes smoothly, the deal is expected to be approved in 45 days. Pan Am will then get $60 million in cash from Delta. But analysts doubt $60 million is enough to keep the airline flying even through December. Delta has agreed to honor Pan Am's tickets through February 1992.
 
A Speculator Off the Hook
 
For John A. Mulheren Jr., the Wall Street speculator, last week brought a dramatic reversal of fortune. A Federal appeals court threw out Mr. Mulheren's conviction for conspiring to manipulate stocks with Ivan F. Boesky, the convicted stock swindler. Until the reversal, Mr. Mulheren was headed for 366 days in jail and had been fined $1.6 million. But the court said the Government's case was tainted by a major flaw: It had not presented any conclusive evidence that a crime had occurred. Judge Joseph M. McLaughlin, one of the three judges who heard the case, wrote that "we are convinced that no rational trier of fact could have found the elements of the crimes charged here beyond a reasonable doubt." The ruling was the third reversal by the appeals court of cases that were based at least in part on information supplied by Mr. Boesky when he agreed to become a Government witness in 1986. Critics of the Government, like Ira Lee Sorkin, former head of the New York office of the Securities and Exchange Commission, contend that the reversals show prosecutors pursued these cases with more zeal than care.
 
Borland Barbarians
 
"We're true barbarians," said Philippe Kahn, the colorful chairman of Borland International Inc., the nation's No. 3 software publisher. What Mr. Kahn was referring to was Borland's decision to buy the Ashton-Tate Corporation last week for $439 million in stock and its willingness to take on all comers in the marketplace -- even the leading Microsoft Corporation. The acquisition will make Borland stronger, analysts say. It gets control of Ashton-Tate's best-selling database program, called dBase, which competes directly against Borland's Paradox program. According to Mr. Kahn, the match-up means the two companies will finally release versions of their software that can talk to each other. When that happens Borland can look to big sales of new releases of both products.
 
A Cleaner Fuel
 
Last week Arco announced it had developed a new gasoline blend that cuts some pollutants by as much as a third. The new gas, called EC-X, pollutes about as much as the methanol blend favored by the nation's farmers -- 85 percent corn-based methanol and 15 percent gasoline. But Arco's announcement comes with a catch. The new fuel, the company contends, is cheaper than the methanol blend but 15 to 20 percent more expensive to produce than conventional unleaded gas. As a result, Arco said it won't produce EC-X unless the Government tells it to. With 180 million vehicles on the road, cutting emissions by a third would certainly contribute to cleaner air. It would be especially helpful in Los Angeles, where Arco is based. "The whole process of looking at gasoline has undergone a renaissance," said Michael J. Bradley, an air pollution expert in Boston.
 
TRW and Big Brother
 
Ever wonder if all that information about you stored in the nation's databases is accurate? Six states are alleging in a lawsuit that not only is it sometimes inaccurate, but that the database run by TRW Inc., a credit bureau, is not just a database. "TRW is masquerading as a mere library of credit histories when in fact it is secretly rating the creditworthiness of consumers," said Attorney General Robert Abrams of New York. The states -- New York, California, Idaho, Michigan, Alabama and Texas -- are also alleging that TRW is selling confidential credit information on the 170 million names in its files, but not to you. The suit says TRW conceals its credit-rating information from individuals.
 
Mixed News
 
At first glance the news from CBS Inc. looked grim. Profits fell 63 percent in the second quarter because of the advertising slump, the network said. Earnings per share, however, were down only 38 percent because of a stock repurchase plan. And ratings for the network were up in the latest period. For the market, that was the important news. CBS stock climbed $1.25 and closed the week at $171.50.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Japanese-Style Justice
 
In Japan, justice is blind -- and easy. Nomura Securities admitted it provided $100 million in financing to help Susumu Ishii, a Japanese crime figure, manipulate stocks. Nomura also admitted to giving back $120 million that its biggest customers lost in the market. Yamaichi Securities, Nikko Securities and Daiwa Securities admitted similar wrongdoing. Penalties were announced last week. Four days of restricted business activity for the firms, said the Finance Ministry. The Ministry fined the companies a total of $116,000. (Nomura had $1.74 billion in pre-tax profits last year.) But perhaps the strangest element in last week's announcement was that the Finance Minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto, is also fining himself. He is taking a 10 percent pay cut from July to September for failing to anticipate the scandals.
 
Illegal or Just Efficient

Are Japanese auto makers dumping mini-vans on the American market? Last week the United States International Trade Commission said there was sufficient evidence to begin an investigation. The charges were made initially by Detroit's Big Three, which said Toyota, Mazda, Mitsubishi and Nissan gained market share by selling mini-vans manufactured in Japan at up to 31 percent less than they should. The Japanese deny the charges. They are just more efficient producers, they explained. Though Chrysler remains the top seller, the Japanese share of the market has climbed to 12 percent this year, from 4 percent in 1988. If Dumping is proved, Japan's auto makers could be fined and their imports restricted.
 
Germany's Tough Stance
 
The Bush Administration has been pressuring Germany and Japan to lower their interest rates. Japan caved in and lowered its rates. But last week Germany's Bundesbank, ever defiant, said it would stand pat. The bank's council, led for the last time by Karl Otto Pohl, who is retiring as president, will keep its discount rate at 6.5 percent. That action, along with big dollar sales, pushed the dollar down to 1.78 marks from 1.8 marks earlier in the week.
 
 
 
THE ECONOMY

 
Why Keep Greenspan Waiting?
 
When President Bush announced he would nominate Alan Greenspan to another four-year term as chairman of the Federal Reserve, it was not unexpected. Most economists give Mr. Greenspan high marks, though they dicker over whether he could have prevented the recession. But with Mr. Greenspan's term ending Aug. 11, why did the Administration wait so long to make its move? Even though interest rates have been coming down since December, "the Administration wanted to exert pressure on Greenspan because it wants lower short-term rates," said Mickey Levy, chief economist at CRT Government Securities in Manhattan. Last week, Mr. Greenspan said the recession was over.
 
Free Airwaves
 
With cellular telephones, police radio and foul-mouthed D.J.'s, the nation's airwaves are crowded. So last week the House of Representatives voted unanimously to transfer at no cost large portions of the frequency spectrum from the Government to commercial users. The Bush Administration said it will veto the measure; it wants to sell the frequencies, not hand them out. According to the Commerce Department the frequencies the Government now controls may be worth $200 billion. House leaders think they can override a veto.
 
The Inflation Fighter
 
Mr. Greenspan has vowed to fight inflation. He cares even more about keeping prices stable than he does about growth, some economists say. But last week, there was evidence Mr. Greenspan may be winning the fight. The Producer Price Index, which charts inflation trends at the wholesale level, showed a decrease of 0.3 percent in June, according to the Labor Department. That is the third decline in three months and suggests that inflation, though not dead, may be on its knees.
 
A Flaccid Recovery
 
This recovery is no Arnold Schwarzenegger. Retail sales fell 0.2 percent in June, the third loss this year, according to the Commerce Department. "Growth will be positive," said Samuel D. Kahan, of Fuji Securities in Chicago, "but it won't be gangbusters."

HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
Half Smiles on Flat Panels

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
Last week's ruling by the Commerce Department on the dumping of flat-panel computer displays by Japanese manufacturers had something to please and disappoint nearly every interested party. James M. Hurd was no exception.
Mr. Hurd, the 42-year-old president and chief executive of Planar Systems Inc. of Beaverton, Ore., spearheaded the formation of the Advanced Display Manufacturers of America, a group of seven small manufacturers of flat panels that brought the dumping case. The panels are key components of laptop and notebook computers. The American group charged that Japanese manufacturers were selling the panels here at unfairly low prices. 
 The Commerce Department found that the Japanese were indeed dumping so-called active matrix displays, which are not widely used now but are expected to be in the future, and proposed a stiff 62.67 percent duty. But it spared passive matrix displays, the most common type for laptop computers today.
"We couldn't be more pleased" with the decision on active matrix displays, Mr. Hurd said, adding that Planar will now consider manufacturing those screens.
But levying the duty on only one type of display "goes against logic, common sense and reality, which makes you suspect there's been a degree of political influence on the process," he said.
Opposing Mr. Hurd and his group were American computer manufacturers, some of whom are his customers, and the Japanese screen manufacturers, some of whom are his suppliers. "It's an unfortunate situation because I'm certainly not making any friends in some of these larger companies," he said. Nevertheless, he added, "even the Japanese recognize that dumping is not a good way to develop their economic base."

HEADLINE: Midlantic's 'Credit Czar'

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Hurt by heavy losses on delinquent loans, bankers are taking a hard look at the nuts and bolts of their lending business -- how to avoid making loans that turn bad, and how to spot problems quickly.
At the Midlantic Corporation, an Edison, N.J., banking company that lost $195 million last year, mostly from bad commercial real estate loans, the introspection led to the hiring of Alfred J. Schiavetti Jr. to fill the newly created job of chief credit officer. Mr. Schiavetti, 52, had been at Chemical Bank for 29 years, most recently as a managing director in the company's Realty Group. 
 Beginning this month, Mr. Schiavetti takes on the role of Midlantic "credit czar," a senior banker with enough experience to remember the tougher lending standards that in many cases were abandoned during the 1980's. It is a job that many banks are creating these days at the suggestion of Federal regulators.
"In an ideal world, a good banker strikes the right balance between making new loans that a bank needs to grow and making sure that the loans are high quality," Mr. Schiavetti said.
But in the real world, where many companies like Midlantic grew rapidly during the last decade by acquiring other banks, there is a need for someone to set and enforce lending standards, he added. "The lending officers need a system of checks and balances," he said, and guidance about when standards should be adjusted as the economy changes.
G. Charles Roy Jr., a managing director at D. E. Foster & Partners, an executive search firm, said that "in the past, credit officers may not have had as much clout within a bank as they should have, but now experienced people with good reputations can name their own price."
Other large banks that recently created positions for top credit officers include the Fleet Norstar Financial Group of Providence, R.I., which hired Peter C. Fitts from Citibank, and the Shawmut National Corporation of Hartford, which hired a senior Federal bank examiner, Richard M. Kovarik.

HEADLINE: Moving the Pampers Faster Cuts Everyone's Costs

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

DATELINE: CINCINNATI

 BODY:
For decades, the Procter & Gamble Company was known as a tough bargainer -- occasionally even a bully -- in dealing with the stores that carry its products. But these days, the company is cited by marketing experts as a leading example of how packaged-goods and food manufacturers form partnerships with major retailers to slash costs in the pipeline that connects manufacturers to consumers.
The partnerships aim to cut inventories for both parties, smooth out production schedules and quickly identify service and quality problems. They are looking for the same kinds of benefits that automakers and other industrial companies have been reaping in recent years from "just-in-time" delivery arrangements with suppliers. 
 To achieve such gains, some consumer-goods companies and their retail customers have abandoned the traditional practice of meeting only through low-level sales representatives and buyers whose worlds revolve around this week's price margins and the size of the next order.
Today, companies like P.& G. and K Mart assign teams to deal with each other -- teams that mix data processing experts, who automate and harmonize order and record-keeping systems, with sales and purchasing representatives.
The companies' logistics managers share information that helps P.& G. avoid sudden spikes and dips in orders for, say, Pampers, and coordinate delivery schedules with K Mart's warehouses. Marketing and finance managers share both up-to-the-minute sales data on the latest promotions and long-range plans for coordinating P.& G.'s new product introductions with K Mart promotional campaigns.
"When we started looking at this, we saw a potential savings of $1 billion annually in the United States for P.& G. and just as much, if not more, for our customers," said Lawrence D. Milligan, the company's senior vice president in charge of sales. "But the elephants have to dance together to get there."
Consultants say that more often than not it is the product makers rather than the retailers who are reluctant to join in.
"Many consumer packaged-goods companies don't think of retailers as their customers," said Frederick Schneider, director for the food and consumer packaging consulting business of Andersen Consulting in Chicago. "They see them as impediments in getting to their customers."
And even companies that say they are committed to partnering sometimes find that it fails to live up to their expectations. It may require more executive attention than companies are willing to give. Or it may call for expensive investments in new computers and other data handling systems. Or fundamental conflicts may crop up over prices or the timing of new-product introductions.
Frequently, manufacturers and retailers compromise. They identify and discard areas where cooperation is feasible but not potentially profitable enough to justify the organizational changes or marketing risks they would require.
Even so, retailers and manufacturers alike say that the benefits are real and that the conflicts are easier to minimize when each side knows more about the other's operations and goals.
"This can only be described as a retailing revolution," said James Reider, a consumer products specialist with the consulting firm of Arthur D. Little Inc. in Cambridge, Mass.
The extent of the change shows up in P.& G.'s recruiting literature for new sales managers. The company woos college graduates with promises that they will be urged to "understand all facets of your customer's business, from the board room to the checkout lane."
Noting that sales managers are now teamed with other experts, P.& G. goes on to say that the recruit's success in handling such famous products as Tide detergent, Crest toothpaste, Folgers coffee and Cover Girl cosmetics will be measured on their ability to obtain profits "for both the company and the customer."
Among the manufacturers, consultants say, the Kraft General Foods subsidiary of Philip Morris Inc. matches P.& G. in its commitment to the team strategy and outstrips it in working with store managers on local marketing programs.
Quaker Oats, Helene Curtis, General Mills, Frito-Lay (a subsidiary of Pepsico), Nabisco (a subsidiary of RJR Nabisco), Johnson & Johnson and Pepperidge Farms (a subsidiary of Campbell's) are all cited by consultants and retailers as active proponents of extensive partnering, although not all of them rely on multifunctional teams to the extent of P.& G. and Kraft.
Kraft set up almost 400 sales teams, starting in the upper Midwest in 1988, to pursue its goal of "micro-merchandising" -- that is, helping retailers sell more of everything, especially Kraft products, by using the growing mountains of data on consumer preferences to develop a detailed picture of each store's clientele, which products are selling best and which displays and promotions are apt to be most effective at that site.
Sometimes, Kraft sales teams even recommend that some of the company's own products be replaced with those of a competitor or with different categories of products.
One reason for the drive, according to Michael Blyth, the Kraft executive overseeing that company's partnering program, is the increasing challenge manufacturers face in reaching consumers directly. Trends such as the declining viewership of network television make it harder to develop brand loyalty and sales through national advertising.
Equally important, Mr. Blyth said, is that society has fragmented from the nuclear family of "Leave It to Beaver" into a number of distinctive consumer groups with different buying patterns and susceptability to brand names, discounts and other promotions. Electronic scanning systems give retailers the data they need to profit from such segmentation, but few are capable of fully exploiting that information without the cooperation and help of the big manufacturers.
The changing consumer market has been just one of the trends encouraging partnering. Globalization, for example, caused multinationals to question their traditional approaches. P.& G. executives were easily convinced that big improvements in efficiency were both possible and necessary after seeing that retailers in Japan frequently moved inventory through their stores 10 times as rapidly as their American counterparts.
Also, the emphasis on quality in manufacturing that spread through industry in the 1980's led to a thorough reconsideration of what goes into high-quality customer and supplier relationships in sales and purchasing departments. Total quality concepts dictate a focus not just on today's price margins, but on cash flow throughout a production system. Thus, P.& G. switched from seeking the lowest shipping price from among 250 trucking companies to ongoing relationships with 15 major ones, many of whom were made part of teams serving the most important customers.
Most of the projects seem mundane on their own. For example, P.& G. marketing experts found that K Mart was intent on building an image of environmental responsiveness. So they interested K Mart marketing managers in new refillable packaging for Downy fabric softeners. Those managers helped persuade K Mart purchasing managers to put aside their natural reluctance to place large orders for new products.
The resulting promotion sold a lot of Downy and met K Mart's strategic needs, according to Michael Ryan, director of P.& G.'s efforts to develop the K Mart partnership.
The combinations of improved information exchange and logistical adjustments has led to a wide variety of improvement in service to Wal-Mart. One example: the retailer's inventories of Tide have been cut to two days from 30.
In another case, Shaw's Supermarkets Inc. of East Bridgewater, Mass., worked with P.& G. to standardize the language and structure of electronic order processing systems. At first, P.& G. was able to electronically process only 10 percent of Shaw's computerized orders, according to David Jenkins, the supermarket chain's chief executive. Now, that figure is more than 90 percent, removing one of the many causes of delay and uncertainty that force retailers and suppliers to keep large inventories on hand. In addition, more error-free orders cleared the way for more electronic invoicing, leading to prompter payments and fewer disagreements about whether orders had been filled.
The cumulative effect of such partnering can be impressive. Ralph W. Drayer, P.& G.'s top logistics executive, figures the company is now capturing about half the annual $1 billion benefit it foresaw from partnering.
P.& G. said that cooperation has allowed it to automate replenishment of supplies for 12 retailers. In one case, the automation reduced the inventory of P.& G. products by 80 percent. For such retailers, each order is sold out so rapidly that they have re-ordered and are piling up cash from those re-orders by the time the 10-day period for paying P.& G. is up. That cash cushion allows them to operate without borrowing a dime to finance inventories of P.& G. products.
Now, P.& G. is aiming for further gains by paring back promotion practices like manufacturer's discounts, which consumers see in the form of, say, "30 cents off" labels.
The retailer gets all, or most, of the discount and the plans become costly to manufacturers when retailers suddenly -- whether planning to divert supplies to regions where the discount isn't being offered or because they want to build up low-cost inventory -- order unexpectedly large amounts.
Such forward buying and diversion creates production spikes at P.& G.'s factories, often followed by periods of lower than normal demand. At the same time, according to P.& G., retailers often fail to take full account of the warehousing and accounting expenses involved, leading them to underestimate the disruptive impact of such deals on cash flow.
"Historically, it was a question of how do I transfer as much of my cost as possible to the retailers and they were asking the same about us," explained Thomas Muccio, the P.& G. vice president who oversees the company's relations with Wal-Mart. "No one understood how much their moves were costing others."
 
 
 
PARTNERING THAT TOUCHED A NERVE

Perhaps the best-known example of partnering is P.& G.'s relationship with Wal-Mart, the rapidly growing discount chain that last year passed Sears, Roebuck to become the nation's largest retailer.
The partnership with its biggest customer, P.& G.'s first in the United States, began in 1988. Wal-Mart demonstrated its interest by sending a group of executives to a P.& G. quality seminar in Cincinnati. P.& G. then highlighted its commitment by moving a squad of executives to Fayetteville, Ark., a short drive from Wal-Mart's Bentonville headquarters.
One unexpected side effect was suspicion. Other major customers worried that Wal-Mart was getting special deals or other forms of favored treatment. Some smaller retailers complained that P.& G. was slow to respond to their requests for partnering.
Now, senior P.& G. managers are quick to note that the company has more than 120 teams assigned to different domestic customers. They also point out that other customers now are tied even closer to P.& G. in some respects -- with cash register scanners linked directly to P.& G., for example, so that P.& G. can automatically replenish stock as it is sold.
 When they discuss Wal-Mart, P.& G. executives stress that Sam Walton, the retailer's visionary chief executive, has pursued similar relationships with all of Wal-Mart's major suppliers. "We didn't go to Wal-mart," said Ralph W. Drayer, general product supply manager in P.& G.'s customer services group. "They came to us and said there's a better way to do things."
In fact, P.& G. executives say, special offices to serve other major customers would have been opened if other customers had been based so far from P.& G.
"Partnership is the commonly used word but it's bad," said Lawrence D. Milligan, P.& G.'s senior sales executive and chief worrier about how partnerings are perceived. "It implies preferred relationships, which are illegal under the antitrust laws."

HEADLINE: All About/Candy Makers;
America's Chocoholics: A Built-In Market for Confectioners

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER

 BODY:
Even Willy Wonka, the mythical chocolate maker in the Roald Dahl novel, would be impressed by the size of the American candy industry. It is an $8.7 billion business that is highly concentrated. Two giants -- the Hershey Foods Corporation, in Hershey, Pa., and the privately held M&M/Mars of Hackettstown, N.J. -- together have nearly 70 percent of the market.
The candy business is virtually immune to the ups and downs of the business cycle. And this year, when the price of the average candy bar sold in a vending machine went from 55 cents to 60 cents -- the first increase since 1986 -- sales remained steady. 
 "Candy is about as recession-proof as a business gets," said Kurt A. Feuerman, a confectionery analyst at Morgan Stanley in New York. "You might forget a car purchase, or you may not buy that T-bone steak, but you won't defer your chocolate bar," he said.
Americans certainly are not deferring their candy purchases. According to the National Confectioners Association in McLean, Va., Americans consumed 20.7 pounds each of all kinds of candy in 1990. Chocolate is their favorite, by far. Last year, Americans ate 2.6 billion pounds of it -- about 11 pounds per person.
"What is very interesting about this industry is that it has been growing, even though there is a perception that because everyone is health conscious, it would decline," said Nomi Ghez, a confectionery analyst at Goldman Sachs, New York. "The market is growing at a rate of 2.5 percent, which is faster than population growth," she said.

 
 
The Kings of Candy
Mars and Hershey Fight It Out
 For decades Mars and Hershey have been slugging it out at the top. Both companies had about the same share of the candy market until 1988, when Hershey bought the American operations of Britain's Cadbury Schweppes for about $300 million.
As a result of the acquisition, Hershey pulled slightly ahead of Mars. Hershey now has about 36 percent of the market versus Mars's 35 percent. Last year Hershey had $2.7 billion in sales. It is projecting an increase to $2.9 billion this year -- further evidence that candy is a recession-proof business. And profits are also up. Last year profits were $195 million. And this year they are expected to increase to $220 million.
Mars, which is the nation's No. 2 candy maker, is privately held and does not disclose its sales figures.
The third-largest candy maker is Nestle, with 10 percent of the market. Nestle, which is the American unit of the Swiss chocolate and dairy-food company, has $7 billion in American sales but does not break out its candy sales separately.
Candy bars -- a broad category that includes almost all individually packaged confections -- are by far the best-selling type of candy.
According to Jerry Prescott, president of Ann Arbor, Mich.-based Distributor Concepts, a consultant to candy distributors, the bar segment of the market accounts for about 40 percent of retail sales. Loosely packed bags of candy are next with about 35 percent of the market. Mints and hard roll candies -- another separate segment -- make up about 8 percent of the market. Bulk candies, which include candy sold by the scoop, account for 5 percent of sales. Local retail brands and seasonal candies make up the remaining 10 to 12 percent of sales.
In the bar category, the Snickers bar, an M&M/Mars product, is the biggest seller. It is followed by Reese's Peanut Butter Cups, made by Hershey. Then comes M&M's Peanut Chocolate Candy and Kit Kat bars, made by Hershey. Trailing this group are the Butterfinger and Baby Ruth bars, both made by Nestle.
Snickers has been No. 1 since the beginning of time, according to analysts, or at least since the the early 70's. "The world could come to an end, and those leading candy bars will still hold their positions," said Mr. Feuerman.
The chances of a new candy bar beating the No. 1 Snickers -- or even Baby Ruth -- is about as far-fetched as an amateur knocking out Mike Tyson. Even so, companies continually bring out new products hoping to win market share.
One new entry, coming this summer, is from Dove Bar International, an ice cream maker that is a unit of M&M/Mars. Dove Bar is test-marketing a new premium candy bar that features the thick, dark chocolate the company uses on its ice cream bars.
The new candy is being test marketed in New England and Chicago and -- if successful -- will be sold nationally shortly after. But even with M&M/Mars behind it, the new candy is expected to become a niche player at best.
Still, in an $8.7 billion market, not all niches are small. "If you look at the size of the market, the 10 percent made up of small and medium-sized companies is still pretty good," said Patricia Magee, publisher of Candy Industry, a trade journal.
For example, she said: "Tootsie Roll Industries Inc. does wonderfully. They outdo their sales each quarter." Last year Tootsie Roll had revenues of $179.3 million.

 
 
The Older Market
Grown-Ups Like Toffee and Nuts
 Candy makers know that they have the kids, the most voracious consumers of candy in the country. But to grow further, they are aiming most of the new products at older, more affluent consumers.
"The bar category has had to adjust to a new population profile," said Richard T. O'Connell, president of the National Confectioners Association and the Chocolate Manufacturers Association, also in McLean, Va. "We've gone to variety in the size of bars, and companies will have to compete on that level," he said.
According to Mr. O'Connell, bite-sized candies, once languishing, are on the comeback trail. The reason is that smaller portions appeal to dieters and to parents who think their children should eat fewer sweets. Into this growing segment, Mars recently introduced bags of bite-sized Milky Way bars.
Candy with nuts has increased greatly in popularity over the last three years. "Nuts in chocolate, toffee and peanut butter are very big because there is a perceived wholesomeness there," said Joan Steuer, president of Chocolate Marketing Inc., a Los Angeles-based firm specializing in product development. "There is the idea that there is more protein and nutrition."

 
 
The Sticky Health Issue
Persuading Parents Sweets Won't Hurt
 Health is an issue that has continually vexed the candy makers. The industry contends that its negative image is unjustified. "We now know that chocolate does not cause acne or hyperactivity," said Mr. O'Connell. The Chocolate Manufacturers Association cites a number of studies from various sources to support its claim that candy is not damaging to health. But Mr. O'Connell admits getting this message across has been difficult.
In New York, industry lobbyists are now supporting legislation that will overturn a 1987 law that prohibits selling candy to children in public schools before lunch.
The measure, described by its sponsors as "the promotion of healthy, nutritious dairy products," is presently on the summer legislative calendar, where it may likely sit until recess.
Activists like Victoria Leonard, the director of the children's nutrition program at the Center for Science in the Public Interest, in Washington, oppose the bill. "Every bar a child eats in school will replace a healthy meal they could have had in the lunch room," she said. The center is also keeping an eye on the health claims made by the industry.
Tough new rules set earlier this month by the Food and Drug Administration governing the labeling of juice have also caused concern among some candy makers. But even if candy makers have to own up to their sugar content on their wrappers, it is not likely that the overall growth rate of the industry will be hurt.
"Candy does well because people see it as an affordable indulgence," said Ms. Steuer of Chocolate Marketing. "It's the ultimate feel-good food."
 
 
MAKING A LOW-FAT CHOCOLATE
 Americans, whose passion for fatty foods is sadly incongruent with their battle with cellulite, are beginning to embrace fat substitutes as the solution to their dieting dilemmas. But will they tolerate them in candy?
The Proctor & Gamble Company recently asked the Food and Drug Administration to approve a low-calorie fat substitute called caprenin, which has characteristics of cocoa butter and could be used in confectionery products.
But not all analysts are as enthusiastic about the new ingredient as Procter & Gamble is. "This is not something that confectioners will jump on right away," said Patricia Magee, publisher of Candy Industry, a trade journal. "There is an emphasis on low fat, but these days people feel healthy and reward themselves with chocolate. They will never move away from traditional products."
Joan Steuer, president of Chocolate Marketing Inc., a consulting firm in Los Angeles, also warned that caprenin will have to taste great. "Based on random conversations with consumers as well as retailers, I found there is very little demand for a lower-fat chocolate," she said.
But if it can pass the taste test, caprenin may help the candy makers. "Fake fat has been driving big growth in other categories, yet not really in confections," said Kurt Feuerman, an analyst at Morgan Stanley in New York. "But if they build a better widget, it could drive growth."
M&M/Mars and Hershey, the industry leaders, have yet to comment about the ingredient publicly. But Mr. Feuerman said, "If it is a tradition that is for real, Mars and Hershey will be there."

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
The Stylishness of Latin America

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD

 BODY:
Latin America is in; Europe is out. That is the message sent by single-country closed-end funds in the first half of 1991.
The biggest winner in this volatile category was the Brazil Fund, whose share price more than doubled even as the premium to its underlying assets shrank. The Latin America Fund was up 69.8 percent, and the Emerging Mexico Fund rose 62.6 percent. 
 The funds with the largest drops, and widening discounts to underlying assets, were European. But the European results defied predictions last year by many market observers who had expected a rise because of the Soviet Union's economic restructuring, the reunification of Germany and the dismantling of trade barriers by the end of 1992. Investors, it seems, saw it otherwise.
Indeed, prices have fallen so far that "it's time to be accumulating shares in European funds," said Thomas J. Herzfeld, a Miami-based investment adviser.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
An Appetite for Banking Stocks

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
Out of crisis comes opportunity, the proverb says. In the United States, savings and loan associations are enmeshed in a crisis; the banking and insurance industries are struggling. In Japan, Britain and Switzerland, banks have also been battered.
Hoping to prosper from all this is the Global Value Fund, a new mutual fund sponsored by Venture Advisers in Santa Fe, N.M., which invests mainly in banks, savings and loans, insurers and financial services companies worldwide. 
 Because of the bad news in the banking industry lately, the fund "is a tough sell," said John Rekenthaler, senior analyst with Morningstar Inc. in Chicago. "But over the long term, there's a chance to make some pretty good money in this."
The $3 million Global Value Fund was set up in May, but its manager, Shelby M. C. Davis, is hardly a neophyte. Mr. Davis, 54 years old, has managed the $400 million New York Venture Fund since its inception in 1969. New York Venture placed 15th among the 3,000-plus funds tracked by Lipper Analytical Services in Summit, N.J., for the decade that ended on June 30. Its annualized return was 16.9 percent, Lipper says.
 The new fund grew out of Mr. Davis's interest in financial services stocks, which play a prominent role in New York Venture -- now, about 25 to 30 percent of its portfolio.
At the end of 1990, financial services stocks dropped precipitously. That led Mr. Davis to think that the strong companies in the industry would ultimately "be able to enlarge their market share by acquiring weaker players or because some competitors would go out of business," he said.
Meanwhile, financial services stocks are selling at bargain prices, he says. Many stocks trade at price-earnings ratios that are about one-third less than the market average; others sell below book value. The battered stocks include some very strong companies tarred with the same brush as weaker concerns. He thinks that a number of them will enjoy a doubling of earnings, a 50 percent expansion of price-earnings ratios and a tripling in stock prices by the end of the decade.
At least through the mid-90's, Mr. Davis expects a benign period for interest rates like the 1960's, when 30-year Treasury-bond were steady at 6 to 8 percent. It was the double-digit interest rates of the 1970's and the sharp spikes and drops in rates since then that compounded the industry's troubles, he said.
After a consolidation of the financial services industry in the middle of the decade, Mr. Davis expects steady growth. Surviving companies will post annual earnings gains in the 10 to 15 percent range, he said, and if all falls into place, "financial services stocks will regain the respect they had in the 1960's."
 The restructuring of financial services in the United States is beginning to pay off -- the group jumped 29 percent in the first half, placing first among the 19 stock-fund categories tracked by Lipper. But the road to health will probably be bumpy. As a result, investors should expect to hold their shares for the long term, at least 10 years, Mr. Davis says, and take advantage of short-term setbacks in the industry to add to their holdings.
 Right now, the fund has 60 percent of its stock portfolio in banks and savings and loans and the balance in insurance companies. Mr. Davis says brokerage stocks soared too high in the new issues boom in the first quarter, and he is waiting for prices to drop. About 90 percent of the stock portfolio is in domestic issues because "there's such a candy store of value in the U.S.," he said.
Because the fund is so young and money is still flowing in, a large chunk is in cash. But Mr. Davis says he is buying stocks every day, at what he considers fire-sale prices.
Among the top-tier banks and savings and loans, he says, the "cream has already risen to the top," but he expects strong long-term growth from some of his favorites: Banc One in Columbus, Ohio; Republic New York; State Street Boston; Wachovia in North Carolina, and Golden West Financial in Oakland.
Among bank stocks that "are potentially exciting, but riskier," he especially likes Bank of Boston. The bank is ahead of schedule for working out bad loans, and Mr. Davis sees the Northeast as a "chief crisis opportunity, like Texas five years ago." Another favorite: United New Mexico Financial, the largest banking company in that state.
Among the top-tier insurers, Mr. Davis favors American International Group, a global insurance company with a large chunk of earnings from overseas, and Chubb, a specialty insurer based in Warren, N.J., that insures half of the chief executives of the Fortune 500 companies, Mr. Davis said.
As for companies with middling ratings, he likes two regional auto insurance companies in California. Mercury General, based in Los Angeles, and 20th Century Industries in Woodland Hills are both "good, low-cost operators in a tough regulatory state," he said.
In the bottom tier, Mr. Davis cites Broad Inc. in Los Angeles, which is acquiring companies with "junk bond" components. Another favorite: MBIA Inc. of Armonk, N.Y., an insurer of municipal bonds.

HEADLINE: Flying Eye Hospital Uses Tact to Reach Cuba

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HAVANA

 BODY:
Stepping briskly from his sleek white DC-8 aircraft, Oliver Foot, director of Project Orbis, the flying eye hospital, immediately sought to put a receiving line of Cuban doctors and Government officials at ease.
Bringing relieved smiles to the faces of his hosts, Mr. Foot told them, "We are coming to Cuba to share knowledge and to learn from each other so that what we learn can be disseminated around the world." 
 Although in their travels Orbis doctors often emphasize that they learn even as they teach, for an increasingly isolated Cuba the remarks were seen as a vital statement of mutual respect without which the rare humanitarian mission would have risked a sputtering start.
Cuba's universal health care system, whose quality in many ways rivals that of more highly industrialized countries, remains one of the proudest hallmarks of a Communist system that is locked in an economic decline.
For Orbis, negotiating such Cuban sensitivities was merely one of a host of challenges in a three-week mission beginning in mid-June that broke modest new ground in bilateral ties while serving as a reminder of the frosty diplomatic and political void that has kept Cuba at least at arm's length from the United States.
"We were in China just after Tiananmen Square, and the Soviet Union well before glasnost, but this was arguably the hardest trip of all for us to pull off," said Mr. Foot, who has helped organize visits to some 60 countries since joining the eye foundation in 1982.
Because of the United States' 30-year economic embargo of Cuba, and an equally long tradition of mutual ideological hostility, exchanges between the two countries have long been largely limited to family visits and occasional study trips by academics.Because it is a nonprofit medical charity that is broadly international in its membership and fund raising, Orbis had hoped it would have little trouble breeching the gulf between the two countries.
But as the tentatively scheduled date for the visit approached, frosty Cuban-American realities quickly began to encroach on the foundation's plans. Although Cuban eye specialists had long agreed on the desirability of a visit by the flying hospital, a Government invitation failed to materialize, perhaps another reflection of Havana's reluctance to be seen as wanting in health.
To expedite things, Mr. Foot enlisted the help of the former Canadian Prime Minister, Pierre Elliott Trudeau, who personally reached President Fidel Castro to promote the visit.
With the Cuban invitation in hand, Mr. Foot said he called the State Department a month before the departure date to make a routine inquiry into travel security in Cuba and was told "security is fine, but Treasury regulations won't allow you to go."
 
Positive Aspects Highlighted

The next month was spent wrangling with the Treasury Department, which, citing the potential monetary value of medical techniques, declined to give it a special exemption from the ban on economic exchanges with Havana.
Finally, with quiet support from the State Department and a pledge to spend only monies raised by the foundation's offices in London and Hong Kong, the trip was approved.
Once on the ground, Orbis doctors, perhaps sensing the delicacy of the situation, repeatedly highlighted the positive aspects of Cuban care, even as they privately noted some of its deficiencies.
"The cases presented to me would have been difficult ones in any clinic in the world," said Dr. Forrest Ellis, a pediatric ophthalmologist from the University of Indiana, after surgically correcting an eye muscle in a 6-year-old girl that his Cuban counterparts thought was congenitally absent.
Cuban health-care professionals, who worked side by side with their American counterparts, seemed delighted by the exchange.
"Who cares who is the most sophisticated or the most advanced," said Anna Remon, a 40-year-old ophthalmological nurse who assisted in Dr. Ellis's operation. "Our cooperation seems to have helped this little girl, and that is what matters."

HEADLINE: Name That Tune

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Dancing to the Wrong Tune in Europe" (Forum, June 23), Milton Ezrati takes a shortsighted negative stance on monetary union. Germany has adopted a tight-monetary/loose-fiscal balance to address domestic needs. Does Mr. Ezrati suggest a recipe of spiraling inflation and currency depreciation for Germany, a loose-monetary and loose-fiscal policy? 
 The gloom-and-doom attitude for Europe is not justified. European countries are not being "killed" by Germany's tight monetary policy. They are not aggressively expanding their fiscal policies; nor are they willing to accept currency devaluation. They are committed to maintaining stability. The Bundesbank is cognizant of the European situation and may be willing to target slightly higher inflation to prevent future rate hikes. Eventually, rates will unwind, along with the economic cycle.
European Monetary System countries are adjusting to future competition by increasing productivity and decreasing inflation. Monetary union will also reduce currency transaction costs for intra-European trade. Europe is already dancing to the right tune.
 
BRIAN J. BRENNAN
Baltimore, Md., June 23

HEADLINE: Investments and Nuclear Trusts

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"First-Generation Nuclear Retirement" (Forum, June 2) misstates the real issue regarding attempts to liberalize the investment restriction on funds set aside to cover future costs of decommissioning nuclear power plants. Vermont Yankee's request to the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission for permission to invest in common stocks suggests good business sense, not a departure from "pension grade" investments. 
 There are good reasons to be conservative with decommissioning funds collected from ratepayers. Future costs are difficult to project and whatever is collected today should be prudently invested. But restrictions on investments made by nuclear decommissioning trusts are extremely cautious regarding credit quality. Most of the $3 billion of assets in such funds are invested in conservative investments like United States Treasury securities.
To provide diversification and protection against inflation, it makes sense to allow part of these funds to invest in common stocks and other investments. There are no simplistic answers to complex investment challenges and no substitutes for experience and expertise in portfolio management. Especially with decommissioning funds that must be adequate some 20 to 30 years in the future, we can ill afford investment advice from amateurs.
 
JOHN M. PAWLIK
Chicago, July 1

HEADLINE: The Magnanimous 7?

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, July 13

 BODY:
In some ways, the gathering of the leaders of the seven iggest industrial democracies starting here Monday shows how little the nations' leaders accomplished in Houston one year ago, when they last met to deal with some of the world's most acute economic problems.
 Now, as then, the seven are divided about whether they should give large amounts of aid to help the Soviet Union replace Communism with a market economy, with Germany, Italy, and France in favor, and Japan, the United States, Britain and Canada saying the Soviets have not yet shown they really mean to make the shift. 
 Now, as then, the Soviet Government and the legislature are debating sweeping reform plans to replace the crumbling edifice of state planning before the political forces of separatism throw the country into chaos.
And despite their pledge last year to get the latest round of negotiations on a global trade and tariff agreement completed by 1990, the talks failed in Brussels last December. The issue then was disagreements between the United States and the European Community, the eighth participant in these "economic summits," over agricultural subsidies, which are still unresolved.
But in other ways, the world has changed in important senses since last July. Most important, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union has managed, after two years of knocking at the door, to get an invitation to come tell the seven in person next Wednesday just what kind of economic change he does have in mind.
 
Mood in Soviet Union
 And though a 23-page letter he has sent to the summit participants is short on specifics, the political mood and balance of forces inside the Soviet Union now are very different from what they were only six months ago.
Last fall, ambitious plans to bring a market economy to the Soviet Union within 500 days, only one of several such schemes, were defeated by the forces of Communist conservatism. On the ascendant until early this year, they have since been weakened by Boris N. Yeltsin's popular election as President of the Russian federated republic, on a platform of privatization and private ownership.
Mr. Yeltsin is among the leaders of 9 of the Soviet Union's 15 constituent republics who have agreed to the outlines of a new, looser treaty of federation that could make Mr. Gorbachev's plans for change more convincing to Western leaders, if the message he presents to them is that this time, it is for real.
But the war against Iraq, which invaded Kuwait soon after the Houston summit distracted the world's attention from the Soviet Union and the trade negotiations, has also changed the political climate since last July, demonstrating both the possibilities and the limitations of cooperation in the post-cold-war era.
This year's "economic summit" is the 17th in a line of gatherings originally intended to be fireside chats where the leaders who run the world could shoo the bureaucrats out of the way and get down to the nitty-gritty.
 
Swarms of Officials
 Instead, the meetings have swollen to behemoth size, with swarms of major and minor officials, fleets of helicopters darkening the skies, and motorcades tying the host city in knots for days, a process that began today with the arrival of the Japanese Prime Minister, Toshiki Kaifu, and his party from a meeting with President Bush in Kennebunkport, Me. Mr. Bush is scheduled to arrive Sunday evening.
Their British host, Prime Minister John Major, wants the summit meeting this year to strengthen the new international order that followed the end of the cold war and allowed the United States and the Soviet Union to join United Nations-backed sanctions against Iraq.
But on the issue of aid to the Soviet economy, the expense of the gulf war, the persistent recession in most of the summit nations, and the high costs of unification in Germany all make it unlikely that Mr. Gorbachev will come out of this meeting with much cash no matter what he tells the others.
Mr. Gorbachev apparently did not ask for cash in his letter. A senior Western official said he invited private Western investment to help convert Soviet military plants to civilian purposes -- $10 to $20 billion worth, British officials say -- but apparently leaves it unclear whether these companies would become privately owned.
He also appealed to the West to supply commodities and consumer goods, possibly as grants, to prevent runaway inflation when the Soviets decontrol prices next year, another official said.
Though the letter itself has not been published, it did not materially change the prospects for an uneasy consensus at the summit that, though the industrial democracies want to encourage the Soviet moves, they do not believe they justify large amounts of aid now.
 
'150 Tons of Gold'
 "They may also ask to reschedule their foreign debt," estimated at $65 billion to $70 billion, a Japanese official said. "But what about their 150 tons of gold? This is not a country where people are starving to death."
This is also the United States view now, as it was a year ago in Houston. Until the Soviet Union begins the process of privatization, the United States and its allies are saying, large sums of money would go down the drain. What the summit meeting will most likely do, officials involved in the preparations say, is simply pick up cautiously where last year's meeting left off.
Last July, the participants asked the International Monetary Fund and other international financial organizations for recommendations. In December, these institutions recommended intermediate membership for the Soviet Union, to enable it to benefit from technical advice and expertise.
Some form of special association with the I.M.F. is likely to be offered by the seven when Mr. Gorbachev meets them Wednesday afternoon. In the long run, officials here say, a successful outcome of the international trade negotiations would do more to help the Soviet Union, along with everybody else.
Mr. Major said, a couple of days ago: "The impact if the Uruguay Round failed would be very serious, in the implication that it would lead people toward all sorts of artificial trade barriers, protectionism, and a trade war. We need a specific commitment of the heads of government, if necessary, to make sure that there is a sufficient degree of political clout to make sure that the Uruguay Round does proceed."
With the United States and Europe still bickering over agricultural subsidies, and European countries still arguing about whose farmers would be worst affected if the European Community's expensive price subsidies are removed, the outlook for that seems almost as cloudy as the prospects of quick Soviet economic reform.

HEADLINE: U.S. Reports Gains in Drug War, but the Battles Keep On Shifting

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 13

 BODY:
Almost three years after President Bush declared a war on drugs, the blossoming of the Cali cartel in Colombia is only one development that challenges Administration claims that major progress is being made.
Government studies indicate that casual use of cocaine and marijuana is declining, particularly among the affluent, the middle class and students. But critics in Congress say the Administration's statistics are not persuasive, and officials concede that progress is far slower among the homeless, blacks and other minorities. Skeptics point to a rise in drug-related crime and in the number of deaths linked to use of heroin or cocaine. 
 "I think we are winning a lot of individual battles," said Bob Martinez, director of the Office of National Drug Control Policy. "But there are a number of areas of great concern."
 
More Heroin Arriving
 Some Administration officials say they are bracing for a new wave of heroin addiction, with heroin possibly replacing crack as the drug of choice in urban ghettoes by the end of the decade. The United States Customs Service said it seized nearly 1,500 pounds of heroin last year, more than double the amount for 1986, suggesting an improvement in enforcement but also a larger volume of traffic.
Cocaine and marijuana producers are facing stiffer opposition from a number of Latin American governments, but opium and heroin manufacturers in much of Asia meet with little official interference. While cocaine trafficking through the Caribbean and Miami has been reduced somewhat by by tighter American enforcement, the Latin American traffickers have adjusted by moving more cocaine through Panama and Central America.
Melvyn Levitsky, the Assistant Secretary of State for International Narcotics Matters, told a Congressional panel on Wednesday that there "are real signs of progress" in the anti-drug effort pursued in conjunction with Andean nations, the primary source of cocaine consumed by Americans. But he warned that the Peruvian program was "hampered by a collapsed economy, anarchy, wanton terrorism and widespread corruption."
In Bolivia, he said, "Government corruption continues to compromise counternarcotics operations," impeding economic programs designed to steer peasants away from growing coca leaf and find new sources of income for them.
 
Like 'Squeezing a Balloon'
 Efforts to reduce drug cultivation and trafficking are like "squeezing a balloon," Mr. Martinez said. While Colombia is making strides in shutting down sites for cocaine production, for example, "laboratories are springing up in Bolivia and Brazil," he said.
Mr. Martinez had praise for Mexico's efforts to limit the flow of drugs through its territory, but said that traffickers are now refueling in Guatemala and Belize instead.
Since President Bush announced his national strategy for drug control in January 1990, federal spending to combat trafficking and abuse has jumped from $6.3 billion in 1989 to $9.5 billion in 1990 to an estimated $10.4 billion in the current fiscal year. "I am more and more convinced that we will win this war," he declared recently.
Mr. Martinez said the Administration's efforts were beginning to make a dent in the problem. He pointed to a recent report indicating that Americans spent about $40.4 billion on drugs last year, down from $49.8 billion in 1989. The number of Americans who use illegal drugs has also dropped, to 12.9 million last year from 23 million in 1985.
 
Critics Distrust the Figures
 Congressional critics say that such figures are highly unreliable.
"I don't know of any successes," said Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of Manhattan, the chairman of the House Select Committee on Narcotics Abuse. "They say there are less high school seniors on drugs, but in my community if you have made it to be high school senior, you are already a success. It's the dropouts we have to be concerned about."
He said the Administration had failed to come up with effective programs to teach children about drugs, or new treatment techniques that could be suggested to state governments.

HEADLINE: Political Talk

BYLINE: By Frank Lynn

 BODY:

Early Line on Bottom Line
In the first test of the relative strength of New York's four prospective Democratic candidates for the United States Senate, the least-known, Representative Robert J. Mrazek of Suffolk County, has emerged as a viable fund-raiser, the prerequisite for any high-level candidacy. 
 Mr. Mrazek raised almost as much as Robert Abrams, the veteran State Attorney General, and has considerably more cash on hand than does Mr. Abrams, traditionally a big campaign spender. Two other well-known Democrats, New York City's Comptroller, Elizabeth Holtzman, and Geraldine A. Ferraro, the former Queens Representative and vice presidential candidate, are also seeking to challenge the Republican incumbent, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, next year. Both trailed in the dollar derby.
The candidates' finance reports for the six months ending on June 30 are due in two weeks, but their vital statistics were disclosed by the candidates and their handlers.
Mr. Abrams has raised at least $700,000 for his Senate campaign and $250,000 to pay off loans left from his campaign for attorney general last year. But his direct-mail fund-raising has been expensive, so he has about $400,000 in his treasury. Mr. Abrams also has the advantage of five previous statewide campaigns and a high-visibility office. He has been generating favorable news releases on his official activities, including campaigns against industrial polluters and insurance companies that failed to issue rebates to motorists who install safety features like air bags.
Mr. Mrazek said he had about $800,000 on hand after raising $700,000 and transferring $350,000 from a House campaign account. He has spent about $230,000. He has used a professional fund-raiser and a cadre of heavy-hitter constituent fund-raisers from his wealthy district on the North Shore of Long Island.
Ms. Holtzman has raised close to $550,000 and has spent about $100,000, but this money has been raised under very liberal state contribution limits. The Comptroller, the only candidate of the four not to have formally announced, is just getting around to setting up a campaign committee under Federal election law, which imposes stricter limits on contributions.
Ms. Ferraro has raised about $500,000, largely through a costly telephone fund-raising program that has eaten up all but about $100,000 of the money raised.
 
Off the Pace

The incumbent, Senator D'Amato, has been one of the Senate's champion fund-raisers, passing the basket continuously throughout his six-year term. He has about $3 million in his campaign kitty, but that is considerably less than the nearly $5 million he had at this point in the campaign six years ago. Then, his treasury helped to scare off Mr. Abrams, Ms. Holtzman and Ms. Ferraro as challengers.
The recession, which has made fund-raising difficult for most candidates, and an investigation by the Senate Ethics Committee have taken their toll on Mr. D'Amato's fund-raising. The committee is investigating whether the Senator improperly helped contributors win Federal contracts.
 
 Big Spenders Welcome

A year from yesterday, the Democratic National Convention will arrive in New York City, bringing a boom in hotel guests, delegates, gawkers and hawkers.
 Mayor David N. Dinkins, awash in red ink, layoffs and other fiscal horrors, took advantage of the one-year-to-go point to announce at a news conference that he was increasing his estimate of "economic activity" from the convention to $300 million from $100 million. He said that the larger figure came from a new city study of the convention and its economic ramifications.
But all that spending and the jobs that will be created will produce a far more modest return in direct tax revenues to the city: an estimated $27 million, city officials said. Even if accurate, that is just $6 million more than the city plans to lay out for police protection, insurance and preparing and renting Madison Square Garden for the big event.
But the Mayor brushed off that fiscal reality. "That's not an expenditure, mind you, but an investment -- an investment, in fact, that has great returns," he said.
 
 Timing Is the Key

One of the better patronage plums in Queens is about to become available. After 20 years, Surrogate Louis D. Laurino is retiring, effective Aug. 3. The date is significant because it is too late for a primary, so the Democratic candidate chosen by Representative Thomas J. Manton, the Queens Democratic leader, will not have a primary challenge and presumably only token Republican opposition in the general election.
The leading contenders, Mr. Manton said, are Justices Joseph G. Golia and Robert L. Nahman of State Supreme Court, Rocco M. Longo, counsel to the Queens public administrator, and Michael Feigenbaum, a former counsel. "I always lean to a sitting judge," Mr. Manton said. He did not specify which one.
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo could appoint an interim surrogate, but will apparently pass because so little time is left before the election and because the State Senate, which would have to confirm an interim appointee, is out of session -- at long last.
The surrogate, who makes $95,000 a year, presides over the probating of wills and estates and often appoints lawyers to represent parties in such cases.

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
Deficit Up, But in '91 The Furor Has Passed

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 13

 BODY:
This time last year the budget was front- page news. President Bush and Congress were deadlocked in negotiations that had been going on for months. When Richard G. Darman, the President's budget director, submitted his annual midyear fiscal review, the deficit projected for the fiscal year that began Oct. 1 seemed shockingly large -- $231 billion.
Drastic consequences would occur if a way could not be found to reduce that deficit, Mr. Darman asserted. Under the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget-balancing law, many air traffic control installations would be closed. Meat inspection would be ended for five months. Vaccinations for a million children would be canceled. 
 That was last year. On Monday, Mr. Darman is to release this year's midyear review. It will show a deficit of perhaps $315 billion or $320 billion for the next fiscal year, nearly $100 billion above the figure last July, $35 billion or $40 billion above what was forecast as recently as February and far and away the biggest deficit ever. But nobody seems to care.
The Bush Administration portrays the new deficit figure as a statistical anomaly. The economists and political scientists who filled the nation's op-ed pages last year with doomsday columns about dangers of the deficit have turned their attention elsewhere. And the Democrats in Congress have had not only their hands but also their tongues tied by the five-year budget deal they struck with Mr. Bush last fall.
The Administration's stance is understandable on both substantive and political grounds. The high deficit next year will be due in part to one-time-only costs: the savings and loan bailout, bank failures and leftover expenses from the war against Iraq. "These are transitory events," said an Administration economist. "So long as the economy does passably well and the budget agreement is not broken, you should see a double-digit deficit heading toward balance by the middle of the decade."
As for politics, the President must be delighted that the deficit and his broken promise not to raise taxes are out of the news.
The scholars' lack of attention to the deficit this year is also readily explained. Benjamin M. Friedman, a professor of political economy at Harvard, said he believed just as strongly as he did last year, when he was writing regularly about the subject, that the deficit was "ruining the country." But he said he felt like someone who had tried unsuccessfully to persuade an alcoholic friend to stop drinking. "You've done absolutely everything you can do, and now it's not at all clear it will do any good to continue harping."
But what about the Democrats? In a year, the 1992 election campaign will be in full swing. The country has been in a recession, and the recovery looks tepid indeed. States and cities from Maine to California are staggering from cutbacks in Federal aid. Now, the President's budget director puts forth the biggest deficit in history. How can the Democrats be silent?
"It's the peril of being the Congressional party," said a Democratic political strategist.
What he meant was that when the economy was sour in 1980, Ronald Reagan could run against Jimmy Carter by promising, without showing how the numbers added up, to cut taxes, raise military spending and balance the budget all at the same time.
The Democrats do not have the same freedom. They signed the deal that put off further debate on the budget until after the 1992 election. They agreed that all new spending would be balanced by cuts elsewhere. They forfeited their right to criticize a President with a stratospheric popularity rating on the one issue on which he seems vulnerable.
Even more, they cannot promote their best issues. When Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th of West Virginia talks about helping children or when Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts advocates universal medical insurance, they must document how they would pay the costs.
Last year's budget agreement may have been responsible policy for the Democrats. But politically, it has proved disastrous. "No doubt about it," said a Democratic senator. "We laid down some of the biggest weapons in our arsenal."

HEADLINE: A Nomination Sets Off Battle On C.I.A. Role

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 13

 BODY:
Beyond the charges and denials involving the Iran-contra affair, the struggle over Robert M. Gates's nomination as Director of Central Intelligence is a battle over the course of the nation's 50-year-old espionage establishment.
Broadly, the conflict pits two contrasting views of American intelligence. Supporters of Mr. Gates would shift the historic focus of American intelligence away from the Soviet Union, secret wars and back-alley covert operations to the sophisticated analysis of regional and global political and economic trends. On the other side are veteran spies, in the mold of John le Carre's fictional George Smiley, whose views were forged in the cold war and the shadowy world of espionage. 
 The conflict matches the Central Intelligence Agency against an array of military espionage agencies that have designs on the C.I.A.'s historic turf. The infighting comes as the military and civilian agencies are competing for scarce Federal money and Congress is studying an overhaul of the Government's espionage empire.
 
Simmering Since 1989
 And the conflict pits those who want to lift up the veil of secrecy that has shielded intelligence agencies from the rest of Government against those who fear that such a move would destroy the secrecy that they say makes espionage possible.
The struggle has simmered largely under classified wraps since the disintegration of the Soviet empire began in 1989. Now it is surfacing in the debate over Mr. Gates, a man whose strong views and canny bureaucratic skills inspire unusual ardor from backers and enemies alike.
The Iran-contra scandal, not his views, is the most urgent threat to Mr. Gates's ambition to head the C.I.A. The Senate Intelligence Committee, which this week put off hearings on his nomination, is unlikely to elevate Mr. Gates to the top C.I.A. post until it is certain that his knowledge of Oliver L. North's secret shipments of arms to Iran and the Nicaraguan rebels was slight and his actions proper, as he has contended they were.
But the debate over Mr. Gates's role in the Iran-contra affair mirrors the larger debate over the direction in which he will take the C.I.A.: toward its swashbuckling tradition of third world coups, assassination plots and spying on domestic protesters, or along a new course that would make it less a collector of secrets and more the world's most eminent and reliable source of information.
Many of Mr. Gates's sharpest critics are former members of the C.I.A.'s operations directorate, the invisible league of spies and guerrilla warriors who comprise the business end of American espionage. Four of the agency's previous directors -- Allen W. Dulles, Richard M. Helms, William E. Colby and William J. Casey -- came from that tradition.
Mr. Gates, 47 years old, is a career intelligence analyst, wholly outside the trenchcoat-and-dagger culture that has dominated the agency since its founding in 1947. While that is not the only difference between Mr. Gates and his critics in the intelligence empire, it may be the most significant.
"I think the nomination of Mr Gates is a major development in the history of intelligence," said Mr. Colby, an old operations master who nevertheless says he supports Mr. Gates. "Finally, finally, we're achieving the basic concept of central intelligence, that it's the analyst who's at the center of things. I think his nomination is a recognition that we have arrived at an appreciation of that fact."
Some members of the agency's clandestine service take a different view. To them, Mr. Gates is a tepid bureaucrat with a distaste for the dangers of spying who would remove the last vestiges of Mr. Casey's high-risk era and return the C.I.A. to the more cautious days of President Carter's intelligence director, Adm. Stansfield Turner. The two directors are widely regarded as antitheses. Mr. Gates was a top aide to both men in the 1970's and 1980's.
"He's an honest-to-God pol," one recently retired senior operations official said of Mr. Gates. "To work for Turner and then turn around and work for Casey! What does he stand for?"
 
Feet in Both Camps
 In fact, Mr. Gates seems to have feet firmly in both camps. A Sovietologist by training and profession, he expresses in speeches and papers the kind of dark suspicions and aggressive defiance of Moscow that the late Mr. Casey would have embraced. As a deputy to Mr. Casey in the 1980's and William H. Webster in 1987 and 1988, former intelligence officials say, he took an active interest in the C.I.A.'s covert operations in Angola and Afghanistan.
His conservative views have clashed with those of other senior members of Mr. Bush's administration, including Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, who once killed a tough speech on the Soviet Union that Mr. Gates had been scheduled to deliver.
Even admirers acknowledge, however, that Mr. Gates, like Admiral Turner, is wary of the sometimes-risky style of the C.I.A.'s clandestine operators.
As the deputy director for intelligence from 1982 to 1986, a job in which he managed the C.I.A.'s thousands of intelligence analysts, Mr. Gates lobbied long and successfully to move some of his most promising analysts into undercover posts overseas, so they could learn the spying business firsthand. Several analysts were made the chiefs of important C.I.A. stations, positions that traditionally have gone to the best or most favored members of the agency's operations directorate.
"That goes a long way toward explaining why so many of the old boys are bad-mouthing Bob Gates on the Hill," said another former C.I.A. official. "They don't like Gates because he brought some new ways of doing business between the D.D.I. and the D.D.O.," the acronyms for the intelligence and operations directorates.
"They've been doing things the same way for the last 20 years, and they don't want to change," the former official added. "There's a trepidation that if Gates goes out there, he'll shake things up."
"He's not a D.D.O.'er," said Bobby Ray Inman, a former deputy to Mr. Casey who is perhaps Mr. Gates's strongest supporter. "There was a view among them that he was too forthcoming with the oversight committees when he was Casey's deputy -- that he told them more than they needed to know."
 
Are New Skills Needed?
 Others disagree with Mr. Inman. Some on the Senate Intelligence Committee have accused Mr. Gates of not being forthcoming enough when he first testified to them about the Iran-contra affair in 1986 and early 1987. And some contend that Mr. Gates secretly harbors the same dislike of Congressional oversight of the C.I.A. that was the hallmark of his former boss, Mr. Casey.
Other supporters argue that Soviet-oriented operations officials could dominate the C.I.A. in the days when Moscow was America's only rival but that the agency needs different skills more suited to Mr. Gates's background in the next century.
Mr. Webster, the current Director, has been nudging the C.I.A. along this path for some time. Under his tenure, the clandestine service has sought to build a credible network of undercover agents in the Middle East, the focus of many of Washington's national-security concerns, and has dispatched some of its most promising officers to work directly with analysts in special centers devoted to terrorism, counterespionage and drugs.
Perhaps more important, the agency is moving to acquire more powerful computers that can absorb the growing cascade of print and broadcast news in the old communist bloc countries and in the developing world and put it in a form that analysts can use.
That reflects a growing view that traditional state secrets, while still an important part of the spying business in crises, are no more important than a broad knowledge of the world that can enable Washington policy makers to spot and respond to emerging political and economic trends.
