HEADLINE: NBC News 'Professionals' Fight to Decline Honor

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
Writing the words that Tom Brokaw reads to nearly 15 million Americans weeknights on the NBC Nightly News might sound like a terrific job. But Jack Freeman, who writes those words, has a different view. He calls it routine, formulaic, highly supervised and unimaginative.
Mr. Freeman is not your average office griper. Along with some colleagues, he has taken his complaints to Federal court. 
 In a labor dispute as meaningful for its paradoxes and subtleties as for its financial stakes, Mr. Freeman and about a dozen other news writers and producers are contesting how the National Broadcasting Company calculates their overtime pay.
At the heart of the dispute is whether news writers and producers are professionals. Federal labor laws and regulations exclude from overtime payments certain types of workers, including so-called "learned" professionals like doctors and lawyers, "artistic" professionals like cartoonists and advertising writers, and administrators.
 
Other TV and Newspaper Suits
 The issue has come up at a number of news organizations in recent years. Similar lawsuits have been brought by some reporters, producers and news writers at a television station in Dallas, KDFW-TV, and by a reporter at The Washington Post. They, too, contend that they are not professionals and so must be paid overtime; their employers maintain that they are professionals and are therefore exempt.
A Federal district court and an appeals court have ruled in favor of the employees in Dallas. The Washington case has not come to trial.
A decision is expected soon in the NBC case, which has ambled through the courts for six years.
To win it, the writers and producers have to convince a Federal magistrate that their jobs are fundamentally mundane and uncreative. NBC has to demonstrate that their work is original and imaginative, and that they frequently exercise discretion and independence.
NBC contends that creativity is the hallmark of the work performed by its news writers and producers and that they constantly make vital judgments and decisions on their own.
 
'It's Not Brain Surgery'
 "The management of NBC News just had a lot of trouble accepting the notion that the people they are hiring for these important jobs are not professionals," said Jay E. Gerber, a lawyer representing the network.
Mr. Freeman said there was no doubt that his work required skill and experience, but that under the law the fact that he made news judgments did not make him a professional.
"We're proud of the work we do," he said. "We think it's very important work and we think we do it very well. But it's not brain surgery and it's not painting 'Mona Lisas.' We are just not creative artists. We are journalists."
Until late last year, when the system was changed, news writers and producers at NBC were paid the same base salary, with varying fees added for different categories of writers and producers. Overtime was paid only on the base salary, not on the fees.
 
160 Workers Originally Sued
 The base pay, before the changes, was $895 a week, and fees ranged up to about $260 a week, Mr. Freeman said. A producer making the maximum fee would have received almost $10 more an hour on overtime if the fees were included in the computation.
In a suit filed in 1985, about 160 news writers and producers for the network and for television and radio stations owned by NBC in New York, Chicago and Los Angeles sought to have the fees included. In a settlement, NBC agreed to make some small changes, and the union, the National Association of Broadcast Employees and Technicians, which had brought the suit for the workers, agreed to drop it.
But about 30 producers and writers decided that they did not want to settle and continued the case on their own. Of this group, about a dozen remain.
Mr. Freeman was joined in the first case to go to trial by two others: Bernard S. Brown, a producer for NBC News, and Robert L. Garner, a news producer for WNBC-TV in New York.
The suit was begun in a very different economic climate. In the last two years, both newspapers and network news divisions have been cutting costs in response to declining revenues. In the last week alone, NBC's owner, the General Electric Company, announced that it was closing its network news bureaus in New York and Miami. NBC, like other networks, had previously closed or scaled back other bureaus.
In the prolonged dispute between NBC and the writers and producers who chose not to settle, neither side has indicated any change of heart.
NBC contends that Mr. Freeman and his colleagues are professionals and administrators and so do not qualify automatically for any overtime. They received overtime computed on their base salaries as a result of collective bargaining, the network said.
NBC argues that the employees bring exceptional skills to the reporting of news. They have broad latitude in their work, it says, and they have the obligation to be accurate and to use their imaginations to create compelling stories for television news programs.
 
'Judgment and Discretion'
 "They regularly exercise judgment and discretion in determining what is newsworthy and how to present such stories through a blend of words, pictures, sound and graphics," Mr. Gerber, the network's lawyer, said in a brief written after the trial, which was held during February and March of 1990.
He continued, "It is preposterous even to suggest that the work of these plaintiffs for NBC -- one of the world's largest and most prestigious news organizations, 'the pinnacle of broadcast news,' where employees such as plaintiffs are expected to be 'the very best' -- involves ministerial, mundane and routine tasks."
In another brief submitted two months ago, he noted that the writers and producers were so talented that they represented themselves in the prolonged litigation, writing complex legal briefs and cross-examining witnesses.
 
Not a Question of Intelligence
 Mr. Freeman said that he was flattered but that the praise was irrelevant. He said the legal question was not whether he and his colleagues were intelligent or skilled. Under Federal rules, he said, he is a professional only if his work primarily requires creativity and an administrator only if he is granted broad discretion.
Mr. Freeman's case rests strongly on the Labor Department's written interpretations of its own rules. These say that only newspaper writing that is predominantly original and creative represents professional work and is exempt from overtime. As examples of exempt newspaper writers, the interpretations cite editorial writers, columnists and other "top-flight" writers of analytical and interpretive articles.
Mr. Gerber noted that the interpretations are not legally binding. He also said they were written in 1949 and do not reflect the evolving sophistication of journalism in general and television news in particular.
Mr. Freeman said that his work allows for occasional creativity but that creativity is not its prime characteristic.
 
Processors, Not Creators
 "Is it more important that I be creative or clear?" Mr. Freeman asked. "Is it more important that I be creative or accurate?"
"We don't make up the news," he added. "We don't create it. We process it." Most of that processing, he asserted, is done under the strict supervision of senior managers at NBC News.
The network disagreed. News writers and producers may be supervised, but the process is collegial, with considerable give and take, senior NBC producers said in court.
Mr. Gerber, who frequently twitted the news employees in his legal briefs for what he described as their self-deprecating testimony, contended that the work of television journalists, and virtually all contemporary journalists, requires analytic abilities, creative writing and broad discretion and judgment.
"Does it involve so little discretion, judgment and originality that it would be deemed to be a mechanical, routine process?" he asked. "I cannot believe that anyone would seriously say that. There is clearly an amount of selectivity, discretion and judgment that is involved that journalists must make all the time."

HEADLINE: Fire at Hispanic Family's Home Is Seen as Bias Crime

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins visited the home of a Hispanic family in Ozone Park, Queens, late yesterday afternoon, 38 hours after two fire bombs were hurled onto the porch of their frame house in what the police are investigating as a bias-related crime.
The family, including several children, was forced to flee by flames that destroyed parts of the front wall and the roof. Awakened by a daughter who had been sleeping in the living room downstairs, they escaped out a back door and ran across the street. No one was injured. 
 "The kids were hysterical," Lucy Jimenez, the mother of four children and foster mother of three others, said yesterday.
"My 4-year-old, he won't let me go out the door unless he's behind," said Mrs. Jimenez, who is 44. "He's terrified. He doesn't even like the sound of the fire siren."
 
Ethnic Slurs in Letter

The police said they considered the fire a bias crime because of a hand-scrawled letter delivered by mail to the two-story home on Sutter Avenue on May 28. A police spokesman, Sgt. Norris Hollomon, said the family immediately turned the letter, which included ethnic slurs, over to detectives from the 106th Precinct. "They deemed it bias then," he said.
Mr. Dinkins, who arrived at 5:15 P.M., spent about 10 minutes with the Jimenez family.
"I just wanted to come to demonstrate that we care," the Mayor said outside the house.
"Most people in our city are kind and good people and would disassociate themselves from this kind of behavior, this kind of act," he said.
The arrival of the Mayor and his entourage brought residents out of their homes, a few of whom booed as he stepped from his car. One neighbor, who declined to be identified, said she had lived in Ozone Park for 63 years. "They're making out like this is racial, like this is another Howard Beach," she said. "There's never been any problem like that in the time I've been here."
Mrs. Jimenez's 18-year-old daughter, Christina, said that neighbors have offered support. "Everybody was telling us not to move, not to worry," she said. "It makes me feel happy, because at least there are people who care."
 
 'You People Ruin It'

Earlier yesterday, Mrs. Jimenez read a copy of the letter, spelling out the misspelled words.
"It's very badly misspelled," she said, "but it says: 'The people around here really don't want any rickons or spics. Here we have a nice class of Italians and Irish. When spics move in you people ruin it, O.K. You people don't belong around hear. Do us a good deed, move back where you belong. You might have to move soon anyway. You dirty people have your own area. Yous work on your cars in the street like people in the getto do.' "
The letter was not signed.
Sergeant Hollomon said the fire-bombing occurred about 2:30 A.M. Friday. "Two Molotov cocktails were thrown," he said. "One entered through the window of the porch area, and the fire damaged that area and moved upwards." The other broke on the porch.
 
Family Was Sleeping

Mrs. Jimenez and her husband, Angel, 31, an unemployed construction worker, have lived at the house with their children since January 1990. They had experienced "no trouble at all" until the letter arrived, Mrs. Jimenez said.
"We were all sleeping," she said of the attack on Friday. "My 27-year-old daughter, Brenda, was sleeping in the living room. She heard something hit the front where the window is.
"She ran upstairs to wake us up and we came down and took the kids outside on the other side of the street," Mrs. Jimenez said. "The wall was in flames, below the window and above."
Christina Jimenez said: "All I want is just peace, the peace that we always had. There are kids here. We don't bother nobody."
Mrs. Jimenez, asked how she felt about the Mayor's visit, said, "I'm very honored, but I wish it would have been on a different occasion, for my kids to be proud of.
"Jaime and Brian play baseball for the Bushwick Little League," she added. "They wish that it was when they won the all-star game, not for somebody burning our home."

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 1; Column 4; National Desk

LENGTH: 1892 words

HEADLINE: Poll Finds G.O.P Growth Erodes Dominant Role of the Democrats

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 13

 BODY:
After a decade of party growth, Republicans have drawn almost even with the Democrats nationally, and ahead, though barely, in the allegiance of whites and adults under the age of 40.
The dominance in party identification that Democrats established in the aftermath of the Great Depression has evaporated. Polls by The New York Times and CBS News over the first half of this year show that 34 percent of the 14,695 people interviewed now call themselves Democrats and 31 percent call themselves Republicans. The margin of sampling error in the combined polls was plus or minus 1 percentage point.
 
Republicans Viewed Favorably
 President Bush's continuing popularity gives these trends a major lift, but the party's strength runs beyond him personally, though it does not appear to have reached the point of threatening the Democrats' sway over Congress, where the House has gone Republican just once in four decades. 
 The latest Times/CBS News Poll, conducted June 3 through 6, shows that more Americans have a favorable view of the Republican Party than of the Democratic Party. The Republicans are also preferred on a wide range of matters, from insuring prosperity, a Democratic asset until the 1980's, to a what is perceived as a history of offering "better candidates" for President.
As Lorraine Ingram of Minneapolis, a 35-year-old poll respondent, said in a follow-up interview, she abandoned the Democratic allegiance of her parents as she grew older and "Republican values became more and more important." These values, she said, include "the family, free enterprise, independence from government intervention."
The survey's news was not altogether bleak for the Democrats, whose 1992 national convention will begin in New York a year from today. The telephone poll of 1,424 adults showed the Democratic Party substantially ahead on issues connected to its image as the party that cares more about human needs, from education to health care. This poll has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
A resounding 53 to 24 percent said the Democrats were the party "more concerned with the needs and problems of people like yourself."
The Democrats also retain an image as the party that looks after people of all income levels, while the Republicans are still seen as the party of the rich. That image is not always helpful to Democrats.
Faye Boom, 49 years old, a clerk in the Milwaukee County Courthouse who was not in the poll sample but was interviewed later, said: "The social programs that the Democrats are likely to enact are going to cost me tax money, and they probably aren't going to be directed at me. I vote for what I think is the best for most people."
Democrats often stated their allegiance with some reservations. "I am pleased with my party, but, even so, I'd like to see even more performance," said George Prappas, a 34-year-old Detroit teacher. But as with many of his fellow partisans, disdain for Republicans helped explain his allegiance. "The Republicans sacrifice education whenever they are trying to fix the economy," he said.
 
Older Groups Also Shifting
 Mr. Prappas was not typical of his generation. Younger Americans were once overwhelmingly Democratic in party allegiance, splitting 37 to 20 for the Democrats in 1980 polling, with the rest uncommitted. But by 1985, The Times/CBS News Polls showed Republicans with a 32 to 28 percent edge among this group. In the 11 polls by The Times and CBS News this year, the Republicans' lead had grown to 35 to 28 percent among 18-to 29-year-old voters.
And as those voters who came of political age in the early years of the Reagan Administration have aged, older age groups are also growing less Democratic. In the 11 polls this year, Republicans held a narrow but statistically significant lead among 18-to-39-year-olds, with a 33 to 31 percent margin over the Democrats.
By two other measures, the Republicans have done even better than to draw within 3 percentage points in partisanship, among all adults. When respondents in this year's 11 polls who said they had no party allegiance were asked if they leaned toward one, the Republicans narrowed the gap to a single percentage point, 43 percent to 44.
And in the June poll, when people were asked their opinions of the parties, 62 percent said their view of the Republicans was favorable. Only 52 percent said that of the Democrats.
In the latest poll, respondents were asked which party cared more about the needs and problems of women, of men, of blacks and of whites. Forty-six percent said Democrats were more concerned about women, while 19 percent said Republicans were; 37 percent said Republicans were more concerned about men, while 24 percent said Democrats were. These images go beyond party lines. Republicans were about evenly split on which party cared more about women; Democrats divided almost equally on which cared about men.
The differences were even more dramatic on the issue of race. Fifty-six percent of all those polled and 46 percent of the Republicans said the Democrats cared more about blacks, while 15 percent of the those polled said Republicans did.
Forty-five percent of the public said Republicans cared more about whites, while 19 percent said the Democrats did. White Democarts sided with their party, with 39 percent saying Democrats cared more about whites and 32 percent saying Republicans did.
 
Polling Amid Rights Debate
 This poll was conducted just as the debate over the civil rights bill reached its peak in the House and angry accusations about quotas and racial politics were being traded. But the answers to the questions about race and sex were similar to past findings and apparently not influenced by the news.
Those impressions of party preferences, especially the impressions based on race, often translated into strong political attitudes. One Republican poll respondent, Patricia Clark of Parsippany, N.J., said, "The Democrats' major weakness is that they're too concerned with quotas and blacks and getting them into jobs."
Even though she saw Democrats as more concerned with women and Republcans with men, Ms. Clark was more influenced by her view that Democrats cared about blacks and Republicans about whites. "Republicans look after my interests best," the 21-year-old college student said, because they are "not just interested in minorities but the majority."
Differences between the political attitudes of men and women widened sharply during the Ronald Reagan years, although both sexes became more Republican in that period.
Among men, a 39 to 23 percent Democratic edge in 1980 fluctuated in the following years and has now become a 33 percent to 31 percent Republican advantage.
 
Women With More Allegiance
 Women's party allegiances did not change as erratically. From a 43 to 23 percent Democratic edge in 1980, there has been a more gradual shift to a 38 to 29 percent Democratic margin in 1991.
The Democratic lead anmong whites dropped from 36 to 24 percent in 1980 to 33 to 30 percent in 1984. Republicans took a two point-lead in 1985, dropped to a tie in 1986 and a one-point deficit in 1987 and have led ever since. In the 1991 polls, their margin was 34 percent to 30 percent.
These allegiances are not always strong or enthusiastic. A black Democratic poll respondent from Newark, Gloria Hackman, said, "They're doing terrible jobs, Democrats and Republicans."
A white Republican respondent from Langhorne, Pa., Joseph Carp, said: "Neither party looks after my interests. They just don't get anything accomplished. They spend too much time with their high salaries."
The June poll found both parties rated almost equally when the public was asked which was "more likely to waste your tax money." Thirty-three percent picked the Republicans and 30 percent the Democrats. Another measure of the decline of the Republican image of fiscal soundness was that Republicans held only a 36 to 28 percent lead over Democarts when people were asked which party was more likely to reduce the Federal deficit.
But an area of traditional Democratic strength had also weakened. Democrats held only a 37 to 32 percent lead when people were asked which party could do best in dealing with unemployment, perhaps a reflection of how little the party has said or done in Congress since the recession began. In the recession of the early 1980's, when Democrats assailed the Republicans relentlessly, they regularly held 20 point leads on that question during 1982.
 
Republicans and Prosperity
 Republicans were favored as the party more likely to see that the country remains prosperous, by a 44 to 29 percent margin.
They were also seen as the party which "has usually had better candidates for President" by a 57 to 26 percent margin over the Democrats. Democrats had a 41 to 28 percent edge when the respondents were asked about candidates for local offices, and five and three point leads, respectively, when the question dealt with candiates for governor and Congress.
When respondents were asked, "If George Bush runs for re-election in 1992, do you think you will probably vote for George Bush or probably vote for the Democratic candidate," the breakdown was like this: 45 percent said they would vote for Mr. Bush, 22 percent for the Democrat and 24 said they could not say until the Democrats chose a candidae.
The Democrats' uncertainty tinged with pessimism ranged from the comments of Jane Wood of Bluefield, W.Va., who complained that her party leaders "just sit back," to James Gleason, a funeral director in Schenectady, N.Y., who said foreign policy appeared to be a natural Republican strength and added, "I think George Bush will win that election and have no idea who the Democrats would even run as their candidate."
 
 
 
HOW JUNE POLL WAS TAKEN
 The New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted June 3 to 6 with 1,424 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of exchanges in the country. The exchanges were chosen so as to insure that each region of the country was represented in proportion to its population. For each exchange, the telephone numbers were formed by random digits, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. The numbers were then screened so that calls would be placed to residences only. Within each household one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the poll.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to region, race, sex, age, and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American adults.
The potential sampling error for smaller subgroups is larger. For example, for either Republicans or Democrats or independents it is plus or minus five percentage points.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Politics, The Knicks And N.Y.C.

BYLINE: By WILLIAM C. RHODEN

 BODY:
"I think New York's the greatest place to play in the world. You play before the most knowledgeable fans in the country, you play in the media capital of the country so that your success is amplified. You also play in the most critical place in the country, that means you can't pull anything over people's eyes. They respect effort, humility, winning -- and style. They love style." -- Senator Bill Bradley
 In October 1967, an unassuming, self-assured forward from Princeton reported for his first season with the New York Knicks, who were coming off a dismal fourth-place finish. 
 Bill Bradley was the Knicks' first pick in 1965, but he delayed his pro career for two years to take a Rhodes scholarship at Oxford and play professionally in Europe.
 Bradley had general political aspirations at the time, but nothing hard and fast. "It was not something that I personally was planning or aspiring to," Bradley recalled recently. "I always said I wanted to go into the State Department. It evolved over time."
 Twenty four years later, the Knicks have drafted another aspiring politician, Greg Anthony, a point guard from the University of Nevada-Las Vegas. As a player he is a hard-nosed defender, as a person he is gaining the reputation, at 22, as a polished statesman.
 Although the two men are removed by age and background -- Anthony was reared in the inner city of North Las Vegas, Bradley comes from the middle class in Crystal City, Mo. -- they have similarities that the Knicks hope will translate into success for a listless franchise.
 New York was an overwhelmingly Democratic city when Bradley arrived. The city's first-term Mayor, John V. Lindsay, was a Republican, as Bradley had been until his senior year in college, when he switched affiliations.
 Like Anthony, who served as a congressional aide during college, Bradley worked as a summer intern on Capitol Hill.
 Two decades later, Anthony as that rare-breed black Republican, begins his career in a city that is 83 percent Democratic.
 Where Bradley sketched a political career as he went along, Anthony has already made the rounds. He was a guest at the Mayor's birthday party earlier this week and spoke with youngsters at two locations in Harlem. On Friday, he announced plans for establishing a foundation to aid youth development and promised that at least some economically disadvantaged children would see the Knicks play this season.
 As Bradley discovered years ago, political plans are enhanced when you win. When Bradley arrived, the Knicks had not finished higher than fourth place in 11 of the previous 12 seasons. He was a starter on two Knick teams that won world championships (1970 and 1973). Bradley retired after the 1976-77 season. A year later, he was elected to the Senate.
 Anthony joins a team that has not advanced beyond the second round of the playoffs since 1974. The franchise is under new management, and the team has a new coach. In the backcourt, the best guard is too old and the younger one is not quite good enough. The best player isn't sure that he wants to play for the Knicks anymore and the community is wondering if the Knicks will ever be great again.
 This is the environment that Anthony wanted to begin his professional and political career. High stakes, high payoff.
 "The team is located in the largest city in the country," he said. "That allows me to magnify my successes -- if I succeed -- on a broader scale and help more people," he said.
 Anthony wants to develop programs to help children make the most out of their lives and help the elderly complete their lives with dignity. But what sounds great in July often crumbles in January with the onslaught of losing streaks or a string of poor performances.
 "The problem for an athlete, especially in New York, if you succeed is that you're well known and therefore when you fail everybody knows you failed," Bradley said. "The challenge is to find places where you can fail in private so you can grow as a person."
 The Knicks needed a soul and they hired Pat Riley as coach. If Ewing stays put, they will have the dominating, hard-driving superstar.
 What the Knicks desperately need now is an infusion of enthusiasm and they hope that's where Anthony fits in. They need a player who will soothe bruised egos, patch differences, forge alliances and make individuals share the vision of a common goal.
 The Knicks' young Republican will have to be a masterly politician to negotiate his way through this season.

HEADLINE: Auto Racing;
New Leader Sets Sights On Restructured CART

BYLINE: By JOSEPH SIANO

 BODY:
Picture the National Basketball Association with no salary cap or any other cost controls, and with its showpiece event -- the championship final -- being run by an entirely different league.
That is the kind of sports organization that A. William Stokkan took over a little more than a year ago when he became chairman and chief EXecutive officer of Championship Auto Racing Teams, the governing body for Indy-car racing. 
Discussing his first year at the helm last week on the eve of today's Marlboro Grand Prix at the Meadowlands Sports Complex in East Rutherford, N.J., he sounded like a marketing expert worthy of N.B.A. Commissioner David Stern, a man he openly admires. Stokkan (pronounce stoke-KAN) referred to race promoters as his "distributors," and promised to tear off the "CART" label this fall and sew on a new one.
 
Two Major Challenges
 "To the uninitiated, it sounds like we are either doing Go-Kart or shopping-cart races," Stokkan said of the 16-race CART series.
But the challenges that face him as he comes out of his honeymoon period into a time when he will have to justify CART's choice can't be solved with minor alterations. In short, he must deal with two issues that threaten the long-term health of Indy-car racing.
The first is the rapidly rising costs of running a competitive Indy-car team, costs that are outrunning the willingness of corporate sponsors to pay. "In the eighties," Stokkan said last week, "aggregate spending in advertising and promotion increased on an annual basis anywhere from 8 to 8 1/2 percent. The cost of our sport increased over 20 percent each year."
The second is agreeing with the Indianapolis Motor Speedway management on a stable set of rules for the latter part of the 1990's that will encourage close racing and limit costs.
Although the Indianapolis 500 literally defines the sport of Indy-car racing, for the last 13 years it has been run by a sanctioning body other than CART, the United States Auto Club.
 
The Marketing Angle
 CART accounts for 70 percent of the Indy-car prize money, attendance and television viewership annually, Stokkan said, with Indy accounting for the rest. But qualitatively, he said, "the Indy 500 is probably 70 percent and the series is 30 percent."
"If you have two elements of a sport where there is that kind of an imbalance between the quantitative and qualitative dimensions of it, you know up front you have a problem," Stokkan said.
If anyone has the business skills and wit to solve the problem, it is Stokkan, who was president of Playboy Enterprises' merchandising group before coming to CART. Stokkan, 40 years old, was born in Norway, and earned an undergraduate marketing degree at Pace University and a graduate degree at the University of Chicago. One of his favorite jokes, told in an erudite, accented English, is that he joined Playboy, an enterprise built on precious little clothing, and turned it into a successful clothing seller.
 
Calm or Another Storm?
 Stokkan said that the first person he met with after CART signed him to a three-year contract was Tony George, the 31-year-old president of the Indianapolis Motor Speedway. One of the main issues they discussed, Stokkan said, was "just how we should parallel market our sport and the Super Bowl of our sport."
This dichotomy exists because of a car-owners' revolt in 1978. They believed that USAC, then the existing sanctioning group, was letting the sport stagnate.
The owners broke away and formed CART. But the Indy management, which has always counted loyalty as one of its virtues (sometimes to an extreme), stuck with USAC. Now, the Indy 500 is the only Indy-car race run by USAC, which follows the Speedway's philosophies.
Just when the CART-Speedway relationship seemed to be approaching a calm, George announced after this year's race that the track was thinking about switching to the same engines used in Formula One cars. Three former winners -- Al Unser Sr., Johnny Rutherford and Tom Sneva -- couldn't find competitive cars for Indy, and George was upset that the CART owners couldn't make room for them.
 
A Matter of Money
 "He has a problem with the CART structure," said Stokkan, who can sympathize.
"Our board meetings are sometimes what I call an exercise in ego pinball," Stokkan said, referring to the CART board of directors, which comprises 20 car owners.
But he shares the car owners' fears that switching engines will sharply increase costs. It is estimated that a Formula One engine converted to Indy-car use will cost two to three times what the current Indy-car engines cost.
"I spent $4.2 million in 1987," said Vince Granatelli, one of the more competitive car owners. "This year, I'm scheduled to spend $6.9 million." Over that same period, Granatelli said, his team has grown from 19 employees to 37, "and we're about eight people short."
And during that same span, the cost of a chassis (the entire car minus the engine) went from $160,000 to $320,000. Some of that increase was caused by inflation in England, where the Lola chassis is built, and an unfavorable exchange rate, but it still must be paid.
Mark Coughlin, manager of sports marketing for Valvoline, a leading auto racing sponsor, said that some sponsors were being priced out. "There's a lot of players for $2 million, but when you get up to $5 million, that shuts a lot of people out," Coughlin said.
Stokkan said that the first part of CART's plan to control costs was to keep the rules as stable as possible, eliminating the expense of buying redesigned cars. He wouldn't mention any other potential controls because, he said, they are still being discussed by the board.
But Andrew Broadley, a customer engineer and liaison with Lola cars, said that stabilized rules could only slow cost increases, not eliminate them.
"We're in this business to win races, so we do wind-tunnel testing and other research," Broadley said. "It costs money, and we put that into our prices."
 
MEARS ASSURED OF POLE POSITION
EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., July 13 (Special to The New York Times) -- A wet track surface for today's qualifying sessions assured Rick Mears of starting on the pole for the Marlboro Grand Prix Indy-car race here on Sunday.
Mears had the fastest qualifying speed, 115.991 miles per hour, in qualifying on Friday. The rain that fell today on the 1.217-mile temporary race circuit around Byrne Arena here made it impossible for any drivers to improve upon their speeds from Friday.
Starting alongside Mears on the front row will be his Penske Racing teammate, Emerson Fittipaldi, with a speed of 115.413. The washed-out qualifying session sat well with Fittipaldi for another reason: He was taking his 10-year-old daughter to a 2 P.M. performance of "The Phantom of the Opera," and qualifying was to end at 1 P.M.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 3; Column 4; Week In Review Desk

LENGTH: 813 words

HEADLINE: The World;
Trade Embargoes: Do They Work?

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
A lot of attention was given to economic sanctions here last week -- the lifting by President Bush of sanctions against South Africa, a vote in Congress to impose high tariffs against China and the nagging question of whether anything short of violence can bring Saddam Hussein to heel. But for all of that, the lessons America can draw from its experience with sanctions remain unclear.
Sanctions have been used by the United States 77 times since World War II but they have been applied unevenly, administered chaotically and lifted haphazardly. Their goals and duration have varied widely. 
 Carla A. Hills, the United States Trade Representative, argues that sanctions should be tailored to each country, with different goals set in each case, and she says this approach has been a consistent theme in the Bush Administration. She also argues that two traditional criteria for the likely effectiveness of sanctions against a country -- that its economy depends on international trade and that all other nations take part -- remain important.
But she rejects the contention of some academics that sanctions only really work in achieving limited goals against governments that depend on fairly broad public support, rather than on an individual or close-knit oligarchy that can insulate itself from deprivation.
Some analysts, however, say such a conclusion is only bolstered by Washington's experiences with South Africa and Iraq. "Where the United States has imposed sanctions against somewhat open countries, of which they are not very many cases, they have generally been successful," said Gary C. Hufbauer, a visiting fellow at the Institute for International Economics in Washington. But autocrats seldom bend under pressure from sanctions, and in such cases the sanctions either succeed or fail spectacularly, he said.
South Africa's whites have governed as a generally open society that was vulnerable to sanctions, Mr. Hufbauer said, while Mr. Hussein has shown himself to be a particularly ruthless dictator who has withstood pressure -- at least so far.
Indeed, by other criteria South Africa appears to have been a poor candidate for sanctions. A developed economy and an abundance of natural resources make it quite self-sufficient. And penalties on South Africa were never applied universally; the European Community has been a sometimes reluctant participant and goods have been shipped through South Africa's neighbors.
 
Just One Factor
 Yet liberals and conservatives now agree that sanctions must have contributed to the release from imprisonment of Nelson Mandela, the African National Congress leader, and to the gradual dismantling of South Africa's racial segregation laws under President F. W. de Klerk.
Sanctions, however, were hardly the only factor at play, and conservatives minimize their contribution. "I can't say that sanctions had no effect," President Bush said. "But I think far more important than sanctions was the fact that you had a forward-looking man of Mr. de Klerk's stature."
Perhaps more basic, the sanctions also coincided with a sustained campaign of opposition to apartheid by the black majority; in addition, the widespread discrediting of Communism seem to have tempered the fears of South Africa's whites that a black-led government would inevitably nationalize their assets.
Still, the American penalties cost the South African economy 1 to 3 percentage points of growth a year, said Senator Richard G. Lugar, the Indiana Republican who drafted much of the legislation. There is little doubt that this, along with South Africa's exclusion from most international sports competitions, played a role in creating interest in change among white voters.
By contrast, the sanctions against Iraq had nearly unanimous international support and were leveled against a country that has imported three-quarters of its food and all the spare parts for its sophisticated equipment. But Mr. Hussein has so far defied the sanctions and appears able, at least for now, to insulate himself and his narrowly based regime from these problems. "He's still in his bunker with chandeliers and 11 rooms," Mrs. Hills said.
The sanctions case that could prove the most difficult for the Bush Administration over the coming weeks is that involving China. On the day Mr. Bush lifted sanctions against South Africa, the House voted for high tariffs on imports from Beijing, in an effort to change human rights and trade policies there.
Recent results suggest that such a measure is unlikely to change Chinese policies, however. The United States is the only country still trying to punish Beijing for the Tiananmen Square massacre in June 1989, and China is still led by a small oligarchy resistant to pressure for change.
"It's like saying one bank won't lend you money, in a town that has 108 banks," Mrs. Hills said.

HEADLINE: The Region;
The Budget Balances, But Now Reality

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
EXCEPT for some figurative fireworks, the eve of a new fiscal year usually is not celebrated with the gusto that marks the beginning of the Julian calendar in January -- particularly when an agreement to raise taxes and reduce municipal services heralds a summer of discontent. But New York City officials were euphoric two weeks ago for having agreed at all. So when Philip R. Michael, the budget director, was asked how many dollars officials planned to spend in fiscal 1992, he replied glibly: "Twenty-nine billion, give or take a billion."
Mr. Michael was just joking. Mayor David N. Dinkins was not amused. The Mayor's pained expression suggested the frustration of an official who prides himself on speaking precisely, but whose administration, in conjunction with the City Council, produced a budget that raises questions for this year and may compound the taxpayers' liabilities later on. It was a spending plan that only a juggler could love because, like the budget director's glib reply, it appeared to defy gravity. 
 "The Mayor, to his credit, did manage to put this bridge over the River Kwai together with the City Council," said Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation "While this rickety structure holds up, something more solid has to be built for the long haul."
Two weeks into the fiscal year, the city's $28.5 billion budget is still dependent on plenty of variables. While the politically sensitive State Financial Control Board, which reviews city finances, may wink at those uncertainties next month, many monitors in and out of government suggest that the balance between projected revenue and expenditures is largely illusory. They express deep skepticism that the budget will remain balanced all year without major revisions. Moreover, they are even more wary that, while the budget includes fewer gimmicks than most governments use, some current savings will cost more later, spending will continue to outpace revenues in a sluggish economy and deeper deficits will develop.
"I had one formulation that got up to more than $5 billion by 1996," said Elinor B. Bachrach, the Deputy State Comptroller for New York City. Her assessment of the budget: "I don't think anyone would claim it represents structural balance. It represents hanging on by the skin of your teeth."
The problem, she said, is not with the city's revenue projections, which may even prove conservative and are cushioned by a $150 million reserve. Rather, Ms. Bachrach said, "we see more than $150 million worth of problems on the spending side" -- about $100 million more, including higher overtime costs and interest payments, and perhaps as much as another $200 million if the city turns out to have shortchanged the Board of Education under a state formula that protects school systems from jarring budget cuts.
 
Iffy Assumptions
 In subsequent years, the city's financial plan may be even more precarious because it relies on iffy fiscal and political assumptions. The plan does not provide for pay increases for city employees, she said, and relies on hefty property tax increases, which the Council seems unlikely to pass and which edge closer to the constitutional tax limit, which is based on changing real-estate values.
 City officials point out that deficits are typically projected in the last years of the city's four-year plans, but have been bridged. This year's budget pressures may be ameliorated if the Dinkins Administration realizes its hopes to strike an agreement on concessions from organized labor and to persuade the Municipal Assistance Corporation, which was created in 1975 to borrow on the city's behalf, to refinance $1 billion in bonds. But neither negotiation has progressed much. And, with thousands of workers already gone from the payroll and thus from union rolls, the pressure on labor leaders from remaining members to accept cuts that would restore jobs may not be as great. But Mr. Rohatyn has said his agency's cooperation is contingent on labor's participation in a comprehensive restructuring -- a word that has become to New York City government in the 1990's what infrastructure was to the 1980's.
"If people seriously expect M.A.C. to come forward to give the city long-term relief," he said, "it is quite out of the question for us to do it from a fiduciary, legal or moral point of view until there is a viable four-year plan on the table." Or even a viable one-year plan. Mr. Rohatyn, who this year is facing stiff competition for his customary role of Cassandra, described the current budget as "probably technically balanced" but "extremely fragile." The underlying question, he said, is, "Can it be maintained under normal economic conditions? And the answer is probably no."
The most likely tool for rebuilding the rickety budget bridge Mr. Rohatyn described may be the joint commission that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo is forging with the Dinkins administration. "People will be unforgiving if nothing comes out of it because there's so much at stake," Mr. Rohatyn said. In the near term, what's at stake is whether the city can fend off the Financial Control Board, which could resume control if a gaping deficit emerges or the city can no longer borrow money. In the longer term, the stakes may be the very economic viability of a city that continues to spend more than it collects when a number of economists -- among them Herbert Beinstock of Queens College, former regional commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics -- predict that the city will not begin to reap the benefits of any recovery from the recession for a few years.
But as they bob toward solutions, public officials are swept backward by several undertows: the reluctance to be viewed as undermining the Mayor; the mindset, as Mr. Rohatyn called it, "that we are victims of a Greek tragedy -- that there are powers beyond our control that are creating this"; and a potential for complacency as each crisis is averted and the sense of urgency evaporates.
The city's financial plan was revised last week to reflect the budget as adopted. It will face its first credibility tests next month, when the city plans to sell securities and when Allen J. Proctor reports to the Financial Control Board he directs.
"You can tell Allen Proctor he can go on vacation," Mr. Michael, the budget director, exulted two weeks ago after reaching agreement with the Council. Instead, two days later the Control Board imposed stricter oversight. Mr. Proctor says he probably won't go on vacation until the end of August. Even then, he said, "if you mean 'when do we relax our effort?' -- we never do."

HEADLINE: Trickle Down;
At the Summit, A Chance to Set the Stage For Growth

BYLINE: By LEONARD SILK

 BODY:
WHEN President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union arrives this week in London to ask leaders at the economic summit conference for help with his sinking economy, his presence will stand as a dramatic symbol of the West's victory in the cold war. But even without Mr. Gorbachev, this year's assembly of the leaders of the seven most powerful industrial democracies would be of unusual significance.
With nationalism and economic regionalism on the rise and the world economy practically at a standstill, the Western powers can lead the way toward closer integration and more stable and vigorous growth, helping to create conditions for an enduring peace. Or they can let the world economy stagnate and fracture into competing trade blocs, setting the stage for future national and regional conflicts. 
 The risks of global economic stagnation are anything but theoretical. The United Nations has just released its World Economic Survey for 1991, showing that global economic growth slowed to 1 percent last year and is falling to zero this year. Since world population is growing by 1.8 percent a year, living standards are deteriorating for most of the world's 5.3 billion people, of whom more than 4 billion live in the poor countries of the third world and 405 million live in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union.
Recession or a declining rate of economic growth in the rich industrial nations has aggravated the problems of the poor countries and of the Communist or formerly Communist countries seeking to become market democracies. The economic disaster in the East has exceeded the gloomiest expectations of Western economists. Last year, the Eastern European economies contracted by 11 percent. Unless growth accelerates in the industrial world, the plight of the third world and the ex-Communist countries will worsen.
At the London summit, one of the biggest challenges for the United States will be to persuade the central banks of the Western world to stimulate economic growth and push down interest rates by injecting more money into the international system. Faster growth in the West would provide the additional capital needed to check the deterioration of living standards in the third world and hasten the transition of Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union to market economies. Each 1 percent increase in the rate of Western economic growth, the United Nations estimates, would add $150 billion a year to the world supply of capital.
Because the international money supply has not been growing fast enough, world commodity prices have been falling and are now back to their 1987 lows. And with the demand for money outstripping the supply, interest rates remain too high. If monetary growth continues at so slow a pace, commodity prices will stay weak, aggravating the problems of the third world and Eastern Europe -- and of American and other Western farmers.
But the United States will have to convince other countries at the summit that in the soggy state of the world economy, monetary growth can be increased without creating inflation, as unemployed labor and other idle resources are brought back into production.
In press briefings before the summit, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said the "shared objectives" of all seven summit countries -- the United States, Japan, Germany, France, Britain, Italy and Canada -- are "a sustained recovery and price stability." President Bush's announcement last week of the reappointment of Alan Greenspan as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board seemed designed to reassure the countries meeting in London, and financial markets throughout the world, that the Administration, while seeking faster growth, would not dump a demonstrated foe of inflation.
There are signs that the Administration is making progress in its effort to stress the importance of taking some risks for the sake of more rapid expansion. Earlier this month, the Bank of Japan voted to cut its discount rate by half a point, to 5.5 percent.
The United States will also find the summit an important forum for its continuing campaign to open world markets to freer trade in agriculture, manufactured goods, intellectual property, and financial and other services.
There is a serious risk today of a reversal in the trend toward freer world trade. The trade talks known as the Uruguay Round of the General Agreement on Trade and Tariffs almost came to grief with the breakdown in negotiations last December over the European Community's unwillingness to slash its subsidies to agriculture. Last week the executive commission of the European Community approved a farm proposal that could restart the trade talks. The proposal, which still must be acted on by the 12 member nations -- and which could be blocked by any one of them -- would cut production and subsidies to farmers. It represents, the commission said, "the most fundamental reshaping of the European Community's Common Agricultural Policy" since it was created 30 years ago.
But the problems are not over. Peter B. Kenen, a Princeton University economist, said he worries that the Uruguay talks "will die with a whimper and no one will care very much, because everyone is trying to build regional arrangements to shelter their favorite markets."
Though the leading champion of an open world economy, the United States itself is pursuing its regional interests by building a free-trade zone with Canada and Mexico -- and may extend it further into Latin America.
Regional arrangements -- like the American free-trade zone, the European Community's "single market" of 1992 or Japan's closer ties with Asian countries -- can further the growth of world trade, provided they do not raise barriers around themselves.
At the same time, rules for the regulation of international finance must be strengthened. The global mess created by the collapse of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International (a k a "the Bank of Crooks and Criminals International"), whose assets were seized by seven countries that charged the institution with fraud, reveals the need for better regulation in a shrinking, increasingly borderless world.
Indeed, another term for integration is "borderless." Private business is adapting to the global economy far more readily than governments because businesses seek profits anywhere in the world and politicians seek votes from national or local constituencies.
In hard times, popular and even business support for an open world economy frays. The public and private financial authorities who constitute the so-called Group of 30 described the situation last week in a pre-summit statement.
"Nationalism is on the rise," the group warned. "Europe and North America have renewed hostility toward Japan over its one-sided trade and investment flows. In Japan, a nascent nationalism is finding voice in a way that was unthinkable even a year or two ago. Several of the G-7 have residual resentments about the way the gulf war was waged and paid for."
And many Americans, especially in the Administration, have mirror-image resentments over the damp and grudging support they got from most of their allies in the war. The strain to the Western alliance is reflected in heightened trade and economic tensions.
Nationalist sentiments were held in check for four decades by the common perceived threat of Soviet aggression, but now that Communism is a spent force, Western cohesion -- Western is really a misnomer, since the West stretches to the Far East -- has been weakened.
At the same time, the ex-Communist countries' dash for freedom and independence came at a heavy economic cost. As East Germany united with West Germany, the Soviets slashed their purchases from their former vassals in the East, and Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Poland, East Germany and the others slashed their trade with one another. The loss of markets caused a loss of jobs and a further contraction of markets. Lacking goods of a quality and price that they could sell in the West, Eastern Europe saw production and employment take a nosedive.
The new democracies of Central and Eastern Europe, said Secretary Baker, stand "at what is really a critical juncture in their development of free market economies." The seven summit countries, he said, "will want to encourage them to promote competitive industries and businesses that can create jobs," and that of course will require increasing domestic and foreign investment. But, he added, "investors and businessmen are going to hold back if businesses don't have opportunities to sell their goods, and that in turn translates into a need to stress the opening of our markets to the exports from those countries."
The main reason the London summit is so critical is that it can strengthen economic cohesion and start the long task of laying the foundations for a more peaceful and prosperous 21st century -- after what has doubtless been the ugliest and most violent century in human history, an era that gave birth to nuclear, biological and chemical weapons of mass destruction. These could make the next century uglier still, unless the economic conditions of peace are firmly established.
Thus, the economic summit is closely linked to the arms negotiations with the Soviets that now appear to be very near a successful conclusion. Mr. Gorbachev's presence in London may help wind up a major arms agreement, which is of vital importance both politically and economically to the Soviet Union and the United States. This could be the sweetest fruit of summitry. It would rescue the "peace dividend" and provide the budgetary relief, savings and capital needed to establish the basis for stronger and more stable economic growth.

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
B.C.C.I.'s Fall Shows Gaps In Policing Global Fraud

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
THE fall of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International has left a trail of scandal, billions of dollars in losses, tarnished reputations and unanswered questions. The shadowy banking empire exploited holes in the net of global banking supervision for years. Yet for banking regulators, there has been one measure of comfort: unlike notorious international banking failures in the past, the collapse of B.C.C.I. did not prompt a scare in the world's financial markets or banking system.
The coordinated swoop on July 5 by Britain and other countries to seize the bank's assets was a byproduct of reforms in international banking supervision in the wake of two previous major bank scandals, the 1974 failure of Germany's Bankhaus I.D. Herstatt and the 1982 collapse of Italy's Banco Ambrosiano. The worldwide seizure was timed just before the financial markets opened that morning. "It relied on a very high degree of cooperaton by the central banks," said E. Gerald Corrigan, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and chairman of the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision, which orchestrates global banking regulation. 
 The joint action calmed the markets rather than stirring panic. "It reassured people that there was some international watchdog out there," observed Lawrence Kudlow, Bear Stearns's chief economist.
But the watchdogs moved slowly. It took them years to detect what they say is massive fraud. British officials say the hidden losses and phony loans dated back to before 1985 and surfaced only after the alarm was raised by some disgruntled B.C.C.I. employees and the bank's auditors.
B.C.C.I.'s founder, Agha Hasan Abedi of Pakistan, organized the bank's operations to avoid detection, putting key offices in the tax and regulatory havens of Luxembourg and the Cayman Islands. Then he worked with a coterie of front men to conceal B.C.C.I.'s hidden control of businesses, including the big bank holding company in Washington, First American Bankshares, whose chairman is the prominent lawyer and Democratic figure Clark Clifford. Mr. Clifford maintains that both he and the Federal Reserve were deceived about B.C.C.I.'s clandestine control of First American. As the bank expanded, Mr. Abedi tried to burnish its image by forging ties with prominent Westerners, donating generously to Jimmy Carter's charities and hiring a former British prime minister, James Callaghan, as a consultant.
 
Tracking Far-Flung Banks
 After the Herstatt and Banco Ambrosiano scandals, the member nations of the Basel committee agreed to try to track the finances of far-flung international banks. The regulators in "home" countries, typically the ones where banks were headquartered, would supervise a bank's activities worldwide and regulators in countries with branches of the bank would share information with the home-country regulator.
Luxembourg had the main responsibility as B.C.C.I.'s watchdog. After the small parent holding company received its banking license there in 1972, the bank gradually expanded to operate in more than 60 countries and amass a reported $20 billion in assets. But the tiny grand duchy, with 365,000 residents, whose main industry is providing an agreeable home for 180 banks, is known as a half-hearted regulator.
The weakness of this arrangement was evident early on. In 1976, for example, John G. Heimann, then New York State's Superintendent of Banks, oversaw the sale of a small local bank, Chelsea National. The proposed buyer was a young Pakistani whose annual income was $34,000. His banker was B.C.C.I., and when Mr. Heimann's staff sought more information, "it was clear this was a bank without a primary regulator," said Mr. Heimann. State officials told the Pakistani applicant that he had not given satisfactory answers; Chelsea National found another buyer.
The B.C.C.I. scandal, banking experts say, should prompt a closer look at what "home country" supervisors are responsible for tracking.
Estimates of the losses at B.C.C.I. start at $4 billion. Major Western banks appear to have had few deposits, partly because they regarded the bank as a pariah after it pled guilty last year in Florida to laundering drug money.
The bank's 120,000 depositors in Britain, including many small businesses of Asian and African immigrants, will probably absorb big losses. The Bank of England is trying to persuade Sheik Zayed bin Sultan al-Nahayan, the ruler of Abu Dhabi and B.C.C.I.'s largest shareholder, to inject $500 million or more to compensate them.
But the more pressing concern could be the money that third-world governments and central banks may have lost, and the political fallout from that. The bank assiduously courted third-world leaders. For example, it is accused of helping former President Alan Garcia of Peru hide funds in offshore accounts. He gave them substantial deposits from Peru's central bank. Private investigators working for Peru said that after Mr. Garcia was ousted in 1990, the funds were withdrawn. It remains unclear how many other countries were lucky enough to pull their money out in time.

HEADLINE: The World;
10 Die a Day, Or Disappear, And Peru Goes Numb

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru

 BODY:
FOR Peruvians, killings by guerrillas, the police and the military have become so common that any such death gets little reaction. It is the kind of news that papers often relegate to the inside pages, and that television news broadcasts have come to limit to one minute of air time.
Peru is a nation numbed by statistics. 
 Last year almost 3,400 Peruvians died in political violence, nearly 10 a day, and the number is expected to increase this year. June was the bloodiest month in Peru's 11-year history of internal violence; an average of 18 people a day died. And for the fifth year in a row, Peru, a nation of 22 million people, is likely to lead the world in the number of reported "disappearances" at the hands of Government authorities. Last year 302 people were reported missing after being forcibly detained.
"Life really isn't worth much any more in Peru," said Carlos Tapia, a former member of Congress and a leftist political analyst. "For you in the United States to have this kind of violence would mean more than 50,000 killed a year by police, the army and terrorists."
But last month, the country was shaken from its stupor with the murders of a 27-year-old medical student and two teenagers, whose capture by the Lima police was recorded by a television reporter. The deaths may have done more to focus the country's attention on abuse of human rights than years of talk.
The medical student, Freddy Rodriguez, was on his way to study with his girlfriend in the outskirts of Lima on June 22, when he happened to pass as the police raided a safehouse of the Maoist-inspired Shining Path, the country's most feared guerrilla group.
In a sweep of the area, Mr. Rodriguez and the two teenagers, Emilio Gomez, 14 years old, and his 17-year-old brother, Rafael, were stopped, bound and stuffed into the back of police cars. As the reporter's videotape shows, the arresting police officers kicked one of the victims and held rifle muzzles to their heads. Within hours the bodies of all three showed up at the morgue, all with bullet holes in them. Mr. Rodriguez, who had been heard to offer the police his medical student identification, received five bullet wounds to the head.
The outcry was so strong that President Alberto F. Fujimori ordered an investigation. Within days, several policemen were named as responsible and higher officials were also said to be under investigation.
The quick response also appears to be a byproduct of Peru's concern over its human rights report card, which is now being scrutinized, along with Peru's commitment against drug trafficking, as President Bush prepares to make a recommendation to Congress on $60 million in aid to the South American country.
No military official has ever been prosecuted for rights abuses here, although a few police officers have.
 
Distinguishing the Enemy
 "The military in particular has operated with tremendous impunity," said an official of a rights group who asked that he not be named. He noted that in the last three years an estimated 2.5 million people in Lima, or a third of the population, had been stopped and searched by the police or the military, and 9,000 had been detained.
Carlos Rodriguez, the father of Freddy Rodriguez, said, "There is no difference between the police and the Shining Path, when both are the ones who kill us."
In an interview earlier this month, Mr. Fujimori admitted that he was dissatisfied with Peru's rights record but said the blame is often misplaced. "There are denunciations over a number of disappeared persons and some indeed can be attributed to the forces of order," Mr. Fujimori said. "But you have to say that a good number of the disappeared persons should probably be attributed to terrorist groups."
Rights advocates said that one year after taking office Mr. Fujimori is hamstrung in addressing abuses because he does not appear to have control of all his police and armed forces. Such control is a condition of United States aid to Peru under the International Narcotics Control Act.
Without a rein on the police and the army, there are, in effect, two Perus. In Lima and other major cities, the elected officials govern and the judicial process is observed. But in the mountains and jungles, where more than 50 percent of the country lives, it is a different story. There, because of guerrilla activities, the population is under a state of emergency, and the law is effectively set and enforced by military commanders whose idea of justice may be shaped more often by fear than protocol.
"It's very hard to change things in the emergency zones," said Mr. Tapia. "When you ask commanders in these areas why they can't stop the disappearances, when they're really honest, they say: 'Look, my guys are being shot at every day. They make $30 a month. If they capture a terrorist and put him through the judicial process, he'll be out in days just to shoot at us again. We're in a war.' "
Those who would have Peru certified as eligible for the United States aid say that withholding the funds would only weaken Mr. Fujimori's hand against the guerrillas. In a nation where half of the people are so poor that they can't afford to eat regularly, withholding the aid could only exacerbate the economic straits.
That in turn could alienate even further a populace that already has a hard time distinguishing between the hard arm of the law and that of the Shining Path. And that is just the scenario the guerrillas want.

HEADLINE: The World;
India Peers at Its Future With a Sense of Gloom

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB

DATELINE: NEW DELHI

 BODY:
THE monsoon rains have failed to arrive on time in northern India, a bleak sign for the nation's food crop and an ominous portent for the new Government. With temperatures hovering around 110 degrees, electricity and water supplies in the capital disappeared for hours in recent days. As India's 10th Parliament opened last week, the newly elected lawmakers hugged each other, exchanged greetings and placed garlands of flowers around their leaders' shoulders. But the mood was decidedly sour.
"All of us have proved unequal to the challenges that are before the nation," grumbled Chandra Shekhar, the former Prime Minister. "If the leadership fails at this hour, I think we are entering into an era of total uncertainty. I do not want to be a prophet of doom, but the situation will be beyond redemption if this time we should fail." 
 Facing the most severe economic crisis in its 44-year history, the three-week-old minority Government of Prime Minister P. V. Narasimha Rao and the politically divided Parliament have begun what, for many Indians, is a highly unusual exercise of self-criticism and self-doubt. For a nation that spent years lecturing the industrialized West, and especially the United States, about its flaws, the dispirited mood has been marked by an examination of India's past and present and the realization, for many Indians, that they don't especially like what they see.
Perhaps the most surprising acknowledgement is that one of the central architects of modern India, Jawaharlal Nehru, and his Congress Party disciples may have been flat wrong in their economic agenda: that the nation's Fabian socialist pursual of self-sufficiency and disdain for consumer goods was ruinous, that the notion of central planning borrowed from the Soviet Union was calamitous, that the use of deepening state controls on industries and trade was a blunder. A visit to the fringes of New Delhi -- to a village with its fetid open sewers, its blizzard of flies, its malnourished children and adults, its squalid mud huts -- shows vividly the failure of many of the policies that have shaped India since independence from Britain in 1947.
"Of course we're witnessing the repudiation of Nehruvian doctrine without anyone saying so," said Ashis Nandy, a political scientist at the Center for the Study of Developing Societies. "The idea that the state could play the primary role in rejuvenating India's economy is not even given lip service any more."
The impoverished villages that Nehru and his Congress Party heirs sought -- and failed -- to uplift are as grimly commonplace now as they were a decade ago. Well over a quarter of the nation's 850 million people earn no more than about $25 a month.
What is significant, however, is that at least one television set has now entered even many of the most primitive villages. The pictures of refrigerators and toilets, running water, clean clothes and other facets of middle-class life raise expectations, and India has witnessed an unprecedented level of restlessness and rage among the poor. In such backward states as Bihar -- where the literacy rate is officially 38 percent, but is probably far lower in reality -- gangs of the poor and so-called untouchables are increasingly murdering and hacking landlords and upper-caste Indians, out of sheer rage at their plight.
 
'There's So Much Hate'
 At the same time, the Government must also cope with rising Hindu-Muslim tensions and worsening insurgencies rooted in ethnic and religious quarrels in such states as Kashmir, the Punjab and Assam. In the capital, police and security forces are everywhere.
"There's so much hate in the land," said Rajmohan Gandhi, grandson of modern India's spiritual founder, Mohandas K. Gandhi. "We have failed to deal with the anger and hates and hurts in people's minds. Why? I would say that above all it is a lack of a great common vision for the future. We have become an inward-looking, backward-looking, quarreling people."
Although Prime Minister Rao, who is 71 years old and frail, has moved to restore economic stability, he has yet to confront the other difficult issues that could stir political problems. The Congress Party, though stronger than any other party, is still 15 seats short of a majority in Parliament, and will have to depend on the support of other parties to pass legislation and remain in power. India has endured four governments in two years, and the opposition is in no mood for another election now; certainly it is in no mood to take over a nation on the edge of bankruptcy. Mr. Rao has pledged to open India to foreign competition, liberalize trade, scale down subsidies and overhaul the bureaucracy.
Publicly, the new Prime Minister speaks fondly of "Nehruvian principles," and of India's role as a leader of the nonaligned movement. But even some of Mr. Rao's closest aides admit that no one is quite sure any more what the nonaligned movement is, given the new cooperation between the Soviet Union and the United States and the hunger for arms, even nuclear weapons, in third-world countries. The fact that few third-world leaders showed up for the funeral of Rajiv Gandhi rankles among Indians, who now also are more willing to admit that their efforts to preach on foreign policy issues probably do not deserve much attention in the United States and the Soviet Union.
"Just by giving a verdict on every problem, you do not get importance," the former Prime Minister, Chandra Shekhar, a socialist politician, said on Indian television the other night. "If you are not able to solve your own problems in this country you cannot play an eminent role in world politics. Nothing can be more hypocritical than this."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Television images of middle-class amenities have created restlessness, rage and violence among the poor in India's primitive villages. (Raghu Rai/Magnum)

HEADLINE: The World;
South Africa Faces Lingering Wounds To Its Economy

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG

 BODY:
WHEN the United States Congress enacted a tough package of sanctions against South Africa in 1986, President P. W. Botha responded with defiance.
"South Africans will not allow themselves to be humiliated in order to prevent sanctions," Mr. Botha said. "We do not desire and we do not seek it, but if we are forced to go it alone, so be it." 
 Last week, President Bush removed the sanctions embodied in the Comprehensive Anti-Apartheid Act and South Africans paused to consider the cost of Mr. Botha's boast. About $10 billion in badly needed capital has hemorrhaged out of South Africa since the mid-1980's. American assets in South Africa dwindled from $2.6 billion to $1.5 billion, according to the American Chamber of Commerce, which estimates that an additional $2 billion was lost annually in bilateral trade and investment. And 197 American companies disinvested, leaving 129 companies still in place.
But President Bush's decision to lift the sanctions seemed unlikely to have as much immediate impact. In the years before and since the American sanctions law was adopted, other obstacles have also grown up, and they will continue to inhibit any revival of trade and investment. For example, many American states and cities have adopted sanctions at the local level, and many companies that disinvested are wary of returning. And continuing violence and uncertainty about the economic direction of a post-apartheid South Africa also undermine investor confidence.
If sanctions worked in the sense that they inflicted pain on South Africa's business and political establishment, they also had lasting effects on black South Africans -- and not just in rising unemployment. "I believe sanctions have contributed to economic decline," said the Rev. Stanley Mogoba, who heads the Methodist Church in southern Africa. "Poor socio-political and economic conditions have in turn contributed to the violence that has raped our land and debilitated our people."
The president of the South African Chamber of Mines, Naas Steenkamp, warned that "South Africa's problems have not ended with the repeal of the Comprehensive Anti-Apartheid Act." One barrier involves contracting laws adopted by 26 states, 20 counties and 78 cities in the United States, according to the American Chamber of Commerce here. The laws punish companies that deal with South Africa, even indirectly, by barring them from local contracts. The African National Congress, which criticized the lifting of sanctions as premature, urged American supporters to continue using them to keep pressure on Pretoria.
President Bush expressed the hope that the states and cities would follow his example, but The Citizen, a pro-Government newspaper in South Africa, was pessimistic. "The sanctions lobby is still very much alive and will listen more to Mr. Nelson Mandela than to Mr. Bush," it said.
Chris Stals, the Governor of the South African Reserve Bank, said the lifting of American sanctions would not immediately bring money back into South Africa because the country still did not qualify for loans from the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. The Gramm Amendment passed by Congress in 1983 obliges the United States to block any South African request for financing from the I.M.F., and the Evans Amendment enacted in 1978 similarly denies import-export credits.
In addition, Wayne Mitchell, the executive director of the American Chamber of Commerce in South Africa, said the American companies that had disinvested were particularly cautious about returning "because they've been here and had their fingers burned." And some American companies have shifted to more potentially lucrative markets in Eastern Europe or Asia.
South African business executives seem likely to move faster than Americans to explore trade opportunities. But they may find it hard to climb back into the American market, whose consumers have grown accustomed to boycotting South African products. In the years since sanctions were imposed, other countries have filled American import quotas that were taken away from South Africa. For example, South Africa's sugar quota was given to the Philippines. And South African Airways may have difficulty reclaiming the landing rights it lost in 1986, if only because of congestion at American airports.
In South Africa, some militant black organizations and labor unions have threatened strikes and demonstrations against Western companies that try to return.
"American companies that fall in line with sanctions-busting must expect to be subjected to the wrath of the black working class," said Strini Moodley, the spokesman for the Azanian Peoples Organization, a black consciousness movement.
Foreign investors are also reluctant to return to South Africa while politically motivated violence is destabilizing its black townships. And they are confused by the African National Congress's mixed signals on foreign investment, nationalization and the redistribution of wealth.
"You need stability and you need predictability, and without stability and predictability, companies are not going to put their money back in," said Cedric Suzman, the South African-born vice president of the Southern Center for International Studies in Atlanta.
Still, the gesture of appreciation that President Bush extended to President de Klerk last week, along with the readmittance of the country to Olympic competition by the International Olympic Committee the day before, gave a psychological boost to South Africa. "It's just the sort of thing that we need to kick us out ofthis recession," said Philip Timperley, a Johannesburg businessman. "There can't be too many South Africans who are unhappy with the events of the past couple of days."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Sowetan, a South African daily, announcing last week that American sanctions had been lifted. (Reuters)
