HEADLINE: Donors Look for Benefit From Charities

 BODY:
In "United Way Warns Agencies of Drop in Allocations" [June 16], the president of the Westchester/Putnam branch of the organization says, "Something interesting is happening out there." Certainly is.
 Contrary to the sense of the article, 1990 was the best year in United Way's history. Nationally, it topped $3 billion for the first time. Locally, it raised over $15 million or 0.8 percent more than in 1989. 
 That the recession, changes in corporate attitudes and sacrifices by staffs at local nonprofits have become standard components of United Way's explanation of what is happening -- rather than basic changes in donors' attitudes -- comes from an apparent belief among the agency's executives that the more you lament, the more attention you get.
 On the contrary, lamentations mostly bring forth counterlamentations from givers worried about changing economic tides, population shifts and so forth. Furthermore, those people capable of making major contributions (and probably most of the people who make smaller gifts) seek solutions to social problems as a result of their giving, not complaints. Above all, they don't want to hear the same arguments for making pledges that have been used for generations.
 When United Way came into existence, it appears to have had two major objectives. First, to make certain that those who received the largesse not only showed up on time for work on Monday mornings but stayed out of trouble with the law. And second, to ban from their offices hordes of solicitors seeking donations. In the big houses on the high hills, they didn't much care which folk dances the rest of the population enjoyed. Nor did they particularly worry about what lower orders thought, unless they thought about socialism.
 But by 1991, as studies at Yale and elsewhere during the 1980's amply demonstrate, things are different. Government now takes the major responsibility for financing solutions to social problems. And lower echelons in corporations don't demonstrate great enthusiasm for giving to make managers and vice presidents look good to presidents or chairmen of the board. Similarly, workers hardly become ecstatic about making foremen look good to managers and vice presidents. Put another way, unless prospective donors see how they can benefit (not only spiritually, but practically), their enthusiasm becomes muted. It is for this reason that black groups have successfully contested United Way's exclusive right to raise funds during designated periods in several cities.
No, the main issue isn't United Way's tight-money situation. The main issue is how we will deal with perceptions of voluntary giving at a time when we can barely pay our taxes.
 
MILTON GOLDIN
Tarrytown

HEADLINE: In the Nation;
'Pounding' Mr. Bush

BYLINE: By TOM WICKER

 BODY:
On the day he lifted sanctions against South Africa, George Bush complained that he was taking a "pounding" from black leaders who did not think he cared about blacks or civil rights. It might well be replied: Why should they?
Mr. Bush not only seemed wounded by the obtuse world he sees out there; he indulged himself in Bushspeak -- a language, or something -- a local alderman might not dignify with use. 
 "Hey, listen, we got a good record on civil rights," said this graduate of Andover, Yale and affluence. "We got a good civil rights bill."
Hey, listen, we also got a President that don't talk as good as Lincoln. Or Eisenhower neither.
Mr. Bush acted on South Africa over the protests of Nelson Mandela, the African National Congress, the South African Council of Churches, the Congressional Black Caucus and the N.A.A.C.P. on grounds that progress already made toward ending apartheid was "irreversible." He was convinced, he said, that ending sanctions also would "encourage further change."
Those may prove to be defensible reasons; certainly it remains to be seen whether lifting sanctions will further the release of the 850 political prisoners Amnesty International believes still are behind bars in South Africa. But defensible or not, Mr. Bush's decision is one more in a series not likely to endear him to most black Americans and many whites.
You don't have to start as far back as Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey; he cited Congressman George Bush's opposition to a civil rights bill in 1964. Begin, instead, with the famous Willie Horton ad that helped elect Mr. Bush in 1988.
He protested that the ad wasn't racist but only asked if voters believed "in a furlough program that releases people from jail so they can go out and rape, pillage and plunder again." But it was a black who was depicted in "rape, pillage and plunder." Mr. Bush, moreover, repeated the ad's false message. Most prison furlough programs have been successful in helping inmates return to straight life; and no inmate ever has been released on purpose to "go out and rape" etc. all over again.
Then there's the civil rights bill Mr. Bush vetoed last year and opposes in this year's version. If Congress really wants a civil rights bill, he insisted, "pass mine, pass mine now." By the same logic, if the President really wants such a bill, he could "accept theirs, accept theirs now."
But Senator John Danforth, a Republican, could not negotiate a compromise rights bill with the Bush White House. He now says the real difference in the two measures is that the Bush version would allow employers to erect job qualifications having no relevance to job requirements. Mr. Bush says the Democrats are pushing a "quota bill," and no doubt will try to make quotas the burning issue in 1992 that Willie Horton was in 1988.
The President supports a policy upheld by the Supreme Court that prevents poor women from receiving information about abortion in federally funded clinics. He says he could agree to an "acceptable" compromise, but must maintain his "fundamental position" -- which makes compromise hard to imagine.
Now Mr. Bush has nominated Clarence Thomas to succeed Thurgood Marshall on the Supreme Court, though Judge Thomas is suspect among many blacks for his opposition to affirmative action. The Congressional Black Caucus opposes him and the N.A.A.C.P. has not yet decided whether to back him. Mr. Bush defends his choice as "the best" -- not the best black but "the best" -- but the President can hardly be surprised if those who revered Justice Marshall's achievements don't regard Judge Thomas as highly.
More important, most American blacks are still on the economic fringe, including many who have dead-end jobs. Black unemployment runs about twice as high as that of whites. For black youths, joblessness and hopelessness are astronomical.
George Bush's "fundamental position" against abortion, even advice about abortion, hits hardest against such desperate groups. He has made little effort to attack or alleviate poverty and unemployment, preferring instead to keep pounding away for a capital-gains tax break for the rich. Denouncing quotas and deploring critics are no substitute for economic policies that might create enough jobs to go around, and hope for all.
So to repeat: Why should they think he cares?

HEADLINE: The Paradoxes of Help

BYLINE: By By Vaclav Havel; Vaclav Havel is President of Czechoslovakia.

DATELINE: PRAGUE

 BODY:
When I addressed the joint session of Congress in February 1990, I made the following remark: "I often hear the question, How can the United States of America help us today? My reply is as paradoxical as the whole of my life has been: you can help us most of all if you help the Soviet Union on its irreversible but immensely complicated road to democracy." As a rule, I do not quote myself, but recently people have asked me, often in anticipation of the forthcoming summit meeting of the Group of Seven and of the meeting with Mikhail Gorbachev there, whether I still stood by what I said then, and what I really meant.
To account for my affirmative answer to the former question I have to answer the latter first. Too many people took for granted that I meant economic help, which I did not -- that is, not only, not even mainly. I meant that it was in the interests of my country, of Europe and of the whole world to help make the Soviet Union a more free, more democratic and more stable place, with the emphasis on democracy. 
 The experience of the postwar period has shown us that no amount of economic assistance will make a totalitarian country more prosperous unless it is also made more democratic.
In the beginning of 1990, the Soviet Union was still largely undecided about where it was going, and any economic assistance would most likely have gone down the bottomless drain of bureaucracy, incompetence and corruption. This situation has changed. The democratic forces are trying to organize themselves and to make a radical break with the past. The former Foreign Minister, Eduard Shevardnadze, and his colleagues from the democratic camp are the foremost representative of this trend. Progress has also been made in talks about the new union treaty. Although its final shape is still unclear, one thing seems certain: the republics and the political and economic reform they advocate will play an ever more important role. The Russian President, Boris Yeltsin, will hardly have to leave the offices of Western governments through the back door again. And, finally, it seems Mikhail Gorbachev himself is now more committed to reform than ever before.
There should be, however, explicit guarantees that the Soviet Union will not revert to its totalitarian, imperial past, and will not threaten other countries in the future. The situation may present an opportunity for democracy and peace in the world for decades to come. It also presents a risk should the antidemocratic forces in the Soviet Union prevail again and use whatever outside assistance might come to bolster their obsolete regime.

 An evaluation of both the opportunity and the risk shows several things about the nature of assistance to the Soviet Union that could be forthcoming: it should be assistance to the people and politicians with a democratic mandate rather than to the bureaucrats. It should be conditional on the Soviet Union clearly showing its willingness not to project its force outside its territory and to let all its neighbors choose their own way, including those republics of the present Soviet Union with aspirations to determine their own destiny independently -- Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia in particular. It should be assistance to the individual republics, with ever-increasing rights, rather than to the center of the union. And it should be a thousand points of small assistance targeted to specific areas of a newly created market economy rather than one big bulk assistance designed to support the original pillars of the crumbling edifice. The decision in each case should depend on the economic merits of a project rather than on the arbitrary will of central planners.
In this connection, we come across another paradox. How can one reconcile the obvious need for stability in Europe and the Soviet Union with the equally obvious longing of a number of peoples there for emancipation from the central power? How can one reconcile the stated principle of territorial integrity of states with the equally stated principle of self-determination of nations? When assistance is discussed, should it be applied in support of the former or the latter principle?
There is no easy solution to this except perhaps more democracy. The trend in democratic countries seems to be toward both integration and differentiation, toward both increasing the identity of the regions and diminishing the importance of the frontiers. When this principle is applied to the vast territory of the Soviet Union, it would seem to speak in favor of assisting the most promising areas, the islands of positive deviation which could later spread over the whole area, regardless of its future internal structure.
The question, of course, is what those new islands are and what would be the most adequate form of help to each of them. The lack of experience with the transformation of ossified totalitarian regimes into functioning market economies with democratic governments, as well as the size of the country and of the population, make the task almost impossible to solve. Yet some precedents are already there.
They are the countries of Central and Eastern Europe that have already embarked irreversibly on the road to pluralist democracy and a market economy. For 40 years, they shared the same totalitarian system imposed on them by the Soviet Union. After overthrowing the system in peaceful popular revolutions, they have to cope with the same problems of transformation, privatization and democratization.
Of these countries, Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Poland seem to have made the most progress so far. With moderate economic assistance from the West, they have introduced changes. Most Western analysts now recognize that these three countries have every chance of succeeding. If and when they do, their success will also be an example, model and measuring rod for other countries of the region, including the Soviet Union and the peoples of Yugoslavia, which is undergoing a painful transition toward its new shape.
The economic reform in Czechoslovakia started in earnest on Jan. 1 of this year, 12 months after the victory of democratic forces, with a strong mandate of free elections. On that date, most price controls were lifted and the currency made convertible, thus opening up the country to market forces. Several weeks later, the first of tens of thousands of small enterprises, services and shops started to be auctioned off to the highest bidder. Big industries are being made ready for privatization as well. Legislation has been passed to open up the country to foreign investors and to protect their investments.
Six months later, the first results are encouraging. After an initial and expected sharp rise in prices, the month-to-month inflation rate is now less than 2 percent and showing signs of decreasing even further. The currency is stable after the initial devaluation. Even before privatization proper has started, new joint ventures and stock companies have secured new commercial foreign investments exceeding $5 billion .
In spite of the Government's strict monetary policies, which include tight wage controls, the Government enjoys massive public support. There has been no large-scale social unrest or industrial action. The tripartite talks between the Government, entrepreneurs and unions have so far managed to settle amicably all potential sources of conflict. The majority of the population is strongly committed to the transformation.
The process is now entering its structural and adaptive phase. Some industries will have to close, others will have to undergo a costly recapitalization. The unemployment rate, now around 3 percent of the labor force, will rise. It will be in this crucial phase that we shall not be able to do without assistance from the most developed countries.
One form of assistance would seem to be particularly helpful. It would be the opening of trade between the West and Czechoslovakia (Hungary and Poland) to compensate for the collapse of our traditional markets in the Soviet Union and other countries of the late Comecon.
To protect at least in part the still fragile economy and to balance the so far one-sided orientation of Czechoslovakian trade, the opening would have to be asymmetrical, thus favoring Czechoslovakian exports to the West, including the "sensitive items" such as textiles, steel and agricultural products. Because of the relatively low competitive value of our goods and limited production capacities, the volume of the exports could never seriously threaten the domestic markets or the balance of trade of Western countries.
It is part of our strategy to integrate Czechoslovakia into the family of European nations. By the end of the century, we hope to become full members of the European Community. The association agreement being negotiated between our country and the E.C. should envisage our full membership and pave the way for it. It should also reflect the initial asymmetry in our trade exchange and thus open the European markets to our products.
We would welcome a more flexible approach by the E.C., giving us access to their markets now, for we will be facing the biggest problems in the transformation process in the very near future. The competitive atmosphere of the European market will help increase the quality of our goods. The agreement will also open the way for a broad political dialogue and close cooperation with the E.C. countries. Our friends in Hungary and Poland are following the same strategy. We feel we will have a better chance to attain this goal by cooperation with the two countries rather than by competition.
Because of our long association with the Soviet market and because of the similar character of the transformation process, the changes in the Soviet Union present both an opportunity and a problem to our economies. The Soviet Union is interested in buying our goods but does not have the money to pay for it. The resulting drop in trade between the two countries threatens the fragile balance of our economy and leads to a further increase of the Soviet debt to Czechoslovakia, estimated at $4 billion. Hungary and Poland are experiencing similar difficulties.

 It would help the Soviet Union and it would help us if a part of the possible Western credits to the Soviet Union were set aside to finance Soviet payments for our exports to their country. This is basically the idea Czechoslovakia's Foreign Minister, Jiri Dienstbier, introduced at Harvard last year. Polish and Hungarian foreign policy experts and economists have voiced their own versions of the same idea. Some of the leading Western European banks are also studying the possibility of similar operations. The same principle could be applied to the food aid that the Soviet Union may need. It could help solve the problem of our agricultural surpluses without disturbing the balance of the already saturated agricultural markets in the West.
The countries of Central and Eastern Europe should never again be limited in their sovereignty, which includes their right to make their own security arrangements. The withdrawal of Soviet troops from Germany and Poland is of primary importance, and there is no need for it to be delayed or slowed down. A negotiated and peaceful departure of the troops is a prerequisite for a full renewal of the sovereignty of the two countries.
Unfortunately, remnants of the old imperial thinking still linger in the Soviet Union as evidenced by disagreements over security clauses in talks about new bilateral treaties between the Soviet Union and Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Poland, and by the so-called Falin doctrine, which bears a sad resemblance to the infamous Brezhnev doctrine [Soviet intervention to prevent a retreat from Communism]. This is all the more anachronistic, for Mikhail Gorbachev himself takes a more enlightened view of the new treaties in holding that they should be based on the principles of the Paris Charter for the New Europe.
We never accepted the efforts of some Soviet politicians to equate the Warsaw Pact with NATO. For us, NATO constitutes the main pillar of European security, supplemented by other institutions, such as the West European Union and the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe.
An American presence on the Continent has been the backbone of the defense of freedom and democracy for 40 years, and is, in my view, still needed here. It presents no threat to the Soviets but rather a guarantee of peace and stability for the whole of Europe, and the Soviets should accept it as such.
I cannot conclude but with yet another paradox. In our painful transition toward a state of affairs that most people in the West consider quite natural, Western countries can indeed help us most of all by helping the Soviet Union on its way to democracy. At the same time, in the more difficult transformation of the Soviet Union, Western countries can conceivably help it most by helping Czechoslovakia and other countries in Central Europe -- to show that it can be done and that it is well worth the effort. The countries of Central Europe can become a center of stability and a source for the diffusion of democratic values and benefits to the whole post-Communist region.

HEADLINE: Noted With Pleasure

 BODY:

How to Make a Meadow
 
 Many plants depend on insects to spread the pollen needed for fertilization. When we see a meadow thick with wildflowers, we're actually looking at a landscape made possible and farmed by a variety of flying insects. Friedrich G. Barth explains in "Insects and Flowers: The Biology of a Partnership" (Princeton University, paper).  
 The greater the number of plants existing side by side and even blooming at the same time, all of which depend on cross-pollination, the stronger is the selection pressure on each to be unique, to look different from the competitors and have an unmistakable scent. Insects -- at first attracted by the abundant pollen offerings -- were involved in this process from the very beginning of flower evolution. . . . The diversity of the devices employed by the flowers reflects the diversity of ways to be more attractive, so that the insects will help them reproduce under the pressure of competition. Conversely, the plants also help to shape the insects, which are exposed to equally strong pressure of competition. The insect with the best chance of harvesting the food is the one with mouthparts best suited to exploit a certain flower economically, and with the most suitable sensory abilities and behavior. . . . In this sense the plants and their pollinators are environment and reflection of one another.
 
In Search of the Vanishing World

 
 Robert Eisner suggests some reasons for the strong resurgence of interest in travel writing, and identifies the special challenge facing travel writers in an increasingly open and familiar world, in "Travelers to an Antique Land: The History and Literature of Travel to Greece" (University of Michigan).
As tourism cloys, a taste for travel and for travel literature is growing anew. In the past, curiosity about the unknown and a lack of opportunity to travel themselves enticed readers to travel literature. Today it may be a dissatisfaction with their own prepaid low swoops into the alien that drives them to seek something deeper through the literature. Conversely, the travel writer's task has become harder -- to find the choice and the special out there amidst the creeping quotidian and the shrinking alien, and to keep on finding it for two or three hundred pages.
 
The Voice of the Defiant

 
 Reflecting on her father, a transplanted Yankee who embraced the qualities he identified as uniquely Southern, Shirley Abbott discerned in his behavior a key feature of the Southern character and described it in "Womenfolks: Growing Up Down South" (Ticknor & Fields, paper).
Whatever the nature of the Southern identity, my father isolated one element of it and made himself Southern by absorbing it. He never voiced it, but something like this went through his head: "I'm not like you, and though you may send an army against me, I won't give up, and I won't change my ways either, and the reason I won't is that I'm better than you." This, of course, is the voice of the whipped and defiant, the underground. Blacks have said the same of themselves against whites. It is no accident that the idea of passive resistance occurred to Martin Luther King Jr. when and where it did, though he attributed the notion to Gandhi. Men of all races, indeed, have used the tactic against all manner of terrifying antagonists -- the church, the law, the military. And women have used it against men. If Southern history has no other meaning, this is the one worth preserving: that there is something better than success, than being top dog, than having the habit of command.
 
Literature's Green, Eternal Fields

 
 In this excerpt from his diary the Portuguese writer Fernando Pessoa (1888-1935) argues that only literature bestows a kind of immortality on the fragile beauties of life. This is from "The Book of Disquiet" (Pantheon).
Literature -- art wed to thought, attained without the stain of reality -- seems to me to be the goal toward which every human effort ought to strive, if that effort were really human and not an animal superfluity. I think that to say a thing is to retain its virtue and throw out its terror. Fields are greener in the saying than they are in their own verdure. Flowers, if they are described with phrases that could define them in the air of imagination, will have colors of a permanence that cellular life does not permit. To move is to live, to speak is to survive. There is nothing real in life that is not real because someone described it well.
 
Time Like an Arrow

 
 Michael O'Malley reminds us of some of the many symbols by which we have sought to understand and explain the passage of time in this excerpt from "Keeping Watch: A History of American Time" (Penguin, paper).
Western European cultures have traditionally understood time both as a circle -- a series of repeated natural events like sunrise and sunset or the passing seasons -- and as an arrow, shot by God at the dawn of time and stopping only God knows where. Linear and cyclical time have always co-existed, and still co-exist, in our thinking, just as any given society may contain different and even contradictory ideas about time. We depict time, for example, as both a dial, with its endlessly repeated sequence of twelve hours, and as years, totaling an ever higher number toward an uncertain future. Linear time may mean technological and industrial "progress" into that future; it may also recall the inevitability of death and decay. Cyclical time often accompanies the idea of balance in nature, but it just as often recalls the repetitive, clocklike movements of machinery. Our time, in a sense, is like a hoop rolling down a road. In different phases of history and culture we emphasize different aspects of time's duality.

HEADLINE: FOOTBALL NOTEBOOK;
Contract Collusion? Some Think So

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY W. SMITH

 BODY:
Though neither side is willing to make a definitive statement on the matter, National Football League teams and the representatives of players who are negotiating contracts with the various clubs suspect one another of collusion.
 When the Players Association functioned as a union, it could pool salary information and then share it with players and their agents. The N.F.L. Management Council functioned in the same capacity for the league's teams. Now that the Players Association has declared that it is no longer a union, it is not supposed to be a clearinghouse for salary information. It denies that it is. The management council also denies that it is supplying salary information to teams. 
But both player agents and N.F.L. team executives admit that contract talks are not being conducted in a vacuum. They also say they don't know where the leaks are coming from.
 "I'll have agents come in and they'll start telling me what this player was offered by this team or what that player got from that team," said Mike Brown, Cincinnati's assistant general manager. "I don't know where they got the information. I don't accept it, because there isn't any way to verify it."
 Last year, Brown added "nondisclosure clauses" to all player contracts, which penalized the player 10 percent of the total value of the contract if the salary figures were ever made public. Although salaries of Bengals players were published, Brown never invoked the clause, saying the salary information he saw was not accurate.
 When asked if he thought the agents were sharing information, Brown indicated that he did.
 Leigh Steinberg, the West Coast mega-agent who represents three first-round picks this year, said he doesn't share salary information.
 "Do lawyers talk with each other? Yes," he said. "Do I have the slightest idea of what is going on with the signing of players in proximity to Dan McGwire? I do not. Do I know what's going on with the players below Eric Turner? I do not."
 Meanwhile, The Associated Press reported last week that the N.F.L. plans to subpoena 10 agents in connection with a suit the league has filed against the Players Association charging it with collusion in fixing salaries. Maybe the truth will eventually surface.
 
Rembert's Troubled Patterns
 Reggie Rembert, the second-round Jets pick in 1990 who was then sent to Cincinnati in a trade for linebacker Joe Kelly, is walking a very thin line with the Bengals these days because of a number of off-field incidents.
 Rembert, a 6-foot-4-inch, 200-pound receiver, spent all of last season with the Bengals on injured reserve. He was recovering from a pulled hamstring, but more than that, he was trying to learn Coach Sam Wyche's complex offense. Now, he will need a strong showing in training camp to make Cincinnati management forget about his transgressions.
 Last winter, Rembert was charged with public intoxication after police in Covington, Ky., found him asleep behind the wheel of his car. He pleaded guilty and was fined $67.
 At the time, Rembert was supposed to be getting off-season tutoring on the offense from several of the Bengals' assistant coaches. But he missed several sessions without offering any excuses for his absences.
 Then, on May 22, Rembert was charged in Covington with driving under the influence of alcohol, operating a vehicle without a license and reckless driving. The case is set for a jury trial in on July 31.
Shortly after that incident, he got into a fight with a flower vendor in the parking lot of a nightclub in Covington. He was charged with assault, and a trial is scheduled for Aug. 1.
 In June, Rembert spent two weeks at an alcohol-rehabilitation clinic in Minneapolis after Brown strongly recommended he do so. Rembert has also enrolled in an outpatient alcohol- treatment center at Christ Hospital in Cincinnati.
 The Bengals like Rembert's size and speed, and would like to pencil him in as the No. 3 receiver behind Eddie Brown and Tim McGee. But without any tangible returns on the field, his antics could place him in the unemployment line.
 
They're Out of This World
 As of last Friday, 80 World League of American Football players had signed free-agent contracts with N.F.L. teams. The Montreal Machine, which finished 4-6, saw 11 of its players signed, the most of any World League team. The New York/New Jersey Knights had five players signed to contracts.
 
Bigger Expectations for Jets
 The Jets open training camp on Tuesday at Hofstra University with rookies and veterans reporting together. Expectations are even higher this season now that Coach Bruce Coslet has been on the job for a year. Last year, the Jets finished 6-10, despite having an offense that committed only 24 turnovers. Only three other teams in the league finished with fewer turnovers than the Jets.

HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
Digital Diplomat

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
Just a trade show or two ago, executives in the electronics industry were steadfastly adhering to their blood oath not to pay royalties to the music industry. But in a remarkable sea change last week, the industry agreed to compensate rock stars, songwriters and music publishers for profits lost to home recordings made using the latest digital technology.
 The recession and the need to spark life into the consumer electronics business are getting some of the credit for the landmark agreement. So is John V. Roach, the 52-year-old chairman and chief executive of the Fort Worth-based Tandy Corporation. 
No one had a larger role to play in getting the process under way than John Roach," said Jason Berman, president of the Recording Industry Association of America.
Mr. Roach's interest goes beyond aspirations to become the Henry Kissinger of the audio industry. Tandy, as part of an attempt to improve sales at its Radio Shack stores, is planning to introduce a sophisticated digital compact cassette player (DCC) next year, using technology licensed from Philips N.V. Mr. Roach plans on "using DCC as a springboard for making Tandy a presence in the United States audio business," said Paul Gluckman, managing editor of Audio Week, a newsletter.
 To do that, Mr. Roach needs Michael Jackson and other stars on digital cassette, and without the royalty agreement, the music industry was refusing to let their recordings be played at the digital party.
 "Tandy wants to market DCC next year without the encumbrance of a political hassle," said Mr. Gluckman.
 Mr. Roach is also clearing the way for Tandy's long-promised recordable compact disk, which has been delayed for several years because of technical problems.
 Said Mr. Berman, of the Recording Industry Association, "He introduced a businessman's perspective."

HEADLINE: WHAT'S DOING ON: Cape Cod

BYLINE: By SETH S. KING; SETH S. KING, a former national correspondent for The New York Times, lives on Cape Cod.

 BODY:
On Labor Day many Cape Codders celebrate "Over the Bridge Day," gathering on Route 6 overpasses to hang out signs bidding good-natured farewells to summer visitors. Sometimes these aren't so gentle; one favorite declares "Goodbye and Close the Gate Behind You." But you may not see that one this year. Instead, travelers to the Cape will find that people serving them or selling them something will be wearing buttons handed out by the Chamber of Commerce proclaiming "We're Glad You're Here!"
After one of the worst economic winters in recent memory, when unemployment reached 17 percent, members of the Cape's commercial community depend more than ever on tourists to keep them afloat until next summer. 
 Consequently, there is now more of everything on the Cape -- more theater, music (especially jazz; the Cape Cod Jazz Society, [508] 394-5277, has current listings), art shows, whale-watching and sightseeing cruises, and more houses for sale. And with some of the Cape's best weather coming in September, more places are staying open longer into the autumn.
 
Beaches
 Cape Cod boasts of having the most miles of clean, sandy public beaches in the Northeast. There are 77 beaches in all, and they begin at the Cape Cod Canal and end 70 miles later at Race Point, near Provincetown. The waters of Cape Cod Bay, along the north side, are quieter and shallower, making them more suitable for small children. Those on Nantucket Sound, the south side, are generally deeper and have more surf. The big waves, to the delight of the surfers, break on Nauset Beach in Orleans -- a favorite of the younger crowd -- and all along the National Seashore. Virtually all of the Cape's north and south coastlines are open to the public and most do not charge those who walk in, though there is usually a parking fee.
Fifteen of the Cape's towns maintain beaches, providing lifeguards and cleanup crews and -- at some -- concession stands and changing rooms. They also maintain parking lots at which they charge daily parking fees of $8 or $10. Besides Nauset, other outstanding town beaches are Mayflower on the north side in Dennis and Sea Gull beach on the south side in West Yarmouth.
Along the eastern arm of the Cape, which the locals call the Backside, there are more than 40 miles of unspoiled National Seashore, from Orleans to Race Point. The National Park Service operates two visitor centers -- one at Salt Pond in Eastham, the other at Race Point -- which provide maps showing all parking areas. They are open 9 A.M. to 6 P.M. daily. There is a daily parking fee of $5 a car, $2 a person if walking in. A season's parking pass costs $10 a car.
 
Sights
 The Wellfleet Bay Wildlife Sanctuary, (508) 349-2615, off Route 6 in South Wellfleet, is open daily from 8 A.M. to 8 P.M. Operated by the Massachusetts Audubon Society, the 1,000-acre area has well-marked, easily walked trails along Wellfleet Bay. Among other programs, sanctuary biologists conduct walks daily through August at 9 A.M. and 2 P.M. Admission to the sanctuary is $3 (free for society members); the walks are free, though there are charges for some other programs.
When it rains, visitors interested in the outdoors can turn to the Cape Cod Museum of Natural History, (508) 896-3867, on Route 6A in Brewster. It is open Monday to Saturday from 9:30 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. and Sunday from 12:30 to 4:30 P.M.; closed Monday after Oct. 12. The museum has an extensive collection of Cape wildlife and exhibits explaining the geology, flora and fauna of the area. Admission is $2.50.
On display at the Provincetown Museum, (508) 487-1310, at the base of the Pilgrim Monument, is "The Treasures of the Pirate Ship Whydah," artifacts from the ship of the infamous pirate Samuel (Black Sam) Bellamy sunk off the shoals of Wellfleet in 1717 and identified in 1984. Included are the ship's bell, cannon and other arms. The museum and the exhibit are open daily; through September hours are 9 A.M. to 9 P.M., and closing time is 4 or 5 P.M. the rest of the year. Admission to the monument, the museum, and the Whydah exhibit is $5; $3 provides entry to the museum and monument but not the exhibit.
 
Events and Arts
 The 126th annual Barnstable County Fair, (508) 563-3200, takes place July 22 to 28 at the County Fair Grounds, about two and a half miles west of the Mashpee rotary in East Falmouth. This is an old-fashioned country fair with music and entertainment (including Chubby Checker and Helen Reddy) in the natural amphitheater, judging of farm products and animals, horse and pet shows, and a midway. Admission is $5.
Cape Playhouse, (508) 385-3911, on Route 6A in Dennis, marks its 65th season with performances in July and August, including "Where's Charley?" starring Jamie Torcellini, and "Man of La Mancha," with John Raitt. Performances are Monday to Saturday at 8:30 P.M., with matinees Wednesday and Thursday at 2:30. Tickets are $10 to $25.
The Monomoy Theater, (508) 945-1589, on Route 28 in Chatham, presents a season of repertory through Aug. 24 by the Ohio University Players, including "An Enemy of the People," "Tartuffe," "The Bad Seed," "The Philadelphia Story" and "Twelfth Night." Performances are Tuesday to Saturday at 8:30 P.M. Tickets are $10 or $12.
At Falmouth Playhouse, (508) 563-5922, off Route 151 in North Falmouth, "Nunsense" is presented through July 21. The series of musicals ends with "Pippin" starting Sept. 25 for two and a half weeks. Performances are Wednesday to Friday at 8:30 P.M., Saturday at 5 and 9 P.M. and Sunday at 7 P.M.; matinees are Wednesday and Sunday at 2. Tickets are $15 to $18.
Wellfleet Harbor Actor's Theater, (508) 349-6835, on Wellfleet Harbor, presents avant-garde works. Productions include David Steven Rappaport's "Giggle and Scream" until July 20 and Steve Tesich's "Speed of Darkness." July 26 to Sept. 1. Curtain is at 8 P.M. and tickets are $11.
Mashpee Commons Performing Arts Festival, (508) 477-5400, takes place July 28 to Aug. 10, at a shopping center designed to look like a New England village, just off the Mashpee rotary on Route 28. Music, ballet and drama are presented every evening, usually at 7. There will be children's programs on some afternoons. All entertainment is free.
"Magic by the Sea" is a new family-oriented magic show performed every Monday and Wednesday to Aug. 23 and 24 at 8 P.M. in the Barnstable Comedy Club Theatre, Village Hall, on Route 6A in Barnstable Village. Tickets are $5.
Harwich Junior Theater, (508) 432-2002, Division and Willow Streets, West Harwich, marks its 40th summer of children's theater with "Arkansaw Bear" by Aurand Harris and adaptations of "Beauty and the Beast," "Robin Hood," and "The Hobbit." Performances, through Aug. 22, are at 8 P.M. All tickets are $6.
 
Where to Stay
 One of the nicest bed and breakfasts on the Cape is Ashley Manor, (508) 362-8044, on Route 6A just east of the village of Barnstable, on two acres with a tennis court. The house, originally built in 1699, has six guest rooms, all with private baths, fireplaces and decorated with antiques, at $100 to $165 a night a room, including full breakfast. Also on two acres, the Wedgewood Inn, (508) 362-5157, on Route 6A in Yarmouth Port, is a Greek revival house built in 1812. It has six rooms, all with private bath at $105 to $145 a night for the room, including full breakfast and tea.
There are associations that have extensive listings, such as Bed & Breakfast Cape Cod, Post Office Box 341, West Hyannis Port, Mass. 02672, (508) 775-2772, which lists more than 85 homes and small inns with rates from $50 to $185. Orleans Bed & Breakfast Association, Post Office Box 1312, Orleans, Mass. 02653, (800) 541-6226, has more than 75 listings on the lower Cape from Harwich and Chatham to Truro, with the average double at $65.
Chatham Bars Inn, (800) 527-4884, is a landmark on the shore of Pleasant Bay in Chatham, with sprawling Cape-style main inn and surrounding cottages. A double in the main inn starts at $220 including breakfast and dinner, and $140 without meals. Cottages start at $395 for a one-bedroom with breakfast and dinner and at $315 without meals.
The Lighthouse Inn, (508) 398-2244, is situated around the old Bass River Lighthouse 50 yards from Nantucket Sound in West Dennis. Cottages and other buildings of varying sizes surround the main building. Rates start at $134 a day for two, including breakfast and dinner.
Budget choice: Governor Prence Motor Inn, Route 6A in Orleans. (508) 255-1216, is on a five-acre site and has a swimming pool. It is a five-minute drive to Nauset Beach. A double room is $80; $52 after Sept. 3.
 
Where to Eat
 The Cranberry Moose, (508) 362-3501, in Yarmouth Port on Route 6A, is one of the Cape's more interesting restaurants, serving food with a Mediterranean accent. The short menu changes periodically, but usually includes house specials such as rack of lamb with pistachio crust and black currant sauce, $24.75, or Mediterranean seafood stew for two, $38. Dinner for two with appetizer, entree and wine is about $96. Reservations are essential in summer.
Scargo Cafe, (508) 385-8200, across from the Cape Playhouse on Route 6A in Dennis, serves seafood, chicken, veal and pasta dishes. Scrod bonne femme, baked in a creamy white sauce, at $11.95 is a longtime favorite. Dinner for two with appetizer, entree and modest wine, is about $55.
The Roadhouse Cafe, (508) 775-2386, in Hyannis on South Street east of the West Main Street rotary, is a casual Italian place. Favorites include chicken homard (stuffed with lobster), $18.95, and calamari marinara with linguini, $13.95. Reservations suggested. Dinner for two, with appetizer and wine, is about $60.
Marshside, (508) 385-4010, on Bridge Street near the junction of Routes 134 and 6A in East Dennis, is a comfortable place that serves hearty breakfasts for $3 to $5. Lunch features fish and chips and lobster-salad rolls; dinner includes scrod Mornay, $10.95, and chicken piccata, $11.50.
Jack's Out Back, (508) 362-6690, in Yarmouth, is a favorite of Cape artists and actors. It is down a small road off Route 6A (Main Street), marked by a sign saying 161 Antiques. Customers get their own beverages and bus their dishes. Belgian waffles at $3.10 are a breakfast specialty. Top lunch price is $4.50 for the chicken plate. By August, Jack expects to begin serving dinners for the first time, for $4.95 to $9.95. No alcoholic beverages. Credit cards are not accepted.

HEADLINE: The Down Side of the Donald

BYLINE: By Susan Lee; Susan Lee, a former deputy editor of The New York Times's Op-Ed page, is an economist.

 BODY:

TRUMPED!
The Inside Story of the Real Donald Trump --
His Cunning Rise and Spectacular Fall.
By John R. O'Donnell with James Rutherford.
Illustrated. 348 pp. New York:
Simon & Schuster. $21.95.  
 You probably know more about Donald Trump than you consider strictly necessary. You probably know that he bought a lot of so-called trophy properties, like the Plaza Hotel in New York City and a yacht that once belonged to the Sultan of Brunei; that he constructed giant luxury apartment buildings; that he scarfed down the Eastern Shuttle, renamed it the Trump Shuttle and made the steward esses wear pearls.
You probably know that business magazines slobbered over him, putting him on their lists of the richest people. And you probably remember his best-selling book, "The Art of the Deal."
You also probably know that his empire was built on money borrowed from banks and bondholders. And you probably know that eventually his properties did not generate sufficient cash to cover operating expenses and pay interest on his debts, so the banks are now pretty much running his business and have put him on an allowance.
You also know that he hung around, or hangs around, with a young woman named, improbably, Marla Maples. And you probably know that when his wife, Ivana, decided to get a divorce, the cupboard was almost bare.
But if you want to know more, pick up "Trumped! The Inside Story of the Real Donald Trump -- His Cunning Rise and Spectacular Fall."
John O'Donnell worked for Mr. Trump for three years, the last as president and chief operating officer of the Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino in Atlantic City. When Mr. O'Donnell was passed over for a key position, he went to work for the competition, Merv Griffin's Resorts Casino Hotel, as executive vice president and chief operating officer. He also wrote this tell-all book, with the help of James Rutherford, a freelance New Jersey writer.
Among the tidbits Mr. O'Donnell offers is that Mr. Trump's two casinos, the Plaza and the Castle, each ordered 4,000 copies of "The Art of the Deal." When selling them in the lobbies wasn't sufficient to work down the inventory, the hotels gave them away to guests.
You will read that Mr. Trump does not smoke or drink alcohol but eats a lot of chocolate and popcorn; that he has a terrible fear of baldness and of disease (he hates shaking hands and washes directly afterward).
Mr. Trump never spent any of his money (or the banks' money) on petty extravagances such as tipping the help. But he spent more than $1 million to alter every sign, logo, decal and fixture in order to change the name Trump's Castle to Trump Castle.
Mr. O'Donnell tells how crude Mr. Trump is. He once said to him about Ms. Maples: "God, I wish you could see her body! . . . If you could take one look at it, just one look, you wouldn't believe it. It's unbelievable. Better than a ten." (According to Mr. O'Donnell, he also used four-letter words all the time.) Mr. Trump also said that the publicity from his liaison with Ms. Maples and his divorce would be good for business.
Indeed, according to the author, Mr. Trump was not above exploiting the publicity surrounding the 1989 helicopter crash that killed three of his top executives. Although there was never any possibility that he would have been aboard the helicopter, for weeks after the tragedy Mr. Trump went around implying that he had had a brush with death.
Not bad as far as dish. But Mr. O'Donnell impugns Mr. Trump's business acumen as well. Take, for example, his purchase of the Taj Mahal in Atlantic City. Anybody with expertise in construction, the author contends, would have understood that during the years the Taj Mahal stood unfinished, the salt air and cold weather had deteriorated its structure, requiring millions of dollars in rehabilitation.
Nor did Mr. Trump understand that operating the Taj Mahal would be self-defeating because, as his third casino in Atlantic City, it would attract a large number of preferred customers from the other two.
Mr. O'Donnell outlines a bunch of bad deals that Mr. Trump insisted on. And he tells how, when they went sour, Mr. Trump always blamed somebody else -- often his dead executives.
Mr. O'Donnell also implies that Mr. Trump is a racist and a touch anti-Semitic. Speaking about a black accountant at Trump Plaza, Mr. Trump, according to the author, opined that "laziness is a trait in blacks" and said to Mr. O'Donnell: "I've got black accountants at Trump Castle and at Trump Plaza. Black guys counting my money! I hate it. The only kind of people I want counting my money are short guys that wear yarmulkes every day." It isn't any wonder that, according to Mr. O'Donnell, when Mr. Trump heard that he was writing this book he tried to intimidate him into abandoning the project.
Okay. What you know about Donald Trump won't enable you to survive alone in the wilderness. But if you always suspected that beneath his crude, callow, shallow exterior lay a crude, callow, shallow interior, read "Trumped!" It will give you the pleasure of knowing that you were right.

SECTION: Section 12CN; Page 4; Column 5; Connecticut Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1311 words

HEADLINE: Public Libraries in State Face Abridged Budgets

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
LIBRARY officials across the state are cutting their book purchases, pruning periodical lists and reducing hours, as they struggle to cope with smaller budgets.
In Bridgeport 30 of 67 library workers have been laid off, and the main public library will be open only 20 hours a week this summer. Three of the city's branches will operate only one day a week, and the fourth, North Branch, will be open two, said the city librarian, Louise Mackay Minervino.
Similar problems afflict all the larger cities, and suburban libraries are cutting back, too. In Monroe, for instance, the library director, Lynn M. Rosato, said she was forced to end evening hours. 
 "I don't think we've ever had to make cuts in the schedule," Ms. Rosato said. "It's been increases only for many years."
 
Voluntary Furloughs
 The cutbacks are nearly universal, said the president of the Connecticut Library Association, Marcia M. Trotta.
"I don't think you'll find a library that hasn't had to cut back in some respect," she said. "New Haven has a brand new library in a building that cost millions of dollars to renovate, and they can only keep it open 28 hours a week."
At the Meriden Public Library, where Ms. Trotta works, each library employee has agreed to take a one-week furlough this year, to save three positions. At other libraries, she said, people are being laid off.
That means that fewer staff members will be available to help people learn computer programs that might find them jobs or to help with research for home-based businesses.
"One of the problems is libraries are not looked at as essential services," Ms. Trotta said. "But as a cog in the economic wheel we are critical, and the long-range effects are going to be devastating."
The library director in Brookfield, Robert R. Gallucci, said: "In most towns the governing boards look at the library as a frill. It isn't a life-saving thing like police and fire. It isn't a state-mandated thing like the schools. So it kind of gets lost in the shuffle."
 
Library Use Keeps Growing
 Mr. Gallucci quickly added that his library got a 4.5 percent budget increase this year, thanks to townspeople and officials who rallied to its support. Every selectman, and most of the Finance Board members, hold library cards, he noted. But even in Brookfield, the budget increase was insufficient to give library employees any pay increase, Mr. Gallucci said.
Assessing how badly libraries will fare this summer is difficult, because many towns are still without budgets, and all are still waiting to hear how much they will get in state aid.
The use of public libraries has been growing at a far faster pace than the population, according to the Library Research Center at the University of Illinois. In the last 40 years, while the nation's population has grown by about 70 percent, the use of libraries has grown more than 160 percent.
Still, the library has been one of the first places that towns have sought to cut, as budgets have grown out of control.
Even the legislature's library, considered the state's library of record, has suffered in the last couple of years. If the State Library, across the street from the Capitol, were a bridge, it would be in danger of collapse, said the state librarian, Richard G. Akeroyd Jr.
The State Library, which shares a building with the State Supreme Court, is Connecticut's principal law library. But this year it has dropped its subscriptions to all foreign law journals, as it struggles to accommodate a 35 percent cut in its materials budget.
 
Deteriorating Infrastructure
 The library is cutting back on the number of state newspapers it receives daily, and it is reducing purchases for its two satellite operations, in Willimantic and Middletown, Mr. Akeroyd said.
"Local libraries are cutting back, expecting to rely on our collections," he said. "But we've had to cut back as well, so there won't be as much for them to draw on."
"This is a government infrastructure that's been allowed to deteriorate much faster than our roads," Mr. Akeroyd said. "We still have rotary dial phones. The President has proposed spending $92 million to link libraries in a computerized research and education network, and we aren't equipped to take advantage of it."
Not all the efficiencies have been damaging, librarians said. At the University of Connecticut Library in Storrs, the director, Norman D. Stevens, said he was forced to cut $200,000 in journal subscriptions.
"We had not carefully reviewed our subscription list in a number of years," Mr. Stevens said. "And we're not necessarily distressed at all the journals we had to sacrifice."
 
Information Gap
 But most librarians said that economic restraints are hurting their operations. The cutbacks could not come at a worse time, said the Windham Library's director, Ted Perch, because the public library is always used heavily in a recession.
"When people are unemployed, they come around more often," Mr. Perch said. "Or instead of going out to eat, they may check out a book. But now we have fewer people to deal with greater demand."
Ms. Trotta said: "We're developing a gap between people who can afford access to information and those who can't, creating a whole new class of people who are information poor. If you have the money to buy Prodigy at home, or to have an encyclopedia data base, there's no problem. But if you can't, the library has traditionally been the place to get it.
"I'm not worried about the person who wants to read the latest best-selling novel. I'm worried about the person who really needs information, for whatever reason."
At many libraries budget cuts will mean some reorganizations. In Bristol, where $63,000 was cut from the $943,279 library budget this year, acquisitions, capitol projects and office expenses are down, and the staff will drop to 21 full-time and 10 part-time employees, from 22 full-time and 13 part-time workers, said the librarian, Francine A. Petosa. The art and music collection, which had a separate staff last year, will become part of the rest of the collection, she said.
"Many of the art and music books are very expensive," Ms. Petosa said, "and this new system should give us a little more control over them."
 
Books Lost Forever
 Mr. Akeroyd said, however, that not all the new efficiencies will be beneficial in the long run, particularly the cutbacks in book purchases. The state library lost $500,000 from its acquisition budget this year.
"Because of the tax law changes a few years ago, publishers can no longer depreciate their back stock, so books go out of print very quickly," Mr. Akeroyd said. "That means, even if I got the $500,000 now, a lot of the books we've decided not to order we couldn't even get, which would leave gaps in our collection.
"It's a fact of life -- you keep information current, or you lose it."
And at many of the libraries, the cutbacks are having immediate impacts, particularly on the number of hours they are open.
 "I don't even know that we're going to be able to keep the main branch open 20 hours," said Ms. Minervino in Bridgeport. "I show the staff the schedule I've worked out, and everyone says, 'I hope no one gets sick, because this schedule will fall apart.' "
She said she is particularly concerned because libraries should be a haven for city youth in the summer. Children who live near the Newfield Branch, for instance, are exposed to endless violence on the streets, she said, but the branch will offer them a safe place only eight hours a week.
"It seems like everything is eroding, and we can't do anything to stop it," Ms. Minervino said. "Maybe I'd feel differently if we were doing a poor job of it. But that isn't the case. People in Bridgeport love the public library and use the public library, but that's just not enough."

SECTION: Section 7; Page 12; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1254 words

HEADLINE: Labor's Last Heavy Hitter

BYLINE: By James Edward Miller; James Edward Miller is the author of "The Baseball Business: Pursuing Pennants and Profits in Baltimore."

 BODY:

A WHOLE DIFFERENT BALL GAME
The Sport and Business of Baseball.
By Marvin Miller.
Illustrated. 430 pp. New York:
Birch Lane Press/Carol Publishing. $21.95.  
 In his 1983 book, "American Baseball: From Postwar Expansion to the Electronic Age," the historian David Q. Voigt called Marvin Miller "the liberator." Taking charge of a ramshackle players' association, Mr. Miller turned it into America's most successful union of the post-World War II era. From 1966 to the early 1980's, while trade unionism was everywhere in retreat, Mr. Miller and his players were rewriting the rules of labor-management relations to their advantage, winning enormous salaries and, as Mr. Miller repeatedly reminds us in "A Whole Different Ball Game," catapulting the sport to new heights of fan interest and profitability.
Mr. Miller, the domineering union chief, was also that baseball rarity, a hardheaded statesman. As he explains, he started from the assumption that big profits were in everyone's interest. As he told Walter O'Malley, the owner of the Dodgers, only money-making teams were in a position to enrich the players.
The owners never understood Mr. Miller, who came to baseball after 16 years with the steelworkers union. Offended by his insistence on substituting labor law for paternalism as the basis of player-management relations, they rejected his offer of a cooperative relationship and spent the next 17 years battling the union at every turn. The owners resisted collective bargaining strenuously and rejected any modification of the reserve clause, which contractually bound a player to a team for life. In the end, they lost both the reserve system and their advantage at the bargaining table.
Moreover, the years of intensely personal fighting created the extreme adversarial relationship between the union and the owners that is central to the game in the 1990's. The owners have had capable negotiators at the bargaining table, but they have lacked a flexible strategy that would permit cooperation with the union in mutual self-enrichment. The latest example of their shortsightedness was the 1990 lockout, when the owners again -- and just as futilely -- unilaterally attempted to impose a salary cap on on the players.
Mr. Miller, in his rambling memoir, discusses the creation and triumph of unionism in baseball, analyzes baseball economics and details the psychic wounds that he says management inflicted on him. His discussions of tactics, his explanation of labor law, his recounting of his initial involvement with the players and his examination of labor-management negotiations are interesting and rewarding. He is particularly informative on the critical talks in 1976 that defined the free agent system under which (with slight modifications) major league baseball continues to operate. His comments on player agents are sensible. The final chapters contain some insightful commentary on the evolution of labor-management relations after Mr. Miller's retirement.
When Mr. Miller describes his personal ordeals, his book becomes a bitterly unrestrained attack on his opponents that frequently diminishes its author. His bitterness over the owners' intransigence and dehumanizing tactics is understandable. His attempt at revenge amounts to a self-inflicted wound. The book is filled with cheap shots at the owners and their chief representatives, the commissioners of baseball.
A. Bartlett Giamatti is singled out for particularly savage treatment. Mr. Miller approvingly quotes his wife's appraisal of the baseball commissioner, written shortly after Giamatti's death in 1989: "angry, cold, severe, flag-waving, pennant-waving . . . a smooth talking casuist, a union-busting conservative." The author then takes his own potshots at Giamatti's "pretentious, overripe prose." In an unnecessary display of spite, he also brings up the drinking problems of Horace Stoneham, the former owner of the San Francisco Giants, who died last year. Walter O'Malley, George Steinbrenner and Charles Finley fare only slightly better. Mr. Miller paints all three in strongly negative terms but admits to grudging admiration for the latter two. As he dryly notes, the union couldn't have done it without Mr. Steinbrenner, the free-spending Yankees boss whose player acquisitions fueled nearly two decades of salary inflation and may have hastened his exile from the game.
Mr. Miller's long-standing antagonist, the former commissioner Bowie Kuhn, receives the roughest comments. The apparent source of Mr. Miller's grievance is "Hardball," Mr. Kuhn's 1987 memoir. "I never wished Bowie harm," Mr. Miller says piously, as he ceaselessly lowers the boom on his hapless adversary: "Bowie was a bad loser." The "perception of reality was never his strong suit." He "had nothing to offer . . . except . . . cliches and bromides." "His approach could best be described as a will to fail." Nor can he resist gloating over Mr. Kuhn's postbaseball financial problems.
Mr. Miller charges his immediate successor as head of the Players' Association, Ken Moffett, with a 10-month reign of financial mismanagement, indifference, arrogance, featherbedding, being the owners' stooge and -- above all -- failing to consult his predecessor. Any ballplayer who crossed Mr. Miller -- the number includes Reggie Jackson, Bob Boone and Catfish Hunter -- is duly pilloried. (Commenting on contract arbitrations concerning Carlton Fisk and Fred Lynn, Mr. Miller writes, "Neither player was perceptive enough to understand what had happened.") Not even his faithful legal assistants, Dick Moss and Donald Fehr, are exempt from a trip to the woodshed. The reader repeatedly wants to cry out, "Lighten up, Marvin!"
Mr. Miller's intolerance of differing opinions was rooted in exaggerated fears about the players' loyalty toward the union. Any show of player disagreement during negotiations led the owners to dig in their heels, he argues. In fact the union has always showed impressive solidarity, enjoying 25 years of unbroken success despite occasional well-publicized differences in its ranks. Mr. Miller has consistently underestimated the players' ability to understand their best interests.
Concern with the union's image apparently explains the book's major lacuna: Mr. Miller avoids a serious discussion of drug use among the players. The problem emerged in the 1970's, was a major factor in Mr. Moffett's ouster as union chief and plagued baseball throughout the 1980's. Except for passing shots at Peter Ueberroth's handling of the issue when he was commissioner, Mr. Miller remains silent on this embarrassment.
Marvin Miller the writer needed the same sort of help Marvin Miller the union leader gave to the players. This book screams out for professional editorial work that would have reduced its length, given it focus, eliminated a number of small errors and toned down its harshness. The book is poorly organized. Events described in detail in one chapter reappear a chapter or so later. The last two chapters, which contain some of Mr. Miller's most interesting reflections, seem slapped on to the rest of the book.
While this type of writing is too often the norm in sports books, Marvin Miller deserves better. No one did more for the dignity and economic well-being of the players than the hard-driving former chief economist of the United Steelworkers. These memoirs vent his frustrations but undercut his achievements. Eventually a competent biographer will give Mr. Miller his due.

SECTION: Section 12NJ; Page 1; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1664 words

HEADLINE: Questions Arise On Shore Trail Plan

BYLINE: By LEO H. CARNEY

 BODY:
A PLAN by the National Park Service to promote the Jersey Shore nationally as one major tour destination, like a national park, is being questioned by environmentalists and others for its potential to create more traffic congestion and harm the state's beaches and ocean water quality.
The New Jersey Coastal Heritage Trail, as the plan is known, will feature five thematic tour routes from Sandy Hook, its northern anchor, to the Delaware Bay shore in Cumberland and Salem Counties, its southern anchor. The themes, which are still being discussed, will include the state's maritime history and will encompass more than 372 cultural, historic and environmental attractions and individual buildings, according to spokesmen for the Park Service. 
 But those concerned about the coastal trail said in recent interviews that although it would be an invaluable marketing tool, the plan so far had not addressed the potential impact of motor vehicles and more people on the Shore's air quality, sewage treatment plants, the ocean and the state's park system.
"If we were going to use the beauty of the Shore to attract tourists from all over the country, like a Yellowstone Park, it will be an injustice to them that we do not have a healthy and stable marine environment for them to enjoy," said Dr. Dennis Sternberg, co-founder of Save Our Shores, an environmental group based in Ocean Township.
Except for parts of the sparsely populated bay shore, Dr. Sternberg and other critics said, the Shore is already heavily strained from the last four decades of imprudent development and lax state regulation.
"I did not think that you could get any more people down to the Shore than we have now," said Cindy Zipf, the director of Clean Water Action, a 100,000-member environmental coalition based in Sandy Hook.
Ms. Zipf was one of several spokesmen for environmental groups, including the New Jersey Audubon Society, who said they had not been invited to testify at public hearings held by the Park Service last year and this year to plan the trail.
Janet Wolfe, the Park Service's project director for the coastal trail, said there was "no question that we will have to comply with the national Environmental Protection Act and develop environmental impact statements for each of the five individual theme routes that will make up the trail." She said public hearings would be held on the routes before the first route is scheduled to open in September 1992.
The objections to the trail plan come at a time when the Shore economy struggles to recover from several years of declining tourism revenue -- a result, in part, of widespread reports of ocean pollution and beach closings beginning in 1987. Last month, the Legislature took up consideration of a proposal for further restriction of development in the state's coastal zone.
Moreover, Gov. Jim Florio has made protection of the state's coastal waters one of his administration's top priorities.
 
Sponsored by Bradley
 The trail concept was sponsored in the form of a law by Senator Bill Bradley and authorized by Congress in October 1988. Senator Bradley defended the trail, saying that its very intention was to preserve the Shore's cultural, historic and environmental features while "tying them all together so that they can be interpreted and enjoyed as a whole."
This, he said, "will be done without any environmental degradation." He said it was hoped that the additional tourists would visit from March to May and from September to November, not during the crowded summers.
The New Jersey Coastal Heritage Trail will take in a region generally east of the Garden State Parkway in Monmouth, Ocean, Atlantic and Cape May Counties. This would be linked with the state's Delaware Bay shore, south of Routes 47 and 49 in Cumberland and Salem Counties, to form a contiguous coastal tour route from Sandy Hook to Deepwater.
Among the trail's attractions are parts of the Pinelands National Reserve, the 350-year-old Cumberland County community of Bridgeton, the historic districts of Cape May and Ocean Grove and dozens of parks and historic structures.
The attractions also include rivers like the Maurice, which is the natural east-west boundary of Cumberland and Salem Counties and is awaiting designation as a national wild and scenic river by the Department of the Interior. Other points along the Park Service's tour routes are the Atlantic City Convention Hall and, to the south in Margate, Lucy the Margate Elephant, a huge 110-year-old elephantine landmark at the beach that was originally built to attract tourists.
 
A Special Designation
 Although it will not be a national park, Mrs. Wolfe said, the coastal trail has received a special designation by the Park Service and will appear on the service's nationally distributed lists and brochures of places to visit.
Eugene Dilbeck, the director of the State Division of Travel and Tourism, said the lists and brochures were often used by tour travelers who visit designated Park Service destinations and who can afford such vacations.
Mrs. Wolfe said the coastal trail would be listed as a major attraction in all Park Service literature. Tourists, she said, will be guided to the trail's different routes and attractions by a system of visitor centers, special road signs and maps and brochures.
Edie Sheam-Hammond, a spokeswoman for the Park Service's regional office in Boston, said there were about 1,000 local recreational trails recognized by the Park Service, including the Freedom Trail in Boston and the St. Lawrence Seaway Trail. But she said the New Jersey Coastal Heritage Trail was the only one in the nation created by legislation and "the only one that is a designated unit of the National Park Service."
As described by Mrs. Wolfe and others, each of the five routes along the trail will run the full distance of the trail and carry a theme, like maritime history or natural history -- for instance, birding. Some attractions are as large as the Pinelands National Reserve and the Cape May Historic District, others as small as individual buildings and parks of local historic importance.
The anticipated environmental impact statements for the five routes, Mrs. Wolfe said, will be done in stages as each trail is developed and put into place between September of next year and 1993. She said annual development costs of $400,000 would come from the Federal Government.
 
New Kind of Tourist Sought
 Mr. Dilbeck, the state tourism director, said of the trail: "This certainly will help the division in our marketing and promotional efforts. It will enable us to use the National Park Service promotion of the trail to attract a whole new category of tourists who normally do not visit New Jersey -- the tour traveler."
Nevertheless, Dr. Sternberg said the Park Service might be creating "a coastal park of questionable safety." This is so, he said, because of New Jersey's history of problems with things like beach closings, the longstanding state advisory against eating certain amounts of bluefish, striped bass and blue crabs caught in the ocean waters north of Island Beach State Park, and the state's failure to so far control the "vast amounts of storm-water runoff and sewage effluent that empty into our coastal waters."
Specifically, Dr. Sternberg said the State Department of Environmental Protection had failed to enforce the 1988 Sewage Infrastructure Improvement Act. It was to have provided $33.5 million for coastal municipalities to identify and map all outfall lines to bays and the ocean, with an eye toward eventually reducing the bacteria and chemicals that find their way into the Atlantic.
Barry Chalofsky, an official of the department's Division of Water Resources, said that only 10 percent of the $33.5 million had been spent so far and that the division had missed the state law's Feb. 3, 1990, deadline for producing a final map that would identify the coast's pollution problem spots.
"There have been a lot of problems with the administration of this law," Mr. Chalofsky said.
 
Other Plans Preferred
 Kenneth J. Smith of Manahawkin, a lobbyist for engineering and other coastal development interests in the state, qualified his approval of the coastal trail.
"If I had my druthers," he said, "I would rather see a statewide beach management plan and a statewide storm-water mitigation plan before I see the coastal trail."
The coast, Mr. Smith said, has an immediate need for $300 million to $400 million worth of construction to put up sea walls and other beach protection projects, "to assure that these new visitors will have a beach to go to in the future."
Gregory A. Marshall, the director of the State Division of Parks and Forestry, said greater funds than the division now had in its budget would be needed if the park system became even more crowded because of the coastal trail.
"As it is, you cannot rent a cabin for the spring or summer in any state park in New Jersey after February," Mr. Marshall said. Parks like Island Beach State Park, he said, are filled and must close their gates to the public before noon on summer weekends.
 
Debate Over a Loophole
 State environmental officials say that since 1980, there has been a periodic debate over closing a loophole in the state's coastal management regulations. The loophole, they say, exempts developers who build 24 or fewer residential units at a time from obtaining building permits that are predicated on proof of environmental compliance.
That debate was renewed last month when a contingent of Ocean County Republicans vowed to defeat a bipartisan measure seeking to close the loophole.
John R. Weingart, director of the state's Division of Coastal Resources, which administers the regulations, said further limitations might be needed if a large plan, like the coastal trail, sought to attract many more people to the Shore and encouraged development.
