HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Optimistic Fed View Is Expected

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Now that Alan Greenspan has been named to another term as the Federal Reserve Board's chairman, he is expected to accentuate the positive this week when he delivers his semiannual testimony to Congress on monetary policy and the economy.
Analysts said that when he addresses the Senate Banking Committee tomorrow, Mr. Greenspan will probably reiterate recent comments that in the Fed's view, the economy has begun to crawl out of the recession. He is also expected to have good things to say about inflationary pressures, which continue to moderate. 
 The tone may be more upbeat, but Mr. Greenspan, an economist long before he became a central banker, will almost certainly admit that the recovery he sees is very fragile.
"I would not go out and open a bottle of Dom Perignon just yet," said Joseph Wahed, chief economist at the Wells Fargo Bank in San Francisco.
 
Threats Still There
 Many of the same dangers Mr. Greenspan cited six months ago as potential threats to a recovery are still there. Specifically, the shortage of credit, identified in February by Mr. Greenspan as "the most critical thing that confronts monetary policy at this particular stage," has shown few signs of easing.
Steven Slifer, an executive vice president and financial market economist at Lehman Brothers, said that "banks have tightened their lending standards a lot, and until they satisfy the new minimum-capital requirements as well as build an additional cushion from which to make new loans, they aren't going to loosen them."
Six months ago, Mr. Greenspan fretted that a prolonged war in the Persian Gulf could undercut public confidence and spending. The fighting ended less than 10 days after he made those remarks. Yet, since March, notes Joseph Carson, chief economist at Chemical Bank, retail sales have risen by only three-tenths of 1 percent.
 
No Governmental Help
 No help is coming from the governmental field either. If anything, the fiscal outlook at every level of government is more restrictive now than it was in the winter. Evidence of Washington's budget problems, and its inability to stimulate the economy, is likely to be provided today, when the Bush Administration releases its midyear budget review.
Despite a handsome profit from the Persian Gulf war because of payments from allies, the budget shortfall for the fiscal year ending Sept. 30 will likely reach $280 billion, Susan Hering, an economist at Salomon Brothers, wrote in the firm's weekly "Comments on Credit."
Moreover, the absence of war profits in 1992 and climbing outlays to shore up the bank deposit insurance system will far outweigh any increase in revenue from a reviving economy, Ms. Hering said. The Administration will be forced to admit that the deficit problem will worsen in the 1992 fiscal year, she predicted. A shortfall of $325 billion or more, roughly 5 percent of the country's gross national product, is not unlikely, she added.
 
Local Problems Cited
 The slowdown in inflation and increases in hours worked should, in theory, help increase consumer spending. But budget cuts, tax rises and layoffs at the state and local government level will probably dampen some of those positive developments. Indeed, Mr. Carson of Chemical Bank and other analysts said they would be listening closely to see whether Mr. Greenspan addressed the issue of how the Fed might respond to the economic drag created by problems at the state and local government level.
"Last year, Mr. Greenspan said the Fed would ease monetary policy if Congress put together a credible budget package," Mr. Carson said. "But the fiscal drag produced by solving budget problems at the state and local government level is twice as large as the Federal budget cuts were last year. So far he has failed to address how the Fed might respond to that."
Mr. Carson predicts that renewed signs of economic weakness during the third quarter will prompt the Fed to lower the overnight rate on bank loans in the Federal funds market, currently at 5.75 percent, late this quarter.
 
View Not Widely Held
 That view is not widely held by most other analysts. In his testimony, Mr. Greenspan is not likely to rule out another easing of policy, but the Fed will probably adhere to a steady monetary policy for the balance of the year, other analysts said.
"I don't see any need for the Fed to move the funds rate," said Lawrence A. Kudlow, chief economist at Bear, Stearns & Company.
Aside from the Greenspan testimony, June reports on housing starts and consumer prices, both expected Wednesday, will be examined carefully by credit market participants. Some analysts said the housing numbers may be particularly important, since that sector is showing signs of a renewed slowdown after an encouraging first quarter.
Lyle E. Gramley, chief economist at the Mortgage Bankers Association, said a small survey of large mortgage bankers conducted by the trade group showed a clear decline since March in mortgage applications to buy new homes. "There are indications that activity is beginning to slow," he said. "But the question is whether this is a pause, or whether we are dead in the water. Right now I think the former."
Compared with the very friendly producer price report released on Friday, a report showing that producer prices fell by three-tenths of a percent last month, analysts said June's consumer price numbers may come as something of a disappointment.
"Since it contains services, it is highly unlikely the consumer price numbers will be as favorable as the producer price data," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at the Chase Manhattan Corporation. "But consumer prices are coming down as well. And the longer the economic recovery stays fragile, the better inflation performance becomes."
Most analysts estimate that the Consumer Price Index rose by around three-tenths of a percentage point last month, following a similar increase in May.

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
How Dinkins Plan To Combat Crime Detoured Critics

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
A foreign tourist dies from gunshots fired in a Chinatown gang war. A token-booth clerk is killed in a subway robbery. A woman is murdered while walking her dogs on the West Side. A 14-year-old is critically wounded by a bullet fired through his bedroom window in Harlem. A prosecutor is gunned down at a Brooklyn bank. A Bronx grocery store and a Brooklyn social club are hit by hand grenades.
And Mayor David N. Dinkins's own public appeal for gun controls is interrupted by gunfire in East New York. 
 The city's seasonal mayhem has only just started. But so far public fear and frustration has not been galvanized into the outrage that was captured last summer in a single headline -- "Dave, Do Something."
Why not? The public agenda is largely defined in the city's streets nowadays. But last summer's surge in crime was outpaced by the surge in crime reporting during a news void that has not yet developed this year.
Also, Mr. Dinkins made himself more vulnerable by seeming to respond to the crime wave with detachment. He failed to explicitly endorse the hiring of thousands more officers -- as proposed by his own police commissioner.
"This is not Dodge City," Mr. Dinkins declared defensively last summer after the fourth child in a little more than a week had been killed by bullets intended for someone else. It is arguable whether Dodge ever outpaced New York in murders, but not a single homicide was recorded there last year, although the 1991 toll has already hit one -- a shooting victim.
"Crime is up a little, like everywhere else," said Oakley Ralph, Police Chief of the Kansas city of 20,000 people (where the homicide rate has not risen high enough to inspire the headline, "Oakley, Do Something").
Illegal weapons have become so common that even Congress is moving toward a required waiting period for gun buyers, although New York's City Council, in what Police Commissioner Lee P. Brown described as "an embarrassment," failed last week to ban assault weapons. The Council is expected to do so later this month but is still debating whether to legalize the 2,163 that are already licensed.
 In the first three months of 1991, the police in New York City reported 14,393 crimes involving guns against people -- up more than 10 a day over last year.
 Some New Yorkers, numbed to the banality, to the ubiquity and -- despite modest statistical decreases -- to the quiet riot that crime represents, may simply have given up on the criminal-justice system's ability to safeguard their lives and property.
Perhaps the primary difference between this year and last is that Dave finally did do something. Mr. Dinkins coupled an anti-crime plan last fall with proposed preventive services to help young New Yorkers. After several false starts, he managed to win over the Council and the State Legislature. History may record this phase of pruning social services while expanding the police force as Mr. Dinkins's blue period.
Economies have delayed deployment of the full complement of police officers, may jeopardize some improvements that were predicated on planned civilian replacements who are now being dismissed, and have severely curtailed the planned expansion of youth services.
But, compared to June 1990, more officers were on patrol last month -- 7,279, or 652 more, on average -- and they were more visible under Commissioner Brown's strategy of community policing, which he instituted well before the Mayor's "Safe Streets, Safe City" plan was finally unveiled.
"We were doing something," said Mr. Brown, "but it wasn't getting covered."
By 1994, the police force is to have grown to more than 31,000 -- including 5,000 officers on foot and scooter patrols in communities, compared to the 750 assigned to neighborhood patrol programs a year ago.
"What we're trying to do is institutionalize the feeling of a police presence," Mr. Brown said.
In some neighborhoods, that presence may have already helped alter public perception. "While a lot of people deplore crime, what's to recommend?" said Thomas A. Reppetto, president of the Citizens Crime Commission, a private organization. "That we need more cops? We're getting more cops." Moreover, Mr. Brown said, "the number we will end up with is close to being the optimum number."
By what benchmark though? During the first six months of this year, the death toll in two crime categories that only a year ago had seemed novel to many New Yorkers went down ever so slightly -- to 31 bystanders and 39 youngsters under the age of 17. Barring a sensational crime or a critical mass of killings, Mr. Dinkins may survive another summer without the public demanding that he do something more. But probably only one summer.
"If the same thing is happening next summer," Mr. Reppetto said, "people will say, 'I thought Safe Streets was going to help us.' "

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Press Notes;
Dailies Find Lower Prices At Auction

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
THE buying and selling of newspapers has all but stopped in the last year, mostly because prospective buyers have refused to pay the premium prices that dailies commanded two years ago -- prices that most sellers still demand.
Newspaper brokers say the few papers being sold are trading at prices that reflect the sharp decline in advertising and questions about whether all of it will return when the economy improves. 
 "I've got one now I could have sold three years ago over the phone at a very solid price," said Gerald D. Reilly, a newspaper broker in Greenwich, Conn. "But right now, it's going to be a lot of work, and when it does finally sell, it will sell for one third less than it would have at its peak."
Brokers say plenty of newspapers are for sale, though many owners do not want that generally known.
For example, E. M. Warburg, Pincus & Company quietly tried to sell The New Haven Register last fall, without success.
John Vogelstein, vice chairman of Warburg, said the investment firm authorized Henry Ansbacher Inc., a New York company that specializes in media companies, to try to sell the paper for $350 million. The paper had been bought by Warburg in 1989 for a reported $245 million.
Mr. Vogelstein said that a few prospective buyers took a look, but that The Register was taken off the market in a few months when it became apparent that the asking price was "not attainable."
Lee Dirks, president of Lee Dirks & Associates, a newspaper brokerage based in Birmingham, Mich., said a daily paper in a booming community could have been sold for as much as five times its annual revenues in 1989. He said the same paper today would be worth perhaps four times its revenues.
Less attractive dailies, like those in very depressed areas and with heavy competition, might be worth only 1.5 times annual revenues, Mr. Dirks said. In the late 1980s, they might have been worth twice that.
Mr. Dirks sees little chance that prices will roar back, because there is a growing glut of newspapers for sale and a paucity of buyers.
 
Tabloids' Game Shocker!
The knives were out at The New York Post and The Daily News last week and both tabloids slashed each other with ferocity as they battled for circulation.
On Wednesday, The Post's front page screamed, "GAME WAS FIXED!" -- referring to The News's most recent $5,000 winner in the paper's Lucky Bucks contest. In an article inside, Jerry Nachman, The Post's editor, said he was "shocked and dismayed" that the rival News would stoop so low.
Since May 19, The News has been spending 33 dollar bills a day around New York and then publishing their serial numbers in the paper. Those holding the bills can redeem them for cash prizes. The idea is that hopeful winners will buy The News to see if their dollars match.
The Post's expose showed The News to be more hapless than sinister. Ricardo Rolon, the winner, said a man he had never seen before came into the Brooklyn bakery where he works, asked for coffee, handed over a dollar and said to him and a co-worker, "Look, that bill is going to come out in Lucky Bucks tomorrow."
The News denied that the person handing out the bills had tipped off Mr. Rolon, though an article in the paper said it was not unusual for those handing out the bills to say, "Are you playing the Lucky Bucks?"
If Mr. Rolon's account is accurate, the motive was apparently not to reward him personally, but to insure that somebody claimed a winning dollar, which could then be trumpeted in The News. Very few actual winners of big prizes have come forward since the contest began.
When Mr. Rolon won, The News ran an article and a picture. The News knew of Mr. Rolon's account of getting the winning dollar, but did not mention the comment by the anonymous benefactor.
But The Post found out anyway and put the news on page 1.
The News answered The Post's broadside by sarcastically thanking The Post for "free publicity."
And The News also lambasted The Post's game, "Second Chance Lotto," in which old lottery tickets win prizes.
On the day of The Post's page 1 blast at The News, The Post had used 56 as one of the winning numbers in its own contest. The News pointed out that the numbers available in Lotto go only to 54, and denounced The Post for printing a "phony number."
The Post asserted that it had made a typographical error.
But at The News, James P. Willse, the editor, said he was "shocked and dismayed" that the Post would stoop so low.
 
A Letter and a Pink Slip
In Nantucket, Mass., the island's two weeklies are locked in an economic battle that has been further complicated by a thorny legal dispute with First Amendment implications.
In 1989, the upstart Nantucket Beacon went into competition with The Inquirer and Mirror, which was founded in 1821.
The timing was odd. The island's real estate boom of the mid-80's had just gone bust, and a depressed New England economy had made the going tough for newspapers.
The Inquirer and Mirror, which is owned by Dow Jones & Company's Ottoway group, had previously been so fat that it needed no advertising sales force.
That has changed, and both papers are scrambling for every ad dollar.
In October, Michel Magee, a cartoonist and columnist at The Inquirer and Mirror, was dismissed by Marianne Stanton, the newspaper's editor and co-manager.
Ms. Magee said she lost her job because she sent a letter to the editor of The Beacon about abortion.
Ms. Magee said that when she told Ms. Stanton she was going to send the letter, Ms. Stanton responded, "Anyone who writes for The Beacon doesn't write for us."
Ms. Magee has filed suit charging that her civil rights were violated. In her filing, she said The Inquirer was "paranoid" about The Beacon.
Ms. Stanton said Ms. Magee's dismissal was not based on the competitive environment, but declined to discuss the issue. The Inquirer has maintained that the dismissal was for job performance.

HEADLINE: Judge Declares Rates on Medicaid In Washington State Inadequate

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: SEATTLE, July 14

 BODY:
A Federal district judge has ruled that Medicaid rates paid by Washington State failed to compensate hospitals adequately and thus were illegal.
The ruling by Judge Thomas S. Zilly follows a decision last year by United States Supreme Court allowing health care institutions to sue states for higher rates. 
 David Bennett, a lawyer who represented 10 Washington hospitals that sued the state, argued that the Medicaid payments were unreasonably low and resulted in a "hidden tax" on patients with private insurance who were charged more to make up the balance.
 
Judge to Issue Final Order
 "This is going to make the state pay its fair share," Mr. Bennett said.
Judge Zilly's opinion, which was issued July 3, is to be followed by a final order this week.
Jim Peterson, assistant secretary for medical assistance at the State Department of Social and Health Services, said the state was awaiting Judge Zilly's formal order before deciding whether to appeal it to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco. He said that the state was already paying its share and that the judge's ruling would increase costs and reduce health care for poor people.
The state Medicaid program for in-patient hospital care in 1990 paid out $275 million and assisted an average of 6,700 hospital patients a month.
 
State Pays 80% of Costs
 Mr. Peterson and Mr. Bennett estimated that the state had paid an average of 80 percent of hospital costs. Mr. Bennett contended that the rate had failed to reasonably meet the financial needs of many hospitals.
The Medicaid program, which pays for certain medical and hospital expenses of poor people from state and Federal money, is federally mandated to set "reasonable and adequate" payments to meet the costs of "economic and efficient" hospitals.
Mr. Peterson argued that the state had no responsibility to pay 100 percent of costs when most hospitals negotiated discount rates with private insurers or other private payers who were not required by Federal law to pay reasonable fees.
"There are plenty of insurers getting discounts from hospitals," he said. "We're trying to strike the same balance."

HEADLINE: Japan Sets Tough Rules On Business

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 14

 BODY:
Under pressure from the United States, the Japanese Government has published new regulations prohibiting companies from fixing prices, driving competitors out of the market and blocking certain types of imports, in what could mark -- on paper at least -- a big change in the way Japan does business.
The critical question is how strictly the rules will be enforced by Japan's Fair Trade Commission, which is not known for its political clout or its eagerness to enforce the country's antitrust laws. Nonetheless, the new rules are one of the biggest changes brought about yet in Japan by the broad trade talks with Washington that are known as the Structural Impediments Initiative. 
 Most important, the rules attack a cornerstone of the "keiretsu" system, in which companies hold each other's stock to cement a business relationship. The new rules say that such a stockholding is fine -- but that it cannot be used to block a company from doing business with a competitor of the stockholder.
 
'Suggested Retail Prices'
 Under the rules, published last week by the Fair Trade Commission after a year of debate, companies operating in Japan are prohibited from enforcing "suggested retail prices," a widespread practce that accounts for the absence of many discount stores here. Companies are also enjoined from acting together to boycott new entrants to a market, a traditional way of keeping new suppliers and competitors out of a field.
Historically, Japanese business has not been regulated by laws but by informal guidance, arising from talks with Government ministries and other enforcement officials. It is generally understood here, for example, that price wars cut everyone's profits; as a result, relatively few companies are willing to break ranks and sell consumer goods at a deeply discounted price.
Japanese newspapers and consumer advocates have embraced the new regulations. "It is time for the F.T.C., which has been criticized -- not only at home but even abroad -- as a watchdog that never bites, to take action," the newspaper Asahi Shimbun said in an editorial on Friday.
In a statement last week, the commission said it was committed to "take vigorous measures" against any violations of the new rules.
 
Businesses Protest
 Perhaps the most controversial element of the new guidelines permits the Fair Trade Commission to order a company to sell its stockholdings in another company "where it is considered necessary to do so to eliminate a violation" of Japan's Antimonopoly Act. The ruling brought an immediate protest from Keidanran, the organization of Japan's biggest businesses, which said it hoped the commission would "use caution" before ordering any companies to divest their holdings in a business partner.
In fact, any such effort is likely to touch off a big political storm. The "keiretsu" relationships are considered by the Japanese to be a key to the country's economic success, and Japanese negotiators have resisted any efforts to break up those relationships. American officials maintain that they are essentially exclusive relationships that put foreign companies at a disadvantage.
 
Returning Unsold Goods
 Most of the new rules deal with the abuse of power by "influential" companies, defined as those with a market share of greater than 10 percent or a position as one of the top three suppliers or dealers in a market.
For example, it prohibits companies from using their "dominant position" to force clients to shun competitive goods, no matter how low the price or how high the quality. It bars manufacturers from preventing their dealers from handling competing lines, or cutting off a dealer that offers discounts on its goods.
It also prevents big retailers from using their "dominant bargaining position" to return unsold goods to suppliers under some circumstances. Because most companies can return their goods in Japan, there are rarely sales to clear out old merchandise.
Retailers are also barred from forcing suppliers to make frequent deliveries in small lots at no extra cost, a practice of many food and convenience stores.
Some of the strictest new rules cover "parallel imports," the importation of goods that are already available in Japan. Many luxury goods makers have been attempting to send their goods here, if they can find a distributor. Often, the Japanese companies maintain that the imported goods are fakes. Or they contend that the goods cannot be fixed in Japan.
The rules say no Japanese company can assert that parallel imports are fake in order to dissuade dealers from carrying them.
The commission said it would set up a "prior consultation" system to allow companies to seek a ruling about the legality of their pending decisions. The consultation results will be published, the commission said, adding that it would also establish a "complain section" for foreign companies.

HEADLINE: At Tourist's Burial, Grief, Hope and a Call for Justice

DATELINE: MANILA, July 14

 BODY:
It would have been better, said Dr. Renaldo Lantin, if his daughter had never gone to America.
"The Philippines is written about as a violent country where killings are common," he said. "But Rhona would have been safer here." 
 Today, relatives and friends buried Rhona Lantin, a 26-year-old tourist from Maryland who was killed in Manhattan on July 4 by a stray bullet as she searched with friends for a restaurant in Chinatown.
Those close to her remembered her as smart and caring, but they said there was a hardness to her, too,
Ms. Lantin was paradox, said her mother, Rhoda. "She has a collection of dolls and stamps but, at the same time, she was a sharpshooter, a champion in rifle-shooting competitions."
 
'She Likes to Be Independent'
 She also had her own mind. She was born in Ames, Iowa, where her parents were pursuing post-graduate studies at the Iowa State University: her father in agriculture, her mother in chemistry. After two years, they brought her back to the Philippines, where she spent most of her life.
But in 1987, she accompanied her grandfather to the United States on a vacation and decided to stay and do graduate work, her mother said. "She likes to be independent," said Mrs. Lantin.
Since Friday, Ms. Lantin's body had been kept for viewing at her family's residence in Los Banos, Laguna province, about 40 miles from Manila. Hanging on the wall of the living room were photographs of her at various stages in her life, from when she was a chubby baby up to her years as graduate student.
At the funeral, the mourners wore white instead of black, signifying purity and hope in life after death.
 
'Let Justice Be Done'
 One fierce hope is that the killer -- who the police believe fired the fatal shot during a gang dispute in Chinatown -- is captured.
"Let justice be done," said Rico Carpio, an uncle of Ms. Lantin. "We hope there is meaning to her death."
"It is a waste," lamented Dr. Jun Custodio, a former college professor of Ms. Lantin's. "I always remember her to be brainy in class and active in school organizations."
The mourners talked repeatedly of Ms. Lantin's intelligence. While in elementary and high school, she was always near the top of her class. In 1986, she graduated magna cum laude from the University of the Philippines in Los Banos. She had a bachelor's degree in agricultural business, and at the time of her death, was completing her master's in agricultural economics at the University of Maryland.
 
'But Today, We Give Her Up'
 In a Mass before the burial, Dr. Lantin held back his tears. "Twenty-six years ago, we had a jewel," he said. "Rhona was full of life. She made a big difference in our lives. But today, we give her up in human form."
Ms. Lantin was to marry 29-year-old Patrick Canning next year. Mr. Canning, also a graduate student at the University of Maryland, attended the funeral.
In a letter to the Lantin family, which was distributed to friends, Mr. Canning's parents, Sean and Evelyn, wrote: "We have often said how lucky Pat was to have such a beautiful bride-to-be. And now -- this senseless violence, this crushing loss!"

HEADLINE: Near Gang Turf, Theater Features Peace

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, July 14

 BODY:
The homeboys came, but they mostly left their colors at home and "dressed down," as they say in the 'hood, to see "Boyz N the Hood."
While sporadic violence on Friday night caused eight movie theaters elsewhere in Southern California and the nation to cancel showings of the film, there was no trouble where many had expected it to be the worst, at the Baldwin Hills Theater, which lies at the edge of the gang-torn South Central Los Angeles neighborhood where John Singleton's drama of growing up in the ghetto was set. 
 All weekend, long orderly lines of young black people waited to get into the theater, then quietly absorbed its message of the value of family, school and hope.
That there were no shootings or fights was testimony to two things: the hidden strengths of a community that is perceived mostly through news reports of gang violence, and the stern, fatherly management of Lance E. Drummond, a Harlem-born businessman who is chairman of the company that owns the theater.
 
A Speech to the Audience
 As at many theaters, extra security guards were hired to insure against misbehavior. Before the Saturday night showing, the 60-year-old Mr. Drummond mounted the stage of the 420-seat house, apologized for the tight security and told the audience: "Many people thought we should not show this movie. But I saw it and I felt the community needs to see it. It shows the good and bad. It also shows what is necessary. Look at this movie. I think you'll get something out of it."
The audience watched the film in rapt silence. Afterwards, many pronounced it the most realistic and positive portrait they had ever seen of South Central Los Angeles, which has been battling the ravages of gang terrorism, crack cocaine addiction, alcoholism and broken families. "It's a very positive movie," said Mashia McGraw, a receptionist. "It sends a message out to all black people. Everybody should come and watch it."
The film, written and directed by the 23-year-old Mr. Singleton, tells the story of a young man's passage to manhood in this tough setting. It preaches against gang violence, cocaine use and teen-age pregnancy, and stresses the importance of having a strong father and getting an education. Though it has bloody scenes of gang shootings, it is not a film about gangs.
Clashes among actual gang members left at least 33 people wounded and one dead when the film opened Friday at 829 screens around the nation. The film was expected to gross about $9.2 million for the weekend, said Columbia Pictures, the film's distributor.
Mr. Singleton complained Saturday in an interview with the Cable News Network that the news media were "lying in wait" for violence.
If they were lying in wait at Baldwin Hills, they were disappointed. The three-screen complex lies about 10 miles south of downtown Los Angeles, in a largely middle-class black neighborhood in which Mr. Singleton lives. It is about two miles from the heart of the toughest gang-dominated areas. After the film ended Saturday night, a band of Bloods in red caps and loose-fitting jeans strolled past the theater in their characteristic slouching walk, under the watchful eyes of the police.
 
'Sensitive to Our Patrons'
 The theater complex is owned by the Economic Resources Corporation, a not-for-profit company based in Lynwood, Calif., that invests in minority ventures. It calls Baldwin Hills the only black-owned first-run theater in the United States. The theater, immaculate, employs local teen-agers, who sell popcorn while neatly dressed in white shirts and bow ties. Outside, celebrities like Louis Gossett Jr., Billy Dee Williams and Marvin Gaye have put their hand prints in the cement sidewalk, just as movie stars have at the historic Mann's Chinese Theater in Hollywood.
The reason that violence occurred at white-run theaters and not at Baldwin Hills, said its general manager, Nelson Bennett, was that the theater knew and respected the community while other theaters tended to treat young blacks with fear and contempt. "We are just trying to be sensitive to our patrons," he said. "If you come from the perception of extreme, this translates into the audience's being set up for trouble."
Mr. Drummond said: "We are not going to allow what happens in other parts of the city. We are not turning this theater over to anyone. We live in this community. We hire the local kids. Maybe the gangs respect this. They walk in here and take off their hats. This is neutral territory."
Nevertheless, a certain amount of tension surrounded the Saturday night screening. Security men scrutinized the line to keep apart members of Crips and Bloods gangs. Few of them flaunted the blue of the Crips or the red of the Bloods, but they were there. One man wearing a fire-red turban that identified him as a Blood was asked to remove it at the door. "You behave yourself, now," Mr. Drummond admonished the man, who did.
Afterwards, Dana Bell, an 18-year-old high school senior who said she lived amid the nightly killing seen in the film, said the film gave a true expression to the way many people in her community felt. She was also pleased, she said, that it was directed by a black man who grew up nearby.
To Harmon Spruill, a young black man who recently graduated from California State University at Los Angeles and who supervises youth programs in a local park nearby, the film's virtue was that it "showed attitudes of many people who continue to live in South Central" and portrayed them, for all their troubles and failings, as feeling, intelligent human beings. "This was not entertainment," he said. "This was reality."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Many people thought we should not show this movie," said Lance E. Drummond, a Harlem-born businessman and owner of the Baldwin Hills Theater, which lies at the edge of the gang-torn Los Angeles neighborhood where the film "Boyz N the Hood" was set. "But I saw it and I felt the community needs to see it." (George Brich for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Detroit Abuzz: Who After Iacocca?

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, July 14

 BODY:
In an industry where strong executive rule is a matter of course, Lee A. Iacocca defined authority with such force that his persona and that of the Chrysler Corporation are virtually indistinguishable.
Now, with Chrysler nearing a financial crisis and Mr. Iacocca almost two years past normal retirement age, Chrysler directors are pressing Mr. Iacocca to get on with a plan for succession that will ease the jolt of his eventual departure and prepare new leaders for Chrysler's dicey future. 
 Mr. Iacocca, who will be 67 years old in October, has alternately portrayed himself in recent months as a lion in winter who is weary of the automotive wars and as Charlie Hustle, determined to whip Chrysler into shape -- possibly so it could be sold to a bigger, stronger auto maker. Asked who is being groomed to succeed him, he adopts a third persona: the Artful Dodger.
From interviews with company officers and associates who speak on condition of anonymity, it appears Mr. Iacocca is reluctant to designate either Robert A. Lutz, Chrysler's president, or Robert S. Miller Jr., its vice chairman, as his heir. Instead, he seems to be prospecting for someone whose stature and forcefulness he considers equal to his own. It is not clear, however, whether Mr. Iacocca will judge anyone as meeting that standard.
Mr. Iacocca may be ambivalent about giving up power. When he was approached to fill the seat of Senator John Heinz of Pennsylvania, who was killed in a plane crash, Mr. Iacocca declined, implying that it was too late to enter a new line of work and saying, "It is no secret I'm nearing the end of my automotive career."
But several executives who have left Chrysler in the last three years are convinced he will never leave voluntarily, especially since the board last year awarded him a lucrative contract permitting him to stay as long as he likes. The company has no mandatory retirement age, although most executives do not stay beyond 65.
One executive who had doubts about Mr. Iacocca's departure schedule was the former vice chairman, Gerald Greenwald. Mr. Greenwald was Mr. Iacocca's heir apparent until May 1990, when the unions representing workers at the UAL Corporation paid him $9 million to spearhead an effort, ultimately unsuccessful, to buy the company, which owns United Airlines. Mr. Greenwald subsequently went to work for Dillon, Read & Company, the Wall Street investment house.
 
Heroes Have Trouble Leaving
Leaders of heroic proportions, like Mr. Iacocca, appear infrequently in corporate America. They leave a mark on companies, industries and the American scene, but quite often they cannot surrender leadership gracefully. Past examples include Dr. Armand Hammer of Occidental Petroleum, William S. Paley of CBS, and Edwin Land of Polaroid.
"It's very easy for some of these individuals to believe in their own indispensability," said Jeffrey Sonnenfeld, professor of management at Emory University. "They have made a difference, and without their companies they feel there is an abyss of insignificance. A violinist can do many things after leaving an orchestra, but a conductor only has the group."
The uncertainty about Chrysler's survival and who will lead it has set Detroit's gossip mills buzzing. Like Washington, Detroit is a city of pecking orders and ambition, and periodically it becomes a stage for feudal power struggles. In recent weeks, newspapers have published the names of various G.M. and Ford executives rumored to be potential Chrysler chairmen. The men, through spokesmen, deny that they have been approached by Chrysler.
The Wall Street Journal last week published a story, so far unconfirmed, saying that Mr. Iacocca used the former chairman of the Ford Motor Company, Donald E. Petersen, as an intermediary last winter to approach Ford about a merger. The Detroit newspapers then reported, quoting anonymous Ford sources, that Felix G. Rohatyn, a general partner at Lazard Freres & Company was the go-between.
Mr. Rohatyn said the report was rubbish. He did say, though, that he was familiar with Chrysler's situation because he represented Fiat, the Italian auto-making giant, last year in talks with Chrysler aimed at merging the two companies.
Chrysler's president, Mr. Lutz, a 59-year-old cigar-smoking former Marine fighter pilot, makes no secret of his wish to replace Mr. Iacocca. He is known to strongly disagree with Mr. Iacocca's attempts to sell Chrysler or merge it with another auto maker, and he believes Chrysler's new Jeep and car models scheduled to debut next year, will put the company on the road to financial health.
Now, after failing to find buyers for various assets, Chrysler is reported to be mulling a common stock offering to raise as much as $500 million. The new shares would dilute current holdings, probably causing a drop in price to below Friday's close of $14.625 on the Big Board -- a price that itself is well down from the $29.625 range at which Chrysler's shares traded in January 1989. A dilution would mean that major stockholders, including Mr. Iacocca, would lose millions.
But Chrysler may be running out of options. Its low credit ratings effectively preclude borrowing in public debt markets. Banks have granted the company a $1.7 billion credit line but will attach plants and machines as collateral if Chrysler uses the credit.
Starting this month, auto makers have little revenue because they are changing tools for the 1992 model year and do not produce many vehicles. Some analysts speculate Chrysler could be pressed for cash by the end of the fiscal quarter in September.
 
Dissent Among the Designers
 Many Chrysler executives, engineers and stylists complain that many of the company's car and truck models have sold poorly in recent years because of changes and delays ordered by Mr. Iacocca. The designers, in particular, roll their eyes when describing how Mr. Iacocca, with a wave of his cigar, has forced them to submit long, boxy designs and plenty of chrome, when rounder, cleaner models were clearly winning customers.
While diplomatically declining to apportion blame, Mr. Lutz nevertheless has begun to exercise more authority and impose his own tastes on future Chrysler models, leading many engineering and styling executives to assume that he would soon take command. He has also been reorganizing departments and appointing loyalists to positions of influence, notably Francois Castaing, who is now vice president for engineering.
Chrysler's vice chairman, Mr. Miller, a financial specialist, is seen as a less likely candidate because at age 53 he is younger and does not have much nuts-and-bolts knowledge of vehicle development, production and marketing.
Chrysler spokesmen, fearful of arousing Mr. Iacocca's ire by having quotes attributed to them, nevertheless acknowledge that Mr. Lutz's differences in taste and style, complicated by his ambition for power, have led to some loud and nasty confrontations between the two men.
"You would expect that from two people with strong personalities," one said.
About four months ago Mr. Lutz and Mr. Iacocca -- who typically does not socialize with subordinates -- were spotted dining together in a suburban Detroit restaurant. During the meal Mr. Iacocca was heard loudly criticizing Mr. Lutz's job performance. By the next day the story was making the rounds at the company's Highland Park headquarters.
Some Iacocca loyalists believe that if Mr. Lutz becomes chairman he would brand his predecessor the cause of Chrysler's troubles and tarnish Mr. Iacocca's place in history as the man who dusted himself off after being dismissed as president of Ford in 1978 and only a few years later helped Chrysler avert bankruptcy.
Mr. Iacocca "might be willing to give the chief executive's job to someone who would allow him to keep his perks and stay on in an advisory capacity," one former Chrysler executive said, "but not to someone who wants to build his career on Lee's ashes."

Mr. Lutz makes no secret of his wish to replace Mr. Iacocca, who is past retirement age, but Mr. Iacocca appears reluctant to designate him. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Rising Costs Force Towns to Share Various Services

SERIES: Shared Solutions Governments Cooperating/First of two articles.

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO

 BODY:
Crusading to hold down costs, local governments across the New York metropolitan region are beginning to share everything from police forces to Latin teachers.
In Rockland County, N.Y., the village of Nyack dissolved its 23-member police force this year and now pays to be patrolled by officers from nearby Orangetown and Clarkstown. 
 On Long Island, the towns of Babylon and Islip are pooling their garbage to help make more efficient use of incinerator plants in their communities.
In Bergen County, N.J., two school boards have agreed to the joint hiring of a private food-service company -- a decision that will save the Northern Highlands Regional High School and the Allendale School District more than $40,000 each.
And in Westchester County a two-way video monitor is sending a teacher's lessons in advanced Latin from Ossining into a high school classroom in Pleasantville, while an introductory Latin class is beamed back to Ossining.
The consolidation of services comes as cuts in state aid and rising costs have placed many communities in a financial chokehold. At the same time local officials are reluctant to find a solution in property-tax increases, because many residents complain that they can scarcely afford their taxes now.
 
Breaking the Status Quo
 While municipalities in the New York region have increasingly looked to merge services, such arrangements are more difficult in other parts of the country, where towns and cities are often farther apart. But some counties, like Duval and Hendry in Florida, have agreed to share things like landfills with their neighbors.
At all levels of government in the New York region, officials who have not set in motion the sharing of services are at least thinking about it, even though the idea of giving up local control, and the jobs and prestige that go with that, has long been anathema.
"One of the good effects of a fiscal crisis is that you break the iron grasp of the status quo," said Dr. John Shannon, a senior fellow at the Urban Institute, a research organization in Washington. "You see it working out very well in the Northeast, where things are happening both to save money and improve efficiency."
In New Jersey, the State Assembly has passed a bill aimed at taking the pulse of voters on whether they are interested in regionalization. The measure, now before the State Senate, would give residents in towns with fewer than 10,000 people the right to vote this November on creating a committee to talk with neighboring towns about sharing services.
"I want to start a grass-roots revolution," said the bill's chief sponsor, John Paul Doyle, the Deputy Assembly Speaker and a Democrat worried about taxpayer backlash in legislative elections this fall.
But it is a revolution that is meeting considerable resistance in some quarters.
"In the cause of efficiency, are you going to wipe out this wonderful euphemism of local control?" said Dr. George Sternlieb, the former director of the Center for Urban Policy Research at Rutgers University. "Over my dead body. The real measure of local control is who sits on the money and who sits on the jobs."
Barry Skokowski, deputy commissioner of the New Jersey Department of Community Affairs and the director of the Division of Local Government Services, said: "The political reality is that someone is going to lose a job somewhere, and that makes consolidation difficult. But the majority of our towns have fewer than 5,000 people. It lends itself to at least joint services, if not full consolidation."
 
Battling 'Suburban Apartheid'
 There seems to be a growing awareness that the economic arguments for joining forces may be more compelling than the arguments for going it alone, or what Dr. Shannon of the Urban Institute describes as a state of "suburban apartheid."
Jeff Morosoff, executive assistant to the Town Supervisor in Babylon, said: "The problem for many years was that towns never looked beyond their borders. But there is such a cost to isolating yourself."
The cost to Babylon in the matter of garbage disposal was a penalty assessed by the incinerator plant in its community because the town could not meet its guarantee of 750 tons of refuse a day. On the other hand, Islip, an adjacent town, had 900 tons of garbage a day, but the incinerator it used could handle but 600 tons. Islip had to ship its excess out of town at high cost. Solution: Islip now sends some of its excess to Babylon and saves.
The layers of government are so dense in the suburbs of New York City that it is not unusual to have an incorporated village lying within an incorporated town, each with its own administration, police force, highway department and local court.
In New York State, for instance, there are some 10,000 separate governmental entities, from counties, cities, towns and villages to fire, water and sewer districts. "There's a big tax revolt, and people perceive that they may be paying taxes to six or seven layers of local government," said Secretary of State Gail S. Shaffer, who heads a Commission on Consolidation in Local Government recently established by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.
On the public education front, because of declining enrollment over the last 20 years, many school districts now have fewer than 2,500 students, making it difficult to pay for advanced courses and electives. In New Jersey, where Gov. Jim Florio has been pushing for regionalization, 43 high schools have fewer than 500 students.
"There's small, and then there's too small," said Tom Corcoran, the Governor's policy adviser for education. "When you start to drop below a certain level, then either your costs go up or the range of services you can offer is reduced -- or both. And that's not good."
 
Small Districts, High Costs
 A study released last month by a Princeton research group buttressed that argument. The Public Affairs Research Institute said that smaller New Jersey school districts tended to have disproportionately high administrative payrolls, based on a study of 460 of the state's roughly 600 school districts.
The research group said that all but five of the 128 districts that spent less than 3 percent of their 1988-89 budgets on administration salaries served more than 1,000 students. All but four of the 55 districts that spent 6 percent or more had fewer than 700 pupils.
In Connecticut, the Governor's Commission on Quality and Integrated Education came out last December in favor of regionalizing school districts to cut costs and achieve a measure of racial and socio-economic integration.
Education Commissioner Gerald N. Tirozzi, who says Connecticut can no longer afford to operate 166 school districts, will soon ask the state to create "some carrots and sticks" to encourage mergers. "If you were to consolidate school districts," he said, "you could save a small fortune."
"It isn't going to be an easy sell," said Mr. Tirozzi, "because home rule is so important in New England. But people are so concerned about the economic plight of the state that you might be able to put certain recommendations on the table that weren't palatable a few years ago."
 
Consolidation Catching On
 In Westchester County, a new report called "Government at the Crossroads," published by a quasi-public corporation called Westchester 2000, proposed the creation of a central school board in the county to oversee the existing 56 districts. It also floated the idea of combining some of the county's smaller towns and villages.
"The scary part is that the reaction has been unanimously positive," said Dr. Sal J. Prezioso, executive director of Westchester 2000. "Five or seven years ago this thing would never fly. But now, with the recession here and the state and Federal governments washing their hands, municipalities realize they're in trouble."
Still, officials have to be convinced that sharing services will result in savings, and they do not have much recent experience to guide them. It has been 30 years since the last time two municipalities in New Jersey became one -- when Vineland and Landis Township merged. Furthermore only a single merger occurred between two school districts in the last 10 years. And the idea of sharing services has not been actively pursued until now.
The lack of example has stymied officials like Mayor James T. Dowden of Bridgewater, N.J., who met with his counterparts in neighboring Somerville, Branchburg and Raritan to see how they could share services.
Mayor Dowden said his township and the borough of Somerville were ready to undertake a 90-day test to merge their police departments. After receiving cooperation from the county prosecutor's office and the state's Criminal Justice Division, Bridgewater's Council backed down.
 
Results in Advance Asked
 "They wanted financial data up front -- how much is this going to save, what is it going to mean," said Mayor Dowden. "Well, these were questions you could only answer once you did the test."
When two school districts in Westchester County tackled the topic of merging, the plan was derailed by arguments that were both economic and emotional.
"My guess is you might save 3 percent by merging," said Dr. Stanley Toll, the Superintendent of the Ardsley Union Free School District, which considered merging with the district serving the neighboring village of Ardsley. He said the cost of education could be driven up by the need to expand special academic programs in one district to the other and vice versa.
In any case, when the idea of folding the two districts into one was broached two years ago, it whipped up such a fury in Ardsley that a formal study was dropped. "There were no fans of this," Dr. Toll said. "They said they moved to Ardsley and not to Dobbs Ferry or anywhere else. Whether they're right or wrong, they feel we're better."
 
Identity Hard to Surrender
 Liz Jaffe, executive director of the Westchester-Putnam School Boards Association, said: "People like their own identity, and we haven't seen the proof yet economically in terms of where the savings really are. Schools probably aren't going to start merging unless the state mandates it."
From Albany to Trenton to Hartford, state officials say they do not plan to force school districts and towns to consolidate or even to share services. But they do intend to make changes in state statutes and regulations that would at least make it easier for local officials to start the process themselves.
"We're not going to impose some grand design for local government consolidation," said Ms. Shaffer, New York's Secretary of State. "It's obvious that these issues can become emotional and political. We are trying to remove some of the impediments and create some incentives."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Big Gamble on Schwarzkopf Book

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN

 BODY:
While the spending of more than $90 million on Arnold Schwarzenegger's capers in Carolco's new movie, "Terminator 2," strikes many as bold but quite possibly shrewd, the payment of close to $6 million for a mere book with a few hundred pages and a handful of motionless pictures still seems outlandish.
Yet that is what Bantam Books, a subsidiary of Bertelsmann A.G. of Germany, has recently agreed to spend for the world rights to the memoirs of a real-life warrior, Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf. In so doing, it is betting that like Lee A. Iacocca, Donald J. Trump and Brig. Gen. Chuck Yeager the hero of the Persian Gulf war has a story that will sell books in unusual quantities. 
 The celebrity's life story, written with a collaborator, is now such a staple of American life that few big stars or heroes have resisted.
But the recent history of the genre is so checkered that a prediction is hazardous. For every Iacocca book, there is a Ronald Reagan memoir that flops; for every Trump best seller, a Trump sequel that is a disaster.
"Once in a long while, you sell a million hardcover copies of this kind of book, and that causes the entrepreneurial spirit of publishers to rise," said Roger Donald, the publisher of Little, Brown. "But if you don't do it, it's very easy to lose a couple of million dollars."
Although there are many variables that affect a book's profitability, it appears from some publishers' estimates that the Schwarzkopf book will have to sell at least 450,000 copies in hardback and 1.5 million copies in paperback to break even.
Little, Brown bid what Mr. Donald called "a great deal of money" for the Schwarzkopf book, but not enough. Macmillan Inc. bid $1.2 million; Viking Penguin, about $3.2 million, and Random House, $5 million. The very range of these offers reflects the extreme unpredictability of such projects.
The only big house that did not bid was Simon & Schuster, which lost what other publishers estimated as a seven-figure sum on Mr. Reagan's book last year. Having paid an estimated $7 million in 1989 for Mr. Reagan's memoirs, as well as a book of speeches, the house fell victim to the ephemeral whims of Americans.
"When we signed that contract, there was a warm feeling in everyone's hearts for Mr. Reagan, but we did not realize how thin that was," a Simon & Schuster executive said. "Reagan just evaporated, and the nostalgia we hoped would sell the book was not there."
And Charles Leerhsen, who collaborated with Mr. Trump on his calamitous second effort, "Surviving at the Top," said, "The ultimate thing with this kind of book is the public perception of the person at the time it is released."
 
Big Loss for Random House
 Mobbed at a booksellers' convention in June 1990, Mr. Trump was a dubious loser by the time his book came out two months later. His first book, "The Art of the Deal," sold more than a million copies; "Surviving at the Top" sold about a tenth of that. Random House is believed by other publishers to have lost well over $1 million on it.
So could the man that Bantam executives refer to as "the good general" be as vulnerable to an abrupt swing in the public's mood by the fall of 1992, when his book is due to be published?
"When you go into a project like this, you give it a great deal of thought," said Linda Grey, Bantam's publisher. "We would not have pursued it if we felt there could be a turnabout in feeling for the general. Could I be wrong? Of course, I could be."
She added: "I believe America is a country in search of heroes. We've had our problems; we've been told we're no good anymore, that we can't compete with Japan. Well, Schwarzkopf is the antithesis of that. He stands for American know-how, competence, doing a job right. He embodies values, such as the very work ethic this country was founded on, that have enduring popular appeal."
Just how popular the Schwarzkopf book must be to justify its price amounts to a complex equation. But almost all publishers now have computers "to run the numbers."
Feed in an imaginary hardback sales figure, hypothetical foreign rights sales in Japan or even Saudi Arabia, estimated marketing costs, assumed paperback sales and the author's advance, and the computer will flash back the profit or loss.
"The editor can input any assumptions he wants," said Barry Lippmann, Macmillan's publisher. "The only limits are one's ability to fantasize and capacity to delude oneself."
Peter Mayer, the chairman of Penguin U.S.A., added: "This is not like running numbers in a normal business. These are no more than 'guesstimates.' "
 
What the Book Needs to Do
 One leading publisher agreed to do some estimates on the Schwarzkopf book. Imagine the following: a $22.95 hardcover price and a $6.95 paperback price; net sales of 625,000 units in hardback and 1.5 million units in paperback; foreign rights, first serial rights and book-club sales for a total of $2.5 million; an advance paid to Schwarzkopf of $6 million; marketing costs of $750,000, and production costs of $1.44 a book for hardbacks and 51 cents a book for paperbacks.
Then, push a button: Bantam will make a net profit of $1.25 million, or a margin of 8.26 percent, slightly below the minimum of 10 percent that publishers want to earn on a book.
But change a few numbers. Cut the hardback sale to 375,000 from 625,000, the paperback sale to 1.2 million from 1.5 million, the rights sales to $2 million from $2.5 million, and Bantam posts a net loss of $1.3 million.
Of course, nobody has any idea how many copies the Schwarzkopf book will sell. All that is known is that to sell more than 500,000 copies of a nonfiction hardback is very arduous, and more than a million exceptional. But, Ms. Grey said, "we have the experience to reach a very high plateau."
Bantam is indeed renowned as a superb marketer of books and has published two other nonfiction works -- Mr. Iacocca's and General Yeager's -- that sold 2.6 million and 1.1 million in hardback, respectively. If the house can sell more than a million copies with General Schwarzkopf, it will make a killing. "I suspect that the book is probably a pretty smart buy for Bantam," Mr. Donald of Little, Brown said.
 
Advantage of a Film Maker
 But what Bantam cannot do with General Schwarzkopf, apparently, is hedge as effectively as a film maker by selling the product abroad and in other forms like videos and pay television. Carolco, for example, said it had earned back most of its investment on "Terminator 2: Judgment Day" through foreign sales before the movie came out. Even the most generous assessment of Bantam's rights sales would not allow the house to earn back more than half its investment before publication.
"On the movie side, you can spread the risk much more easily, both geographically and through products such as video," said Steven Rattner, a general partner and head of the media department at Lazard Freres & Company. "For books there has not been the same explosion of outlets. The Schwarzkopf deal strikes me as an enormous amount of money."
Bantam is clearly concerned about the general's image over the next year and what it perceives as the need for speed in getting the book out before a Reagan-like fadeout. "The general will work very hard on the book and make only a few selected public appearances," Ms. Grey said.
Marvin Josephson, the general's agent, said General Schwarzkopf "could be doing commercials, endorsements, licenses, but his desire is to keep a low profile."
Ms. Grey has told agents representing writers who may work with the general that the manuscript must be delivered by May 1, 1992 -- leaving just eight months to write it from the general's retirement -- and that it is essential the book be out before the 1992 elections.
Indeed, the book contract is believed to include a clause giving the general a substantial bonus for delivering the book on time.
The autobiography will have to compete against several quick books on General Schwarzkopf, including one by this reporter. But Ms. Grey dismissed the rival books. "People want the general's view," she said. Furthermore, Bantam is obviously betting that those books will no longer be competing for buyers when the general's autobiography appears.
Aside from the money the book earns, Stuart Applebaum, a Bantam vice president, argued that his entire company would benefit from the fact that "Scwhwarzkopf is now a Bantam author." The general's presence at sales conventions and at the American Booksellers Association's annual meeting is expected to provide excitment for all of Bantam's books.
Moreover, even if the book proves not to be worth the amount paid, it should still be a best seller.
Whatever else it is, the Schwarzkopf autobiography is representative of the modern publishing world.
Competition for celebrity names drives up prices. As Mr. Mayer of Penguin U.S.A. observed, "These are massive sums to be spending, and there is no question that the last few years has seen an enormous increase in unearned advances."

SECTION: Section A; Page 10; Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 745 words

HEADLINE: After 4 Years, British Envoy Is Leaving a New South Africa

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAPE TOWN

 BODY:
When Sir Robin Renwick arrived here as the new British ambassador in 1987, his debut coincided with a bleak period of resistance to change in South Africa under former President P. W. Botha.
"What we were seeing at that time," Sir Robin said, "was an attempt to respond to the steam building up inside the caldron by trying to nail the lid down harder and tighter." 
 Four years later, Sir Robin takes a more optimistic leave of South Africa as it repudiates apartheid under President F. W. de Klerk.
"Now the country's facing problems of a completely different nature," said the diplomat, who is to become Britain's Ambassador to Washington next month. "I do think that the underlying situation is fundamentally better in that for the first time in South Africa's history, the possibility has been created of finding a solution to South Africa's problems."
Sir Robin worries less about black nationalists in the African National Congress than about white Marxists tempted to experiment with an ideology rejected elsewhere in Africa and in Eastern Europe. He thinks South Africa can be helped best not through sanctions but through foreign assistance to its democratic organizations.
And he contends that South Africa is lucky to have Nelson Mandela and F. W. de Klerk. Sir Robin described both leaders, whose confidences he earned, as patriots concerned about the dangers ahead, though they confronted pressure from different constituencies.
Sir Robin will not have the chance to watch the outcome. In going to the United States, Sir Robin sets aside an expertise in African affairs acquired during much of his 28-year diplomatic career. He worked on the independence settlements of Zimbabwe and Namibia and has played a quiet intermediary role in South Africa's own transition.
In an interview before his departure, Sir Robin offered some valedictory thoughts. To roll back the tide of political decay and poverty in South Africa, he said, required not just multiparty democracy but also a free-market economy that offered blacks participation through affirmative action.
"Unless you preserve the basic framework of a free economy, then I suspect that we will end up with similar economic difficulties to those that exist in the rest of Africa," he said.
"I think state-directed economies never work anywhere, but they particularly don't work in Africa, where the bureaucracy is not strong enough to administer them effectively," he said. "And I think that of all the spectacular failures of Marxism, the fact is that the most spectacular failures of Marxism anywhere have been in Africa."
Because apartheid had skewed South Africa's economy, it lacked credibility for millions of blacks, and, Sir Robin added, "there is in the liberation movements a deeply ingrained belief in state socialism."
He expressed satisfaction that the African National Congress had muted its talk of nationalizing banks and mines when it came to power.
"I do frankly worry much more about the attitude of the white Communists than I do about the black leaders," Sir Robin said, "because quite a few of the white Communists have learned nothing and forgotten nothing and really believe that all these disasters in Eastern Europe were caused by pilot error, that there was nothing wrong with the design of the plane."
"Well, people who believe that are capable of destroying a few more economies," he said.
Sir Robin has been critical of economic sanctions, but he said he was not doctrinaire about the issue. He credited the arms embargo with getting Pretoria's forces out of Angola, for example.
"What always has worried me has been disinvestment. If you talk to companies who are leaving, almost any company will tell you that in all honesty they don't intend to come back," Sir Robin said.
Sir Robin believed the best way to hasten apartheid's demise was to assist community groups and organizations in South Africa working for democratic change. But he said people could choose their strategies.
South Africa's problems, Sir Robin contended, could only be solved through negotiations between the country's black and white leaders without outside intervention. But the transition should be accelerated, he said, with both sides agreeing upon principles that they wanted in a new constitution.
"If that's done, then I do believe that the transitional problems which are difficult and dangerous do become easier to manage," Sir Robin said.

The Economy
Mutual Benefit Life Insurance has been a conservative and respected insurance company, and as New Jersey officials prepare to seize it today, industry experts predict that the takeover will weaken public confidence in the life-insurance business. [Page A1.] 
 Charitable organizations created by Jimmy Carter received $8 million from the Bank of Credit and Commerce International. Andrew Young, the former U.N. representative, had a consulting arrangement with the bank while he was Mayor of Atlanta. [A1.]
Representatives of 12 states will meet tomorrow to consider adopting California's rules requiring electric vehicles and additional anti-pollution equipment for gasoline-powered vehicles. [D1.]
 
International
Japan has published regulations prohibiting companies from fixing prices, driving out competitors and blocking certain types of imports. [D1.] Through the resignations, suspensions and pay cuts in the stock market upheaval in Japan, there has yet to be a judicial proceeding, hearing or modest attempt to relate the flurry of penalties to a legal statute. News Analysis. [D3.]
Leaders of the seven leading industrial democracies gathered in London for three days of talks. [A5.]
 
Companies
With Chrysler nearing a financial crisis and Lee Iacocca past normal retirement age, directors are pressing the chairman to get on with a plan for succession. [D1.]
Time Warner may be concerned about its debt, but it has not seemed willing to trim a corporate style that appears lavish even by the standards of the entertainment business. [D1.] Time Warner will begin its rights offering today to raise $2.8 billion. [D5.]
Merrill Lynch brokers are starting to use a computerized stock-ordering system that could change the business. [D2.]
Telesphere customers are considering an attempt to force the sixth-largest long-distance company into bankruptcy. [D4.]
Hadson proposed that it be reunited with Hadson Energy Resources, an oil and gas producer it had spun off. [D5.]
 
Media Business
By spending close to $6 million for the memoirs of General Schwarzkopf, Bantam is betting that the hero of the Persian Gulf war has a story that will sell books in unusual quantities. [D1.]
HBO viewers are tuning in a sitcom and another regular series in unprecedented numbers. [D8.]
The buying and selling of newspapers has all but stopped, mostly because prospective buyers have refused to pay the premium prices still being asked. Alex S. Jones: Press Notes. [D8.]
Anarchy reigned at another ad awards show, with executives storming the stage -- this time in a parody. Advertising. [D9.]
 
Today's Columns
Comic books are booming, and the owner of Mar<cc16.3vel Comics is trying to sell a minority stake in Spider-Man, the Incredible Hulk, Captain Amer<cc14.9ica and all its other Superheroes to the public. Investors seem to be lining up, and the sale will enable Ronald Perelman, who has controlled Marvel since early 1989, to take out as much as five times the $10.5 million he invested in the company, while still maintaining firm control. Marvel's rapid growth is being used as a key selling point in pricing the company's shares. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D1.]
