HEADLINE: Seized Bank Helped Andrew Young Firm And Carter Charities

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, July 14

 BODY:
Charitable organizations created by former President Jimmy Carter received $8 million in contributions from the failed Bank of Credit and Commerce International, and Andrew Young, the Carter Administration's representative at the United Nations, had a consulting arrangement with the bank while he was the Mayor of Atlanta.
The $8 million in donations spanned several years and were given to Mr. Carter's Global 2000 Inc., which the former President organized to help improve health and agriculture in developing countries. The bank also donated $500,000 toward the construction of the multimillion-dollar Carter Center of Emory University in Atlanta, which includes the Jimmy Carter Library and operates health, agricultural and political mediation programs around the world.
 
'No Strings Attached'
 As investigators sift through the complex history of the bank, which was seized by regulators in seven countries earlier this month, there has been no suggestion that Mr. Carter performed any services for the institution. But the details of the charitable gifts and the arrangement with Mr. Young demonstrate the way in which the bank created ties with American public officials to help it do business. 
 In the first details provided by the Carter Center, Carrie Harmon, a spokeswoman, confirmed the contributions and said today that "all of our contributions are straight, no-strings-attached contributions." She said none of the money, some of which was contributed as recently as a year ago, went to Mr. Carter, who does not draw a salary from the center.
"With everything we know today, we would not be likely to solicit funds from them in the future," Ms. Harmon said. She did not elaborate, but the bank pleaded guilty in Florida last year to charges of money-laundering for drug activities. When regulators seized the bank , the Bank of England accused it of engaging in extensive fraud.
The Central Intelligence Agency had used the bank for intelligence operations before it was seized and the bank was involved in secret arms deals, including the covert sale of American arms to Iran in 1986, according to Government and bank documents and former Government and bank officials.
At its peak, the bank had offices in more than 70 countries. It is currently under criminal investigation in four American cities and has been involved in several foreign political and business scandals.
Mr. Young had a longtime personal and business relationship with the founder of the bank, Aga Hassan Abedi, a financier in Pakistan who later left the country. The relationship lasted for nearly a decade, including years when Mr. Young served as Atlanta's Mayor. The bank provided a credit line to Mr. Young's small Washington-based trading firm, and Mr. Young introduced the bank to third world leaders in exchange for a $50,000 annual retainer paid to his firm, Andrew Young Associates Inc.
All these activities were legal under the ethics laws governing Atlanta's elected officials.
In an interview on Friday, Mr. Young defended the bank and Mr. Abedi, who founded the bank with Middle East money. Mr. Young said he was convinced of Mr. Abedi's personal honesty and said the bank's far-flung financial empire seemed to reflect not only Mr. Abedi's commitment to making money but to contributing to the communities in which the bank operated.
 
 Plane Provided for Tour

"I have never been self-conscious about my relationship with B.C.C.I. and Mr. Abedi," Mr. Young said. "I saw them as a third world bank. They were very free-market oriented, but non-European. Consequently they had the trust of a lot of people who saw themselves as socialists or as victims of neocolonialist exploitation."
"Every good idea that Carter or I had, Abedi was willing to finance," Mr. Young added. "He was never really giving us cash, but he was encouraging the local banks that he controlled to seed our projects. So I am reluctant to see B.C.C.I. as this sinister operation that everybody is making it out to be."
In 1986, Mr. Young recalled, Mr. Abedi provided his personal Boeing 727 for Mr. Carter and Mr. Young to take a whirlwind, five-day tour of five African countries. The trip was an attempt by Mr. Carter to convince the leaders of those countries to allow the Global 2000 project to set up agricultural experiments using specially developed drought-resistant seeds.
Mr. Young said the B.C.C.I.-owned banks in each of the five countries was providing the money to buy the seeds and fertilizer for the experiments.
On another occasion, Mr. Young said, B.C.C.I. donated the money that allowed a number of African government leaders to attend a trade conference in Tunisia that was sponsored by Young Ideas, a non-profit organization created by Mr. Young after he left the U.N. post.
 
 Effort to Eradicate Disease

One Carter Center program that caught Mr. Abedi's eye was Global 2000's efforts to eradicate dracunculiasis, or Guinea worm disease, which infects about 10 million people in Africa, India and Pakistan, Mr. Abedi's homeland. The disease can be prevented by providing clean drinking water. Mr. Carter, who serves as chairman of Global 2000, began an eradication program in Pakistan in 1986 and was later involved in organizing efforts in Ghana, Nigeria and Uganda. The bank's contributions began in 1987.
Mr. Young's third world contacts come from his days as the United States representative at the United Nations. He stressed the building of trade and commercial bridges to Africa, Asia and Latin America during his two terms as Atlanta's Mayor in the 1980's. Mr. Young said that at a time when many in the West were "caricaturing third world" leaders like Michael Manley of Jamaica and Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe, Mr. Abedi and his bank took them seriously and courted them.
"The way to get these countries involved in a free-market economy was through trade and investment and in that sense B.C.C.I. was practicing, to my knowledge, everything that I believed in," said Mr. Young. "I can't defend all of their banking practices, but I can certainly defend Mr. Abedi."
 
Contacts in Third World Nations

At various times in the last 10 years Mr. Young, through his modest foreign trade and consulting business, was a consultant to the bank, providing it with contacts in more than a dozen third world countries. including Nicaragua, Guatemala, Zambia and Tanzania. He said these contacts included businesses and government officials.
"The arrangement with B.C.C.I. didn't trouble me because I never got any of the money per se," Mr. Young said. He added that his firm acted as a middleman in some modest trading of typewriters and oil, for example, but it "was started largely to keep employed many of the people who were involved with me at the U.N. He formed the business in 1979, the year he resigned from the post at the U.N. after a controversy erupted when he privately opened talks with the Palestine Liberation Organization.
Stoney Cooks, Mr. Young's longtime business and political associate who ran the now dormant firm's daily affairs, said that in 1980 it obtained a line of credit from the National Bank of Georgia, which at the time was controlled by Gaith Pharaon, a major B.C.C.I. shareholder and an associate of Mr. Abedi's. Mr. Pharaon had bought the National Bank of Georgia from Bert Lance, President Carter's one-time budget director. In 1981, the line was transferred to B.C.C.I.
 
Began With Five or Six Clients

Mr. Young's business began with five or six clients, Mr. Cooks said. "There was never a shortage of money to pay the loans but as the Mayor became more engaged in being Mayor, he was not available as much," Mr. Cooks added.
"Mr. Abedi thought we could be of assistance to the bank as it sought to expand around the world," said Mr. Cooks. "We introduced them to banking opportunities and we had a good positive feeling about them."
On one occasion, Mr. Young said a Nigerian businessman seeking a loan from a British bank to import American-made farming equipment to his country was denied the loan unless he agreed to purchase British-made equipment. The Nigerian approached Mr. Young, who referred him to the bank and the loan was arranged. Mr. Young said he did not receive any fees for this.
 
Retainer of $50,000 a Year

Of the $50,000 annual retainer, was Mr. Cooks said the money was generally taken in the form of reductions in outstanding loans or travel expenses. In 1985, Mr. Cooks said he submitted expenses on trips he and Mr. Young had made on the bank's behalf at the direction of Swaleh Naqvi, a top official of the bank and a longtime aide of Mr. Abedi's. The expenses slightly exceeded the amount Mr. Young's company owed the bank, Mr. Cooks said. So, rather than receiving the retainer, the travel expenses were used to reduce the balance on the credit line,
At its peak, the bank's credit to the firm was $175,000, said Mr. Cooks, who was its vice president. The interest rate was the prime rate, plus one percentage point, Mr. Cooks recalled. The company regularly paid interest on the outstanding balance out of money generated by the firm's trade deals or fees from Mr. Young's speaking engagements. The credit line has not been used since 1986, Mr. Cooks said.
Although the post of Mayor of Atlanta is a full-time job paying $100,000 annually, no law bars the Mayor, City Council members and even some appointed officials from having private businesses. Those concerns are, however, barred from dealing with the city. Each year, officials must disclose the total income derived from those outside businesses. Exact figures were unavaliable, but both Mr. Young and Mr. Cooks indicated that Andrew Young Associates never was a big money-maker.
 
Served Two Terms

Mr. Young, elected Mayor in 1981, served two terms. During his first term, Mr. Young was criticized because of his extensive foreign travel and absences, though it was not a major issue and Mr. Young was easily re-elected.
As Mayor, he often traveled as an invited guest of foreign governments, for speaking engagements or as a city booster for the local Chamber of Commerce. In most cases, said Carol Muldawer, a former aide to Mr. Young, city money was not used to pay for such trips.
Ms. Muldawer said that by the time Mr. Young reached his second term many Atlantans had begun to see a real benefit for the city. Foreigners financed new construction, more foreign dignitaries visited the city and last year Atlanta was chosen as the site for the 1996 summer Olympic Games.
Mr. Young, who is trained as a Congregationalist minister and was former lieutenant of the Rev. Martin Luther King's and his non-violent civil rights movement, said that he always saw a highly spiritual side to Mr. Abedi's endeavors.
This gave him a different perspective on Mr. Abedi and the bank. "I think white folks in Britain and other places didn't like these third world people having this much money and power," he said, "and I always felt that they were getting so big and powerful that they would come under attack."

HEADLINE: In Ruling, Hope for Students Deceived by Schools

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHARLESTON, W.Va., July 14

 BODY:
No one has challenged George Leeson's claim that Northeastern Business College here lured him with false promises, failed to give him an education and left him with nearly $3,000 in student loans. A state court has called the defunct school's behavior "unconscionable."
The question is who should pay. Mr. Leeson says not him, and a sympathetic ruling by a Federal judge, permitting the suit to go forward, has opened the door to similar arguments across the country. 
 Such rulings could relieve former trade-school students like Mr. Leeson, who are often guileless poor people seeking to better themselves, of tens of millions of dollars of debt. They could also hand large losses to banks and other lenders. And facing such losses, lenders may become unwilling to do business with unscrupulous schools, bringing significant changes to the nation's troubled student loan program.
Under consumer law in many states, banks can be held liable if they act as business partners to fraudulent companies. Banks say that the Federal student loan laws pre-empt the state laws and that the Federal law protects the banks. Ruling in Mr. Leeson's case in June, Judge John T. Copenhaver Jr. of Federal District Court rejected the banks' arguments, saying students could sue under state or Federal law.
 
Moral Victory, Some Say

 Advocates for students are hailing the decision as not only a potential financial victory but also a moral one.
"The Government has fostered this fraud on a wholesale level because it won't police the system," said Dan Hedges, a Charleston legal services lawyer who filed the suit on behalf of Mr. Leeson and about 2,000 other former Northeastern Business College students. "And the banks have been getting rich in the process."
Similar suits are pending in California, Kentucky, New Jersey and Texas, and lawyers expect more to follow. In at least one of those cases, though not in West Virginia, students are also suing the private accrediting agency for approving the school.
The ruling in Mr. Leeson's case comes amid increasing concern about soaring default rates in the student loan program and unscrupulous practices at many private, profit-seeking trade schools. In May, the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, led by Senator Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia, found "fraud and abuse at every level" of the program, with problems concentrated "particularly in the area of proprietary schools."
The Nunn report found that such schools sometimes recruit from welfare offices promising lucrative careers in areas like cosmetology and truck driving. The report said many of the schools were more interested in collecting financial aid checks than in education and called the oversight of the schools by the Federal Department of Education "dismal."
Congress is rewriting the student loan program this year. The Government backs about $12.4 billion a year in student loans. Since 1983, the cost of defaults has more than tripled, to almost $2 billion a year.
 
Exercise in Finger Pointing

As the unpaid bills have risen, so has the fervor of what amounts to an exercise in finger pointing, both in court and beyond.
The Northeastern students here argue that the banks collaborated in a fraudulent business by winking at the school's abuses while reaping large profits in interest from the guaranteed loans. In addition, they say a guarantee agency, the middleman group between the Government and the banks, reaped lucrative servicing fees while failing to supervise the banks or the schools. And they say the Government supervised no one.
"None of them don't care a diddly-darn about us," said Mr. Leeson, who had hoped to become a police officer but now lives on a $613 monthly disability check. "They just want their money."
The lenders -- banks and guarantee agencies -- say it is unfair to hold them liable since no one ever said they were supposed to monitor the schools' quality. That, they say, is the responsibility of the Federal Education Department, state licensing agencies and private accreditation groups. The Nunn investigation faulted all three legs of the triad, saying they failed to insure educational quality.
The lenders say the only reason they lent the money to impoverished students, who are usually considered bad credit risks, is that the Government backed the loans. "To turn around and throw it back after the fact is unfair to the lenders," said Ian Macoy of the American Bankers Association.
In court, the Education Department is supporting legal arguments that would hold the banks liable. But it has also proposing regulations that would protect the banks from such liability. Repeated calls to department officials last week went unanswered.
 
Closed and Without Assets

As is typical, no one can collect from the school itself, since it is closed and without assets.
Mr. Leeson, now 44 years old, brought to the school a lifelong desire to be a police officer. Before dropping out of high school, he served in a cadet corps that allowed him to wear a badge and carry a club, but he was turned down by the force for being too short.
He said the height restriction was relaxed in the years he spent driving trucks and working in junkyards. In 1986, unemployed and recently divorced, Mr. Leeson responded to the school's advertisement for a law-enforcement course that he said virtually promised a job as an officer.
"I fell for it hook, line and sinker," he said.
Mr. Leeson said the school had promised him expense money, a weapons permit and a chance to ride in police cars. Instead, his teachers kept quitting and the course did not even include books. Then, about halfway through the yearlong course, he arrived at school one night to find it padlocked for good. All he had to show for his efforts was his unpaid student loan.
"They picked on the poor people is what they done," Mr. Leeson said. "They didn't go out there and get no highfalutin' people."
He argues that the lenders were not innocent bystanders but rather functioned as the school's business partners.
The school recruited the students, processed the paperwork and received the mailed checks directly from the banks. Mr. Leeson, like many others, never set foot in a bank and says he was not aware until partway through the course that he would be asked to repay the money.
No suits are being filed in cases where students approached a bank on their own, seeking a loan.
The banks argue that such partnership theories are being manufactured in court and were never spelled out in many years of practice or in Government regulations.
 
The Banks' Argument

"Nobody's ever told us that before," said K. Paul Davis, a lawyer for the Charleston National Bank and several others that did business with Northeastern. "The rules say if the school's on the list, you can make loans. It's that simple.
Asked whether the banks knew about the school's practices and turned its head, Mr. Davis said, "I shouldn't comment on that."
He added: "How do I know if a school out in the suburbs is providing education or not? I may hear rumors."
The ruling by Judge Copenhaver, who was appointed to the bench by President Gerald R. Ford in 1976, was handed down June 21 and is not binding on other courts. But Jonathan Sheldon of the National Consumer Law Center in Boston said that as the first clear Federal opinion it was being viewed as influential.
Students must first prove that the trade schools defrauded them before they can erase their debts. In the Northeastern case, the Federal court has not yet addressed that issue. In a separate case, a state court ruled that Northeastern did engage in deceptive practices.
The Federal ruling also left unclear who might ultimately bear the cost of the loans. The banks have already recouped their money in reimbursements from the guarantee agency, which, in turn, has been trying to collect from the students.
Mr. Leeson worries that a collection agency may go after his disability check. He said pellets left in his head 17 years ago in a hunting accident have shifted, leaving him unable to work.
"They start cutting my check, I'll be hurting," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: George Leeson, a former student of Northeastern Business College, discussing his case against the defunct school, which he claims failed to give him an education and left him with nearly $3,000 in student loans. (Gary Truman for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: U.S. AND SOVIET UNION AGREE ON ALL BUT TECHNICAL ISSUE FOR STRATEGIC ARMS TREATY

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 14

 BODY:
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Foreign Minister Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh of the Soviet Union announced today after four days of marathon talks that they had resolved all issues for a treaty reducing long-range nuclear arms, except for one highly technical dispute that they hope to resolve in the coming days.
Given the progress, it now appears that the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty, which will reduce Soviet and American long-range nuclear arsenals by about 30 percent and has been in negotiation since 1982, is on the verge of completion. 
 Mr. Baker said that if the dispute could be wrapped up in the next few days -- which he emphasized was by no means assured -- there would still be time for full-scale summit meeting between President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in Moscow late this month. The two leaders had made the completion of the agreement, sometimes referred to as the Start treaty, a condition for a full summit meeting.
 
Mutual Exhaustion
 "It's a tremendous step forward to finalizing the Start treaty," said a weary-looking Mr. Bessmertnykh, standing next to a similarly weary-looking Mr. Baker at a news conference in the State Department lobby. "The long journey of nine years is coming really to the end. We're a little exhausted, but everybody's happy about the amount of job we have accomplished." [Excerpts from the news conference, page A10.]
In London tonight, President Bush's spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said the President was "encouraged that they've made as much progress as they have and that they're as close to reaching an agreement as they appear to be."
Mr. Fitzwater said "it's hard to say" whether a Moscow summit is possible at the end of July. "The President has been very emphatic in saying that he does not expect to have a summit meeting without a treaty to sign," he said. "So I think at this point it would be very unlikely that we would have a summit without a Start treaty."
 
Reducing Accord to Writing
 The treaty would bring the number of Soviet long-range nuclear warheads down from 11,000 to 7,000 and the United States' from 12,000 to 9,000.
For his part, Mr. Baker emphasized that all the agreements reached in the last four days still have to be turned into the formal language of written accords by treaty negotiators in Geneva .
In the past, that has often led to further wrangling, including disputes over English and Russian translation, and Mr. Baker went out of his way to say that he could not rule out something similar in this case -- even though negotiators codified their understandings in writing.
American officials said the progress signaled that the Soviets really do want to conclude a treaty, which would be the first arms-control agreement to reduce long-range nuclear weapons, apparently in the hope of propelling relations with the United States into a new era in which economic issues are predominant.
Moscow is seeking economic assistance from Western countries to help rebuild its economy. Mr. Gorbachev is expected to make his case for such aid to the leaders of seven industrial nations gathering in London this week.
Mr. Baker said that he and Mr. Bessmertnykh had assigned their specialists to try to reach an understanding on this last technical dispute -- how to define a nuclear missile's throw-weight for the purpose of determining whether the missile should be classified as a "new type," and therefore assumed to carry a different number of warheads.
 
Many Agreements
 The other major issues that divided the sides before the talks began on Thursday have been settled, Mr. Baker said, including how to monitor missile tests, the number of spare warhead spaces allowed on each missile and the broader definition of what constitutes a new type of missile.
"The one issue on which we have not been able to agree has to do with the definition of throw-weight for the purpose of determining whether the missile is a missile of a new type," Mr. Baker said. "This is a very technical issue. And our technicians and experts will continue to work on this issue. Perhaps the Minister and I might be able to follow up ourselves when the two Presidents get together in London on Wednesday.
"If we can cover this one last issue, we will have an agreement."
Mr. Baker suggested that in the endgame of negotiations the Soviets made most of the concessions, and the Americans virtually none, which drew a few amused smiles from Mr. Bessmertnykh. The Russian did, however, acknowledge some concessions.
Politically, both Mr. Baker and Mr. Bessmertnykh came into the talks keenly aware that the appearance of how they concluded the treaty could be almost as important as the actual substance in selling the pact to their respective legislatures -- the Senate and the Supreme Soviet -- for approval.
Richard R. Burt, the former chief American negotiator on long-range arms, said that "neither side wants to appear to have made the last concession."
Both American and Soviet hard-liners put their respective negotiators on notice that they intend to scrutinize every aspect of this treaty with an eye to rejecting it.
Indeed, Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, told Mr. Baker hours before he began his talks with Mr. Bessmertnykh that the Soviets are "cheats and liars and scoundrels," so Mr. Baker had better come to the Senate with a treaty that is airtight to prevent Soviet evasions.
 
Who Conceded What?
 While all of the details have not been disclosed, there appears to be some basis for Mr. Baker's suggestion that the Soviet side made more concessions. The Americans appear to have gotten much of what they were seeking from the Soviets on the issues of spaces for warheads and of data denial, or how missile tests are monitored, while the Soviets got close to what they had been seeking on defining and dealing with new types of missiles.
For instance, on the issue of data denial, the Soviets agreed to an American proposal that they exchange tapes from every one of each other's long-range nuclear missile tests, as a way to insure compliance with the treaty.
The Soviets had initially resisted exchanging so much data, and when they accepted the concept of trading tapes they wanted to do it on some tests rather than on all, as Washington demanded.
Because the United States tests its missiles over water, where Soviet ships can easily pick up their telemetry data, they had an advantage over the Americans, as Soviet tests are conducted primarily over land and the electronic data is harder to pick up.
 The Soviets also seem to have given ground somewhat on the limits on the number of nuclear warheads for both sides. Many missiles now carry 10 warheads. Both sides would prefer to reduce the number of warheads per missile, without having to build new missiles expressly designed for fewer warheads, because it is cheaper.
To accomplish this, missiles capable of carrying 10 warheads will carry fewer andbe counted as though they carry fewer. Nevertheless, they will have the capacity to carry spares and if eitherside wanted to break out of the treaty, the missiles could carry 10 warheads again.
The two sides agreed to a total ceiling of 1,250 of such missile warheads for each. That could include the Minuteman 3, the SS-N-18, plus two other missiles for each side.
"The Soviet side," Mr. Baker said, "was willing to move substantially from what their position had been."
While ratification of the treaty, once it is completed and signed, is by no means a foregone conclusion, at this stage it seems highly likely. With a Republican President lobbying his party, and the Senate Democrats by inclination favoring the treaty, the two-thirds needed for ratification appears likely.
 
A Ranking Democrat's View
 Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., Democrat of Delaware and chairman of the Foreign Relations subcommittee on European Affairs, who will play a leading role in the ratification process, issued a statement saying:
"The treaty favors the United States, but still leaves superpowers with Armageddon arsenals that far exceed any rational need. While the treaty's details may engender some Senate controversy, resistance to it would be foolhardy. We should move quickly to bring nuclear arsenals into line with post-cold-war realities."
The treaty requires both sides to reduce the number of their bomber aircraft and sea- and land-based missile delivery systems to a total of 1,600 each and to reduce the number of warheads carried by those delivery systems to a total of 6,000 per nation.
But 3,000 American nuclear gravity bombs, short-range missiles carried by bombers and sea-launched cruise missiles are excluded from the treaty limits for a variety of political and military reasons negotiated over the last decade. This also applies to roughly 1,000 similar Soviet warhead systems.

HEADLINE: 7 Arrive With Soviets on Their Minds

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, July 14

 BODY:
Leaders of the seven largest industrialized democracies gathered here today for three days of talks that are expected to focus on ways of encouraging the Soviet Union to move to a market economy without much help from any of them.
President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union will present his latest plan for economic change to the leaders here on Wednesday afternoon. That meeting, sought by Mr. Gorbachev for two years, is a recognition of the interdependence of all the world's economies now that the cold war is over. 
 But a 23-page letter that Mr. Gorbachev sent to all the summit participants last week gave them little reason to believe that he is going to present the kind of detailed, step-by-step plan that could draw aid from Western financial institutions, officials of several countries said today.
United States officials dismissed the letter as a vague "circular," and one economist said, "It's clear on the aim, but not on the means of getting there." Others said it now appears that it might take decades rather than years for the Soviet Union to switch to a market economy.
 
Letting Gorbachev Have His Say
 "I think it would be courteous to hear what he says," the host of the summit meeting, Prime Minister John Major of Britain, said today after seeing Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada.
Mr. Mulroney told reporters, "I don't believe you will see either miracles or blank checks."
President Bush, who is to meet separately with Mr. Gorbachev on Wednesday, flew in this evening from Paris after talks with President Francois Mitterrand of France and joined Mr. Major for dinner at 10 Downing Street.
How to respond to Soviet plans for economic change is only one of the pressing issues that will be on the table when the leaders of the United States, Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy and Japan -- plus the representative of the European Community -- begin their talks Monday afternoon in Lancaster House, near St. James's Palace.
Mr. Bush has been consulting with allies on ways of insuring the destruction of Iraq's capacity to build nuclear weapons as required under United Nations cease-fire resolutions.
The summit participants are unlikely to endorse military strikes, officials of several countries said, but they could agree on a statement opposing the lifting of United Nations sanctions against Iraq until it complies with all Security Council resolutions connected with its occupation of Kuwait.
Mr. Major wants the summit participants to back a proposal by the British, Americans and Japanese for a United Nations register of arms sales, which would be aimed at preventing countries like Iraq from amassing vast stocks of offensive weapons. Iraq has successfully played international suppliers off against each other in the past.
The threat of civil war in Yugoslavia will also be on the minds of the leaders. And Mr. Major, who is presiding over his first summit meeting, wants the heads of government to pledge to attend the international conference on global warming in Rio de Janeiro next year, and to push negotiators toward a a new worldwide trade treaty by the end of this year.
 
Soviets Point to Difficulties
 Some Soviet economists working in London in advance of Mr. Gorbachev's arrival emphasized the difficulty of moving to a market economy while the existing Communist-run system is rapidly deteriorating and people are anxious about scarce supplies of food and consumer goods.
"In the political sphere, we've made tremendous progress," said Leonid A. Abalkin, a Soviet economist who helped draft Mr. Gorbachev's letter. "But in the economic sphere things remain where they were five or six years ago. The Soviet Union itself has to do the bulk of the work of change."
He acknowledged that Mr. Gorbachev's latest plan is the 10th one he has reviewed, and that none has been put into action.
Grigory A. Yavlinsky, who worked with Mr. Gorbachev over the weekend and has been urging him to adopt elements of a radical plan backed by professors at Harvard and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, decided not to come to the summit meeting, a Harvard official said. The official said Mr. Yavlinsky had not explained whether he was forgoing the meeting because Mr. Gorbachev had not gone as far as he wanted.
Mr. Abalkin said the letter from Mr. Gorbachev outlined Soviet plans to privatize 80 percent of the country's light industry by the end of 1992. He acknowledged that Soviet heavy industry, which is mainly related to the military, would take longer. The Western leaders are expected to demand the rapid conversion of plants to civilian use as proof of Moscow's intention to make fundamental changes in the economy.
Mr. Major, like Mr. Bush and the Japanese Prime Minister, Toshiki Kaifu, whom he also met here today, is skeptical about the usefulness of large financial aid to the Soviet Union while the uncertainty continues.
"We are very concerned to insure that not only the Soviets pass the legislation for economic reform, but they actually implement the legislation so that the economic reform itself can actually come about," Mr. Major said.
Germany has provided or pledged $31 billion worth of aid to the Soviet Union over the last year in exchange for Moscow's assent to German unification. The German Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, said in an interview released today that he would argue that helping the Soviet Union to introduce democracy and a market economy would be in the West's interest.
But "the Germans obviously can't do everything," he told the paper Frankfurter Allgemeine. "Our resources are limited. We have no cash cow."
 
Advice Instead of Money
 Instead of cash, the summit participants are expected to offer the Soviet Union a form of association with the International Monetary Fund. That would enable Moscow to receive technical advice on making the ruble convertible, getting inflation under control and freeing prices on domestic goods.
"If anybody is looking for anything dramatic in London, they'll be disappointed," one American official said. "But if the Soviet Union comes forward with a real plan, and it's clearly thought through, and lays out a timetable and then keeps to it, I think there will be a response on the part of the West to attempt to underpin it."
Whatever they decide about the Soviet Union, the Western leaders will seek in the declarations they issue on Wednesday to offer firm support for continuing the flow of aid and capital to Eastern Europe. Most Eastern European countries have gone much further than the Soviet Union in adopting free-market reforms.

 Mr. Gorbachev meets with Mr. Major all day at Downing Street.

 Mr. Gorbachev meets the British Labor Party opposition leader, Neil Kinnock, and former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher before departing in the late morning.

HEADLINE: Excerpts From the Briefing Held by Bush and Mitterrand

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 14

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a news conference by President Bush and President Francois Mitterrand today in Rambouillet, France, as provided by the Federal News Service, a transcription company, through the facilities of CNN: 
 Q. Mr. President. The President of France is being quoted as saying there are circumstances that he would cause intervention, that would take intervention in Iraq. . . . Have you seen that statement or could you tell us your own position, your own terms for moving militarily against Iraq?
MR. BUSH. I just have not seen the statement, but if it says you phrased it, I would support his statement. We are together in the way we're looking at this situation in Iraq, the situation I'm referring to being Saddam Hussein's continuation of lying and trying to go forward with some nuclear capability. And that is a cause for alarm all over the world, and having -- I don't like to talk about a statement I've not seen, but after a discussion with President Mitterrand I am confident that France and the United States, once again, are looking at this important matter in the same way.
. . .
There has been incontrovertible evidence presented to the United Nations Security Council that the man is lying and cheating. There were rumors that force might be used. Shortly after that, Saddam Hussein came forward and said essentially this: I have been lying and cheating. I have been doing things that I heretofore said I have not been doing. But now I'm not going to do them anymore. And I think it is very important to the security of the whole region, indeed to the world, that he not do them any more, that he not go forward with the nuclear program, that he comply with each and every United Nations resolution. So that's what this is all about. And let us hope that his last confession or his last statement that he would comply is followed to the letter and to the T. I can tell you I am still, in spite of that, very much concerned about his intentions, and with reason. I'm not just thinking that way; I have evidence to back that up.
. . .
MR. MITTERRAND. Now, would we be prepared for military intervention? You would not talk about Kurdistan incidentally, and yet I decided to maintain by transfer of troops from northern Iraq to Turkey, we decided to keep on the spot a few hundred troops . . . in order to be able to intervene within the framework of the Kurdish if Iraq decided to exercise repression of the Kurds. And that is a fact. That has already been decided.
As to military intervention against the proposed nuclear site, I said to President Bush that the important thing would be the information forthcoming to us so we could be sufficiently certain that there was nuclear activity going on, for it to be justified.
. . .
Q. President Saddam Hussein -- let's put the question in a very straight way -- do you think it's time to get rid of him?
MR. BUSH. You put it in a straight way, and I'll put the answer in a rather circuitous way. The United States will not have improved nor normalized relations with Iraq as long as Saddam Hussein is in power. I will not have our people voting to lift sanctions as long as he is in power. He is hurting his people. Before the war started, I made very clear over and over again that our argument was not with the people of Iraq, it wasn't even with the regime in Iraq. It was with Saddam Hussein. And I've had a chance to talk to President Mitterrand on this and get his views, and my view remains that the best thing that could happen would be for him to step aside and let us all begin with whoever took his place to try to have improved relations. And that would mean, of course, full and total compliance to every T and every I in that, in the U.N. resolutions.
. . .
Q.There've been some reports that because of the focus on President Gorbachev's need for economic reform and assistance from western nations, that some of the needs of the emerging democracies in Eastern Europe might be ignored or not taken care of adequately. Could you address yourself, sir, to your perception of where G-7 might end up with respect to providing aid that's needed for other emerging democracies, not only in Eastern Europe but around the world?
 MR.BUSH: Well I had a chance to get President Mitterrand's views on that, his advice on that, and I can tell you that he and I, and I am confident the rest of the G-7 will not do anything that will send a signal that we are shifting our attention away from the fledgling democracies in eastern Europe in order to help the Soviet Union. They need not be mutually exclusive.
But you raise a very important point, and one that has concerned me, and as for the U.S. side, we will be doing everything we can to make clear to Eastern Europe that we want to be a participant in their continued march down democracy's path.

NAME: Lowell P. Weicker Jr.

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 2; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1301 words

HEADLINE: Weicker: A Maverick Visionary or a Political Realist?

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, July 13

 BODY:
Former Gov. William A. O'Neill, Connecticut's chief executive throughout the prosperous, placid 1980's, liked to call his home state "the land of steady habits." Under Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., it might more aptly be called the land of the rising blood pressure.
In his first six months as the state's first independent non-party governor since the Civil War, Mr. Weicker has ridden roughshod over about as many sensibilities as his brief time in office has allowed. Two-party government? An anachronism. The long-avoided and politically verboten income tax? Long overdue, and anyone who disagrees is lacking in courage or intelligence. But as the state enters its third week without a budget on Monday with Mr. Weicker and lawmakers still apparently deadlocked over the income-tax issue, the questions are growing ever more urgent about just how much a non-traditional governor without a single member of his party in the Legislature can achieve.
 
Thorn in Nixon's Side
 Behind that is the question of who exactly Mr. Weicker is and what makes him push as hard as he has -- through two budget vetoes over the last six weeks and a partial shutdown of the state government carried out over the objections of the state Attorney General and the Comptroller. It is a subject that others have tried to plumb before, and failed.Former President Richard M. Nixon, to name just one, began asking about Mr. Weicker in 1973. Mr. Weicker was gaining national attention and the cover of Time magazine as the young Republican Senator on the Watergate committee who dared attack his own party's Administration. 
 "What the hell makes Weicker tick?" the beleaguered President said to his chief aide, John D. Ehrlichman, according to transcripts of one White House conversation in March of that year.
"Nobody's been able to figure that out," Mr. Ehrlichman said.
Dale Harden, a senior policy analyst from Windsor who has followed the budget follies from his office at Aetna Life and Casualty, thinks that perhaps Mr. Weicker's very size has something to do with it. Mr. Weicker, at 6 feet 6 inches in his stocking feet, often displays an irritable manner and a propensity to reach for barnyard metaphors that allow him to bluster with the best. As a Senator, that manner may have been fine, Mr. Harden said, but as a Governor, perhaps not. "His intimidation creates some of the problems," Mr. Harden said. "When you're dealing with someone who's intimidating, you have a tendency to strike back."
 
Maybe Just a Realist?
 Others say it is simply a matter of Mr. Weicker's ideas. Connecticut is one of only 10 states that do not tax wages. Many residents and lawmakers have attached a deep symbolism to the state's historical aversion to the income tax. They speak of the tax structure as almost a natural resource that has made the state great and must not be squandered. Breaking the income-tax barrier, those opponents say, will create a new revenue source and lead to a sharp expansion of state spending and destroy forever the sense of identity that the lack of an income tax has bestowed.
Income-tax supporters argue that by avoiding the wage tax, the state's other taxes have been pushed to the limit and that the recession brought on the current budget crisis -- not Mr. Weicker. The 8 percent sales tax, the 13.8 percent corporate profits tax and the tax on earnings from dividends and interest, which is as high as 14 percent, are all the highest statewide rates in the nation. A broad-based wage tax would allow all those taxes to be lowered, spurring economic growth, Mr. Weicker and his supporters argue.
 
Born to Wealth
 "Whether he were a little, smooth, pleasant sugary person, or a large, tough, self-assured figure -- I don't think it makes that much difference," said Representative Irving J. Stolberg, a Democrat from New Haven and a staunch supporter of the Weicker income-tax plan. "If he was weaker, he might have buckled, that's all."
Whatever else Mr. Weicker may be, he is not known for buckling under.
Mr. Weicker, who was born in Paris 60 years ago to great wealth as the grandson of one of the founders of the Squibb Pharmaceutical Corporation, earned his political reputation by swimming against the currents and making a great noise while doing it. As one of the last of a disappearing breed of liberal Republican lawmakers in Washington, he battled the party's conservative wing through the Reagan years on a range of issues, including school prayer and abortion.
 
Hero Among Many Liberals
 In 1988, his last year in Washington before being defeated by Joseph I. Lieberman, a Democrat, Mr. Weicker was given a 90 percent approval rating by the Americans for Democratic Action, a liberal lobby group. The average Republican Senator, by contrast, agreed with the group's positions only 27 percent of the time that year, while the average Democrat scored a 72 percent approval rating. Mr. Weicker is the only Republican in the House or Senate that the group has ever endorsed since its founding in the 1940's.
He has also been unpredictable. In the budget struggles here, he vowed that he would immediately veto any resolution that would keep the government running temporarily. But he allowed a two-week resolution to go into law without his signature. The resolution veto would have been overridden, he said.
 
'Phony as a Three-Dollar Bill'
 This has all provided ample ammunition for his detractors.
"He's as phony as a three-dollar bill," said John Gizzi, a former campaign volunteer who supported Mr. Weicker through the 1970's but grew disillusioned as the Senator embraced increasingly liberal causes. Mr. Gizzi, now the political director of the Conservative National Committee, a lobbying group, believes Mr. Weicker is essentially a man who found he could win votes by being contrary and has stuck with the technique.
His supporters say he simply speaks his mind.
"It may not always be popular, but you don't have to guess around him to know what he's talking about," said Audrey Brett, a retired secretary from Manchester. "I appreciate that."
 
A Master of Quotes
 During the course of a 40-minute interview, Mr. Weicker, a Yale University graduate, quoted Saint Paul, the poet John Donne, and former Representative Earl F. Landgrebe, an Indiana Congressman during the 1970's. While doing so, Mr. Weicker said he does not expect, or even really desire, popularity for having put the state on its current course. He said that because the state has "cooked the figures" for years to avoid overhauling its revenue system, a clean break from the practices of the past is the only answer, however painful.
"You tell me who's going to love anybody that is in the role of bringing people face to face with themselves," he said. "The drying-out process is not pleasant for either an individual or a state, and that's exactly what we're in right now, and I'm the doctor."
Opinion poll experts say that the Governor's popularity slipped steadily through the spring, as Mr. Weicker and lawmakers grappled with the budget and the income-tax issue.
 
Ambivalence About Hartford
 In such a climate, even Mr. Weicker's apparent ambivalence about Hartford has become an issue. Shortly after the election, for example, he said he would live instead at his home in Greenwich, called Applejack Farm. The decision provoked a storm of letters and editorials in local newspapers. Though Mr. Weicker subsequently changed his mind, the move to Hartford was delayed by major structural repairs that the governor's mansion's was later found to need.
Even now, he expresses a desire to be away from the building he sought.
"I'm a pretty peripatetic governor, he said, calling his office "the last place I enjoy being."

HEADLINE: Syria Accepts Bush Plan for Mideast Peace Talks

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 14

 BODY:
President Hafez al-Assad of Syria responded today to President Bush's proposal for a Middle East peace conference, saying the plan was an "acceptable basis for achieving a comprehensive solution," state-run Syrian Television reported.
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, speaking to reporters after arms talks at the State Department, said the letter was Syria's most positive and forthcoming approach to Arab-Israeli peacemaking that he could recall. The letter, he said, appeared to have no obvious conditions, although he said there were some points -- which he did not specify -- that Washington would like to explore with Damascus. 
 The apparently positive Syrian response to President Bush's proposals now puts the Israeli Government on the spot, since it has rejected Mr. Bush's plan for a peace conference. There was no formal Israeli comment on the Syrian report.
 
Baker Trip Possible
 "I would characterize the response as positive," Mr. Baker said of the Syrian letter. "I have only briefly read the letter. It is quite long. But I do believe it is fair to characterize the response as positive. I did not see anything expressed specifically as conditions. However, I do think there are in there some suggestions that we would want to probe to determine whether or not they are in any way conditions."
Mr. Baker added that overall, the Syrian response "in this letter moves the Syrian Government further than they have been willing to move in any peace process effort, that I am aware of, before, or any conference."
Mr. Baker, who is traveling to London to join President Bush at the economic summit meeting, is known to be considering splitting off later in the week to go to the Middle East and pursue the peace conference.
In the first week in June, President Bush wrote to both the Syrians and Israelis and proposed a compromise formula for holding a peace conference. That formula was meant to bridge the differences between Israel and Syria over two points: first, what role the United Nations would play at the conference, and second, whether it would be a continuing conference or a one-day ceremonial affair to open direct talks between the parties.
Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel wrote back to President Bush almost immediately and rejected his compromise formula. But the Syrians spent the last six weeks asking Washington various questions to clarify the proposal and pin down some private assurances before answering today. Egypt, Saudi Arabia and the Soviet Union all privately lobbied the Syrians to give Mr. Bush a positive answer that would then put Israel in a corner.
Israeli officials made little effort to disguise their hope that the Syrian response would be negative so that they would not be alone in opposing the Bush plan.
 
Confrontation With Israel?
 If the Syrian response is as positive and unconditional as the Syrian Television report, it could set up yet another confrontation between the Bush Administration and Israel, whose relations have been tense in recent weeks because of President Bush's opposition to Israeli settlement activity in the West Bank. The Administration will almost certainly now go back to the Israelis and try to persuade them to drop their opposition to the American conference proposal.
Syria's Foreign Minister, Farouk al-Sharaa, delivered the Syrian response to President Bush's letter of June 1 to the American Ambassador in Damascus, Edward Djerejian, this morning.
Reporting on the Syrian response, Syrian Television said: "In his letter, President Hafez al-Assad commends the efforts President Bush and Secretary Baker exerted to overcome the difficulties facing the convening of the conference. The President considers President Bush's proposals and the subsequent clarifications positive and balanced and constitute an acceptable basis for achieving a comprehensive solution and a peace process in the region, especially since these proposals are based on U.N. Security Council Resolutions 242 and 338, which apply to all fronts and secure legitimate Palestinian political rights."
The television report also said Mr. Assad expressed "satisfaction" with Mr. Bush's compromise proposals "because President Bush based his proposals on the principles of international legitimacy, gave special attention to the U.N. role in the peace conference, and stressed European participation."
In particular, the televsion added, Mr. Assad highly values "President Bush's pledge that the United States and the U.S.S.R. will be a catalyst for peace and that they will have a special responsibility to make the conference succeed in its objectives as defined by the relevant U.N. resolutions."
President Bush had asked Syria and Israel to agree that the United Nations would be represented at the peace conference by a single observer, who would not be allowed to speak or participate. That was an attempt to bridge Israel's demand that the United Nations play no role and the Syrian demand that the United Nations actually sponsor the conference.
In addition, President Bush proposed that the conference, which would be co-sponsored by the United States and the Soviet Union, would open with a ceremonial session, after which the Israelis and the different Arab parties would break up into direct two-way negotiations, with no formal interference from the co-sponsors.
 
Option to Reconvene
 The President proposed that the conference reconvene periodically to hear reports from the negotiating groups, provided that both Israel and its Arab negotiating partner agree. This was meant to bridge the Syrian position that the conference have some ongoing and permanent nature, so that neither side could stall indefinitely without anyone's taking note, and the Israeli position that the conference function as a purely ceremonial opening and that the co-sponsors not be permitted to pressure the parties or intervene in the talks.
In his initial June 1 letter to Mr. Assad, and in later messages of clarification, Mr. Bush made it clear that even though the conference would not have a permanent structure, Moscow and Washington would actively follow the talks and in that regard the United States would be guided by its own interpretation of United Nations Resolution 242.
That interpretation is that Israel should trade lands occupied in the 1967 war for secured and recognized boundaries with its Arab neighbors and that while Israel has already accomplished that with Egypt, it must do the same with Syria and Jordan as well. Israel holds the Golan Heights, which were seized from Syria, and the West Bank, which was previously held by Jordan.
The current Israeli Government argues that in trading the Egyptian Sinai desert for peace with Egypt it has already fulfilled all of the land-for-peace provisions of Resolution 242.

HEADLINE: BOXING;
Trading Hide-and-Seek For the Old 1-2 Punch

BYLINE: By PHIL BERGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, July 14,1991

 BODY:
It started on the streets of East Los Angeles. The fights were for fun, arranged on the moment as just another recreation.
One of the de la Hoyas, Joel or his little brother Oscar, would square off against one of their cousins and pretty soon two of them would be left throwing punches while the others loudly urged them on. 
 For 6-year-old Oscar, it didn't take long for him to think of ringalevio or stoop ball or hide-and-seek as safer ways to spend a leisure hour.
"Cousin George or Rudy or Eddie, they were older than me -- 8, 9, 10 years old -- and stronger," said de la Hoya, who is now 18 years old. "So my father decided to take me to the gym so I could learn to defend myself."
It turned out that Oscar de la Hoya, who meets Patrice Brooks in the final of the 132-pound class of the United States Olympic Festival on Tuesday, was a quick study.
In a matter of days, he said, he was throwing punches in smart combinations and showing such a flair for boxing that his father, Joel Sr., a former professional fighter, kept him in the gym.
"I had my first bout at the age of 6 at the Pico Rivera Sports Arena," de la Hoya said. "The other boy was 6 also. I hit him so hard they stopped the fight in the first round."
Then came payback time for his cousins.
"By the time I was 9 or 10, I went back and fought them again," de la Hoya said. "This time I made them cry."
Now de la Hoya, with an amateur record of 206-4, stands ready to give the rest of the world a boxing lesson. The fighter, a graduate of Garfield High School here, is regarded as one of the United States' likelier gold-medal prospects in boxing for the 1992 Olympic Games in Barcelona, Spain.
"Eric Griffin, who fights in the 106-pound class, and de la Hoya are the class of the team," said Alex Wallau, the ABC-TV boxing analyst. "What's most unique about Oscar is his body punching. He works very hard with both hands and in combinations. And to be willing to do that in the amateurs' three-round bouts -- to take the time to work the body -- is very unusual.
"Sometimes you can see an entire amateur fight card and not a meaningful body punch will be thrown. Besides that, he's very economical. He doesn't spray lots of punches, the way most amateurs do."
Amateur coaches have an expression: When they want a boxer to accelerate his offense, they sometimes holler, "Shoeshine!" That's a buzz word to trigger the sort of rapid-motion punching that scores points with judges but in truth is not calculated to hurt the opponent.
The scoring in amateur boxing places more emphasis on the number of blows landed than the overall impact of what's thrown.
Shoeshining is a logical way to take advantage of the system.
But de la Hoya does not throw punches for show. He has, as Mike Tyson would say, "bad intentions" when he lets a punch go. Forget shoeshining. By his own account, de la Hoya's instincts are ready made for the pro game.
In his workouts under his trainer, Robert Alcazar, a former professional lightweight, de la Hoya spars with professionals -- last month he went two rounds with Julio Cesar Chavez, the world champion junior welterweight -- and he has come to view himself as a fighter more attuned to the hurt orientation of pro boxing.
"I can't wait to fight 10- and 12-round bouts," he said.
Nor can Shelly Finkel.
Finkel manages the undisputed heavyweight champion, Evander Holyfield, and Mark Breland and, with Lou Duva, co-manages world champions Meldrick Taylor and Pernell Whitaker.
 
Patient Approach
 Finkel has been acting as an unofficial adviser to de la Hoya, who said that when he turns professional he expects Finkel to be involved.
In a semifinal bout on Saturday, against Dezi Ford of Alliance, Ohio, de la Hoya was so patient in the first round, blocking punches and gauging his distance, that he made his handlers uneasy. They were fearful the lack of volume of punches would blow the round.
But the fighter quickly put their fears to rest. He knocked down Ford in the second round with a left-right combination, and disassembled him with three-punch body shots and crisp scoring blows to the head. De la Hoya's mastery over Ford was plain and he won an easy decision.
Now, as the countdown begins on the Olympic year, de la Hoya has begun zeroing in on Olympic glory. He has, he said, extra motivation. Last Oct. 28, the fighter's mother, Cecilia, died of breast cancer.
"Before she died, she told me she was confident I was going to win the gold," de la Hoya said. " 'Do it for me,' she said. I feel I will."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Oscar de la Hoya, right, who has an amateur record of 206-4, during victory over Dezi Ford at the Olympic Sports Festival. (Chris Covatta for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Essay;
The Great Panhandler

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Not since the Treaty of Brest-Li tovsk in 1918 when Lenin granted independence to Georgia, the Ukraine and the Baltic states, and groveled before Germany -- has a Soviet leader inflicted such humiliation on his nation.
Mikhail Gorbachev protests that he is not "going on his knees to beg" for money at the economic confabulation this week in London. On the contrary; he will rattle his tin cup standing up, even menacingly, warning that chaos and war will break out if the West does not help Beggar, thy neighbor. 
 The Great Panhandler will combine his dire threat of nuclear anarchy with delicious incentives: give us the investment capital that will permit us to convert our armaments factories to plowshare production -- just as you want. Give us the grain and consumer goods to prevent riots in the streets as we permit prices to rise in a free economy -- just as you want.
Germany, France and Italy, fearful of an invasion of hungry immigrants, will urge the U.S. and Japan to underwrite the salvation of Communism with a capitalist face. President Bush will be sorely tempted to take the middle way: a little money at first, not a lot, and with strings attached to be nice to separatist republics, and to encourage glasnost.
Mr. Bush shows signs of having given up asking if he should help the Soviet leader maintain power; he seems to be negotiating only how much and when and under what conditions. If he allows himself to be drawn down this path of gradual superpower blackmail, this summer's summits will be his Yalta.
The underlying assumption of government-to-government investment and government handout is wrong. That is their statist way of doing business; it is not our way. If we are to help them at all, we must first await their realization that the only way to attract capital is to offer incentive, and the only way to put food on the table is to adopt the profit motive.
The way for Moscow to prevent runaway inflation when it ends subsidies and price controls is not to promote a black market for Western-contributed consumer goods, but to lower the "ruble overhang" by selling property to the people who now hold the unconvertible currency.
The way for Moscow to finance the conversion of war plants to consumer-goods factories is not to beg for loan guarantees; it is to stop wasting assets making tanks and planes and paying a huge standing army, and to stop subsidizing Cuba at the rate of $4.5 billion a year.
The immediate cause of the collapse of the Soviet economy is the crushing cost of the Red Army. Now 30 percent of all Soviet production goes for arms; U.S. expenditure is 6 percent, everyone else less than 3 percent.
The reason for such huge spending was to build and police an internal and external empire; apparently that has been set aside. The only excuse Red Army and K.G.B. generals still put forward is to defend the motherland against a hostile world.
That excuse, never true, is now an obvious absurdity. What nation or alliance would want to invade or defeat the Soviet Union? Who would want to buy such a headache? The Warsaw Pact has dissolved and Napoleon's route lies open; NATO's response is to break up and go home.
To avoid chaos, to find the money to build a new system under private enterprise, the Soviet people must bring their troops home. Standing army, stand down; you are crushing the people you are supposed to protect.
But if I demobilize the Red Army, Gorbachev says, not only do I lose my power base, but I will have an army of unemployed. If I bring troops home from Germany, where will they live?
Answer: Use the money saved on war production on home production. Give former soldiers a piece of land as their private property, or stock in a privatized company producing consumer goods; homes will get built as never before. Private foreign capital will flow to where profit can be made in convertible currency.
Will the menacing mendicant crashing the summit hear this truth from the free-world leader? Not likely. Mr. Bush will probably sign a communique to permit kibbitzing at the International Monetary Fund, to raid Jacques Attali's Socialist Slush Fund, to form the Spaso House Oil Wildcatters Consortium and to merge the muddy waters of Harvard's Charles River with the Volga.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Ban the Replacement of Workers on Strike

 BODY:
To the Editor:
You report that the Communications Workers of America canceled a speech by Labor Secretary Lynn Martin at its annual convention in San Francisco because of fear of protest against Administration opposition to a bill banning the permanent replacement of striking workers (news article, June 27). You quote Ms. Martin's statement in response, voicing regret that "there are those who let single-issue politics stifle discussion and communication." 
 I was a delegate at the convention, and I must say that Ms. Martin's reply was not only predictable but even the primary reason the delegates chose not to listen to further rhetoric from an Administration that has clearly demonstrated its anti-union beliefs time and again. Ms. Martin is no friend of labor and has no right to speak on our behalf or represent organized labor's interests.
The National Labor Relations Act became law in 1935, providing workers with three basic rights: the right to organize, the right to bargain collectively and the right to withhold their labor (strike). The right to strike has always been a last alternative in any bargaining arena. Its purpose is to force economic pressure on employers to bargain in good faith and insure fair and equitable contracts. A strike is meant as an interruption of the labor-management relationship, not the termination of it.
The labor movement requires acts of substance and not symbolism. Ms. Martin represents administrations in the White House that praise unions abroad as the cornerstone for democracy, yet the Reagan-Bush domestic policies have inundated unions with anti-labor legislation and union-busting tactics.
If it had not been for President Reagan's reprehensible act of firing the air traffic controllers and permanently replacing those workers, corporate America would still see permanent replacements as unacceptable corporate behavior. However, Mr. Reagan's action sent a green light to employers that it is O.K. to engage in union busting. The devastation of unions throughout the United States continues at an alarming rate. Something has to change.
The Communication Workers, and organized labor, have sent a clear message to the White House, and all lawmakers, that passage of legislation to ban permanent replacement of striking workers is our No. 1 priority. Without such legislation, unions everywhere are threatened.
This country cannot continue with the retrogressive labor policies that are coming out of Washington. Passage of the striker replacement legislation is paramount to protect all workers. Lawmakers who support House Resolution 5 (H.R. 5) and Senate Bill 55 (S. 55) should be thanked for saying yes to democracy, and no to permanent replacements and union busting.
 
JOHN G. KINLOCH
Vice President, Local 1058
Communications Workers of America
Bridgewater, N.J., July 1, 1991

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: SIDELINES: A BULL IN A BEAR MARKET;
Ard Playing Let's Make a Deal

BYLINE: By HARVEY ARATON

 BODY:
In these days of a struggling economy and an unpredictable stock market, brokers try to be creative. None is trying harder than WILLIAM DONOVAN ARD of the Westfield, N.J., brokerage house of Butcher & Singer.
Yes, this is the same Billy Ard who played guard for the Giants from 1981-88 and the Green Bay Packers in 1989 and 1990. For eight years, he has spent the off season as a broker. At age 32, he still wants to play football, but he says he will not play unless the Packers guarantee some of his salary. 
 He said the Packers had offered him a two-year contract that would pay him $450,000 this year and $500,000 next year. He said the money was all right, even though four other offensive linemen on the Packers make 50 percent more. But he does not want to report to camp, get cut and go home with nothing. He said the Packers told him they do not make any guarantees.
All right, he told the Packers, let's try to work something out. He told them that three times during his career with the Giants, he was given loans. He suggested that the Packers give him a loan when he signed, and if he was cut he would not have to repay the loan. The Packers turned that down.
Then he suggested that the Packers give him a $25,000 cut clause, as they did last year. He said that if the Packers agreed to that, he would collect the $25,000 if they cut him by July 31 this year. He also proposed that if he was on the roster Aug. 15, he would get a $100,000 loan against his salary. The Packers didn't buy that, either.
"So I'm a full-time broker until they call me and give me what I want," Ard said last week. "I'm in shape to play football, but I don't want to waste my time getting cut in camp and getting nothing out of it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Former Giant Billy Ard is trying to hang on with the Packers. (Keith Meyers/The New York Times, 1987)

HEADLINE: Clarence Thomas and 'Natural Law'

BYLINE: By Laurence H. Tribe; Laurence H. Tribe, professor at Harvard Law School, is author of "On Reading The Constitution."

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
What is really at stake in the nomination of Judge Clarence Thomas to the Supreme Court? While any candidate nominated to replace Justice Thurgood Marshall would likely accelerate the Court's rightward trend, Judge Thomas's adherence to "natural law" as a judicial philosophy could take the Court in an even more troubling direction.
Most conservatives criticize the judiciary for expanding its powers, "creating" rights rather than "interpreting" the Constitution. These critics talk of returning issues like abortion to democratically elected and politically accountable bodies. 
 Clarence Thomas, judging from his speeches and scholarly writings, seems instead to believe judges should enforce the Founders' natural law philosophy -- the inalienable rights "given man by his Creator" -- which he maintains is revealed most completely in the Declaration of Independence. He is the first Supreme Court nominee in 50 years to maintain that natural law should be readily consulted in constitutional interpretation.
When a child born today reaches voting age, Judge Thomas will be 61, still five years younger than Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist is now. By then, the nation will face many new issues -- new reproductive technologies, computer privacy, genetic engineering.
Might a Justice Thomas some day provide a fifth vote to hold that Congress and the states may not respond with measures contrary to natural law, as construed by the justices on the basis of their understanding of the rights "given to man by his Creator?" Whether that understanding coincides with specific religious teachings matters less than how it affects legislative power and personal liberty.
Consider abortion. Judge Thomas has called even the right of married couples to use birth control -- recognized by the Court 26 years ago in Griswold v. Connecticut -- an "invention." Unfortunately, he seems likely to help overturn Roe v. Wade.
But whether Roe v. Wade is overruled is only half the question. No less important is the kind of regime that would follow. The Court in a post-Roe world would probably debate whether the Constitution permitted states to ban the French abortion drug RU-486 and whether state abortion bans must contain life, health or rape exceptions.
In these debates, a Justice Thomas, for whom the right to privacy may seem anathema, might seek to replace Roe not with a system that strengthens states' rights, but with a decree that abortion is murder and that its practice or counseling cannot be permitted by any state.
Judge Thomas has already dismissed talk of states' rights as a "constitutional sideshow." He also endorsed Lewis Lehrman's 1987 American Spectator article, which argued that because abortion violates the "right to life" guaranteed by the law of God in the Declaration of Independence, the Constitution cannot tolerate even a neutral stance on the issue. To Judge Thomas, that extraordinary theological argument was a "splendid example of applying natural law" to define the "right to life" secured by the Declaration.
Or consider Judge Thomas's insistence that "economic liberties [are] a vital part of the rights protected by constitutional government." To be sure, judges today understand that certain economic rights, like the right to fair compensation when private property is taken for public use, are constitutionally guaranteed.
But the last time a Supreme Court majority invoked natural rights theories, some 80 years ago, the Court held that the Constitution protects such economic rights as the "liberty" of employers to conduct business free of health and safety regulations and minimum wage laws.
Libertarians, though, can take little solace: Natural law has most often been cited to justify moralistic intrusions on personal choice -- as illustrated by Chief Justice Warren E. Burger's appeal to "Judeo-Christian moral and ethical standards" in Bowers v. Hardwick, a 1986 case condemning oral and anal sex between consenting adults.
And, perhaps echoing the Declaration's language that "all men are created equal," the Court 120 years ago relied on the law of "nature" and "the law of the Creator" to deny a woman the right to practice law, deeming it the "paramount destiny and mission of woman . . . to fulfill the noble and benign offices of wife and mother."
Before the Senate decides whether to confirm Judge Thomas, they should explore the implications of his views about natural law as the lodestar of constitutional interpretation. With the power of Congress and of every state and local legislature hanging in the balance, the Senate cannot avoid sharing the responsibility for the fate of self-government in the U.S.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Goodbye $, Hello "B"

BYLINE: By Eugene R. Fidell; Eugene R. Fidell is a lawyer.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Numbers have gotten too big. The gross national product, the national debt, the Federal budget, the Social Security Trust Fund. I first thought that I was the problem; perhaps I had lost the ability to tell whether things were costing too much or too little.
However, I now think the problem is in the numbers -- they are just too far from what normal people encounter in their daily lives. Ordinary people are paid in the unit of currency that is legal tender -- here, the dollar. Our mistake lies in assuming that when the House Ways and Means Committee, the Office of Management and Budget and General Motors discuss money, they too are referring to dollars. 
 They're not. What they are thinking of is a unit of currency that bears no relation to the money we earn. The time has come to make official this disparity by giving these high-rollers their own unit of currency. I suggest we call it a Business Unit of Account (B.U.A.).
You can usually tell when a number is calculated in B.U.A.'s from its context or the number of zeros at the end. It would be preferable, then, if instead of marking such sums with the familiar (but misleading) dollar sign, we had a new symbol.
I propose the letter "B" (or the Greek letter beta). Ten billion dollars would appear not as $10,000,000,000 but as B10,000,000,000. Use of the B would prevent taxpayers from equating their grocery bill with the tab for a space shuttle flight.
There is precedent for this. In Britain, according to the Oxford English Dictionary, the guinea (valued at 21 shillings) "is the ordinary unit for a professional fee and for a subscription to a society or institution; the prices obtained for works of art, racehorses, and sometimes landed property are also stated in guineas." Never mind the fact that the coin has not been minted since 1813 and there no longer is a unit of currency called a shilling.
Following this approach, B.U.A.'s need not be confined to Government or large-scale corporate transactions. A useful rule of thumb might be to require lawyers or doctors -- anyone who serves "clients" or "patients" instead of "customers" -- to send their bills in B.U.A.'s. This will alert consumers to the need to shift gears when they open their mail.
Eventually, of course, we can look forward to regulations, B.U.A. futures trading, and so forth. For the moment, however, it might be wise to start with the deficit.
