HEADLINE: Careers;
'Forensic Accountants' In Demand

BYLINE: By Elizabeth M. Fowler

 BODY:
THE accountant at a cocktail party in New Jersey looked weary. "I thought I had retired," he said, "but I keep getting called by towns and counties around here to work on fraud cases."
Two weeks earlier he had testified in court, he added, which takes a lot of preparation. 
 Fraud, whether in corporations or government agencies, and related areas like imminent bankruptcies, which often involve sleuthing for management misdeeds, have become busy new areas for accountants.
The large demand for accountants with pertinent training was confirmed by Terry R. Storevik, national placement director for litigation support services at Robert Half International Inc., one of the largest management recruiters of accountants, financial personnel and information specialists, with 160 offices around the world.
"We call them forensic accountants," he said. "It is the hottest field in accounting firms. We see an explosion of this type of recruitment, especially in major cities." He also wants to see resumes of accountants with experience in other litigation support areas, such as bankruptcy-insolvency and merger-acquisition and the setting of loss damages, workouts and restructuring.
Mr. Storevik, whose office is in San Diego, said, "I place partners and managers with the Big Six accounting firms and with boutique firms that specialize in what we call litigation support services." Salaries range from $50,000 to $200,000.
He added that he could not give figures, but demand for such forensic accountants increased by 100 percent in each of the last three years. "Job openings now are backlogged," he said. "The problem is finding the right persons."
In addition to demand from accounting firms that want permanent employees, there is also a big demand for temporary accountants to work for governmental units like the Resolution Trust Corporation, which has been handling financially troubled savings and loan organizations.
The need is for accountants who can not only do some sleuthing work for fraud but also figure out the market value of assets to be sold, Mr. Storevik said.
The surge in interest in forensic accounting began about three years ago. He attributed it to the impact of the recession, the "junk bond" problems, the savings and loan difficulties and more recently the problems of bad loans at many banks and now at insurance companies.
Misuse of funds by managers, money-laundering and suspicious insurance claims are growing areas of concern that require the new type of forensic accountant. For example, such accountants are at work in the wake of the collapse of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International, tracing its connections to other institutions and people. "It is an exciting area," Mr. Storevik said.
Following a carefully disguised trail of funds requires not only an in-depth knowledge of financial practices but also exceptional investigative and computer skills, he added.
Until recently, forensic accountants received most of their training on an earlier job, haphazardly. Job candidates who had the misfortune to work for several now-bankrupt companies suddenly find their experience to be highly prized, Mr. Storevik said.
"It is almost by accident, or learning through the school of hard knocks," he added. "One good training area is experience with the Federal Bureau of Investigation. I placed two from the F.B.I. at Big Six accounting firms recently."
In the last few years, major accounting organizations like the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants have realized the need.
"More and more seminars about fraud and bankruptcy are being given," Mr. Storevik said.
He also cited the National Association of Certified Fraud Examiners, which has its headquarters in Austin, Tex. It awards the designation of Certified Fraud Examiner, following intensive study of a manual and a two-day examination, costing $150.
The group, which began giving the designation in June 1988, now has 4,000 members. It was founded by its current chairman, Joseph T. Wells, a C.P.A. who worked for the F.B.I. However, anyone with a college degree and two years of experience in a fraud-related area can apply.
A decade ago lawyers generally handled the sale of assets of a bankrupt company. But the increased number of business failures has created a demand for accountants skilled in discovering assets conveyed improperly by insiders, and investigating the doctoring of books and the payment of kickbacks, which Mr. Storevik calls "gumshoe accounting."
Today's investigative accountants are also advising companies on whether to declare bankruptcy or take steps to remain solvent, he said.
He also cited other areas in which the forensic accountant might work, such as the setting of loss damages in the case of insurance companies and construction claims.

HEADLINE: Business Scene;
Pressure on Fed Without Letup

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle

 BODY:
AS chairman of the Federal Reserve, Paul Volcker displeased the Reagan Administration in the mid-1980's, and the President's top aides often said so, in blunt public statements. The Bush Administration deals more softly with Alan Greenspan, the current chairman, but the pressure on the Federal Reserve to shape policy the White House way has been roughly the same -- and without letup.
The President waited until last Wednesday, a month before Mr. Greenspan's term expired, to name him to a second four years as Fed chairman. Bush officials pooh-poohed speculation that the reappointment was ever in doubt. Quite the contrary. One senior adviser, who declined to be named, even suggested that since January, Mr. Greenspan had steered Fed policy roughly as the White House would have steered it, if the President's advisers had been running the central bank. 
 Such talk encourages the impression that the White House deals softly with Mr. Greenspan and his colleagues because harsh criticism isn't necessary: they respond to quiet pressure. It is an impression the Fed's policy makers indignantly reject, arguing that the nation's central bank must remain insulated from political pressures to carry out its functions, and does. "I would not do anything for political reasons," said Robert Black, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond and a voting member of the Fed's policy council.
Whatever the truth, the struggle goes on. During the late winter and early spring, when the recession seemed to be ending, the issue was whether interest rates should be a few notches lower as insurance that a recovery would indeed materialize. With Mr. Greenspan and his vice chairman, David W. Mullins Jr., leading the way, the Fed on three occasions in this period reduced short-term rates, over which it has the most control. The central bank's action helped to lower rates slightly on mortgages, some commercial loans, home equity loans and the like. And the Bush Administration applauded.
Now, the White House and the Fed have concluded that a recovery is under way, so their struggle is taking a different shape. The delay in naming Mr. Greenspan served notice that the White House was beating the drums for a more robust economic recovery than the Fed's policy makers seem to have in mind. How is this to be achieved? In a recent speech, Michael F. Boskin, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, hinted at what the Fed should do. He argued in effect that the Fed should allow the money supply to grow more rapidly, a process that puts more money in pockets and pushes down interest rates.
The President's advisers -- among them Nicholas F. Brady, the Treasury Secretary; Richard Darman, the budget director, and Mr. Boskin -- speak publicly of an economy capable of expanding at an annual rate of 3 percent or more over the next 18 months, a respectable performance in an election year. Many of the Fed's policy makers, however, argue that a 2.5 percent annual rise in the gross national product is the very most the economy can handle over the next two years.
In this Fed view, neither the nation's supply of workers nor the efficiency of businesses is sufficient to generate a 3 percent increase each year in the G.N.P. An attempt to reach the 3 percent level by increasing the money flow would only encourage inflation. People would bid for more than Corporate America could provide in new manufactured goods and numerous services.
This immensely important White House-Fed debate over growth -- one that will affect employment levels, profits, wages and interest rates -- is still very low key. The recovery that both sides believe is under way will have to continue for months before the G.N.P.'s growth rate becomes apparent. Given today's high unemployment level and idle factories, the G.N.P. might even grow for a few months at a 5 percent annual rate without straining the nation's resources.
"The real policy dilemma, the trade-off between inflation and growth, might not come into focus for some time," Mr. Mullins said.
Among the Fed's 17 current policy makers, Mr. Mullins is clearly pro-growth, close to the Administration's position. Mr. Greenspan and a few others appear to be between the Mullins view and a middle-of-the-road group that would accept long-term G.N.P. growth of about 2.5 percent a year. A few policy makers would like to squeeze inflation below its present weak level, keeping the economy on the edge of recession to achieve this.
The Fed policy makers, in sum, aren't as united in their thinking as the President's advisers appear to be. For the moment, in fact, the Fed's leadership seems tilted toward the Administration's view, which helps to explain why the White House can put pressure on the central bank in a soft voice.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Mixed in Slow Day; Prices of Gold Rise Slightly

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was mixed in quiet trading yesterday as the market took a breather after last week's volatile sessions.
Gold prices edged higher in New York, picking up 50 cents to close at $369.10 a troy ounce on the Commodity Exchange. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $368.75, also up 50 cents. 
 Analysts said the dollar was undergoing a period of consolidation after it soared on Thursday and then fell sharply on Friday. On Thursday, traders snapped up the dollar after German officials decided against raising interest rates, but they bid the dollar down the next day in response to selling of the dollar by central banks.
"Friday had a very tumultuous effect on trading," said John McCarthy, chief dealer with the Algemene Bank Nederland. He added that traders were also waiting to see what kind of stand the leaders of the Group of Seven industrialized nations, meeting in London, might take on the dollar.
The Federal Reserve reported yesterday that industrial production rose by seven-tenths of a percent in June, the third straight advance and more evidence that the manufacturing economy was continuing a modest recovery.
But the good economic news had little effect on the dollar. The numbers "were moderately better than anticipated, but not enough to take the dollar through new higher levels," Mr. McCarthy said.
The dollar edged up against the Japanese yen, rising to 136.94 yen in New York from Friday's 136.35. In Tokyo overnight, the dollar closed at 137.00 yen, down 1.73 yen from Friday's close but above its finish in New York on Friday. In London, it was quoted at 136.60 yen.
The British pound rose to $1.65375, from $1.6505 late Friday in New York trading. In London, sterling rose to $1.6510, from $1.6505 late Friday.
Against the German mark, the dollar rose slightly, to 1.78895 from 1.7885.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's prices, included: 1.5483 Swiss francs, down from 1.5580; 6.0745 French francs, up from 6.0730; 1,332.00 Italian lire, unchanged, and 1.1462 Canadian dollars, down from 1.14825.
Earlier, gold rose in London to a late bid of $368.85, up from $368.25 late Friday. In Zurich, gold rose to a closing bid of $368, up from $367.25 late Friday. In Hong Kong, gold rose $1.97 to close at $369.85.
Silver fell 1.3 cents on the Commodity Exchange, closing at $4.352 a troy ounce. Silver was unchanged in London at a late bid of $4.38.

HEADLINE: U.S. Will Abandon Volcano-Ravaged Air Base, Manila Is Told

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANILA, July 15

 BODY:
The United States informed the Philippine Government today that it expected to abandon Clark Air Base in the central Philippines, once a major military air hub, because of the damage caused by the eruption of Mount Pinatubo and the huge costs needed to rebuild the base, American and Philippine officials say.
At the same time, the officials said, American negotiators have told their Philippine counterparts that the United States wishes to retain the use of the giant Subic Bay Naval Station, which was also seriously damaged by the eruption of the volcano but which is considered too valuable to abandon. 
 In recent years, the United States has shown little enthusiasm for keeping Clark because it is no longer as vital to American military and strategic policy as it once was. But Subic, with its logistic and port installations -- the largest outside of the United States -- is deemed important by American strategic planners.
The American lease on the two bases expires in September. Officials said President Corazon C. Aquino was informed of the American plans to pull out of Clark, one of the largest American military installations outside the United States, at a meeting in Manila today with Adm. Charles Larson, who commands all United States military operations in the Pacific.
The Clark base, 10 miles east of Mount Pinatubo, has been smothered by a layer of thick volcanic ash that is two feet deep at points. A Defense Department survey team found that it would cost $500 million to $800 million to dig out the 9,000-acre base and to repair runways and more than 70 buildings that collapsed or were damaged by the ash, American officials said.
 
Volcano Still Spewing
 The Pentagon investigators, they said, warned that the threat from the 5,800-foot volcano was not over. Scientists say Mount Pinatubo could continue spewing its noxious cloud of ash and steam for three more years.
While the decision to abandon Clark has not been announced, the chief American negotiator in the base talks, Richard L. Armitage, gave a strong hint of the American position when he arrived in Manila today for another round of base negotiations with Foreign Secretary Raul Manglapus.
"Our facilities at Clark and Subic have sustained substantial damage,' Mr. Armitage said in a statement read at the city's international airport.
"The estimated cost of reconstituting either or both of these facilities, as well as the time involved, promises to be considerable," he said. "Clark's outlook is further clouded by the continuing emissions of ash from Mount Pinatubo that pose a serious hazard to aviation. I have already indicated to Secretary Manglapus, unfortunately, that the future of Clark is questionable."
Mr. Armitage met Mr. Manglapus later in the day in what was described by an American official as a "cordial" one-on-one meeting before formal talks between the nations open on Tuesday.
An American pullout from Clark would be serious blow to the faltering economy of the Philippines. The base employed thousands of Filipinos and injected hundreds of millions of dollars into local businesses each year.
 
90 Years of Ties
 A shutdown would end nearly 90 years of American ties to the base, which was opened at the turn of the century as a United States Army cavalry post, Fort Stotsenburg, and was renamed Clark Air Base after World War II. A decision to end the American presence at the base would doubtless please prominent Philippine lawmakers and academics who have long described Clark and Subic as symbols of American neo-colonialism.
The Philippine Government is all too aware of the damage at Clark and appears ready, although not eager, to accept a deal only for the naval base. "I think they've realized that because of the volcano, this is a one-base arrangement," said an American official.
American officials say that while the Bush Administration initially sought to obtain a new lease agreement for both Clark and Subic, the Navy base was considered the real prize in the talks.
"In an age of satellites and long-range jets, the United States can get along without Clark," an American military official said. "But Subic is a different matter. It is a nearly perfect, well-sheltered deep-water harbor that is irreplaceable. For the United States Navy, there is nothing like it in this part of the world."
Before the first eruption of Mount Pinatubo on June 9, the United States offered $360 million in annual compensation for a 10-year extension on the leases for both Clark and Subic. Philippine negotiators asked for $825 million a year in exchange for a seven-year treaty. In the wake of the eruption, American officials say they will now insist on at least a decadelong lease for Subic at far less money than had been requested by the Philippine Government for use of both bases.
 
Questions in Congress
 In what appeared to be a warning to Philippine negotiators not to push too far on compensation, Mr. Armitage said in his statement that he had been approached by several members of Congress who questioned the wisdom of an American military presence in the Philippines at a time when budget cuts were forcing the Pentagon to shut down large numbers of military installations in the United States.
The lawmakers ask "why the U.S. Government is contemplating spending large sums of money for military facilities in the shadow of an active volcano halfway around the world," Mr. Armitage said. "My answer is that despite the devastations of Mount Pinatubo, the strategic rationale for these facilities remains valid."
Nearly 2,400 Air Force employees remain at Clark. Some have begun cleaning up the base, while others are packing household belongings left behind by the 15,000 Americans ordered to evacuate the Philippines in the wake of the volcano. "The fact that we're sending all of their belongings home should tell you what you need to know about Clark," said an American military official in Manila. "We're not going back."

HEADLINE: Court Nominee Defied Labels As Head of Job-Rights Panel

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 15

 BODY:
As head of the Federal agency responsible for enforcing the laws against job discrimination, Clarence Thomas was often at war with other Reagan Administration officials, with members of Congress, with civil rights groups and with himself.
Judge Thomas, President Bush's nominee for the Supreme Court, was chairman of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission from May 1982 to March 1990, longer than any of his predecessors. A review of agency files for that period shows that he expressed complex, continually changing, often contradictory views, particularly on questions of affirmative action. 
 As a member of Ronald Reagan's transition team in 1980, he had written a memorandum challenging affirmative action. But as commission chairman in 1983, he defended the use of numerical hiring goals in several celebrated cases.
He abruptly switched his public position after the 1984 election and assailed such remedies for the next 20 months. Then in July 1986, at a confirmation hearing for his second term on the commission, he said the agency would once again advocate the use of goals and timetables, despite his personal opposition to them.
Trying to elucidate his shifting views on affirmative action, and acknowledging his personal reservations, the chairman once told a Congressional hearing, "I'll abide by the Supreme Court, whether I like it or not."
If confirmed for a seat on the High Court, Judge Thomas would shape the law by which others must abide. It is by no means certain that his judicial rulings would echo his views from the world of politics and policy. But for those searching for clues to his likely course on the Court, his record at the commission yields many clues to what he might do.
Judge Thomas, who has sat on the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit since early 1990, declines to discuss his record with reporters, but the commission's files, including some of his speeches and correspondence, suggest he was often torn by conflicts inside himself and with others.
For instance, he said the "single most devastating event" of his tenure was the commission's failure to pursue thousands of age-discrimination complaints in a timely manner. He said the agency's performance was "embarrassing and inexcusable," and attributed the lapses in part to management problems in district offices. Congress eventually passed a law extending the statute of limitations for victims of age bias who would otherwise have lost the right to sue employers.
 
'Tired of Rhetoric About Quotas'
 He had mixed results in his effort to improve the internal management of the commission, which he said was "teetering on the brink of self-destruction" when he took office. The agency adopted many policies to increase the "certainty and predictability" of its law enforcement. Annual statistics compiled by the commission show that the number of lawsuits filed by the agency rose sharply during his tenure, to 640 in the fiscal year 1990 from 241 in 1982. But there was no increase in monetary benefits secured for the victims of discrimination.
Other Reagan Administration officials crusaded against the use of numerical goals for hiring blacks, women and Hispanic Americans; he shunned the flamboyant, confrontational tactics of officials like William Bradford Reynolds of the Justice Department. "We have a job to do," he often said, adding that he was "tired of rhetoric about quotas, about affirmative action."
In a 1985 speech, Mr. Thomas said, "My approach to doing my job has been more methodical, cautious and certainly less noisy and less well-publicized than others." Perhaps remembering his days as a seminary student, he said he had the personality and style of "a monastic recluse."
Judge Thomas contends that goals and quotas, a subject of endless political debate, "don't amount to a hill of beans" in practice, as he put it in a 1986 meeting with reporters, because they are rarely appropriate in cases brought before the commission.
In his memorandum for the transition team in December 1980, he said the commission had gone too far in encouraging affirmative action and should re-examine its policy. But in early 1983, he strongly supported an affirmative action plan under which the New Orleans Police Department was required to promote equal numbers of blacks and whites until blacks accounted for 50 percent of the officers at every rank.
The Justice Department adamantly opposed those goals, telling a Federal appeals court that they were illegal. Echoing the concerns of civil rights groups, Mr. Thomas complained in April 1983 that the Justice Department's position would "invalidate innumerable conciliation agreements, consent decrees and adjudicated decrees to which the commission is a party, as well as the commission's own published guidelines regarding appropriate affirmative action."
The commission had drafted a legal brief in the New Orleans case, but decided, under pressure from the White House, not to file it with the court. Mr. Thomas testified at a Congressional hearing in May 1983 that his agency would continue pressing for affirmative action, including "race-conscious relief" of the type abhorred by the Justice Department.
In October 1983, the commission signed a landmark agreement with the General Motors Corporation setting numerical goals for the hiring, training and promoting of thousands of blacks, women and Hispanic people. In July 1984, Mr. Thomas needled the Justice Department, saying that it was widely perceived as having "a negative rather than a positive agenda on civil rights."
His tone changed after President Reagan won re-election by a landslide in 1984. He indicated that the commission and the Administration were more likely to speak with one voice. He said that numerical goals and timetables were ineffective, and that the commission had overused statistical disparities as evidence of discrimination. In October 1985, the agency's general counsel told staff lawyers not to propose settlements containing goals and timetables.
In a speech in February 1986, Mr. Thomas said preferences based on race or ethnic origin were "a ticking time bomb" that would "hasten the socio-economic demise of black Americans." But at the confirmation hearing for his second term, he promised to abide by Supreme Court decisions endorsing the use of numerical goals.
"Whatever reservations I have are purely personal," he testified. "They're subversive literature now." In the spring of 1987, in an article in The Yale Law and Policy Review, Mr. Thomas affirmed his "personal disagreement with the Court's approval of numerical remedies."
 
Criticized Handling Of Age-Bias Cases
Since 1979, the commission has been responsible for enforcing the Age Discrimination in Employment Act, which protects people who are at least 40 years old. Mr. Thomas has said "bad management" was responsible for the agency's failure to act on thousands of complaints from older workers within the two-year statute of limitations.
In a separate case, the commission delayed action on rules requiring employers to make pension contributions for employees who work beyond the age of 65. Federal officials conceded that the delay could cost older workers $450 million a year in lost benefits.
Ruling on a lawsuit filed here by the American Association of Retired Persons, Judge Harold H. Greene of United States District Court declared in 1987 that the delay was "entirely unjustified and unlawful." He said the commission itself had repeatedly acknowledged over the previous seven years that such contributions were required by the age discrimination law. "That agency has at best been slothful, at worst deceptive to the public," the judge said.
At a Senate hearing six months later, Mr. Thomas defended himself, saying, "To suggest that we are derelict in our duties is an ad hominem attack that impugns my integrity and the agency's."
The commission under Clarence Thomas filed many lawsuits charging that companies had discriminated against women in violation of a 1963 law that requires equal pay for equal work. But he resisted the doctrine of "comparable worth," which holds that men and women should be paid the same for different jobs having the same intrinsic value.
Labor unions and women's groups embraced comparable worth as a way to reduce the differences in pay between jobs held mainly by women, like nursing and secretarial work, and those held mainly by men, like truck driving and warehouse work, which tend to pay more.
But in a 1985 case, Mr. Thomas said such pay disparities, by themselves, did not prove a violation of Federal law. "Congress never authorized the Government to take on wholesale restructuring of wages that were set by non-sex-based decisions of employers, by collective bargaining or by the marketplace," he said.
 
Records of Agency Were in Chaos
The E.E.O.C. chairman's first objective was to solve severe management problems at the commission, on the theory that "there was absolutely no way we could take care of the public's business if we couldn't take care of our own." He said he found financial records in chaotic condition and said there was too much emphasis on settling cases quickly, with little or no investigation, to eliminate a big backlog. He said he tried to establish the commission's "credibility as a law enforcement agency," contending that it had been a forum for "social activism" and arcane legal theories under some of his predecessors.
In its zeal to challenge a broad pattern or practice of discrimination, the chairman said, the commission sometimes overlooked individual "flesh-and-blood victims" of discrimination who came to its offices seeking help. He declared that "every case brought to the E.E.O.C., no matter how small, should be fully investigated and litigated, if necessary," to obtain jobs and back pay for victims.
In 1984, in a major policy change, the commission decided to consider filing a lawsuit in every case in which its staff had found discrimination and tried unsuccessfully to persuade the employer to correct the problem.
Mr. Thomas often asserted that the commission was getting record amounts of money for victims of discrimination through lawsuits, settlements and conciliation. But the agency's data show such monetary benefits were lower in 1989 and 1990 than in 1982. (The figures were $126.7 million, $98.9 million and $134.7 million, respectively, with no adjustment of inflation.)
In 1988, the General Accounting Office, an auditing arm of Congress, said the commission was still closing many cases without full investigations. In many cases closed with no finding of discrimination, "critical evidence was not verified" and "relevant witnesses were not interviewed," the auditors reported.
Mr. Thomas disputed the criticism, saying at the time that the report "trivializes civil rights enforcement to a level commensurate with widget-making."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
New Deficit Estimate Hurts Prices

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Estimates from the White House that next year's Federal budget deficit will be nearly $350 billion, a figure that was on the high end of what Wall Street had expected, helped to depress prices of Treasury securities yesterday.
Over the last few weeks credit market participants have worried about how they would cope with the huge volume of government debt to be issued this quarter, a number many analysts put at $100 billion. The news about the heftier borrowing in the 12 months beginning Oct. 1 intensified those concerns. 
 In its deficit report, which was released late in the afternoon, the Bush Administration said the shortfall during the current 1991 fiscal year would be $282.2 billion. Much of the increase during the coming year is because of a sharp rise in payments to shore up the bank deposit insurance system.
 
Dulling the Pain
 "The fact that a lot of this increase is due to deposit insurance helps to dull the pain," said Susan M. Hering, an economist at Salomon Brothers. "But the direction is wrong for a recovery."
In issuing its revised figures, the Administration is forecasting economic growth in the coming fiscal year at 3.6 percent, up from eight-tenths of 1 percent in the 1991 fiscal year.
The deficit news came near the end of a session in which traders had effectively shrugged off reports showing that the economy was continuing to gain momentum, as well as developments that underscored the fragility of the nation's financial system.
Dealers said the seven-tenths of a percent rise in industrial production reported for June, the third straight monthly advance, had been widely anticipated and did not have lasting impact on market participants. A report that automobile manufacturers sold 7.4 million vehicles at an annual rate in the first 10 days of July, roughly equal to the final 10-day period in June, was also ignored.
 
Unimpressed With Bank Merger
 Traders also seemed unimpressed with news that the Chemical Banking Corporation and the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, two large, troubled banking companies, intend to merge. That development followed the disclosure over the weekend that beacause of bad real estate loans New Jersey regulators would take control of the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company, one of the most conservative institutions in the insurance industry.
"The financial system is still in trouble, and to me these developments favor investing in fixed-income instruments rather than equities, and in Treasury securities rather than corporate or municipal issues," said Samuel D. Kahan, chief financial economist at Fuji Securities Inc. in Chicago.
The Treasury held its weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills yesterday. But concern among traders about the coming supply is focused on record auctions of two-year and five-year notes later this month, and on the quarterly refunding auctions in August.
"We aren't negative on the market per se, but we do doubt the Street's ability to get the refunding issues distributed," one government bond trader said. "The last two refundings caused rates to back up about 40 basis points before the longer-dated securities got sold. The possibility that may happen again remains the biggest threat to the market."
 
Bill Auctions Yesterday
 At the bill auctions yesterday, three-month bills were sold at a an average discount rate of 5.56 percent, down slightly from an average rate of 5.58 percent at last week's sale.
Bids on the new six-month bills produced an average discount rate of 5.7 percent, down from an average rate of 5.71 percent a week ago.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds were offered in late trading at 96 15/32, down 5/32, to yield 8.44 percent, compared with a yield of 8.43 percent late Friday.
Among Treasury note issues, the 8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 98 1/4, down 3/32, to yield 8.26 percent. And the 7 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 7/32, down 2/32, to yield 6.87 percent.
Word of the Chemical-Manufacturers Hanover merger proposal had a big impact in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, pushing up prices of most big bank bonds by a point or more.
 
Bank Issues Score Gains
 Not surprisingly, Chemical and Manufacturers Hanover issues scored the biggest gains.
By late yesterday, traders said that a 8.5 percent Manufacturers Hanover issue due to mature in 1999 was offered at a price to yield 10.15 percent. Late Friday the same issue was offered at a price to yield 10.6 percent.
An outstanding 9 3/4 percent Chemical Bank bond maturing in 1999 was also offered at a price to yield 10.15 percent, compared with a yield of 10.7 percent late Friday.
Following are the results of yesterday's auction of three-month and six-month Treasury bills:

HEADLINE: Improvement Seen in July Vehicle Sales

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, July 15

 BODY:
Confirming that the American automotive market is growing ever more robust, sales of domestically built vehicles fell a modest 7.7 percent in early July from a strong sales period a year earlier.
Sales of cars built in North America -- which the industry considers domestic production -- dropped 4.4 percent, and light-truck sales were off 12.9 percent. The seasonally adjusted annual sales rate was 7.3 million, the second-highest 10-day rate this year, after the 7.4 million of the last reporting period. 
 "I was afraid we might have a downward correction, given the recent strong trend," said Scott Merlis, automotive analyst for Morgan Stanley & Company in New York. He said the continued strength could mean higher car production schedules for the rest of the year. Failing that, he said, spot shortages of certain models could develop by the end of the year.
 
Seasonal Factors Vary
 A year earlier, the rate was also 7.3 million. But the Commerce Department's seasonal adjustment factors vary from year to year, which is why this year's unadjusted sales are significantly lower, on a daily-rate basis, than last year's.
The Big Three and a half-dozen Japanese auto makers sold 270,499 cars and light trucks in the period, compared with 256,448 a year ago. There were eight selling days in the July 1-10 period this year, compared with seven days last year; percentage changes are based on daily rates.
Car sales were 170,755, compared with 156,220 last year; light-truck sales were 99,744, compared with 100,228 last year.
On a historical basis, the recovery in car sales the last two months is nearly as strong as recoveries from the recessions in 1981 and 1975, said Ronald Glantz, automotive analyst for Dean Witter in San Francisco.
The General Motors Corporation's car sales rose 2.4 percent, to 87,759, and the Ford Motor Company said its sales fell 23.2 percent, to 42,389.
The Toyota Motor Corporation showed a substantial 49.3 percent increase in car sales, to 8,411; the Honda Motor Company posted a 2.5 percent increase, to 8,803, and the Nissan Motor Company reported a 7.1 percent increase, to 2,036.
Ward's Automotive Reports, a trade publication, estimated that the Chrysler Corporation's car sales fell 7.8 percent, to 17,500. Chrysler reports vehicle sales once a month.
"It would appear the gradual recovery has not been interrupted," said Joel Pitcoff, a sales analyst for Ford. He noted that early July was the first time since February that the company reported positive year-to-year sales comparisons for its redesigned Escort subcompact. The Taurus and Sable midsize models were also selling well, he said.
 
Large Toyota Rebates
 In explaining Toyota's large percentage increase, a company spokesman acknowledged that July sales were helped by especially generous rebates intended to clear inventories before the 1992 model year begins in October.
G.M.'s light-truck sales fell 17.5 percent, to 41,859; Ford's light-truck sales were off 17.5 percent, to 31,972, and Nissan's rose 1.4 percent, to 2,473. Ward's estimated that Chrysler's light-truck sales also rose 1.4 percent, to 22,850.
As a group, the Big Three's share of the market for American-made cars was 86.5 percent, compared with 89.5 percent a year earlier. The sales share of Japanese cars assembled in the United States -- known as "transplants" -- grew to 13.5 percent, from 10.5 percent.
The Big Three's share of sales of domestically produced light trucks fell slightly, to 96.9 percent from 97.8 percent. Light-truck sales from Japanese transplants grew to 3.1 percent, from 2.2 percent.
